HEADLINE: Port-au-Prince Journal;
Carnival's Theme: Let Lent Come, Haiti Has Hope

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Feb. 28

 BODY:
With the country living under a military dictatorship and harsh economic sanctions, Haitians did not feel much like celebrating the annual pre-Lenten Carnival last year. No wonder, then, that with President Jean-Bertrand Aristide back in power, this year's celebration was quickly baptized "the Carnival of Hope."
Signs of Haiti's newly relaxed political atmosphere have been everywhere during the 72 hours of nationwide festivities, which end early on Wednesday. Here in the capital, a few participants have dressed as roosters, the symbol of the Lavalas movement of Mr. Aristide, or worn Uncle Sam costumes -- masquerades that would have earned them a beating, or much worse, just last year. 
 As marchers paraded Sunday and Monday nights past the National Palace, where a special reviewing stand has been built for Mr. Aristide and invited guests from Haiti and abroad, many chanted the President's name. Over and over again, others sang the politically charged song that has emerged as the popular favorite of this year's Carnival, "Pale Yo," or "Tell Them," which proclaims that the Haitian people are "like little matches, catching fire."
"We've had to endure three long years of Lent" during Mr. Aristide's exile, said Etienne Jean-Louis, a young reveler whose face was speckled with glitter and painted red and blue, Haiti's national colors. "Now we finally get to have three true days of Carnival."
Even so, the fragile security situation of the country and its precarious economy have managed to intrude on the celebrations. On Feb. 21, the Justice, Defense and Interior ministries issued an unusual joint communique, warning that Haitian intelligence had detected what was called "an attempt to destabilize the country on the occasion of Carnival."
The main target of the unidentified plotters, the Government said, was "vital installations in the metropolitan area" as well as Carnival events. As a result, the multitudes that have taken to the streets here each night are dancing, singing, marching and kissing under the watchful eyes of American soldiers and international police monitors.
Concerns that anti-Aristide forces might attempt, under the cover of Carnival, to provoke violence also led the Government to decree a one-week prohibition on the sale of alcohol as of last Wednesday. That ban, though only selectively enforced, has proved unpopular and appears to have put a bit of a damper on the festivities.
"Carnival just isn't Carnival without plenty of beer and rum," Ghislaine Baptiste, a toothless street vendor who was forced by the measure to switch to sales of soda, fruit juice and sugar cane, lamented on Monday night. Besides, she added, "they are interfering with my livelihood."
In many neighborhoods, the electricity shortage that has afflicted the capital since Christmas also kept many celebrators at home or from watching Carnival events on television. The Government had promised a large increase in the electricity supply, but managed to illuminate little more than the parade route and the surrounding downtown area.
If the festivities themselves had a certain slapdash, homemade look, that too may have been evidence of the Aristide Government's economic circumstances. Despite Culture Minister Jean-Claude Bajeux's early vow that this year's Carnival would be "built on new bases" to allow the people to express themselves, the Government could come up with only 12 million gourdes, about $900,000, less than a quarter of the amount initially promised.
But in a country as poor as Haiti, even those relatively small amounts of money are seen as spoils and sources of political patronage to be fought over. Come Carnival time, neighborhood associations, musical groups and parade organizers all flock to local political leaders, seeking money to help pay for their floats, stands and costumes.
"This year, we have had more than a thousand groups register with us," said Evans Paul, the Mayor of Port-au-Prince. "Unfortunately, our budget is such that we can only select a hundred" for any form of official support.
In the poor suburban municipality of Carrefour, there was consternation when the local Mayor announced he did not have enough money to pay musicians, and a band hired for Carnival refused to play. The Mayor of the more prosperous area of Delmas, complaining that the national Government was trying to centralize control of Carnival for political gain, rejected the $5,000 offered that municipality as an insulting pittance.
But the money problem may have been most severe for Mr. Paul, who also got less than he expected. He looks to be one of the strongest candidates in the presidential election scheduled for December, and while he has been a political ally of Mr. Aristide, some of the President's advisers are said to prefer a more malleable successor with no power base of his own.
Under the military dictatorship, of course, Col. Michel Francois, the Port-au-Prince police chief, simply summoned the rich and made it clear it was in their best interests to make donations.
"The difference this year is that we have not called in the businessmen like Michel Francois did last year and said to them 'You have to contribute,' " Mr. Paul said. "We want Carnival to be accessible to everyone, but we also want it to be democratic."

GRAPHIC: Photo: An American soldier on guard inside City Hall in Port-au-Prince, Haiti, as Carnival revelers gathered. (Andrew Lichtenstein/JB Pictures for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: NATO Secretary General Questioned in Belgian Scandal

BYLINE: NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, Feb. 28

 BODY:
A corruption scandal in Belgium involving kickbacks and bribes in the purchase of helicopters from an Italian company has led to the investigation of the Secretary General of NATO.
Willy Claes, the NATO Secretary General and a leader of the Flemish Socialist Party, was Belgium's Economics Minister when Brussels agreed to purchase 46 helicopters from Agusta, an Italian manufacturer, in the late 1980's. State prosecutors now want to question him about what he knew of a reported $1.7 million "gift" Agusta made to the Flemish Socialist Party in 1989, after the Italian company sold the helicopters to Belgium for $267 million. 
 Agusta, which is based in Milan, denies making such payments.
Mr. Claes has not been accused of any wrongdoing. But conflicting statements in which he first denied any knowledge of the payments, then acknowledged that he was at a meeting where they were discussed, have led to calls for him to resign his NATO post. The Flemish-language newspaper Het Laatste Nieuws reported a poll in which 96 percent of Flemish speakers believed Mr. Claes should quit.
Those calls increased today when Johan Delanghe, who was an aide to Mr. Claes when he was a minister in the Belgian Government, was arrested in connection with the bribery case.
"We think he should step down, not because we say he is guilty, but we think it would make it easier for him to defend himself and easier for prosecutors to do their investigation," said Koen Van Caimere, spokesman for the People Unity Party, a mainstream Flemish nationalist party. "We think international politics is losing confidence in Mr. Claes."
Within NATO, most countries have closed ranks behind him, On Monday Vice President Al Gore issued a statement saying that "the United States has full and complete confidence in Secretary General Claes."
But some countries began to express impatience and concern over how the scandal would affect the alliance. "If this drags on, it's bad for NATO," Joris Voorhoeve, the Dutch Defense Minister, said today.
NATO officials concede there is concern over damage to the alliance as well as the distraction to Mr. Claes at a crucial time for NATO. The organization is facing such long-range issues as how to expand NATO to include countries of the former Warsaw Pact and what kind of relationship to establish with Russia, as well as short-term issues such as whether NATO troops will be used to help evacuate United Nations forces from Bosnia later this year.
Although NATO officials say they are worried, they do not expect Mr. Claes's departure soon, barring further revelations.
"I think that if it is a matter of just remembering something differently from the past and then it goes no further, he's not in danger," said one official who spoke on condition of anonymity. "But it can't go further than that."
A spokesman for Mr. Claes said he was not available for comment. Mr. Claes is about to depart for a 10-day trip to the United States and Canada.
Although the Agusta deal is the most wide-reaching scandal in recent Belgian history, it is only one of several to hit European military establishments in recent years.
In the 1980's, Sweden was rocked by a series of military arms scandals involving bribes paid to Indian officials, illegal shipments of explosives to Iran and Iraq, and sales of surface-to-air missiles to Singapore that ended up in Dubai and Bahrain.
Britain has uncovered illegal arms sales to President Saddam Hussein of Iraq before the Persian Gulf war in 1991, and has been accused of paying large bribes to Saudi officials to win defense contracts.
German officials resigned over illegal arms shipments to Turkey, and France has been under pressure for years to halt payments to developing countries to secure arms deals.
According to analysts familiar with the investigation, when the Belgian military sought to buy a fleet of helicopters in 1988, German and French companies submitted what were considered good offers. Agusta prevailed, the analysts said, because it offered not only $1.7 million to the Flemish Socialist Party, but made payments to the French-speaking Socialist Party, and the Flemish and French Christian Democrat parties, which make up the ruling coalition with the Flemish Socialists.
The scandal emerged when a murder investigation in Liege uncovered payments to the French-speaking Socialist Party. In January 1994, three French-speaking Belgian officials, including Deputy Prime Minister Guy Coeme, resigned after they were accused of taking bribes in the Agusta deal.
This month the scandal spread to the Flemish Socialists with the arrests of two party officials. One of them, Etienne Mange, the party's treasurer at the time, has admitted he took money.
Suspicion immediately extended to Mr. Claes, who was one of the Belgian Government officials who approved the deal.
On a radio talk show last week, Mr. Claes said, "I wish to formally confirm not only that I am not involved in the whole affair, but also that I have never, from no one or nothing and nowhere, heard or received any suggestion or proposal whatsoever to set up any such thing."
But hours later, Frank Vandenbroucke, Belgium's Foreign Minister, said on the same station that he remembered a meeting involving Mr. Claes, himself and the party's current head, Louis Tobback, at which Mr. Mange raised the issue of the kickback.
By the end of the day, Mr. Claes had changed his statement.
"We had a meeting," he said. "About what, I do not remember. And there Mange told us in passing that he had heard that the Italians were going about dangling money."
Walter de Bock, a journalist with the independent De Morgen newspaper, said, "Claes is getting the attention of the media because he lied. And lying in politics is becoming a nasty business."

 BODY:

International
 Optimism ran high within Barings P.L.C. that the failed merchant bank could be sold within days, probably in pieces, despite a trader's $1 billion loss. Rumored suitors included Merrill Lynch, Bankers Trust, GE Capital, National Westminster Bank and other institutions from several countries. [D1.] 
 Nicholas W. Leeson, the trader, celebrated his 28th birthday on Saturday in hiding, having fled Singapore with his wife, Lisa. [D5.] Police across Asia were alerted to look for him. [D5.]
 
The Economy
 Alan Greenspan called for an end to the legal barriers that separate commercial banks and securities firms. [D1.]
 The Supreme Court rebuffed the S.E.C., ruling that the money-back protection applies only to initial public offerings. [D1.]
 The House of Representatives approved far-reaching changes in enforcing health, safety and environmental laws. [A1.]
 January sales of previously owned homes fell to the lowest level in nearly two years. The consumer confidence index of the Conference Board fell to a still-high 99.0 in February. [D2.]
 Denver's $4.9 billion airport opened 16 months late, hailed by its backers as a catalyst for the Rocky Mountain economy. [A12.]

Business Technology

A large majority of cable customers are unhappy with their existing service, a survey of 4,000 households shows. [D6.]
 
Markets
 The stock market rebounded in a comeback that carried the Dow Jones industrial average up 22.48 points to 4,011.05. [D8.]
 Treasury securities staged a late rally to finish mixed, after dropping in early trading. [D17.]
 The dollar fell moderately, weakened by an early selloff in the bond market; the German mark advanced broadly. [D18.]
 Copper and lumber prices fell sharply after a report of weaker home sales last month raised fears of softer demand. [D18.]

HEADLINE: Oneidas Seeking Casino at Monticello Raceway

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE VAN GELDER 

 BODY:
The Oneida Indian Nation wants to establish a casino at Monticello Raceway in Sullivan County, just 90 miles from New York City. But Gov. George E. Pataki pledged yesterday to block the plan.
The tribe's proposal would place casino gambling closer to New York City than Atlantic City or the Foxwoods Resorts Casino, operated by the tiny Mashantucket Pequot tribe near Groton, Conn. 
 The casino would be in the heart of the Catskills, where the owners of faded resorts have long wanted to attract casinos but have been blocked by Albany.
The Oneida plan would need Federal designation of the site as tribal land, excluding the area from state laws banning gambling. The Interior Department generally looks to governors before ruling on such requests, and Mr. Pataki made clear that he would oppose the Oneida effort.
At a news conference yesterday outside the Executive Mansion in Albany, he said: "I think it is absolutely wrong for that to happen. I'm very concerned that we'll see the proliferation of casinos and entertainment complexes that pay no property taxes, pay no sales taxes, pay no income taxes. I don't think we should allow it to the extent that we have the legal authority to stop it."
Louis Berenson, who has owned the 220-acre raceway since 1984, would not comment on plans for the track. But other people involved with the Oneidas, with Monticello Raceway and with businesses in the Catskills, said the tribe and the raceway had scheduled a news conference today to announce the sale of the track and the tribe's plans to operate a casino on part of the site.
Under Federal law, Indians can run casinos on tribal lands, and the Oneidas already have a casino, Turning Stone, in Verona, 35 miles east of Syracuse.
A spokesman for the Interior Department said yesterday that two efforts to extend gambling to lands acquired by tribes in Oregon and Michigan had foundered, in part because of local opposition.
Federal law exempts Indian lands from Federal, state and local taxes, as well as zoning regulations.
The tribal representative of the Oneida Indian Nation in New York, Ray Halbritter, said, "When all the factual and accurate information is presented, the Governor and the state will see the tremendous economic benefits the state will see."
The Governor suggested that it might be time to take another look at amending the State Constitution to permit legalized casino gambling in a form that would benefit taxpayers. Last year the Legislature failed to agree on such an amendment, which would have to be passed by two consecutive Legislatures before being put to voters in a referendum.
The chairman of the 1,200-room Concord Hotel in nearby Kiamesha Lake, George Parker, said he had spoken to the people dealing with the Oneidas and expressed support for their plans. Mr. Parker, who has campaigned for legalized gambling in the Catskills, where tourism has been depressed in recent years, noted that the state already had casino gambling at Turning Stone, the $10 million hall that the Oneidas opened in July 1993.
"The only thing this is going to do is bring it closer to the New York metropolitan area and help us out," Mr. Parker said. "It can't hurt us. It can only help. It would increase occupancy dramatically in all the hotels, and the Indians would not be building a hotel on their property."
The publicity chairman of the Sullivan County Chamber of Commerce, Scott Samuelson, said he could give no information before the news conference, and he declined to confirm a report in The Daily News yesterday that Mr. Berenson would sell Monticello Raceway to Watermark Investments of the Bahamas. Watermark, the report added, would in turn sell part of the site to the Oneidas.
Mr. Samuelson said that whatever today's announcement might be, "we are supporting it." A lawyer from Albany who represents the Indians, John J. Poklemba, former State Commissioner of Criminal Justice Services, said the raceway would continue to operate under the plans to be announced.
Senator Nicholas A. Spano, a Republican of Yonkers who is a leading proponent of legalized gambling, bridled at the prospect of an Oneida casino in Monticello. "That they could purchase land and decide to make it part of their reservation is beyond the spirit of the law and mocks the law," he said.
Mr. Spano said he would ask the Governor to block the project. "We get absolutely no benefit from an Indian casino," he said. "They've exempted themselves from every law except the one that exempts them from being taxed. It would do nothing to help towns in the Catskills. It would provide no economic help to the state of New York."
Mr. Halbritter said a study by Coopers & Lybrand, the accounting firm, showed that Turning Stone had created 2,000 jobs and delivered $11 million in economic benefits to the state.
About 70 tribes nationwide offer gambling under the Indian Gaming Regulatory Act of 1988. Intended to generate wealth on impoverished reservations, the law allows tribes to operate games of chance not otherwise outlawed by the state. The Federal law also lets tribes to buy land and declare it part of their sovereign nation.

HEADLINE: THE 104TH CONGRESS: BALANCED BUDGET;
Republicans Postpone a Balanced-Budget Vote

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28

 BODY:
Senate Republicans, a lone Democrat short of the 67 legislators they need to adopt a balanced-budget amendment, reneged tonight on a promise to vote on the measure and abruptly threw the chamber into recess instead.
Asked later when the Senate might vote on the amendment, the majority leader, Bob Dole, replied with a half-smile, "Maybe this week." A second Republican who is leading the amendment debate, Senator Larry E. Craig of Idaho, predicted a vote on Wednesday. 
 Mr. Dole's delaying tactic landed like firecrackers in an institution that still likes to equate a politician's word with a solemn bond. For his part, he made no bones as to his motive: Republican efforts to lure a single Democratic holdout, Kent Conrad of North Dakota, to the side of the amendment's supporters, had stalled after an increasingly frantic day of lobbying.
The chief opponent of the amendment, Senator Robert C. Byrd, Democrat of West Virginia, damned Mr. Dole's move as "a sleazy, tawdry effort to win a victory."
Mr. Dole retorted by saying that the balanced-budget vote was probably the most important of the senators' careers.
"And we don't take amending the Constitution lightly."
But he acknowledged that the delaying action could cost him the very support he was seeking among the undecided Democrats who are the key to the amendment's fate.
"The sad spectacle is, we may lose this vote," he said.
Mr. Conrad seemed to confirm that after the Senate had quit for the night. "I told Senator Dole we may as well vote tonight," he said. "I don't see a prospect of a meeting of the minds."
The manager of the amendment drive for the Republicans, Senator Orrin G. Hatch of Utah, said later that he would work through the night in an attempt to change Mr. Conrad's mind anyway.
Tonight's actions only prolonged a political battle that had seemed a cakewalk for amendment supporters when it began early this year but evolved into a crackling legislative thriller that has rocked the Senate to its staid roots.
At stake was whether Congress should enlarge the Constitution, for only the 28th time in 208 years, to make it more difficult for the Federal Government to spend more money than it earns. Present law allows Congress and the President to spend money the nation does not have with the approval of a simple majority of the House and Senate.
The essence of the amendment is to bar such spending without the approval of three-fifths of the entire membership of both chambers, a standard that would be much more difficult to reach.
But by day's end, arguments of fiscal principle had given way to a virtual dragnet across the Capitol's north wing for any Democrat who would push the cause over the top.
Few would have predicted the supporters' plight. Only five days ago, they claimed they were on the verge of victory, with 52 solid Republican supporters, 12 Democrats and the prospect of quickly picking up at least three more.
But support began to waver Thursday when Senator Sam Nunn, a Georgia Democrat long viewed as a near-certain "yes," demanded that the amendment be changed to bar the Federal courts from ruling on it.
Mr. Nunn reasoned that any court dispute over whether the amendment was being obeyed would amount to an invitation for Federal courts to dictate taxing and spending decisions that the Constitution now accords to Congress alone.
Mr. Nunn's opposition only solidified the doubts of four other undecided Democrats: John B. Breaux of Louisiana, Wendell H. Ford of Kentucky, and Mr. Conrad and his fellow North Dakotan, Byron L. Dorgan. And by today, the prospect that all five would be lost prompted Mr. Hatch and other Republicans to agree to change the amendment so that the courts could not intervene in fiscal matters.
That change sailed through the Senate late today, 92 to 8, and Senators Nunn and Breaux immediately proffered their support. But that still left the Republicans a vote short of passage. And when Senators Ford and Dorgan failed to come aboard, amendment supporters converged on Mr. Conrad.
Mr. Conrad not only had shared Mr. Nunn's concern, but had a second one: that the amendment would tempt the Government to pay down the deficit by taking money from taxpayer contributions to the Social Security trust fund.
The fund is building up a huge surplus which is earmarked, at least on paper, to finance the retirement of today's baby-boom workforce. Mr. Conrad sought a guarantee that that money would not be spent to reduce the deficit, and through the day, Republicans trooped to his Senate seat with proposals to mollify him, to no apparent avail.
Finally, out of the range of television cameras but well within the riveted gazes of those in the packed Senate gallery, Republicans delayed a final vote and, surrounding Mr. Conrad in a knot of dark suits, dragooned him off the floor and into their cloakroom. Mr. Conrad emerged minutes later, only to be hauled off by the minority leader, Tom Daschle, and other Democrats into their cloakroom.
Democrats said later that Mr. Dole had offered Mr. Conrad a bargain: should he support the amendment, Mr. Dole promised, the Senate would immediately pass legislation guaranteeing that within 12 years any surplus in the Social Security trust fund would be excluded from budget calculations.
But Mr. Conrad rejected that as insufficient.
Later, Mr. Hatch said that he had believed that Mr. Conrad had struck a deal in the Republican cloakroom to vote with supporters. But after Mr. Conrad met with Mr. Daschle and other Democrats, Mr. Hatch said, Mr. Conrad returned with a second demand: that Congress be allowed to suspend the amendment, by majority vote, in times of economic emergency.
"We thought we were there," Mr. Hatch said. "We thought we had made it clear we couldn't support the economic emergency language."
Mr. Conrad disagreed with that, saying Republicans had never satisfied his concerns about the use of Social Security contributions to reduce the deficit.
Another Republican said, "The real problem is that he just doesn't like the amendment."
A White House official said that President Clinton would telephone wavering senators tonight to persuade them to hold out against the Republican pleadings.
The White House chief of staff, Leon E. Panetta, and the Administration's legislative director, Patrick Griffin, met with the President to discuss strategy just after the Senate delayed the vote.
Mary Ellen Glynn, the deputy White House press secretary, said that Mr. Clinton had monitored the debate and planned to discuss the situation with Mr. Daschle. The drama surrounding the holdouts unfolded against a day of debate that was stirring even by congressional standards. Supporters argued, again and again, that the Government was hurtling toward insolvency and that, short of a constitutional change, it would never summon the will to brake itself.
"Remember the rallying cry of the American revolution: taxation without representation," said Senator Paul Simon, the Illinois Democrat who is one of the measure's champions. "What are we doing to our grandchildren and generations to come? If that isn't taxation without representation, nothing is."
"This is a shoot-now, ask-later approach," Mr. Daschle warned late in the debate, "and we will regret it."
No one bettered Mr. Byrd. Twice in the final hours, he rose from his seat in the rear of the chamber to deliver attacks, in almost Shakespearean language, on the measure he derided as "this shop of horrors," and "this macabre twisting of the balance of powers."
"Change is the watchword of the day; change merely for the sake of change is suddenly a virtue above all others, a goal to be achieved at all costs," Mr. Byrd thundered. "But I will never, never bow to those messengers of expediency or to the managers of any political party's agenda. The hurricanes may blow, the tides may rise, but there still remain those of us who will never bend."
Mr. Dole paid tribute to his old opponent's oratorical powers minutes later. "I'm trying to get C-Span to give college credit for those who watch it across the country," he said.

HEADLINE: Outlook for Orange County

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: SANTA ANA, Calif., Feb. 28

 BODY:
William Popejoy, the new chief executive of Orange County, Calif., said tonight that the bankrupt county's financial crisis was "much worse" than he had thought upon assuming office two weeks ago.
Mr. Popejoy told the board's monthly meeting that to get through the next six months, the county was likely to use bridge financing and might have to delay debt payments. But he insisted that defaulting on the county's debt was not an option. 
 He said the county would make deep cuts, including substantial layoffs in its 15,000-person work force, to chop $188 million, or 41 percent, from the county-financed portion of its 1995-96 operating budget. The new fiscal year begins July 1. "They'll be nasty," Mr. Popejoy said of the cuts, which he intends to announce next week, along with details of his proposed budget.
He said he would announce on March 28 details of a financing plan to meet $1 billion in bond payments due Aug. 10. At present, he said, the county is $382 million short.
"I've never guaranteed that we'd repay bondholders exactly when they're due," he said. "It's going to be difficult, but I think there are ways we can do it."

HEADLINE: THE 104TH CONGRESS: THE ENVIRONMENT;
HOUSE APPROVES SWEEPING CHANGES ON REGULATIONS

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28

 BODY:
The House of Representatives today approved far-reaching changes in how Federal agencies enforce health, safety and environmental laws.
It directed regulatory agencies to base rules primarily on economic calculations of costs and benefits. Statistics and finances would override the health-based standards at the heart of many existing environmental laws. 
 The bill, approved 286 to 141, is supported by industry groups as strongly as it is opposed by environmentalists. It is the most comprehensive in a series of antiregulatory initiatives being debated in the House under the Republicans' 1994 campaign manifesto, the Contract With America.
If a measure like this eventually becomes law, it would affect every major industry, and decisions about everything from automobile safety standards and workplace rules to emissions from smokestacks and the purification of drinking water could be changed.
It would put newly proposed regulations, even those issued under existing laws, through an elaborate system of risk assessments in an effort to measure scientifically their likely effectiveness, and would require that the financial costs to industry of complying with the rules must be justified by the anticipated benefits to the public.
Opponents have called it a prescription for delay, and maintain that it would override a generation of existing laws.
Sixty Democrats joined all but two Republicans to approve the measure. But the bill was passed only after a spirited debate among the Republicans themselves, as they argued over how far to press the campaign to roll back a generation of environmental laws.
The Clinton Administration opposes the risk assessment bill, and it is far from certain how the Senate will deal with several similar bills that have yet to be considered by committees. In the past, even under the control of Democrats, the Senate has easily approved bills to require risk assessments in new regulations, but no proposal before the Senate has ever gone as far as the one the House passed today.
The bill does not explicitly amend any existing statute. But the laws Congress passes do not have much effect until agencies write regulations to carry them out, and the changes the House approved would go to the heart of that process.
Despite an attempt mounted by some of the most conservative House members from both parties, the House voted not to let industries appeal to agencies for retroactive review of regulations that have long been on the books. Future regulations are affected even if they carry out laws previously passed by Congress.
In an unusual break from the pattern of nearly total solidarity among House Republicans in passing major elements of their 100-day agenda, some amendments to limit the bill's broad reach were offered and supported by a handful of defecting Republicans, but were rejected.
Representative Sherwood Boehlert of upstate New York, a Republican, sponsored the most significant of these unsuccessful amendments, which would have removed what environmental groups considered the most unwelcome part of the bill: its language overriding the environmental standards set by such past laws as the Clean Air Act and the Clean Water Act.
His amendment recommended that whenever a regulatory agency finds that a cost-benefit analysis conflicts with public health or other existing standards used for making regulatory decisions, the agency should report back to Congress, which could then decide whether it wanted to amend the law.
Opponents also lost in efforts to weaken the bill's provisions on judicial review of regulations, to take away the role it gives industry representatives on special panels that will review the risk assessments of new rules and to limit the risk assessments to regulations costing industry at least $100 million, instead of just $25 million.
The bill would give regulated industries an opportunity to go to court to challenge the adequacy of the risk assessments, a provision that opponents said would invite extensive litigation. And it would not prevent interested parties from sitting on the peer review panels established to examine those risk assessments.
But proponents said both provisions were needed to insure fairness to industries that they said must spend hundreds of billions of dollars each year complying with Federal regulations.
Carol M. Browner, Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, said: "This legislation is not reform, it is a full frontal assault on protecting public health and the environment."

GRAPHIC: Chart: "THE BILL AT A GLANCE: Risk Assessment"
 
BILL Risk Assessment and Communication Act of 1995 (H.R. 1022)
 
HIGHLIGHTS: Requires proposed regulations protecting health, safety and the environment to undergo a detailed scientific assessment of how effectively the rules would reduce risks to the public, and requires agencies to certify that the costs of compliance are justified by the anticipated benefits. Risk assessments would be reviewed by expert panels that could include industry representatives, and would be subject to judicial review. The cost-benefit calculations would supersede health-based standards of existing environmental laws.
 
POLITICS Although risk assessment and cost benefit analysis are supported by many Democrats and Republicans alike, most Democrats argue that this bill goes too far and would unduly
 
 restrict regulators. Industry groups favor the measure; environmental groups are strongly opposed. It is one part of a broad assault on Federal regulatory powers being pushed through the House of Representatives as part of the Contract with America.
 
COST Backers say that the legislation would reduce the costs of regulation to businesses and focus spending on the most serious risks. Opponents say it would be costly for Federal agencies to carry out the required studies.
 
STATUS House passed on Tuesday. Several versions of risk assessment legislation have been introduced in the Senate, but none have been considered by committees.
 
WHITE HOUSE Administration officials have argued against the legislation, saying it would roll back existing environmental protections. (pg. A17)

HEADLINE: Communities Fear the Pain Base Closings Will Cause

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

 BODY:
New Jersey would suffer the heaviest blow in the metropolitan region under the list of military base closings released yesterday by the Pentagon, though New York and Connecticut face hard losses, too.
Under the proposal, which is not final, New Jersey stands to lose a naval center in Lakehurst and a marine terminal in Bayonne that sent much of the military hardware to operations in Haiti, Somalia and the Persian Gulf. 
 The recommendations, which would cut 1,866 civilian and 758 military jobs in the state, angered some local officials, who contended that their areas had been unfairly singled out. Others, like the Mayor of Bayonne, tried to put the best face on the news, suggesting that some bases could be transformed into vibrant commercial hubs.
Though the Military Ocean Terminal in Bayonne and the Lakehurst Naval Air Warfare Center in Ocean County would be shuttered, the Picatinny Arsenal in Morris County, which some officials had thought was threatened, was spared, preserving more than 4,000 jobs. And, officials said, Fort Monmouth in Monmouth County would gain 1,188 civilian and 35 military jobs from the closing and reorganization of other bases, including the terminal.
New York would lose 41 military and 1,415 civilian jobs, most of them from the closing of the Rome Laboratory at Griffiss Air Force Base in Rome, N.Y., near Utica. Nine military and 316 civilian jobs would be cut at the Seneca Army Depot in Romulus. But in Brooklyn, Fort Hamilton would lose only 52 civilian jobs and gain 3 military jobs.
In Connecticut, 609 civilian jobs would be cut, mostly from closing the naval base in New London. Statewide, there would be a net increase of 13 military jobs. But the Pentagon figures do not account for the unexpected announcement that the Army's tank-engine factory in Stratford is to be closed.
The factory employs more than 1,000 people under a contractor, the Allied Signal Corporation, whose executives expressed surprise yesterday that the site was on the list.
Besides the direct loss of jobs across the region, there is expected to be a spillover from the proposed closings that could jeopardize the livelihoods of thousands of other people in towns around the bases -- from supermarket workers to auto dealers to hotel owners.
Some officials vowed to fight the Pentagon plan, with the State of New Jersey, for example, agreeing to pay a law firm $300,000 to lobby the base-closing commission. But the going may be rough, as Congress has tried to insulate the process from politics, and the President and lawmakers must accept or reject the commission list in its entirety.
"It's too early to pronounce this dead," said Representative Robert Menendez, a Democrat whose district includes Bayonne.
Mr. Menendez questioned the military's decision to transfer much of the cargo from the Military Ocean Terminal to surrounding commercial terminals in the New York Harbor, maintaining that the flow of military goods during times of national emergency might seriously disrupt nonmilitary operations.
Mayor Leonard P. Kiczek of Bayonne said he regretted the loss of jobs at the terminal -- 100 military and 1,267 civilian -- but he noted that many of those personnel would be moved to Fort Monmouth. He added that he was hopeful that the city would bounce back quickly.
The Mayor said some good could actually come from the terminal's closing. He noted that because it was owned by the Government, the terminal had never paid taxes, even though it occupies about one-fifth of the city's land. The city might benefit greatly, he said, if it were turned into a complex of private terminals, stores, factories and other enterprises. "If a successful plan is enacted, it could be a great boon to our economy," he said.
Others were not so optimistic.
"It stinks," said Paula LoRe, who has worked 20 years at the terminal. "The politicians in this area did nothing to keep the base open."
At the Airship Tavern in Lakehurst, a small borough at the northeast edge of the Pine Barrens, the mood was somber. Francis Mazzotti, a technician at the base, said the cuts were a "threat to national security and a threat to humans."
In neighboring Monmouth County, officials were jubilant. Fort Monmouth had been high up on the list of bases to be closed in 1993.
"This is the shot in the arm that we need," said Art Chasey, a member of the Eatontown council and a real estate appraiser.
But Mayor Ann Y. McNamara of Tinton Falls said: "No one is taking anything for granted. There will be a review of these proposals and a lot of jurisdictions that have been cut will be very active to get these decisions reversed. So we still have to be on guard."

HEADLINE: ABOUT NEW YORK;
At the Jefferson Courthouse, the Bell Finally Tolls, and Rings Out History

BYLINE: By Michael T. Kaufman 

 BODY:
FOR 20 minutes on Monday evening, the two-ton bell in the tower of the old Jefferson Market Courthouse rang over Greenwich Village, breaking a virtual silence of 97 years.
Except for throat clearings of a few bongs now and again, the bell, said to be the second largest in New York City, after one at Riverside Church, had not tolled seriously since sounding Adm. George Dewey's victory at Manila Bay during the Spanish-American War. 
 That was when some battle-enthralled graffiti painter had daubed "To hell with Spain -- Remember the Maine -- 1898," inside the bell's skirt, where the inscription is still visible. But this week's peal had nothing to do with jingo bells.
Instead, what was being marked as Tom Sharkey, the superintendent of the building, pushed and pulled the clapper was a triumph somewhat more parochial than the dismantling of the Spanish Empire; namely, the preservation and restoration of the courthouse at 10th Street and the Avenue of the Americas, which had been modeled after a Bavarian trifle and now houses a branch of the New York Public Library.
"It's a very lyrical moment," said Margot Gayle, who 37 years ago set about rescuing the building as it was about to be auctioned to developers coveting the ground it stood on. She paused and looked up before joining some 80 people who had gathered to recall a long trail of community action now that the building's renovation has been capped off with a new slate roof.
"I keep thinking of all of us who got involved years ago and I realize that we really did it," said Ms. Gayle, who was sitting next to Marvin Schneider, the clockmaster of the city's clocks. "When the bell rang, I felt my spirits rise."
IT was in 1959 that Ms. Gayle began organizing. "I was working for the Department of City Planning and living on Ninth Street. I got to know some architects and they pointed out just how spectacular that courthouse was."
It had been built in 1877 on the edge of what was then one of the city's poorest neighborhood, pushed forward as another of Boss Tweed's extravagances. Large sums were appropriated before anything was ever built, and when construction began, no opportunities for kickbacks seemed to have been ignored, with contractors providing stained-glass windows, gargoyles, Venetian fountains, intricate ebony door frames, the clock with its four faces and the huge bell.
Among the wealth of details, there is an inscription cut into the circular stairway stipulating that "the precepts of the law are these: to live correctly, to do an evil to none and to render to everyone his own." By the time the building was completed, this third requirement must have been fulfilled with everyone duly rendered unto.
The New York Times observed at the time that putting up so lavish a building in such a rundown neighborhood was like placing "a jewel in a swine's snout," and the architects, Frederick Clarke Withers and Calvert Vaux, one of the designers of Central Park, were accused by some critics of incompetence, even insanity.
But 10 years later the courthouse was voted by architects as one of the 10 most beautiful buildings in America.
THE courts moved out in 1927 and by the time Ms. Gayle's interest in the building developed, city agencies had moved out and it was empty.
"It's hard to believe now, but there was absolutely no interest back then in public Victorian architecture," Ms. Gayle said. Plans were made to sell off the property, along with the adjoining Women's House of Detention that was ultimately razed.
"I thought we should focus on the clock," said Ms. Gayle. "For years, its hand had stood at 3:20 and I thought everyone would want the clock to move. So we named our group the Committee of Neighbors to Get the Clock on Jefferson Market Courthouse Started. We were a small group, but we had this very long name."
PEOPLE joined in, among them Lewis Mumford and Jane Jacobs, the architectural critics, and E. E. Cummings, the poet who lived across 10th Street. By 1961, the group had raised enough money to restart and illuminate the clock. That effort spurred greater ambitions, and in response to the committee's appeals, in 1961 Mayor Robert F. Wagner announced the building would be preserved as a library.
Since opening in 1967, the library branch has, according to Paul Schmidt, the director, become one of the best used in the city. "It is a gloriously welcoming building," said the librarian, who has been there from the start. "No, we've had no reports of ghosts. I guess the weirdest thing I can remember is that once a reader left me a note saying that twice the world has been saved because of what had happened in this library. I really don't know what he had in mind."
Ms. Gayle said that bell's ringing had inspired her.
"Don't you think it would be neighborly if the bell rang out the hours?" said the woman who got the clock to move. You could see her thinking.

HEADLINE: Stocks Rebound to End Above 4,000 Level

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The stock market rebounded yesterday in a comeback that carried the Dow Jones industrial average back above 4,000 to close less than a point below its all-time high.
Takeover news affecting technology and other stocks inspired buying, as did a late pickup in the bond market. 
 In staging its comeback, Wall Street managed to overcome uneasiness about the implications of the sudden collapse of a venerable old British merchant bank, Barings P.L.C., and uncertainty about the direction American interest rates would take in the near future.
The Dow industrials, which did not stray far from their starting point for most of the session, advanced decisively in the final 90 minutes of trading to finish at 4,011.05, up 22.48 points. The gain almost erased Monday's drop of 23.17 and hoisted the blue-chip indicator within one point of the record close of 4,011.76 reached on Friday.
Most broader gauges also gained. The New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 1.97 points, to 264.65. Standard & Poor's 500-stock index increased 3.43 points, to 487.39, or less than a point shy of its high of 488.11, also set on Friday. The Nasdaq composite index climbed 9.23 points, to 793.73, while the American Stock Exchange market value index rose 4.27 points, to 452.71.
Advancing Big Board stocks beat decliners by 1,603 to 690. Volume was 317.6 million shares, compared with 285.8 million shares on Monday.
Renewed buying in the bond market helped stocks. For most of the day bonds were weighed down by a report from Chicago area purchasing managers that traders worried contained hints of inflation. Then a Johnson Redbook Service report that retail sales were off prompted bond buying in the afternoon.
Also, the National Association of Realtors said sales of previously owned homes fell 4.5 percent in January to the lowest level in 21 months in a sign that high mortgage rates have discouraged buyers.
Market analysts said investors are torn between hopes that the Federal Reserve is close to achieving its goal of subduing economic growth to a noninflationary pace and worries that the central bank is not yet satisfied and will raise short-term interest rates again to ward off inflation.
Robert Walberg, an analyst at MMS International, said takeover announcements and speculation involving a range of companies provided the main positive influence on equities trading.
News that Samsung Electronics is taking a stake in AST Research helped repair confidence in high-tech issues and lifted the sector, he said.
CBS gained 2 5/8, to 64 5/8, in response to news that Turner Broadcasting had expressed renewed interest in acquiring the network.
Marion Merrell Dow gained 1, to 24 7/8, on heavy volume of more than 2.9 million shares after the company disclosed that it might be acquired by Hoechst of Germany for more than $7.1 billion. Dow Chemical, which owns 71 percent of Marion Merrell Dow, rose 2 3/8, to 67.

HEADLINE: Finally, 16 Months Late, Denver Has a New Airport

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DENVER, Feb. 28

 BODY:
Denver International Airport finally opened today, hailed by its proponents as a mighty catalyst for the economy of the Rocky Mountain region and ridiculed by detractors as a $4.9 billion monument to boosterism and boondoggling.
At 6 A.M., United Flight 1062 pushed back from Gate 38 and headed off for Kansas City, soaring steeply into a snowy sky to inaugurate the first full day of operations. Not since the Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport opened 21 years ago had a major new airport been opened in the United States. 
 And never, said aviation experts, had a more technologically advanced terminal and set of runways been opened.
"We finally did it!" Mayor Wellington Webb declared after he and Transportation Secretary Federico F. Pena, a former Denver Mayor and a central figure in the development of the 53-square-mile airport, snipped a bright ribbon at Gate 38 just before daybreak.
When three jetliners landed simultaneously in bad weather, the only place in the world where it is possible, Mr. Pena exclaimed, "This is a historic first in aviation!"
Because of numerous construction delays, contracting problems and financing difficulties -- some of them now the subject of legal action and government investigations -- the opening ceremony at the new airport came 16 months behind schedule. And the final cost was $2 billion over budget, with a balky, ultramodern baggage system that initially shredded bags blamed for $100 million or more of that overrun.
Critics say all this could have been avoided if the city had modestly expanded Stapleton International Airport, which was shut down just hours before the new airport opened. It served Denver for more than 65 years and its defenders say it easily could have helped take Denver into the 21st century.
"Somehow, we've managed to end up with an airport that has longer runways and a bigger terminal but that -- get this -- also has fewer gates," said Michael J. Boyd, an airline consultant from Golden, Colo., who is one of the new airport's most outspoken critics.
"It's built on dubious traffic projections, and not very well at that, and except for some flights to Mexico and Canada, it has only one international flight -- once a week to London," Mr. Boyd said, adding, "It ought to be called Denver International Avarice."
The inquiries into the construction and financing of the airport are being conducted by the Denver district attorney, the United States Attorney here, the Federal Aviation Administration, the Department of Transportation and the General Accounting Office. Some purchasers of bonds used to finance the airport have filed suit, saying they were not given accurate facts about the project.
City and airport officials deny any wrongdoing.
Whatever the case, as the first passengers scurried through the new terminal today, many marveling at its sheeny spaciousness and its multi-peaked white roof that mimics the Rockies on the distant western horizon, Mayor Webb sought to put the controversy behind.
He noted that no serious problems had been encountered in the initial hours of the new airport's operation. Even the much-maligned $193 million baggage system performed as advertised, except for some soiled luggage.
Mayor Webb confidently said he expected no future glitches, though he confessed that he, like just about everybody else in the terminal, could feel the mysterious vibrations in the floor that had puzzled engineers.
"Now what we must collaborately do is bond our hands together and market this airport and out great city," he said. "To those who would continue to debate whether it ever should have been built, that is nonsensical. It's here. It's working."
By and large. But there was one highly embarrassing moment.
Eleven minutes after Flight 1062 departed from Gate 38, a special flight of airport officials and honored guests arrived, right on schedule, at adjacent Gate 40. A huge crowd was there to greet them.
And then the jetway jammed. The plane, and the ceremony, were unceremoniously moved to Gate 38.
One of the first passengers to use the new field, Leanne Orcutt, a computer programmer from Lake Tahoe, Calif., was willing to concede Mayor Webb his contention that the airport would be a success.
"I've heard about the problems and all the controversy and debate," she said as she checked in for a flight. "But it's still a very impressive place. Maybe Stapleton was O.K., too. Whatever. I just want to get home."
Lying 15 miles closer to the city's eastern edge than Denver International Airport, which sits 23 miles northeast of downtown Denver on an empty prairie, Stapleton was ruled obsolete years ago by city officials. They said its runways were too close for efficient, safe operation in bad weather and too crowded in by suburbs for economical expansion.
Many Denverites and aviation experts countered that expansion was possible and that the city's plan was but the grandiose scheme of ambitious politicians, greedy business executives and dreamy civic boosters.
The doubters also warned that even though bonds would be sold to pay for the project, it nevertheless would end up costing the average citizen money because air carriers would have to raise fares to meet higher landing fees and taxi companies would have to charge passengers for longer trips.
In fact, the fares for many flights in and out of Denver International have been raised $20 each way above the fares to and from Stapleton. Airlines say the increase is necessary because the landing fee for the new field is more than $18 a passenger, compared with $6 for Stapleton.
As for ground transportation costs, a taxi to or from the city's center now costs about $35, more than twice the old Stapleton fare.
"I don't like the extra costs," said Richard Mills, a sales manager from Colorado Springs. "But we've got this new facility now and so it'll just have to become part of doing business. We'll just have to see what tourists and skiers and the like do."
Utah ski resorts think they know. They have mailed out advertisements that read: "In Denver, you could lose your luggage. In Utah you could lose yourself."
If, despite all the problems, the opening of Denver International was a notable achievement, so too was the closing of Stapleton.
After the last flight departed on Monday at 9:38 P.M. -- Continental Flight 34, bound for London -- the runways were officially closed and airport employees then labored through the rest of the night to complete the transfer of more than 10,000 baggage carts, plane tugs, fire engines, catering trucks, de-icing machines and untold truckloads of tickets, tags and gift shop sundries.
Stapleton will be put up for sale, with the city hoping that busy industrial parks and peaceful suburbs will be built where planes once roared. But thus far there has been no great rush to acquire the tract. Likewise, as has often occurred at other new airports in their early days, there is no great rush yet to build on the outskirts of Denver International.
As Continental Flight 34 lifted out of Stapleton on Monday night, ending an era stretching back to the days of open cockpit barnstorming, the tower radioed a final message.
"Continental 34," said the controller, "the torch is passed to you."
There was a snatch of static and then the Continental pilot came on the air. "We'll miss the old place," he said. "A lot of memories. See you over at the new place."

HEADLINE: Drug Trade Imperils Aid To Colombia

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: CALI, Colombia Feb. 25

 BODY:
Bulkier than most courtroom evidence, two Boeing 727 jets impounded at the international airport here symbolize the push and pull between the United States and Colombia over its rampant cocaine exports.
Last month, Colombia angrily denied reports that refitted jets were carrying tons of cocaine to Mexico. But in a reversal two weeks ago, officials reassigned air traffic controllers and impounded the jets. 
 Behind the reversal was a March 1 deadline for President Clinton to certify that Colombia was cooperating with the United States in fighting the drug trade. Colombian officials feared being placed on an outlaw list that last year included only Iran, Nigeria, Syria and Myanmar.
To head off international ostracism, Colombia's President, Ernesto Samper, hurriedly unveiled a program to eradicate all of Colombia's cocoa leaf and opium poppy fields by the end of 1996. Long a cocaine refining country, Colombia emerged in the 1990's as the world's third-largest source of cocoa leaves and the fourth-largest source of opium.
Skeptics in Washington say the plan places a low priority on capturing kingpins of drug cartels based in this city, Colombia's third-largest.
If some Republican members of Congress have their way, Colombia would lose United States aid not related to combatting drugs, as well as other economic privileges.
In Cali, a tropical city enjoying a construction bonanza of largely mysterious origin, business leaders held a press seminar at a local country club, repeatedly telling visiting journalists: "We are the victims."
At the press seminar here, Colombia's Defense Minister, Rafael Botero Zea, gave a graphic explanation of why no major Cali cartel figure has been captured during Mr. Samper's six-month-old presidency.
"If Pablo Escobar used a machete, Cali uses a scalpel knife," the minister said, as local business leaders listened and chafed as if they were witnessing a major breach of local etiquette. "The Cali cartel hires the best people -- the best lawyers, the best accountants, the best computer experts."
The minister plunged ahead, saying that the cartel's information network includes about 1,600 Cali taxi drivers, 1,250 street vendors and 7 private security companies.
"When someone arrives at the airport and goes to a hotel," the minister continued, "very quickly the information goes to the cartel."
Studying a personal computer seized from the cartel, detectives deduced recently that the cartel has access to all telephone calls made in this city of two million. By cross-checking numbers, traffickers decide which telephones to tap. Taped conversations are digitalized. By tapping a few computer keys and running a program, a cartel computer expert can summon up all conversations that used a key word -- like the name of the commander of a police drug unit.
The minister's presentation did not elicit any response from business leaders present -- not a gasp of awe, not a smirk of hometown pride.
After an uncomfortable silence, a local newspaper editor took the microphone and lectured the visitors: "We are not the victimizers. We are the victims."
With Colombia's cocaine flow virtually unchecked in recent years, the nation escaped Washington's list last year largely because police tracked down and killed Pablo Escobar, leader of the Medellin cartel, in December 1993.
This year, the most concrete action against cartel leaders was the recent announcement that family members of cartel leaders had lost their coveted United States visas.
In what could be Colombia's first legal action against the leaders, officials announced recently that they are preparing to try in absentia a leading Cali fugitive, Miguel Rodriguez Orejuela, on charges of smuggling cocaine to the United States.

HEADLINE: Mayor Details Plan for Small Businesses

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced several measures yesterday intended to assist small businesses by providing working capital, financing and financial benefits.
The Mayor said his administration would establish a program under which manufacturers would be able to buy new machinery and equipment through tax-exempt financing at rates about 25 percent less than the prevailing borrowing rates. The financing would be provided through the city's Industrial Development Agency. 
 The Mayor also said the city would begin allowing the Industrial Development Agency to help companies to enter into leases without issuing bonds, enabling the company to receive tax benefits without the high costs associated with bonds.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Earnings at Morgan Stanley Fell Sharply in 4th Quarter

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE 

 BODY:
Reflecting the effects of the worst bond market in a generation, the Morgan Stanley Group reported yesterday that profits tumbled nearly 79 percent for the fourth quarter.
Morgan Stanley, the country's fourth-largest securities firm, said that net income for the quarter, which ended Jan. 31, fell to $39 million, or 29 cents a share, from $181 million, or $2.18 a share, a year earlier. Revenue dropped about 15 percent, to $790 million from $925 million. 
 Results include a one-time, after-tax relocation charge of $39 million for Morgan Stanley's pending move to a new New York headquarters and new offices in Tokyo. Excluding the charge, the firm earned $78 million, or 80 cents a share, in its fourth quarter.
On the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, Morgan Stanley shares advanced $1.25 to close at $67.375.
"Probably every major firm in the industry experienced difficulty in trading in these three months," said Perrin H. Long Jr., an analyst for Brown Brothers Harriman & Company. "The environment for the industry is tough, and I don't see things changing much for 1995."
For the full fiscal year, Morgan Stanley had earnings of $395 million, or $4.18 a share, down roughly 50 percent from $786 million, or $9.59 a share, in the 1994 fiscal year. Revenue was off nearly 16 percent, to $3.5 billion from $4.15 billion. Excluding the one-time charge, net income totaled $434 million, or $4.68 a share, for the year.
Before yesterday's announcement, analyst forecasts were close to the actual net income before non-recurring charges. The mean estimate was 91 cents a share for the quarter and $4.83 for the year, according to the Institutional Brokers Estimate System.
In its statement, Morgan Stanley cited rising interest rates and inflation concerns and noted that although asset-management and global-clearing revenue increased, sales and trading revenue decreased.
Morgan Stanley also said it would raise its regular quarterly dividend by 2 cents, or 7 percent, to 32 cents a share. This dividend is payable on March 24 to stockholders of record on March 13.
In addition, the company's board of directors authorized $150 million more to be spent in its stock-repurchase program, bringing its overall buyback authority to $316 million, approximately 6 percent of common shares outstanding.

HEADLINE: Bishops Assail Pataki's Budget, Calling It Devastating to the Poor

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Feb. 28

 BODY:
New York State's Roman Catholic bishops harshly criticized Gov. George E. Pataki's proposed budget today, saying its deep cuts would be devastating for the poor.
The bishops, including Bishop Howard Hubbard of Albany and John Cardinal O'Connor of New York, met with Mr. Pataki for three hours today to discuss the impact of the cuts, but the Governor said the session failed to change his mind. 
 "I don't expect to see any major Medicaid or social service changes from our standpoint as a result of this meeting," he said, standing shoulder-to-shoulder with Cardinal O'Connor.
Barely two hours after the bishops met with the Republican Governor, another element of Mr. Pataki's financial plan moved forward when the State Senate overwhelmingly approved his four-year tax-cut plan, which would cost the state $720 million this year. The plan is opposed by Democrats, who contend it favors the wealthy and will force the state to make harsh spending cuts for years to come.
The day's events starkly highlighted elements of the emerging debate over Mr. Pataki's proposed $32 billion budget, in which proponents of government welfare programs have been pitted against Republicans who contend that Mr. Pataki was elected with a mandate to reduce state spending and taxes drastically.
The Catholic bishops opened their attack on Mr. Pataki's budget in the morning when Bishop Hubbard described the spending plan as "a much meaner budget than we've seen probably ever in the history of the state."
The Pataki budget calls for slashing social service programs by $1.9 billion in the coming fiscal year, the largest cut to spending for the poor in state history. The largest portion of that cut would be $1.2 billion for Medicaid, the health care program for the poor and elderly.
After meeting with the bishops at the Executive Mansion, Mr. Pataki said he told them that high taxes had driven numerous companies out of the state and that even under his budget, New York would continue to have the most generous Medicaid program in the nation.
"I understand New York's long-term history and commitment to those less fortunate, and I believe this budget will allow us to continue that, not just this year but to build on it in the future," the Governor said.
Cardinal O'Connor said: "Our concern was that the Governor listen. The Governor listened."
As the operators of a sprawling network of hospitals and community programs for the poor, the Catholic Church has traditionally been a strong advocate for increased spending on social services. But the bishops' criticism of Mr. Pataki's budget was unusually vehement.
The bishops said they were also worried about the size of Mr. Pataki's tax-cut plan, which will cost the state $6.8 billion a year in revenues when fully phased in by 1998.
"Given the devastating effects of the proposed budget, it seems to me that a scale-back of the tax cuts that are proposed really needs to be considered," Bishop Hubbard said.
Because Mr. Pataki's tax-cut plan would grow tenfold in the coming four years, Democrats have said that this year's budget cuts will pale in comparison to the reductions Mr. Pataki will have to make to balance the budget in 1998.
Mr. Pataki contends that even without cutting taxes, the state would have to reduce spending this year because it is facing a projected shortfall of $4 billion in the fiscal year that begins April 1.
The Governor and his supporters have also argued that the tax cuts will spur economic growth that will mitigate the need for future budget cuts. But Mr. Pataki has made clear that he believes the state's welfare system needs to be revamped to push people into the work force.
That debate was echoed today on the floor of the Senate, which passed Mr. Pataki's tax-cut plan by a 44-10 vote, with 10 Democrats joining the Republican majority in supporting the bill.
The vote was largely symbolic, because the Democratic-controlled Assembly has rejected Mr. Pataki's plan and, on Monday, passed its own tax-cut bill. The differences now will be resolved in negotiations over the budget.
Under Mr. Pataki's plan, the top income tax rate would fall from 7.87 to 5.9 percent over four years and the number of people paying that top rate would decline markedly.
The Democratic Assembly plan is smaller than Mr. Pataki's, worth $1.7 billion per year when fully implemented. But it would give a larger percentage of its savings to people who make less than $100,000 a year. Under that Democratic plan, the top rate would fall to only 7.75 percent by 1996, while various tax credits and deductions would be phased in to help moderate-income taxpayers.
Senator Pedro Espada Jr., a Bronx Democrat, called Mr. Pataki's plan a continuation of "12 years of Reaganomics" and questioned whether the Governor's margin of victory last year was a true mandate for his deep cuts.
"That 150,000-vote edge would not hold up to the kind of social upheaval, the urban destruction that these kinds of tax cuts, these kinds of budget cuts will have on our communities," he said.
But Senator Michael F. Nozzolio, a Seneca Falls Republican, called the bill "the tax cut plan that the people of New York demanded last November. It will lead to the economic recovery and resurgence of New York State."

HEADLINE: Teacher's Absent. Now What?;
New York Schools Face a Chronic Lack of Substitutes

BYLINE: By PAM BELLUCK 

 BODY:
On paper, everything was in order. The substitute teacher had the required license and had taught at other schools.
But the lesson she gave the sixth graders last November at Public School 64 in the High Bridge section of the Bronx shocked even the children. In the middle of a poetry lesson, the 45-year-old woman wrote on the blackboard an obscene verse about boys, girls and sexual intercourse. 
 Some children told the assistant principal, and after an investigation by the Board of Education, the woman was banned from teaching in the school system. But the episode illustrates the daily difficulty New York City schools have in finding and screening substitutes.
On any given day last year, roughly 3,000 of the system's 70,000 teachers and support staff were absent. But even though the need for trained, reliable substitutes is constant, the school system has been unable to supply every school with them.
And even those who do substitute sometimes do more harm than good. Some can't teach in the language the students speak. Others have disciplined unruly children by striking them with pointers. And many substitutes are so inexperienced that they do little more than baby-sit, principals say.
As a result, some schools have largely given up on substitutes and instead shuffle children to other grades or to the auditorium for the day. At Public School 307 in Brooklyn, for example, the science teacher and librarian sometimes act as substitutes, although this means that the rest of the students can't use the lab or library that day.
"It's not really what you want to do," said Carol Griffin, principal of P.S. 307, "but sometimes you just can't find a sub."
And some parents, when they learn there will be a substitute, have just kept their children home.
The problem is considered serious enough that beginning today, the school board will take more control over how substitutes are screened and trained.
Under the current system, schools and districts are largely on their own to find acceptable substitutes. Some have been inventive and produced systems that screen substitutes carefully and give them the information they need to build lessons for the classes they take over. But other schools, especially those in poor neighborhoods or with low achievement, have had disastrous experiences.
New York has struggled over finding substitutes for years. In 1990, budget cuts prompted the school board to scrap a central registry for substitutes, which some principals said was a failure, anyway. But losing the registry has actually been more costly, because it allowed far more teachers to claim they were unemployed and therefore qualify for benefits. Even a move several years ago to raise the daily substitute pay -- it is $97.69 now -- did not help, officials say.
Now the school board has another plan: a more centralized screening process in which principals or districts interview prospective substitutes and nominate them to the board, which has final say over their approval.
The board will also strongly recommend that day-to-day substitutes take the teaching courses required annually of longer-term substitutes, those who teach more than 40 days a year. Right now, all that is required to be a day-to-day substitute is a bachelor's degree, a medical exam and a background check. The board is also considering bringing back the central registry.
 
It's a Tough Job, Wherever the School
 Most substitutes make the best of what is always a difficult job, teaching children who may see a substitute as an excuse to misbehave. Many substitutes complain about the lack of training or preparation given by schools, which sometimes do not tell them what subject or grade to teach until they arrive. Most consider themselves lucky if the teacher has left a lesson plan, and even then, detailed directions are scarce.
The problems are not confined to New York. Finding good substitutes is "one of those systemic and perennial problems that urban school systems have," said Michael Casserly, executive director of the Council of Great City Schools, a national organization of city school systems, "and nobody has really found a satisfactory way of addressing it."
In Chicago, for instance, "There's a big substitute shortage and we do have substitutes that don't want to go into certain areas," said Ursula Anderson, supervisor for substitute teacher assignment for the Chicago public schools. But, she added, things would be worse without a central registry. "If you just said 'Subs, go wherever you want to go,' then some schools will never get subs."
Los Angeles has a similar system that officials say works well, in part because candidates must pass the same state exam given to regular teachers, said Ken Sutherland, the school district's assistant director of certificated placement and assignments. Los Angeles also urges substitutes to take the same kinds of courses that New York plans to encourage.
In New York, "The quality of subs certainly is questionable," said Art Aronstein, Superintendent of District 9, in the Bronx, where the obscene poetry incident occurred. "They have no curriculum background. They don't know content. They don't know methodology. Many of them don't know what to do. They create havoc."
 
A Struggle to Find Good Substitutes

At Public School 110, Florence Nightingale School on the Lower East Side, one substitute on the Board of Education registry arrived about five years ago with dirty clothes, grimy hair and a patient's ID bracelet from a psychiatric ward.
"She looked like she was a homeless person," said Mary Ann Fagen, the school's assistant principal. "She was very disoriented."
What's more, the woman refused to leave. "Finally, we called a fire drill so we could get her out of the building."
More recently at the same school, where 4 of 30 teachers might be absent on a given day, another substitute, a retired teacher, showed up in a house dress a few years ago, Mrs. Fagen said.
"I knew she wouldn't work out well, but I let her go into one class," she said. "When I went to check on her half an hour later, she was asleep on the desk."
For some schools, particularly in poorer areas or with low test scores, the search for a substitute is especially difficult. Good substitutes usually have their pick of schools and tend to apply to those in less troubled neighborhoods or with strong academic reputations. Those who take teaching courses to make them better substitutes may be scooped up for long stretches or become permanent teachers.
Public School 110 is considered an academic jewel of District One. But its location, under the Williamsburg Bridge, near housing projects, hampers its search for substitute teachers. "When you do get subs," Mrs. Fagen said, "you're often better off not having them."
Public School 27 in the South Bronx has a teacher out about four times a week, but the principal, Awilda Astondoa, said she could rely on only two substitutes, one of whom "has a difficult time controlling the classes." She pulled eight first graders from class in January because they were throwing erasers. Also in January, she discovered that a substitute hired for an English-speaking second-grade class could speak only Spanish.
Some schools make do without substitutes, which means regular teachers have to work harder and students may be shortchanged. At P.S. 110, classes may be splintered: some second graders will go to third grade; some will go to first grade.
"Schools will tell you that in many cases they would rather not take a chance on having a disaster in the classroom," Mr. Aronstein said.
 
So Much to Do, So Little Support
 On a recent schoolday, Brenna Guidotti, 7, swung her black patent-leather shoes aimlessly and doodled a Mighty Morphin Power Ranger. Jason Rubinstein, 8, nestled his head on his desk, eyelids closing sleepily, and Daniel Fields, 7, vroomed a red plastic sports car over his notebook.
The 21 second graders in Room 401 of P.S. 110 had a substitute teacher trying hard to get their attention.
The teacher, Audrey Fraenkel, hadn't expected to be there that day. But when she arrived at the school to drop off her son and daughter, the assistant principal stopped her. The regular teacher had the flu; could she stay? Ms. Fraenkel thought she could handle it, even though she had only been licensed to substitute for two weeks. Already, she had taught first, third and fourth grades, and had even filled in for her daughter's first-grade class.
With no time to prepare and no lesson plan from the teacher, Ms. Fraenkel relied on the contents of her brown shoulder bag. She had a copy of "The Five Chinese Brothers," a book she had read the day before to another class for Chinese New Year. She had some pictures from magazines; the children could use them to make get-well cards for their teacher.
Despite her inexperience, Ms. Fraenkel's willingness to teach has made her something of a savior at P.S. 110. She is better than many other substitutes the school has had, the assistant principal said.
That morning, Ms. Fraenkel wrote "Groundhog Day" on the board and asked the class to spell words with the letters. She reviewed homework and held a math bee.
After lunch, she sent Michael Ng to the principal's office because Lillian Quinones said he had kicked her in the schoolyard. Then she read "The Five Chinese Brothers," followed by "Thumbelina," which she borrowed from Evie Hernandez, in the front row. The second graders fidgeted, but Ms. Fraenkel kept reading -- only faster.
"We're almost done," she said.
Monique Ratliff, 7, said she liked it better "when nobody comes and we go into the third grade."
"We don't do nothing," she said. "We can just chill."
 
Treating Substitutes As Real Teachers
 At Public School 124, Yung Wing Elementary in Chinatown, dominated by low-income families, children see substitutes as real teachers, not just teachers du jour.
That wasn't always the case.
Seven years ago, when Judith Chin became principal, she found the substitutes were "just baby-sitting."
Now, Ms. Chin requires teachers to arrange their own substitutes, from a pool screened by the principal. The teacher prepares the substitute on classwork in detail; the substitute leaves a debriefing note for the teacher at day's end.
As a result, P.S. 124 has become one of the city's schools with a substitute system that works.
But Ms. Chin said that, at first, some teachers balked.
"Teachers in many schools will refuse to call the subs themselves," she said. "They feel that is the job of the administration." But now, they see substitutes as a crucial link at the school, where most days, 2 of 75 teachers are absent.
In Room 217, a fourth-grade class for the gifted, a substitute, Judi Brown, can easily follow the regular teacher's intricate lessons on bridge-building and bookmaking. She is confident enough to assign her own idea, acrostics for a poetry lesson.
Ms. Brown, 44, has been teaching at P.S. 124 for seven years. She received a degree in elementary education 20 years ago, but put it aside to be a Madison Avenue hairdresser. Now, she fills in three times a week, teaching any class she is asked to.
"I definitely feel like I make a difference," Ms. Brown said. "Two or three days without the regular teacher could break the continuity. I keep the continuity going."
The children seem to agree.
"She does a lot of things my teacher would do," said Robin Wong, 9. "It's the same. We try to do some real work."

She taught a second-grade class. (Librado Romero/The New York Times) (pg.
