HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
The Global Casino

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
So I decided to put a little money into global markets last year. I brushed up on Spanish and invested in Argentina. Took a Berlitz course in Japanese and bought a few Tokyo bonds. Lavishly tipped the waiters at the House of Hunan Chinese restaurant and picked up some stock tips in Shanghai. I even learned the difference between G.N.P., G.D.P., DDT and AT&T and invested in equities from Paris to Istanbul. For old times' sake my broker suggested I buy some Lebanese bonds, but I told him our house already had wallpaper.
At the end of the year, I looked over my dismal balance sheet and realized that with all my multilingual, multicultural, multinational research there were two little words I forgot to learn: "Alan Greenspan." 
 Like me, so many mutual fund holders who sailed off into international waters pretended that they really understood the economic reforms under way in Mexico or Thailand or China and found them worthy investments. In reality, though, they were simply going offshore because interest rates in the U.S. had fallen so low that when presented with the chance to earn 10 percent they jumped at the opportunity without comprehending the risks.
But as soon as Mr. Greenspan started hiking interest rates a year ago, a lot of that hot money that had been flowing mindlessly into emerging markets like Mexico hiked right back home into safe, well-paying U.S. T-bills. As that happened, the emerging markets became sagging markets and investors got ravaged.
Lesson 1: If you are investing in international markets you are much better served by studying the words of Chairman Greenspan than the words of Chairman Mao (or Zedillo, or Menem or Rao). In a world where money flows back and forth across borders, no one has more influence over the direction and rate of that flow than Mr. Greenspan. So skip the Chinese takeout and throw away the Japanese language tapes. The best language to be fluent in on the global investment highway is "Greenspanese." Understanding what he is doing with interest rates at home is the first step to investing abroad.
But 1994 was rich in other lessons about the global economy as well.
Lesson 2: Daddy always said, "Diversify, diversify, diversify." So a lot of global investors diversified. They bought bonds in Japan, bonds in China, bonds in Mexico and bonds in Germany. And guess what happened? They got killed all across the board. They thought they were diversified, but in fact they just owned bonds in what is now a single, unified global marketplace. The linkages between global markets today are so tight that you cannot diversify by simply investing in a smorgasbord of different countries. The only way to really diversify is not by country, but by investment instrument and level of risk. You have to spread out among low-, medium- and high-risk stocks, bonds, currencies and commodities. If you just buy bonds in different countries you will quickly discover that you never left home.
Lesson 3: Governments may have lost a lot of power to markets, but they still matter. It is government policies that first shape the quality of the bonds and currencies trading around the globe. Mexico initially got into trouble because its Government tried to buy an election by printing money without devaluing the fixed-rate peso. All the money managers did was tell Mexico this was unsustainable. That is why the global investor George Soros likes to say, "I am the most highly paid theater critic in the world." The leaders put on the show, the money managers write the reviews and the countries suffer (or enjoy) the consequences.
Lesson 4: With markets opening up in China, Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union, never have more people been making more investments in more places they cannot find on a map with more people whose names they cannot pronounce in more financial instruments they do not understand. Robert Baldoni, head of the Emcor derivative consulting firm, has a golden rule for navigating the new world. It applies to individual investors, treasurers of Orange County and 28-year-old traders at Barings. Says Mr. Baldoni: "I invest money for my mother, who is now retired. I will invest in a variety of instruments, but I won't make any investment for my mother the logic of which she can't repeat back to me."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Rally to End Day Mixed

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Fresh economic news yesterday left investors unsure whether the economy was slowing down as much as the Federal Reserve would like, and therefore whether the Fed would find it necessary to raise short-term interest rates once again.
Nevertheless, prices of Treasury securities staged a late rally to finish mixed, after dropping in early trading as investors sold on worries that interest rates would rise and erode the value of their fixed-income holdings. Buyers re-entered the market, lowering yields of the longer maturities while helping the short and intermediate part of the market bounce off the day's lows in the afternoon on news that retail sales were off. 
 The price of the 30-year bond rose 11/32 of a point, to 102 8/32 , for a yield of 7.44 percent, down from 7.47 percent on Monday.
Thomas W. Synnott 3d, the U.S. Trust Corporation's chief economist -- who has predicted the Fed will raise short-term interest rates one more time in May, sending longer-term interest rates back up in sympathy -- said that the Fed's policy of gradually tightening credit and raising interest rates had a very good chance of slowing the economy to a sustainable, noninflationary pace. But that's only part of the problem. "Of almost equal importance is the Fed's responsibility to control the growth of money and credit," he said.
Of the data released yesterday, Mr. Synnott said the slower home sales were consistent with the slowing economy, but they were still fairly high. "We here at U.S. Trust had been looking for a 9 percent drop in housing starts this year, to an average of 1.31 million units on a annualized basis, from 1.45 million units," Mr. Synnott said.
While home sales are down 15 percent from a year ago, he said, "you have to remember that last year was a record level." He added, "You're coming off the mountain."
The market reacted badly to the Chicago purchasing managers' report yesterday, which will be followed by national purchasing data today. "The Chicago report showed a very large jump in the price index component," Mr. Synnott said.
"This data may be a cautionary signal for the bond market, which I think has gotten a little ahead of itself," he added, "leaving itself open for correction."
The Chicago purchasing managers' index for February eased just slightly, to 62.7 percent from 63 percent, about as expected, although the prices-paid component of the index jumped to 88.3 percent from 82 percent.
Johnson Redbook Service also gave traders reason to believe that the Fed's previous rate increases could be sapping the economy's strength. The service reported retail sales were down 2.5 percent in February, and that helped bond prices in the afternoon.
In the corporate bond market yesterday, AT&T, Capital One and Southwest Air sold $ 800 million of investment-grade debt, with the long- distance telephone operator dominating activity with the sale of $ 500 million of 12-year notes through Lehman Brothers.
The senior unsecured debt was given a 7.75 percent coupon and priced at 99.966 to yield 7.754 percent, or about 46 basis points more than Treasury securities with a comparable maturity. The securities, rated Aa3 by Moody's Investors Service, AA by Standard & Poor's and AA+ by Duff and Phelps Credit, are noncallable through maturity. A basis point is a hundredth of a percentage point.

HEADLINE: Fed Backs Removing Bank Curb

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28

 BODY:
The chairman of the Federal Reserve today joined the White House and key Congressional Republicans in calling for an end to the legal barriers that have separated the nation's commercial banks and securities firms since the 1930's.
But Alan Greenspan, the Fed's chairman, questioned some details of the Clinton Administration's plan for abolishing the Depression-era Glass-Steagall Act that established the barriers. He also urged Congress not to move quickly on a proposal by Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, the New York Republican who heads the Senate Banking Committee, to allow nonfinancial companies to own banks. 
 Mr. Greenspan said that the benefits from financial deregulation were so substantial that members of Congress should strive to overcome their differences to strike a compromise. The central bank's "support for the expansion of permissible activities reflects the desirability of removing outdated restrictions that serve no useful purpose, that decrease economic efficiency, and that, as a result, limit choices and options for the consumer of financial services," he told the House Banking Committee.
Most Republicans on the committee echoed Mr. Greenspan's call for quick action to effectively repeal the law that requires investment banks and commercial banks to operate separately. Democrats expressed less support, with several warning that new financial conglomerates might be insensitive to the needs of consumers and small businesses, particularly those in low-income and minority neighborhoods.
But no Democrat went so far as to promise a vote to retain Glass-Steagall. The House Banking Committee has been a bastion of support for changing the law.
When Democrats ruled Congress, the House Energy and Commerce Committee blocked efforts to change the law. But the Republicans took authority over the law away from that committee and gave it to the banking committee.
The Federal Reserve, by itself and through the banks it regulates, wields tremendous political influence on banking issues. Last year, the Fed derailed the Administration's plan to consolidate bank regulatory agencies, which would have diluted the Fed's power over the nation's banking system.
Without criticizing the Administration by name, Mr. Greenspan took issue with a key element of its plan.
Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin outlined on Monday two ways in which the Clinton Administration might allow these banks and securities firms to merge. One would let a bank own a securities firm outright. The other would allow the creation of a corporate parent, known as a holding company, that would own a bank and a securities firm under one umbrella.
Mr. Greenspan said he favored allowing only the holding company approach, in which the bank would not own the securities company directly. Mr. Greenspan said that this approach was more likely to prevent the new financial institutions from taking risks with Federally insured deposits.
Mr. Greenspan took issue with advocates of outright mergers, who argue that certain legal barriers, commonly known as fire walls, can be placed between a bank and a securities affiliate to prevent the misuse of insured deposits.
"Fire walls are not as effective as we used to believe," he said. "They tend to melt inordinately."
The Treasury Department disagreed with Mr. Greenspan's assessment. "We believe that with appropriate fire walls, operating subsidiaries can provide the same protection as the bank holding company structure," a Treasury spokesman said tonight.
The Federal Reserve has an institutional interest in defending the expanded use of holding companies, because it already regulates bank holding companies. Representative Jim Leach, the Iowa Republican who heads the banking committee, has introduced a bill that would require the creation of holding companies for securities firms affiliated with commercial banks.
Eugene A. Ludwig, the Comptroller of the Currency and a senior Treasury official, told the committee today that Mr. Leach's bill would so completely separate banking from securities trading that it would prevent companies from taking reasonable advantage of the two industries' similarities.
Banking industry lawyers were also alarmed by Mr. Greenspan's stance today. Robert M. Kurucza, the general counsel of the Bank Securities Association, which represents big banks that have already set up small securities operations in their holding companies, said that banks needed to be able to conduct at least retail brokerage activities within bank subsidiaries.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
A Fresh Wind Is Blowing at Talks

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., Feb. 28

 BODY:
The effort may fall short, but negotiators in baseball's labor dispute made it clear today they are earnestly trying to make a deal that would enable legitimate major leaguers to replace the replacement players.
On the 201st day of the strike and the second day of this round of talks, neither side could point to concrete progress on the central economic issues of payroll tax, revenue sharing and salary arbitration/free agency. Nevertheless, their relationship remained peaceful and their work positive. 
 "Each side is feeling the impact of the economic activity here and therefore positions change," one lawyer involved in the talks said, trying to explain the difference in the approach the two sides have taken this week.
The results of the second of the day's two meetings perhaps were reflected in the view of Donald Fehr, the union leader, when he explained that the meeting had been recessed so the players' group could discuss some of the new information learned today about the clubs' revenue-sharing plan.
"I do not want to suggest there's any major breakthrough or tremendous thing we've learned that we didn't know before," Fehr said. "But there were a number of points clarified. There were some things we've learned over the last two days that suggest we have not communicated with one another as precisely as we might have liked on some issues."
Meeting at the golf club on Gainey Ranch, the two sides spent about an hour and a half in full committees reviewing their positions on noneconomic and governance issues. They actually have tentative agreement on some of those issues, minor though they may be.
Then two smaller groups held a three-hour discussion on the economic issues, and it is those groups that planned to reconvene Wednesday morning after the players' unit had a chance to digest whatever new information it gleaned.
"Rather than the objective parts of the revenue-sharing plan, maybe we have different views about what Fort Lauderdale does, what effect it may have," Bud Selig, the acting commissioner, said, referring to the plan by the site of its adoption 13 months ago. "The objective today was to increase our level and their level of understanding. I would hope the dialogue both days maybe contributed to that, which maybe gives them a different view than they've had before as we explained our rationale and how Fort Lauderdale got put together."
The revenue-sharing plan has presented a sticking point in the talks because the two sides have different views about how the money for the low-revenue clubs should be generated. It is also linked to the tax the clubs want to place on payrolls to create a drag on salaries.
If the two sides can find a way to reconcile their differences on revenue sharing, they may find it easier to deal with the tax problem.
Jerry McMorris of the Colorado Rockies, one of five members of the owners' small-group negotiators, emerged from the session stating the questions that remain critical to the clubs: "How do we achieve significant economic change? What do we do in terms of a tax and the drag that will produce?"
Calling the meeting "the most positive bargaining session we have had since we began these negotiations," McMorris said in his typically optimistic manner, "A settlement could come tomorrow." But he quickly added, "Is that likely tomorrow? Probably not."
No one else was willing to go that far.
"I believe there's an equal desire on both sides to get a deal and that's where Jerry's optimism comes from," Lauren Rich, a union lawyer, said. "But it's still too early to judge whether we can bridge the large, large gap between us."
Fehr said the talks were not being conducted in the manner of one side making a proposal and the other side presenting a counterproposal. Rather, the negotiators have been looking at the economic elements as a package.
"Everybody knows roughly what the numbers look like," he said, referring to the debate over a payroll tax. "You're dealing with combinations of concepts that might put you closer together."
The two sides, McMorris said, did "a little bit of probing conceptually on how a tax might work in conjunction with looking at the full package together."
In a strike-related matter, the 32-game exhibition schedule of the Baltimore Orioles will be canceled on Wednesday.
When spring training began, the Orioles, the only team that has refused to field replacement players, notified their 12 exhibition opponents that they would not play them if they planned to use replacement players in the games.
At the direction of the commissioner's office, 11 of the 12 clubs individually sent the same notices to the Orioles, telling them if they didn't inform the clubs by 2 P.M. Wednesday that they had reversed their stance, the games would be canceled. Only the Colorado Rockies, who are scheduled to play the Orioles in the last exhibition game, did not send that notice.
"We're not going to respond further," Roland Hemond, Baltimore's general manager, said by telephone from Sarasota, Fla. "They say they are canceling the games. If things get settled, I imagine the league will pick up the schedule where it stands."

HEADLINE: Barings Officials Optimistic on Finding a Buyer

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LONDON, Feb. 28

 BODY:
Optimism ran high within Barings P.L.C. today that the failed firm could be sold within days, probably in pieces, despite the $1 billion loss sitting on its books.
Two days after Barings was brought down by a single trader's enormous losing bet on the direction of Japanese stocks and interest rates, Barings executives said representatives of banks and investment houses from around the world were discussing possible deals with a court-appointed administrator. 
 The rumored suitors were a veritable roll-call of the financial services industry. They included Merrill Lynch, Bankers Trust and GE Capital of the United States, National Westminster Bank and the HSBC Corporation of Britain, ABN-Amro of the Netherlands, Deutsche Bank of Germany and various Japanese institutions. None of them made any public statement of their intentions.
Barings executives said they had completed presentations to six potential buyers, whom they declined to identify. Similar presentations are scheduled over coming days as the firm's bankruptcy administrator scrambles to sell as much of the company for as high a price as possible to make up the huge loss incurred by Nicholas W. Leeson, a 28-year-old trader in the Singapore office of Barings.
Mr. Leeson disappeared on Thursday just before Barings discovered the losses. Despite an intensifying manhunt by the police throughout Southeast Asia, Mr. Leeson, who has not been charged with a crime, was nowhere to be found today.
There was continued speculation within the firm that Mr. Leeson might have been working with someone inside or outside the firm, perhaps in a deliberate attempt to bring down Barings -- a possibility raised by Peter Baring, the firm's chairman, in an interview with The Financial Times today.
But Barings executives and Bank of England officials said it was still too soon to know how and why Mr. Leeson made his disastrous investments. They said he had covered his tracks skillfully, probably by using a variety of accounts and his knowledge of back-office settlement procedures from his early years with the firm, which he joined in 1989.
Bank of England officials said they hoped that an intensive investigation of the Barings records in Singapore and London would determine the extent to which fraud, lax internal controls or poor regulation in Singapore led to the huge losses.
Barings has three major operating divisions that are all expected to attract bidders: its fund-management subsidiary, which had $46 billion invested on behalf of clients last year; its corporate finance arm, which is one of the most active advisers on mergers and acquisitions in Britain and throughout Europe, and its securities business, which is highly respected for its research and trading operations, especially in the emerging markets of Asia, Latin America and Eastern Europe.
"There seem to be an adequate number of interested buyers for all the businesses," a Barings executive said.
But Barings and its court-appointed bankruptcy administrators from the accounting firm of Ernst & Young face a number of daunting obstacles.
Still, the Ernst & Young administrators have told Barings employees that they believe they can sell the operating units before knowing the full extent of the losses from Mr. Leeson's trading, saying in effect that they can sell the assets of the firm without linking them to its liabilities. The lack of buyers willing to take on such unknown liabilities was what doomed the Bank of England's attempt to put together a rescue package for Barings over the weekend.
It is unclear how Ernst & Young can sell assets before defining the losses and stopping them from increasing further, especially since at least some of the operating units are directly affected by the losses. The asset-management business, for example, is believed to have deposited some of its clients' cash in the banking operation, which currently has all its funds frozen. Ernst & Young did not respond to a telephone request for comment.
It is also unclear just how big the firm's losses might become. That will depend in part on whether Japanese stock prices fall further. Monday's 3.8 percent decline in the Nikkei 225 stock index, for example, added $280 million to the losses.
There was also speculation in the financial markets that there could be a ticking time bomb in Mr. Leeson's positions. Analysts and traders in Asia said that in addition to his stock and interest-rate positions, Mr. Leeson appeared to have engaged in a third kind of bet, a complex maneuver known as a straddle, in which he was selling for cash a combination of options on the Nikkei index.
The straddle was a bet that stock prices in Tokyo would remain stable, enabling Mr. Leeson to keep the cash price of the position. Industry executives speculated that Mr. Leeson had sold the straddles to raise cash for margin calls on his deteriorating futures positions in stocks and interest rates. But with the Japanese market having dropped sharply, the straddles would have run up huge losses very quickly, executives said, losses for which Barings would be liable. The Bank of England's public estimate of $1 billion for the Barings losses has not included any accounting for straddles.
A Bank of England spokesman said the central bank was still working to piece together Mr. Leeson's investments, and that it did not yet know whether there was a large straddle position. A senior Barings executive said he doubted whether a large straddle position remained undetected, but that it was possible.
Within Barings today, there was a clear split developing between the various operating arms. The securities business in particular made an effort to portray itself as a cohesive, self-contained unit willing if not eager to break with the banking side. Many executives in the securities business blame the banking and capital markets group for failing to oversee Mr. Leeson.
"There is some blame being apportioned, but there's no merit in pointing the finger at a partnership that no longer exists," a securities unit executive said. "We're concerned about our own future."
The executive said that he knew of no employees in his division who had left to take another job since the firm's collapse and that employees were rebuffing executive recruiters and other firms when they called.
 
Greenspan on Barings
 WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (Special to The New York Times) -- Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, warned today that Barings P.L.C. of Britain might not be the last financial institution to encounter huge losses because of the actions of an individual employee.
It's going to continue," he said as he testified before a Congressional committee, "basically because the technology is there for that to happen."
Preventing damage to the domestic and international financial system was more important than preventing losses at individual institutions, he added. The Fed chairman also said careful regulation was preferable to legislation to try to control such abuses.
"Unless you want to reverse technology," he said, "unless you want to reverse knowledge, move the clock back, it's not capable of being eliminated. Human nature is going to do what human nature has always done, bad things on occasion. Our job is to prevent that from becoming systemic."
Later, at a cocktail party with business economists in Washington, Mr. Greenspan joked that 25 years ago no single individual could have lost $1 billion -- because in the days before computers that would have required filling out a remarkable number of trading slips.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Lumber and Copper Plunge On Weak Home-Sales Data

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Copper and lumber prices fell sharply yesterday after a report of weaker home sales last month raised fears of softer demand for the commodities.
Lumber prices on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange fell by their allowed limit, while copper dropped to its lowest level in almost three weeks on the Commodity Exchange of New York. 
 On other commodity markets, cotton prices soared to a record high.
The Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 commodities fell 0.67 point, to 234.25.
The National Association of Realtors reported yesterday that sales of existing homes fell 4.5 percent in January to an annual rate of 3.59 million, the lowest level since April 1993. Analysts attributed the decline to higher interest rates.
On the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, lumber for May delivery dropped its daily limit of $10, to $312.20 for 1,000 board feet, its lowest price in more than two months. The May copper contract slid 2.50 cents, to $1.2855 a pound, on the Commodity Exchange.
Lumber prices received some support as concerns eased about a possible strike at the CP Rail System of Canada. The company said it hoped to reach a settlement with its unions this week.
Cotton prices closed at the highest level in the history of the New York Cotton Exchange, which was founded in 1870. The price is the highest since the cash market traded at $1.90 during the Civil War.
Cotton for March delivery rose 3.37 cents, to $1.0575 a pound, as traders scrambled to secure supplies before the contract expires on March 9. The May contract gained its allowed limit of 2 cents for the second consecutive day to end at $1.0217.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Declines Moderately While Mark Gains Broadly

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar fell moderately against leading currencies yesterday, weakened by an early selloff in the United States bond market, while the German mark advanced broadly as more financial and political jitters swept Europe.
Worried about the durability of governments from London to Rome, high government debt across the Continent and the stability of Europe's financial markets afterthe collapse of Barings P.L.C. of Britain, investors fled weaker currencies to the perceived safety of the mark. 
 "It's a flight to quality, and at this point quality is found in the Deutsche mark," said Dave Glowacki, senior trader at the NBD Bank in Detroit.
While the market focused on trading among European currencies, the dollar was caught in the downdraft and declined through much of the day until a late recovery in Treasury bond prices helped provide support. Gains in United States markets tend to increase demand for the dollars needed to buy American securities.
In late New York trading, the dollar fell to 1.4625 marks, from 1.4660 on Monday. The dollar, which is trading at its lowest level against the mark since October 1992, has fallen more than 6 percent against the mark this year.
The dollar also slipped to 96.75 yen from 97.07 yen.
With seemingly no safe, long-term bets, many investors have put money into German banks and short-term German securities while they wait for the turmoil to subside. The shift has driven up demand for marks. The mark is viewed as a safer haven than the dollar because of concerns about the impact of Mexico's financial crisis on the United States economy.
Heightening financial worries in Europe yesterday, Compagnie de Suez, parent of Banque Indosuez, a leading French bank, reported a 1994 loss of more than $900 million as a result of huge losses on its real estate operations.
"Coming on the heels of Barings, it was a concern," Mr. Glowacki of the NBD Bank said. "It added to the 'buy the mark' syndrome."
Currency dealers also cited as a concern today's vote in the British Parliament on Prime Minister John Major's Europe policy. The vote is seen as a critical test for Mr. Major's Government.
But the British pound gained against the dollar, rising to $1.5835, from $1.5812 on Monday.

HEADLINE: January's Home Resales Suggest a Slowdown

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28

 BODY:
High interest rates are taking a toll on the housing market, pushing January sales of previously owned homes to the lowest level in nearly two years.
Analysts said the larger-than-expected decline of 4.5 percent reported today by the National Association of Realtors suggested the economy was slowing. But they warned that other reports were sending mixed signals. 
 "Put the sales figures together with slower housing starts and they certainly point to a long-awaited slowdown in the housing sector," Dan Seto, an economist for Nikko Securities, said.
But he added that a new report on consumer confidence by the Conference Board, a research group based in New York, was less clear-cut.
The board's widely followed index of consumer willingness to borrow and spend fell to 99.0 in February from a revised reading of 101.4 in January. Analysts said while the trend was down, the level remained high and was normally associated with a vibrant economy.
In a third economic report released today, the Purchasing Management Association of Chicago said its index of inflation rose to 88.3 in February from 82 last month. Based on price increases experienced by managers, the index is an early indication of inflation.
 The National Association of Realtors said sales of existing single-family homes totaled 3.59 million at a seasonally adjusted annual rate in January, down from 3.76 million.
The January rate is the lowest monthly pace since 3.46 million in April 1993 and is 13.9 percent below the 4.17 million rate of a year ago. The Northeast was the only region where sales rose.
Fixed-rate 30-year mortgages averaged 9.15 percent in January, down slightly from 9.19 percent in December and 9.17 percent in November but more than two percentage points higher than January 1994.
An increase from 7 percent to 9 percent adds $139.32 to the monthly payment on a $100,000 mortgage.
"There's no question that high interest rates have priced out some buyers," said Edmund G. Woods Jr., president of the real estate group. "However, we also have lost a lot of prospects who could still afford to buy but are too jittery about rates to go through with it."
The group forecasts 3.74 million sales in 1995, down from 3.95 million last year.
While higher rates made housing more costly, the median price of a previously owned home remained stable during the year. It inched up just one-tenth of 1 percent, to $108,100. The median is the midpoint, meaning half the homes cost more and half cost less.
Regionally, sales rose 3.7 percent in the Northeast in January. But they fell elsewhere, including a 9.9 percent plunge in the Midwest; a 7.4 percent slide in the West, and a 2.1 percent dip in the South.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (92%);

LENGTH: 950 words

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
Camelot's Seamy Side, Brazenly Reconstructed

BYLINE: By JANET MASLIN 

 BODY:

AMERICAN TABLOID
By James Ellroy
576 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $25.
"I'm saying it's so big and audacious that we'll most likely never be suspected," says a character in James Ellroy's densely malevolent new novel, "American Tabloid," as he proposes a plot to assassinate President John F. Kennedy. "I'm saying that even if we are, the powers that be will realize that it can never be conclusively proven. I'm saying that a consensus of denial will build off of it. I'm saying that people will want to remember the man as something he wasn't. I'm saying that we'll present them with an explanation and the powers that be will prefer it to the truth, even though they know better." 
 Mr. Ellroy, a skilled purveyor of brutally tough prose, assumes the same sort of gullibility on his readers' part. Tapping into an enduringly popular vein of paranoid fantasy, he extrapolates from President Kennedy's assassination to create a scheme that's as intricate as it is irresponsible. Oliver Stone's "J. F. K." looks like the Disney version beside Mr. Ellroy's web of triple-dealing operatives, hapless thugs and public figures -- including Howard Hughes, J. Edgar Hoover and Jimmy Hoffa -- whose private activities are freely imagined and embroidered here.
Mr. Ellroy's prologue offers a defiant justification of such tactics. "It's time to demythologize an era and build a new myth from the gutter to the stars," he maintains. He also notes: "Mass-market nostalgia gets you hopped up for a past that never existed. Hagiography sanctifies shuck-and-jive politicians and reinvents their expedient gestures as moments of great moral weight. Our continuing narrative line is blurred past truth and hindsight. Only a reckless verisimilitude can set that line straight."
This becomes the shaky foundation for Mr. Ellroy's skyscraper of cards, a brazen, violent, sometimes caustically funny assemblage of assassination-linked facts and rumors. What command attention are the sheer intricacy of the author's plotting, the depth of his bottomless cynicism and the staccato energy of his prose, which neither minces nor wastes words. "Nobody talked -- Jimmy Hoffa sulking killed chitchat" is a typically crystalline observation.
Though California crime stories are his usual milieu, Mr. Ellroy segues into political intrigue without missing a beat or changing his tune. Deadly mayhem rears its head at regular intervals. ("They left a cable clamped to Sal's tongue. Voltage burned his face shiny black." "Pete blew his brains out halfway through a rosary.") Navigating their way through this novel's sea of crooks and opportunists are three pivotal tough guys who give the story its back-stabbing intensity.
One is Kemper Boyd, "still too handsome to live," who is attracted to the Kennedy family even as he agrees to spy on them for Hoover, and whose taste for high living lands him on the payrolls of the F.B.I., the C.I.A. and the United States Senate Select Committee on Investigations. Another is Ward Littell, a friend of Boyd's and ex-Jesuit seminarian, with an admiration for Robert Kennedy that turns dangerous during the story.
There's also Pete Bondurant, the Canadian hit man and extortionist who is responsible for many evils, including the deaths of his own parents and brother. "People have this tendency to tell me things they don't want to," Pete says, with admirable understatement.
The chicanery that Mr. Ellroy creates for this threesome is so complicated that it requires constant summarizing and repeating of plot points. Memos, letters and transcripts of taped conversations are all too necessary to make this story "slow and easy for the stupes in the peanut gallery." For all its stylistic economy, the book often sprawls. But the author can sometimes make ingenious use of real historical events, like the killing of four children in the bombing of a black church in Birmingham, Ala. An elaborate feat of gamesmanship ties that bombing to the murder of President Kennedy.
Mr. Ellroy's great flair is for hard-bitten, minimalist locutions (Sam Giancana: "I rue the day I bought Jack Illinois"), which aren't easy to sustain in this context. Putting words in the mouths of real figures is chancy at best, downright awkward when it comes to Presidential pillow talk. ("You see, Darleen, Bobby's more heroic than I am because he's truly passionate and generous," President Kennedy supposedly says.) Walk-ons are better, as when Dean Acheson and Bennett Cerf are spotted at a Kennedy cocktail party and don't have to deliver any dialogue. When the book devotes endless attention to the Bay of Pigs fiasco, it's a relief that Fidel Castro is only referred to as "the bombastic bushy-haired beatnik bard" by a Hughes-owned scandal sheet, and never required to speak.
Mr. Ellroy has as much trouble writing female characters as he does heads of state. "American Tabloid" treads water during its isolated, perfunctory romantic scenes, some involving Boyd with an illegitimate daughter of Joseph P. Kennedy and Gloria Swanson. The book trades knowingly on the existence of such a character, making it part of the swirl of gossip that colors the narrative. Movie stars' sexual preferences and proclivities are used to heighten the inside-dirt ambiance of the title.
For every bit of cleverness engendered by this name-dropping -- as when Boyd mischievously creates the rumor of a President Kennedy-Marilyn Monroe affair -- there's sure to be something specious, like the casual claim that Monroe slept with pizza delivery boys and Rin-Tin-Tin's trainer. At such times, Mr. Ellroy reveals much more about the liabilities of fact-bending fiction than about other types of crime.

GRAPHIC: Photo of James Ellroy. (Marion Ettlinger/Alfred A. Knopf)

HEADLINE: Bean Pies Have Grand New Home

BYLINE: By LENA WILLIAMS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Feb. 28

 BODY:
In a style as grand and audacious as its leader, the Nation of Islam opened a new $5 million restaurant complex on Chicago's South Side today. The opening marked a return to the food service business that helped establish the Nation, the black Muslim religious sect, as a steady economic presence in African-American neighborhoods across the country in the 1960's and 1970's.
Unlike the Nation's earlier restaurants -- small places with Formica-topped tables and tiled floors -- the new Salaam Restaurants and Bakery is a lavish two-story, 15,000-square-foot mosque-like structure. 
 With its landmark yellow star and crescent rising from a 90-foot rooftop pole, the sand-colored restaurant stands in stark contrast to the surrounding neighborhood of brick-and-concrete buildings pockmarked with boarded storefronts and empty lots and dotted with mom-and-pop shops. It is a tough, predominantly black neighborhood of gang conflicts and drug deals, one that most developers have turned their backs on.
Diane Ivy, who lives three blocks from the restaurant, got to peek through the doors Monday, and it was enough to whet her appetite.
"It's beautiful," she said of the building, whose construction she had watched for years. "It makes you want to get dressed up to eat bean pie."
The restaurant's opening, scheduled for 10 this morning, was pushed back to 4 P.M. as workers frantically added finishing touches and tended to a broken water pipe.
Judging from the publicity surrounding the opening, it seems as if Salaam, whose name means "peace" in Arabic, is not just a restaurant; it is a movement by the organization and its leader, the minister Louis Farrakhan, to broaden the Nation's reach beyond its membership and other parts of the black population.
In press information to announce the opening, the Nation of Islam lists its building contractors and consultants and their business affiliations and racial and ethnic backgrounds: 21 blacks, 9 whites, 3 Jews, an Egyptian, an Italian, a Chinese and an Indian. The restaurant will be staffed by local residents and members of the Nation, according to the press information.
Responding to questions from reporters about how his restaurant would be received given the anger and suspicion he has aroused among some ethnic and racial groups over the years, Mr. Farrakhan, known for his fiery and sometimes antiwhite, anti-Semitic oratory, said at a news conference last week that "all" are welcomed at Salaam's tables.
"That star and that crescent says that all of the world and its people are welcome in this establishment and all will be treated with the highest dignity and quality," he said.
He said he viewed the new venture as "a blueprint for economic development and investment in our neglected communities," providing about 100 jobs. The restaurant, on West 79th Street and South Union Avenue, is a few blocks from the Nation of Islam's national headquarters, which includes a mosque, an office building, a bookstore and the building that houses The Final Call, the Nation's newspaper. Mr. Farrakhan said he planned to expand the site later this year.
In Salaam, on the second floor of the complex, a prototype shows the future: a proposed 2,000-seat performing arts center, to the left of the restaurant complex, that will be known as the Emerald Palace.
"We placed this in the heart of the so-called ghetto to say, 'Black people, we love you and you are worth every dime that we invest in you,' " Mr. Farrakhan said. " 'This is your palace. Come here and be treated like the kings and queens that you really are.' "
Janet Hampton and Florence Knight were at the steam tables at 4:30 P.M., ordering fried whiting, sesame chicken, collard greens and macaroni and cheese. The two had been waiting since 3:15 P.M. to taste the food that they remembered from the days when they ate at the old Salaam in the nearby Chatham neighborhood. "My only regret," Mrs. Hampton said as her friend nodded in approval, "is that we had failed to make reservations for the upstairs dining, a mistake we won't make this Sunday."
The project, which took 10 years to develop, was financed by the Nation of Islam, which once claimed as many as 500,000 members, and sales of The Final Call. Recent estimates put the national membership at 100,000, with about 30,000 in Chicago. Members were asked to tithe $600 each for the project. The Nation plans to open five more restaurants, investing up to $2 million in each -- the next in Atlanta later this year, followed by New York, Los Angeles, Houston and Miami.
Several people in the restaurant industry said that even factoring in the differences in regional costs in terms of labor, materials and construction, $5 million is a major investment for a restaurant. Among recent construction of high-profile restaurants, the Gramercy Tavern in New York, which opened last July, cost $3 million, and Wolfgang Puck's Granita, which opened in Malibu, Calif., in 1991, cost $3.5 million.
Salaam is actually three restaurants under one roof. In accordance with the Muslim prohibition of the eating of pork or consumption of alcohol, Salaam's executive chef, Early Primus, former chef to Muhammad Ali and to Mr. Farrakhan, has prepared a menu of soul food and other ethnic dishes from places like North Africa and the Caribbean.
Salaam includes Blue Seas, a small takeout and eat-in restaurant featuring seafood and salads; the Atrium, with a weekend dinner buffet and Sunday brunch under skylights, and Salaam Fine Dining, a grand restaurant with white tablecloths and waiters in white jackets. Salaam Fine Dining features marble columns and floors, crystal and brass chandeliers, a brass elevator and a grand piano.
On the menu at Salaam Fine Dining are Salaam snapper medallions, sweet and sour flying fish, vegetarian jambalaya jardin, double lamb chops Morocco and meatless barbecue spare ribs (their contents are a closely held secret).
Entrees at Salaam Fine Dining range from $12.95 to $15.95. Meals at the Blue Seas restaurant, whose menu includes a selection of vegetarian plates, sandwiches, rotisserie chicken and a full salad bar, average $5.50. The Atrium will serve a buffet, from $7 to $10.
Salaam Fine Dining seats 65 people; Blue Seas and the Atrium, both on the first floor, seat 100 each. A computerized kitchen that cost more than $600,000 can prepare up to 1,400 meals an hour, said Tracey D. Hughes, a Salaam publicity agent.
Free valet parking is available, and members of the Fruit of Islam, the Nation's unarmed security unit, will patrol the area. "There are no police around," said Alderman Allan Streeter, who represents the 17th ward, where the restaurant is situated. "The brothers are walking the streets, taking care of business and looking out for the patrons."
The opening prompts memories of the Nation of Islam's earlier days, when under the leadership of its founder, Elijah Muhammad, the group owned and operated a string of Salaam restaurants in cities like Chicago, New York and Washington.
In Harlem, the Nation's restaurant on Lenox Avenue was popular during the late 1960's and 1970's. Malcolm X and Mr. Farrakhan, his successor as minister of the Harlem mosque, often dined there. Politicians like Charles B. Rangel, the Democratic Congressman from Manhattan, and celebrities like Muhammad Ali were known to order the fried whiting sandwich on whole wheat bread and the navy-bean pie.
The previous Salaam in Chicago, four miles east of the new site, was the last to close, in the late 1970's. According to published reports, the closing was a result of internal conflicts and financial problems in the Nation of Islam, as well as an exodus of business from the area.
At a private party at the restaurant last Wednesday, complete with Hollywood search lights bright enough to pick out enemy planes, public officials and celebrities like Vicki Winans, of the gospel-singing Winans family, and Eugene Sawyer, former Mayor of Chicago, Mr. Farrakhan told guests that they no longer had to go to the gallery district north of the Loop to break bread with the stars. Michael Jordan and Oprah Winfrey own restaurants there.
Ricardo Webb, 29, had heard about the old Salaam restaurants and decided to see for himself whether the new one could live up to the reputation for great food and courteous service. He brought along his son, Ricardo Jr., 7, and his friend Tanya Jones. "It's good for young people to see that a restaurant like this, owned by blacks and in the black community, can be done in such high style," he said.
"It means that we don't have to go all the way to downtown Chicago to be among white folks to have a fine dining experience."

HEADLINE: Wine Talk

BYLINE: By Frank J. Prial 

 BODY:
EVERY year at this time, Americans find out how much wine they drank last year, what kind it was, and what their vinous intake for the year ahead is likely to be. And it looks like wine drinking is going up.
"The wine business has finally turned the corner," said Jon Fredrikson, a wine industry consultant in San Francisco. "Last year was a good year, and we expect 1995 to be the same." 
 Shipments of all wine in the United States reached 455 million gallons in 1994, he estimated, up 2 percent from 448 million in 1993. But a better indicator of wine growth, he said, is the 5 percent increase in shipments of table wine, which includes everything from California jug wine to Chateau Latour, to 356 million gallons.
The improved climate for wine in America, and especially for California wine, has brought back a touch of the euphoria that surrounded the wine business in the 1970's and early 1980's, Mr. Fredrikson said. "Investors are looking for land and planting vineyards," he added. Wineries are rationing their production and scrambling to find good grapes.
"A couple of years ago, export was seen as the way to save the industry," said Mr. Fredrikson, whose firm, Gomberg & Fredrikson, has been tracking the industry for more than 50 years. "Now, they are talking about cutting back on exports to supply the booming domestic market."
His optimism is supported by figures from Infoscan, a service of Information Resources Inc., which monitors sales through supermarket electronic scanners. About 30 percent of all wine sold in the United States is sold in supermarkets.
The star performers last year, according to Infoscan, were two red wine varieties, merlot and pinot noir, which were up 46 percent and 47 percent respectively over the previous year. Cabernet sauvignon, long America's favorite premium red wine, was up 23 percent, while chardonnay, the country's favorite wine of any color by a wide margin, was up 27 percent over 1993.
The strong showing by red wines reflects the continued impact of the so-called French Paradox, which was explored on "60 Minutes" in 1991. The television program reported that red wine as part of a regular diet helped keep down the incidence of heart disease in France. Red-wine shipments have increased 60 percent in this country since the report was first broadcast, Mr. Fredrikson said.
Wine sales have still not matched those of 1984, when the industry peaked, Mr. Fredrikson said. But then, they were mostly sales of inexpensive wines; now they are sales of wines of higher quality.
"California is in a great spot," he said. "We have had five excellent vintages in a row, from 1990 through 1994, which is a lot more than anyone in Europe can say. They've had a string of poor years.
"What's more, we've got all that good wine in the barrel. There are a lot of happy wine makers around the state right now."
Overall consumption last year was dragged down by an 18 percent drop in shipments of wine coolers and an 8 percent drop in "all others," he said, a category that includes domestic and imported fortified wines like sherry.
Mr. Fredrikson's figures are not final; the California results were based on figures from 10 months; the results for wines from all over the United States were based on figures from eight months. Import results were based on figures for the first nine months of the year. Final figures in both categories will be available within four months.
One of the surprises of the new figures was the strong showing of bag-in-the-box wines. Three-liter boxes were ahead 50 percent and five liter boxes were ahead 61 percent over 1993 in supermarket sales. Gallo, which uses the name Peter Vella for its bag-in-the-box wines, and Franzia are the leaders in this category. A five-liter "box" holds the equivalent of 6.7 regular 750 milliliter wine bottles. The box can be stored in a refrigerator and poured through a built-in spigot.
Mr. Fredrikson noted that the drop-off in wine coolers was largely technical. "It's true that they are only at a fifth of what they were at their peak in 1987, but there are still plenty of cooler sales being made," he said. "Gallo sold 14.5 million cases of 24 bottles of coolers last year. But they were malt based, not wine. So they don't show up in the wine figures. Gallo is in the brewing business now, along with everything else."
Imported wine shipments, which were off 9 percent in 1993, showed an 11 percent increase last year, Mr. Fredrikson said. "It's a sign of our improving economy," he continued. "Why else would French Champagne be up 11 percent?"
The wine industry was battered in the 1980's by social and health concerns. A heightened awareness of the problem of drunk driving along with a nationwide emphasis on the benefits of physical fitness served to cut deeply into wine's image as a beverage of moderation.
"Those concerns remain," Mr. Fredrikson said, "but things seem to have balanced out somewhat."

TASTINGS
Ridge Vineyards Merlot, Santa Cruz Mountains, 1991; about $24.
 
Merlot is the grape -- and the wine -- of the moment. It is the second most important grape in the Medoc, and in most years the only grape in the fabled wine of Chateau Petrus. But neither fact explains the extraordinary popularity of the California version. Could it be that people are bored with cabernet? Ridge Vineyards, in the mountains south of San Francisco, has been growing merlot since the 1960's and selling it as a varietal since 1974. This version includes 20 percent cabernet sauvignon and displays typical Ridge Vineyards intensity. It spent 17 months in American oak barrels, was bottled in May 1993 and was released in January. It is usually softer and rounder than cabernet sauvignon, and goes with any meal that calls for a rich red wine.

LENGTH: 529 words

HEADLINE: New Look at a Mexican Murder

 BODY:
President Ernesto Zedillo, already reeling from the consequences of two inherited crises -- an overvalued peso and the armed conflict with peasant rebels in Chiapas -- has courageously taken on a third, the unsolved assassination of Luis Donaldo Colosio. Mr. Colosio was the front-running presidential candidate when he was shot at a campaign rally last March. Mr. Zedillo, his campaign manager, was chosen by the ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI, to take his place.
The new investigation is not yet complete. But it has already brought two new arrests and some preliminary findings by the new Attorney General, Antonio Lozano Gracia, a temperate lawyer chosen by Mr. Zedillo from the conservative opposition. Mr. Lozano contends that the man imprisoned as the gunman could not have acted alone. Instead, he points to a conspiracy that allegedly reaches into the ranks of the ruling party and involves employees of the private security firm hired to protect Mr. Colosio. The Attorney General also finds that previous investigators during the presidency of Carlos Salinas de Gortari ignored critical evidence and deliberately manipulated the crime scene. 
 Mr. Zedillo's administration now stands poised to break Mexico's biggest and most dangerous taboo by ferreting out the murderous connections between corrupt politicians and drug lords. These shadowy alliances are the biggest obstacle to reform and democracy in Mexico. Fighting them may be unsettling to foreign investors, but is unavoidable if reform is to succeed.
Politics and drugs are believed to be behind the killings not only of Mr. Colosio, but of the PRI's reform-minded Secretary General, Jose Francisco Ruiz Massieu, last September and a Roman Catholic Cardinal, Juan Jesus Posadas Ocampo, in 1993. Yesterday a brother of former President Salinas was arrested in connection with the Ruiz Massieu murder.
Mr. Colosio, like Mr. Zedillo and President Salinas, came from the reform wing of the PRI, committed to free markets and less fraudulent elections. Mr. Colosio pushed the party to acknowledge its 1989 defeat in the state of Baja California Norte. The state capital is Tijuana, the city where Mr. Colosio was subsequently killed.
The investigations of the Colosio killing during Mr. Salinas's term lacked credibility. Although the victim was shot from two directions, full blame was placed on a single deranged gunman. Videotaped evidence showing suspicious movements by others in the crowd was not pursued. Mr. Lozano reports that critical evidence was tampered with.
Mr. Lozano's investigation has not yet solved the crime. But its spectacular findings would seem to make any further cover-up all but impossible.
Mr. Zedillo has been unfairly caricatured as a timid technocrat. By taking up this challenge, he demonstrates his commitment to political as well as economic reform. Although at odds with much of his party, he can count on support from reformers in both main opposition parties. He should also be able to count on the strongest possible backing from the United States, which has a great deal to gain if he succeeds and a great deal to lose if he fails.

HEADLINE: New Round of Base Closings Hits 34,200 Civilian Jobs

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28

 BODY:
In what may be the last round of military base closings, the Defense Department said today that about 34,200 civilians would lose their jobs as it shuts down 33 big installations and shrinks or consolidates 86 smaller sites.
Although Defense Secretary William J. Perry said this year's list is smaller than once expected, most legislators predictably howled in anger over the choices -- none louder than Senators Alfonse M. D'Amato and Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York. 
 To protest what they consider the improper injection of politics into the issue, Mr. D'Amato, a Republican, and Mr. Moynihan, a Democrat, moved to hold up the confirmation of seven of the eight members of the Presidential commission that oversees the closings.
Yet the two Senators were protesting cuts that were announced in 1993, not the current round made public today. "The main thing is, New York was not treated fairly" in 1993, said Kevin Sheekey, a spokesman for Senator Moynihan. "And those wounds have not healed, and they may never heal."
The latest round of closings will eliminate 4,650 military and civilian jobs in the New York area and could cost the region more than $300 million in lost wages, contracts and other benefits.
With the end of the cold war and sharp cuts in Pentagon spending, the Clinton Administration has slashed billions of dollars in overhead costs from the armed forces to pay for training and new weapons. But Mr. Perry said this year's round was scaled back because of the steep expenses that are incurred in closing a base and doing related tasks like environmental cleanup.
Indeed, the Secretary directed that for this year's round the armed forces identify installations that had lower closing costs and yielded faster paybacks. As a result, once the Pentagon pays to close and clean up all the bases in this round as well as the ones in 1988, 1991 and 1993, it expects to save $6 billion a year starting in about 2001.
"This has been a painful process for D.O.D. and for the communities involved, but it's necessary to close unneeded infrastructure," Mr. Perry said. In addition to the closings and reductions, the list announced today includes dozens of adjustments at installations involved in earlier rounds of closings.
This is the last scheduled round of base closings, although Mr. Perry said he would probably ask Congress this year to approve another round for three or four years from now.
Some lawmakers said the Pentagon had not gone far enough in this year's recommendations. Representative John A. Boehner of Ohio, the chairman of the House Republican Caucus, said on Monday that the Clinton Administration apparently was satisfied to keep more military overhead than it needs.
"We still have a tremendous number of bases in our country that are no longer necessary or needed for national security," said Mr. Boehner, whose district is next to Wright-Patterson Air Force Base, which will gain 2,500 positions from two bases that are closing. "As painful as it is for the communities in which those bases are located, we ought to bite the bullet."
But the Pentagon plan has provoked uproar in states and Congressional districts where bases are shutting or shrinking, moves that will unleash economic turmoil that will certainly last for years.
The states with the highest loss of military and civilian jobs would be Texas with 6,981, New Mexico with 5,138, Alabama with 4,946 and Pennsylvania with 3,600. California, a strategically important state in the 1996 Presidential campaign, would lose several thousand civilian jobs at the Long Beach Naval Shipyard.
"Texans have a long tradition of not giving up our military installations without a fight," said Senator Kay Bailey Hutchison, Republican of Texas.
Mr. Perry and Deputy Defense Secretary John M. Deutch acknowledged today that they had had "hundreds of conversations" in recent months with lawmakers, community officials and senior White House aides about the process. But they said politics did not play any role in the final selections.
Senior military officials said that while they received no explicit instructions to put a base on or take one off, the body language from senior Pentagon civilians was clear. "We put bases on and off the list depending on what we thought they wanted upstairs," one Army official said.
Mr. Sheekey said that both Senator Moynihan and Senator D'Amato were still upset about closings in 1993, when the Defense Base Closure and Realignment Commission ignored the recommendations of the Defense Department, which wanted to close McGuire Air Force Base in New Jersey and move the jobs to Plattsburg Air Force Base in New York. Instead the commission, then under the chairmanship of former Representative Jim Courter of New Jersey, closed the New York base and moved the jobs to New Jersey.
As a result, the new head of that commission -- and for now its only member, former Illinois Senator Alan J. Dixon -- will probably be sitting alone on Wednesday as he opens hearings on the latest recommendations.
Mr. Sheekey said late in the day that Mr. Moynihan had released his "hold" on the nominations, saying he had made his point and held up the nominations until it would be too late for the Senate to vote on them before the commission meeting.
Wade Nelson, a commission spokesman, said Mr. Dixon fully expected to appear solo at the hearing.
For most members of Congress, the outrage over the closings is partly political theater. The difficult decisions are supposed to be made by the Presidential commission, which was set up to insulate Congress from angry constituents.

HEADLINE: U.S. Says Colombia Refuses To Cooperate in Drug War

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 1

 BODY:
The Administration severely criticized the Government of Colombia today, calling it "the world's primary cocaine production center" and saying it was not doing enough to crack down on the drug trade. But the Administration stopped short of cutting off economic aid.
In its annual drug report, the State Department accused Colombia of prosecuting few traffickers, giving light prison sentences and having no laws against money laundering. 
 The State Department removed Colombia from its list of countries that cooperate in fighting drug trafficking, saying, "Weak legislation, corruption and inefficency hampered efforts to bring mid- and high-level narcotics traffickers to justice."
Colombia criticized the report, saying, "It does not acknowledge the magnitude of the effort our country has made in the struggle against drug trafficking, at a high cost in human life and economic resources."
The Colombian Government said that it was considering rejecting the $16 million it receives every year from the United States to fight drug trafficking, Reuters reported. The agency qoted the Interior Minister, Horacio Serpa, as saying the aid was minimal in view of the $1 billion he said Colombia spends each year to fight the drug trade.
By law, if the State Department finds that a country is not cooperating on narcotics matters, it must cut off foreign aid and veto loans by the World Bank and other international institutions, unless it determines that there are "vital national interests" to continue such aid.
Despite Colombia's lack of cooperation, the State Department invoked the "vital national interests" clause. But the Republican staff of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee is urging Congress to overturn the decision and end aid.
In its report, the State Department said Afghanistan, Iran, Myanmar, Nigeria and Syria continued not to cooperate on drug matters and would receive no American aid. Saying opium production in Afghanistan rose 39 percent last year, the report removed that country from the list of nations receiving waivers.
Robert S. Gelbard, the Assistant Secretary of State for international narcotics and law enforcement, said the State Department believed that continued engagement was the best way to get Colombia to do more to combat drug trafficking.
"It is the most critical country in terms of the President's Western Hemisphere drug strategy," Mr. Gelbard said. "We want to continue to try to develop further bilateral cooperation."
But he adopted a much harsher tone toward Colombia than he did last year, saying at a news briefing: "We are seriously concerned about the fact that there were no major drug prosecutions in Colombia."
He also said there was widespread corruption among Colombia's law enforcement authorities and cited a 13 percent increase in coca production in Colombia last year.
Mr. Gelbard had a few encouraging words for some actions by Colombia, among them setting up a commission to review prison sentences and talking with Washington about enacting laws on money laundering.
The State Department condemned Myanmar, formerly Burma, which it said produced more than half of the world's heroin. It also accused Nigeria, which was added to the list of non-cooperating nations last year, of having "courier organizations that span the globe."
Bolivia, Lebanon, Pakistan, Paraguay and Peru were also found not to be cooperating but, like Colombia, they were given national interest waivers, partly because the United States does not want to sour relations with them.

HEADLINE: I.M.F. Loan Is Expected for Ukraine

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS 

 BODY:
In a development that could have important implications for economic change in neighboring Russia, Ukraine is expected to borrow close to $1.5 billion from the International Monetary Fund later this month.
Ukraine's representative at the I.M.F. in Washington, Oleh Havrylyshyn, and Anders Aslund, a Swedish economic adviser to President Leonid Kuchma of Ukraine, confirmed in separate interviews yesterday that the Ukranian Government would sign a letter this week accepting the I.M.F.'s terms for the loan, which would be by far the largest the institution has given to any country of the former Soviet Union. Ukraine has 52 million people. 
 The confirmations came after Mr. Kuchma announced yesterday the resignation of Prime Minister Vitaly Masol, a holdover from the Soviet era, and replaced him with First Deputy Prime Minister Yevhen Marchuk, who is widely considered to be more sympathetic to the President's efforts to create a free-enterprise economy in Ukraine.
"This is the beginning of a big surge forward in Ukraine," Mr. Havrylyshyn said.
Mr. Aslund, who said the I.M.F.'s executive board was likely to give formal approval to the loan later this month, described it as "a stamp of international approval for Ukraine's effort to transform its economy."
He added that Ukraine had already privatized 11,000 state-owned enterprises and planned to sell an additional 8,000 large and medium-sized companies this year. He said it had also cut its inflation rate from 10,200 percent in 1993 to about 1 percent a month and had reduced the budget deficit to the equivalent of 5 percent of the economy's output.
In a further show of support for Mr. Kuchma and his economic policies, the I.M.F.'s managing director, Michel Camdessus, will visit Kiev, the capital, next week, officials said.
The immediate purpose of the new I.M.F. credit is to help Ukraine gather about $6 billion in foreign economic assistance this year to finance economic development.
Mr. Aslund said he hoped to raise the rest of the money by persuading Russia to reschedule $2.5 billion in Ukrainian debts that come due this year for imports of oil and natural gas and to get money from the World Bank, the United States, Western Europe and Japan.
But he warned that Ukraine's success in borrowing from the I.M.F. might make Russia -- which is still negotiating for a much larger $6.5 billion I.M.F. credit -- reluctant to reschedule the debts that Ukraine owes it. "The Russians will ask why they should help Ukraine when they are not getting I.M.F. help but Ukraine is," he said.
Mr. Aslund also criticized the Europeans for slowness in assisting Ukraine, saying that although Germany and the Netherlands were sympathetic, France, Italy and Spain were more interested in aiding Algeria and other Arab countries of North Africa in a struggle against Islamic fundamentalism.
However, I.M.F. officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said they were reasonably confident that they could successfully conclude their loan negotiations with the Russians within the next few weeks, so that both Russia and Ukraine would get their assistance at about the same time.
Mr. Camdessus has already made tentative plans to visit Moscow at the end of the month in anticipation of such an agreement, these officials said.
These officials and some private experts also suggest that granting Ukraine its loan now will put extra pressure on Russian ministries to compromise and accept the I.M.F.'s terms. The big stumbling block, they say, is the reluctance of the Ministries of Finance and Foreign Economic Relations to surrender their control over Russian oil exports, as the I.M.F. is demanding.
"When other branches of the Russian Government see Ukraine is getting I.M.F. money, they will put extra pressure on them to stop blocking the deal," said Donald Green, a Russian expert with Plan Econ, a Washington economic consulting concern that specializes in the former Communist world.
In fact, Mr Green said, the I.M.F. is already effectively helping Russia by lending to Ukraine and some other parts of the former Soviet Union because these countries spend much of the money buying oil, gas and other raw materials from Russia.

HEADLINE: Indians Offer Part of Profit From Casino

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ALBANY, March 1

 BODY:
As they unveiled a plan to build a casino 90 miles from New York City, leaders of the Oneida Indian Nation said today that they would discuss giving New York State a share of their profits in exchange for Gov. George E. Pataki's approval.
Mr. Pataki, who wields virtual veto power over such proposals, has said he opposes the plan to build a casino at Monticello Raceway in the Catskill Mountains of Sullivan County, and his aides reiterated his opposition today. Republican legislators close to the Governor said they would try to block the plan, arguing that it would enrich the Oneidas but not the state or taxpayers. 
 But at a news conference at the racetrack today, Oneida leaders and their business partners marshaled more than 100 local business owners to endorse the idea as a potential economic boon and to urge Mr. Pataki to honor campaign vows to help their financially strapped region.
"Governor, we're in dire straits," said Chris Ehrlich, an official of the Pines Hotel and a member of the Catskills Resort Association, a trade group. "When the members of the Catskills Association met with you last year, you made a promise to try to help us."
Raymond Halbritter, the Oneidas' elected representative, said the tribe wanted to build a casino with a 100,000- to 150,000-square-foot gambling area on the grounds of the racetrack. The 1,100-member tribe already operates a smaller casino, Turning Stone, in Verona, about 35 miles east of Syracuse.
Under an agreement the tribe has with Watermark Investments, a Bahamian bank that is seeking to buy the racetrack, the Oneidas would invest $5 million to refurbish the track if the casino plan is approved. Mr. Halbritter also said the tribe would pay $2.5 million a year for 10 years into a Sullivan County fund for economic development.
And if the state does not legalize gambling outside Indian lands, he said the tribe would pay $2.5 million a year to Sullivan County's treasury for as long as the casino operates.
Mr. Halbritter said the Oneidas would not build hotels at the racetrack or sell tax-free cigarettes and gasoline in bulk, as is done on many Indian reservations, to avoid competing with Catskill businesses.
Asked how much of their profit the tribe would be willing to give to the state in exchange for approvals, he said, "That's up for discussion."
In Connecticut, the Mashantucket Pequot tribe agreed to pay the state at least $100 million a year from its Foxwoods Casino in Ledyard in exchange for a monopoly on operating slot machines in Connecticut.
Under Federal law, the Oneidas can run a casino on tribal lands, but the raceway is more than 100 miles south of their lands. However, the law does allow tribes to run casinos elsewhere if the Federal Department of the Interior and the Governor approve.
Casino gambling outside Indian reservations is prohibited by the State Constitution. However, there are efforts underway in the Legislature to legalize casino gambling, which would require approval by two consecutively elected Legislatures and by voters in a referendum.
Mr. Pataki has not publicly endorsed casino gambling but has said he would support the initial passage of a constitutional amendment so the state could study the idea. He has said he opposes the proliferation of Indian casinos because Indian businesses and land are not subject to corporate, sales and property taxes.
"We want to be sure that if casino gambling is instituted, we want the owners to pay property taxes, sales taxes and incomes taxes," said his spokeswoman, Zenia Mucha.
Supporters of legalized gambling attacked the Oneidas' plan, calling the proposal to give Sullivan County $2.5 million a year "insulting" and warning that the tribe would use gambling profits to fight the spread of casinos outside reservations.
"Why cut a deal with the Indians in Sullivan County at the expense of Niagara Falls and Lake George and so many other areas of the state that might want casinos?" said State Senator Nicholas A. Spano, a Yonkers Republican.
The Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, Republican of Rensselaer County, denounced the plan, saying, "I don't think it's in the public's best interest to have the Indians all becoming multimillionaires within the state's borders when the state receives practically no revenue."
But Catskill business owners and officials who support the Oneida proposal said their hardscrabble region can't wait the three years or more it will take to legalize casino gambling.
"This is New York's best chance to stem the flow of money that is going out to New Jersey and Connecticut now," said Andrew Boyer, chairman of the Sullivan County Board of Supervisors.
