HEADLINE: Fall in Auto Sales Raises New Fears of Slowdown

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DETROIT, March 1

 BODY:
Sales of cars and light trucks fell in February, in contrast to a robust period a year ago, according to company sales reports released today and estimates by analysts.
The results were below the expectations of Wall Street analysts, heightening fears of an economic slowdown and sending auto stocks falling on the New York Stock Exchange. 
 Taken individually, the sales reports varied widely. At the Chrysler Corporation, sales of light trucks, including mini-vans and sport utility vehicles, plunged, while car sales increased; at the General Motors Corporation, light-truck sales climbed, while car sales took a nose dive. Sales dropped over all at Honda, but rose at Toyota.
Because of such confusing signals, which began to appear in January, monthly vehicle sales have become a kind of economic Rorschach test, revealing perhaps more about the biases of those who interpret them than about the actual demand.
Some auto industry analysts, citing production cuts and rising rebates together with the slower sales, said they saw the beginning of the end of the economic expansion. That view appeared to prevail among investors today, as auto stock prices, already at roughly two-thirds their 52-week highs of a year ago, fell further.
In a generally weak stock market, shares of Chrysler, the second-most active on the New York Stock Exchange, fell $2, to $41.375, a 52-week low. Shares of G.M. fell $2.125, to $40.50, and shares of the Ford Motor Company fell 50 cents, to $25.625.
In the optimists' camp, auto executives and many auto stock analysts argue that sales are slowing because the Federal Reserve has safely brought the economy to a so-called soft landing by raising short-term interest rates. They say that is good news for the industry, portending years of gradual growth rather than the traditional boom and bust. They point to rising incomes as a sign that the fundamentals of the expansion remain in place.
"The U.S. economy is in a sound state," Helmut Panke, chief executive of BMW North America, said today. He predicted moderate growth in vehicle sales this year of 3 percent to 4 percent from unit sales of 15.1 million last year.
Regardless of which view of the market proves to be correct, the slowing of sales is surely good news for vehicle buyers. "We're seeing a shift from it being a seller's market in 1994 to being a buyer's market in 1995," said David M. Garrity, auto analyst with Smith Barney in New York. As sales soften and inventories rise, rebates are rising as well, offsetting the effect of higher interest rates.
A year ago sales rose almost 20 percent from February 1993, outstripping the industry's projections and emptying dealers' inventories. Sales reached an annualized rate of 15.4 million cars and light trucks, higher than the actual results for the year.
By contrast, this February dealers sold vehicles at an annual rate of 14.8 million, according to an estimate by Ward's Automotive Reports. In January the rate was 14.9 million. "It puts auto sales on a path consistent with the sluggishness in home sales," Mr. Garrity said.
The complete sales reports were not available. In February most auto companies began reporting monthly sales on the first business day of the subsequent month. But some auto makers -- most notably Ford -- continue to report on the third business day.
Ward's bases its estimates on production schedules, past market shares and other company information.
Among the most startling results for February was the poor performance of Chrysler's light trucks, which had been setting sales records. Chrysler's light-truck sales fell 15 percent, to 95,214. Sales of the maker's sport utility vehicles fell 14 percent, to 29,138, while sales of Chrysler mini-vans fell by almost a third, to 31,867.
Chrysler said that without Ford's sales report, it could not determine the reason for the drop in sales of its sport utility vehicles. "Without a better industry picture, it's hard to say," said Jim Crawford, a spokesman for Chrysler. But the company attributed the weak sales of its mini-vans partly to the incentives that Ford had placed on its Windstar mini-vans.
Last week Chrysler responded to the marketing move by Ford with increased rebates on its mini-vans, which dealers said had given sales a jump-start.
But Ford has again upped the ante, announcing today a rebate program called "Chrysler Conquest." On top of other, enriched rebates, people who own or lease a Chrysler mini-van can receive $750 cash if they buy or lease a Ford Windstar, Ford Aerostar or Mercury Villager.
At G.M., total vehicle sales fell 8.9 percent, to 365,103. While truck sales rose 2.3 percent, car sales plunged 15.5 percent, in a drop that G.M. attributed partly to a cutback in its sales to fleet customers. Oldsmobile, for example, said its retail sales increased, but a drop in its less profitable fleet sales produced an overall decline in sales of 26.2 percent.
A bright spot for G.M. continued to be Saturn. Sales of its small cars rose 14.3 percent, to 19,275, setting a record for the 12th consecutive month.
Chrysler reported that its total sales fell 6 percent, to 166,572. Sales at Honda fell 10.0 percent, to 50,847, while sales at Toyota rose 5.8 percent, to 74,020. Mazda reported that its sales fell 11.2 percent, to 22,592.

HEADLINE: Thou Shalt Not Traffic in the Demon Gossip;
In a World of Envy and Talk Show Values, a Pacifist Sect Takes a Higher, Harder Way

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: RIFTON, N.Y.

 BODY:
The rest of America may be feeding on modern gossip as an industrial-size staple of the gross national product, but not Christoph Arnold and his fellow Christian pacifists, who live quietly as the Hutterian Brethren here on the banks of the Wallkill River.
"It would tear us to pieces," Mr. Arnold said. 
 The brethren define gossip, demon gossip, as a sin, even as much of the nation seems to wallow in all its electronic and printed titillations.
Humble in attitude, Amishlike in dress, open-handed in greeting visitors, the Rifton Hutterites dedicate themselves to uprooting uncharitable gossiping, backbiting and petty calumnies in their common life with a commitment that could make Geraldo blush.
"That's a no-no, big time," said Ian Winter, one of the brethren who once resisted the group's anti-gossip rule and had to withdraw into solitude until he worked up the courage to confess and apologize before his neighbors and gossip victims.
Other Hutterite tenets sound far more dramatic and rocklike as members stand opposed to abortion and capital punishment, to war and homosexuality, and demand lifetime commitment to marriage and the brethren community. But it is the fight against unneighborly jealousies and social hypocrisies, the childlike urge to tattle and connive, that members smilingly admit to as the true daily cross.
"Each of us is his own main problem," said Art Wiser, 74, who joined the Hutterites 40 years ago, after his experience as a conscientious objector in World War II left him searching for a more honest and fulfilling life.
Mr. Arnold, 55, the brethren's elder, recited the sorry stuff of the Hutterites' struggle. "Selfishness, greed, ego, anger, jealousy," he said amid the serenity of the brotherhood's 190-acre compound here in the Hudson Valley north of New Paltz. "We do fall into gossip, and we must recognize this is wrong."
The Rifton Hutterites, a modern variant of a branch of Anabaptists dating to the 16th century, began flourishing in America in the 1950's after being exiled as pacifists from Nazi Germany. More socially curious and venturesome than Old Order Amish and other related religious groups, the brethren have grown from fewer than 100 pioneer members to 2,000 members in six American communities.
As they have taken root, they have sought to follow their signature stricture, known as the first law of Sannerz, enunciated in 1920 by the branch's founder, Eberhard Arnold, grandfather of Christoph: "There must never be talk, either in open remarks or in insinuation, against a brother or a sister, against their individual characteristics -- under no circumstances behind the person's back. Talking in one's own family is no exception."
That rule might turn an average gathering at the office water cooler into one of the infernal rings of Dante, particularly when coupled with Eberhard's prescription that the sinner must candidly confront his or her gossip victim "whose weaknesses cause a negative reaction in us."
"That's the problem wherever there's human flesh," Christoph Arnold, the lean, bearded elder insisted, smiling gently at his group's near-satirical contrast with so much of surrounding America.
"I know, Marcia Clark and the bloody gloves," he said, laughing at one symptom of the buzzing circus of prurience and folly that he hears circling the brethren, not far beyond the sanctuary's wood line. "A few of us have radios, so we know about the O.J. trial."
He said the brethren are modern enough to feel a need to compose their own news summaries, read occasionally at the noontime common meal.
The Hutterites are a disarming mix of homespun and high tech. Owning all resources in common, they are self-supporting through a chain of computerized factories that produce high-quality children's toys and furniture for the handicapped, using members' own designs, tooling and labor and a global mail-order and phone system. The men dress in black peasant work clothes, the women in modest kerchiefs and aprons. But they reject the full horse-and-buggy austerity of the Amish and have a small common motor pool of cars and even their own Gulfstream charter airplane for missionary work in Nigeria.
Hardly withdrawn, they like outsiders to visit and even stake them to free meals or an overnight stay. The dedication to family is obvious among the 350 residents here, but they spare visitors lectures on family values. Far from proselytizing, they go to protest marches against war, the death penalty, urban violence and racial injustice, but carefully distance themselves from the self-righteousness that they find in the political agenda of some other modern Christian fundamentalists.
"That's where we part company with the religious right," Mr. Wiser said. "We are concerned when somebody takes us into politics and tries to push other people around. That's coercion, force."
In short, the Hutterian Brethren heed a different drummer, and never more so than in targeting gossip. Mr. Wiser, the community's archivist, told of one sister who became increasingly involved in creative writing, to the point of wanting to reprogram the brethren's word processing system for her convenience.
"I began thinking about it and spoke to my wife, Mary, and put a whole negative twist to it," he confessed, smiling sheepishly. "We both instantly realized I had to go to the woman and her husband and tell them."
Rather than citing fear of some divine retribution as motive for this heroic behavior, the Hutterites say their way is based on a simple fact, proven daily, that an open word spoken directly to the other person deepens friendship and is not resented.
"Admonishments come with love here," said Ruben Ayala, a 42-year-old convert to the life of common prayer, hard work, simple meals and charity. He visited Rifton and stayed to marry a Hutterite woman after being impressed by brethren at the Bowery Mission in Manhattan, where he worked as a recovering drug addict and ex-convict. "There's no grudges here."
Hutterites smiled at a visitor's observation that such saintly candor could be an awfully risky business in the outside world.
"Well, it's no Utopia here," Mr. Arnold took care to emphasize.
Mr. Winter felt compelled to look him in the eye and add, "But we do have fun living, you know."

HEADLINE: Blue-Chip Stocks Falter On Fear of Lower Profits

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Blue-chip stocks fell yesterday and the Dow Jones industrial average again slipped below the 4,000-point level, hurt by concerns that slower economic growth this year will translate into weaker corporate profits.
Declines in shares of the Chrysler Corporation, Caterpillar Inc., the International Paper Company, the Aluminum Company of America and other so-called cyclical companies, whose performance is closely tied to swings in economic growth, drove the market down, overshadowing a second day of gains in technology issues. 
 "It's late in the earnings cycle, and when earnings momentum peaks, you usually see that reflected in the stock market," said Edward Goldfarb, head of portfolio strategy at Aeltus Investment Management in Hartford.
The Dow closed down 16.25 points, at 3,994.80, after falling as much as 25.94 points. The broader Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks declined 1.74 points, to 485.65. And despite gains in technology stocks, the Nasdaq composite index dropped 1.86 points, to 791.87.
The retreat in the blue chips was led by shares of the General Motors Corporation, which reported a sharp decline in car sales. Its stock fell 2 1/8 a share, to 40 1/2. Chrysler, which said sales of light trucks plunged in the month, fell 2 a share, to 41 3/8. The Ford Motor Company, which did not release February sales figures yesterday, eased 1/2, to 25 5/8 a share. Ford said yesterday that it was offering Chrysler owners a $750 rebate on Ford's own mini-vans for two months in an attempt to increase its market share in the segment.
International Paper shares slumped 1 1/8, to 75 1/4. Paper stocks reacted to concern about weaker earnings at the Weyerhaeuser Company and added capacity at an Abitibi-Price Inc. plant in Thunder Bay, Ontario. Weyerhaeuser fell 1 1/4 a share, to 39 1/2.
Alcoa shares dropped 1, to 38. Goldman, Sachs & Company downgraded investment ratings on six metal and mining stocks today, among them Alcoa, Alumax Inc., Falconbridge Ltd., Inco Ltd., the Magma Copper Company and the Phelps Dodge Corporation.
Caterpillar shares fell 1 3/8, to 50 1/4, after Smith Barney downgraded the maker of heavy construction equipment to "outperform" from "buy."
The Maxus Energy Corporation, the most active stock, with almost 22 million shares changing hands, was unchanged at 5 1/2 a share after jumping 1 3/4 late on Tuesday in response to a $740 million takeover offer from YPF S.A. of Argentina. American depository receipts for shares of YPF slumped 1 5/8, to 17 3/8.
Trading volume on the New York Stock Exchange totaled 362.6 million shares, up from 317.6 million on Tuesday and above this year's daily average of 329.7 million. Declining issues outnumbered advancers, 1,254 to 1,010.
A number of technology stocks gained for a second day, led by Texas Instruments Inc., which climbed 2 1/4 a share, to 81. The semiconductor maker predicted the worldwide market for computer chips would grow 21 percent, to $124 billion, in 1995.
The Hewlett-Packard Company surged 2 a share, to 117; the Computer Sciences Corporation added 5/8, to 49 3/4; Micron Technology Inc. jumped 2 7/8, to 64 7/8; the LSI Logic Corporation rose 7/8, to 55 3/8; Xilinx Inc. rose 3/8, to 67 1/4, and the Cypress Semiconductor Corporation rose 1 1/4, to 29 5/8.
Many investors "think technology has led us through this whole big rally, and think it will continue," said Anthony Conroy, director of equity trading at BT Global Asset Management, a division of Bankers Trust New York.

HEADLINE: Salinas Blames Successor for Peso Crisis

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, March 1

 BODY:
Speaking publicly for the first time about the nation's severe economic crisis that many Mexicans believe he caused, former President Carlos Salinas de Gortari has tried to shift blame to his successor, contending that President Ernesto Zedillo bungled the peso's devaluation in December a few weeks after taking office.
In a telephone call on Tuesday afternoon to a national television news program, "24 Hours," Mr. Salinas said the decisions by President Zedillo and his administration had cost Mexico billions of dollars "in a single day" and led directly to the financial turmoil that now engulfs the country. 
 Mr. Salinas was referring to a decision by the Zedillo administration on Dec. 20 to devalue the peso 15 percent, after Government finance officials conceded to the nation's top bankers and businessmen that Mexico could no longer support a fixed exchange rate. The officials made the remarks at a meeting in which they discussed Mexico's currency problems.
Elaborating on his accusations in a subsequent telephone interview, Mr. Salinas said that Mr. Zedillo's financial team, by disclosing their intentions, caused investors who received the information to withdraw nearly $13 billion within a day, draining Mexico's shrinking international reserves and forcing the Government to float the peso on Dec. 21. Some analysts here and in New York believe the amount actually withdrawn was far less, a little more than $3 billion.
The Finance Minister at the time, Jaime Serra Puche, resigned the following week. The new Finance Minister Guillermo Ortiz, rebutted Mr. Salinas's contentions in an appearance today before the Mexican Congress. Mr. Ortiz said the roots of the crisis went back well before Dec. 1, when Mr. Zedillo replaced Mr. Salinas as President.
However, senior officials of Mr. Zedillo's own Government have said privately that its handling of the devaluation was, in the words of one of them, "the worst mistake made by the government in years."
Mr. Salinas's criticism of Mr. Zedillo was made just hours after the former President's older brother, Raul Salinas, had been arrested on charges of arranging the assassination of an important Mexican politician in September. The charges by Mr. Salinas were seen here as not just an attempt to defend his own administration's economic policies but also as evidence of a split between himself and his chosen successor, Mr. Zedillo, who has vowed to pursue the assassination investigation no matter where it leads.
Raul Salinas was arrested on Tuesday afternoon on charges of ordering the assassination Sept. 28 of Jose Francisco Ruiz Massieu, the secretary general of the Institutional Revolutionary Party, which has been in power for almost 66 years. Carlos Salinas has not been implicated in the killing.
But with his own reputation tarnished by the economic and now personal setbacks at home, the former President today withdrew his candidacy to head the World Trade Organization, a move that had been widely expected.
"In recent days I made it known that I had chosen to withdraw my candidacy for the directorship" of the newly created trade organization, Mr. Salinas said in a statement. "Today I am making it formal."
 The political fallout from Raul Salinas's arrest helped push down the Mexican stock exchange, which lost a little more than 2 percent to close at just under 1,518 today.
However, the peso was almost unchanged, closing at 5.945 to the dollar. Interest rates on 28-day treasury certificates fell 9.3 percentage points, to 49.7 percent, suggesting some modest relief from Mexico's soaring interest rates.
Interviews with several Government officials and statements by the Bank of Mexico indicate that the Zedillo administration was persuaded by the nation's business leaders and bankers to drop its original plan to let the peso float freely and instead simply to adjust its rate downward by 15 percent against the dollar.
Before this, the peso was worth nearly 29 cents. The devaluation on the first day of the crisis brought it to just above 25 cents. Today, the peso is worth less than 17 cents.
The Bank of Mexico, the central bank, acknowledged that the Government's Exchange Rate Commission decided on Dec. 19 that Mexico had no choice but to abandon a fixed exchange rate because its international reserves had dropped below $11 billion, which was considered insufficient to fight off an attack by currency speculators. The reserves have since been reinforced by an international rescue package that includes $20 billion in American loans and guarantees.
Members of Mr. Zedillo's Government confirmed that the businessmen opposed any floating exchange rate at the meeting on Dec 20.
"We went to them with the idea of a floating rate and they got absolutely scared," said one Government official, referring to the business leaders and bankers. "But eventually they convinced us that a free float wasn't the right way to go."
Once the Bank of Mexico had disclosed to the bankers and businessmen that it lacked sufficient reserves to protect the peso, many went out after the meeting to convert pesos into dollars. By the evening of Dec. 21, the Government Exchange Rate Commission was forced to let the peso float freely.
Many American investors have complained that the Mexican Government had either wittingly or unwittingly given Mexican investors inside information about currency reserves that allowed them to safeguard their positions before the peso's fixed exchange rate was abandoned. Mr. Salinas's remarks appear to corroborate their suspicions.
Luis R. Luis, head of research for Scudder, Stevens & Clark of Boston, said that so much money left Mexico in those two days of December that it "weakened the last hope the central bank had of having a fixed peso policy."
But Mr. Luis did not believe that the economic crisis, which has cost Mexico hundreds of thousands of jobs and lowered almost everyone's standard of living, was caused solely by the mistakes made in December.
"The seeds for the crisis," Mr. Luis said, "were planted much earlier."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Long Bonds Push a Rally For 2d Day

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The long end of the government securities market rallied yesterday for the second consecutive day, as new economic reports suggesting that growth was slowing and the threat of inflation was easing helped to keep the bullish sentiment intact.
In early trading all maturities came under pressure, as investors sold because of concerns that included a postponement of the Senate's vote on the balanced budget amendment and the weakness of the dollar in the currency markets, though it rebounded in the afternoon. 
 The price of the 30-year bond was up 2/32 , to 1026/32 , for a yield of 7.44 percent, unchanged from Tuesday. But bill rates were mixed, with a three-month issue down a basis point, to 5.73 percent.
Susan Hering, an economist with Salomon Brothers, said the Commerce Department's revision yesterday of the fourth-quarter gross domestic product, to 4.6 percent from 4.5 percent, was in line with the market's expectations and therefore had little impact. The Federal Reserve considers a growth rate of 2.5 percent to be acceptable without causing inflation to accelerate.
"Most of the data is several weeks old," she said. "And while the February National Association of Purchasing Management number had more of a visible effect on the market than the revised G.D.P., none of the numbers left a lasting impression."
The purchasing management association reported that manufacturing grew in February at a much slower rate than in the previous month, and fewer companies paid higher prices for raw materials.
"The N.A.P.M. data suggest that the manufacturing sector is moving from a hectic to healthy rate of growth," Ms. Hering said. Components like new orders and production both slowed measurably, and prices moderated a bit, but remained at higher levels.
Ms. Hering added that the market expected the Fed to raise short-term rates again, but not right away. For the remainder of the week, she said, traders will be studying the January new-home sales, which are scheduled to be released today, and the report on initial jobless claims. "If it continues to move up," as it has during the last few weeks, she said, "the market may conclude the economy is continuing to weaken."
Today the Treasury will auction $17.25 billion of new one-year notes; yesterday it auctioned $8 billion of nine-day cash management bills at an average rate of 5.81 percent. Cash management bills are used to meet the Treasury's short-term borrowing needs beyond the money raised through the Government's regularly scheduled auctions.
By late in the day the rate for an outstanding one-year bill was 6.03 percent, up a basis point from the previous day.
In the municipal bond market, yields fell as investors snapped up the $500 million bond offering by New York State. There has been a drought of new tax-exempt issues, with new sales down about 60 percent from this time last year, forcing investors to pay higher premiums for issues.
The New York State 10-year maturity general obligation debt was priced yesterday to yield 5.57 percent.
Lehman Brothers, the senior manager on the pricing yesterday, sold bonds to yield from 4.40 percent for an issue due in 1996, with a 5.50 percent coupon, to 6.05 percent for a bond due in 2014.
The bonds are rated A by Moody's Investors Service and A- by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Prudential's Capital Base Declined 11% Last Year

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Putting the final point on a horrible year, the Prudential Insurance Company of America said yesterday that losses in a number of businesses, primarily its securities and mortgage subsidiaries, caused its capital base to decline in 1994 by $1.2 billion, or 11 percent, to $9.5 billion.
Prudential, one of the world's largest financial services companies, also said that after dividends and taxes it lost $907 million last year, compared with net income of $645 million in 1993. 
 For all of 1994, the company said its revenues fell almost 5 percent, to $43.6 billion.
Because it is a mutual insurance company owned by policyholders, Prudential prefers to emphasize yearly changes in its capital position.
"Capital is the bottom line; it is the net worth of the company," said Gene O'Hara, Prudential's chief financial officer. "We are disappointed in this setback, but $9.5 billion in capital is still a very, very strong position."
By far the biggest contributor to what one analyst referred to as Prudential's "annus horriblis" was the drain on capital created by settlements related to improper and illegal sales of limited partnerships at Prudential Securities, the brokerage subsidiary.
To cover the costs of settling those claims, which relate to partnerships that date from the 1980's, Prudential incurred $1.4 billion in costs last year.
In its financial report, Prudential said that while Prudential Securities' continuing operations were profitable, the firm reported an after-tax loss of $811 million for 1994.
The sharp rise in interest rates that bedeviled many on Wall Street last year hit Prudential's residential mortgage business hard.
The three units that make up the Prudential Residential Services Company had 1994 after-tax losses of $119.1 million.
In addition, Prudential's property and casualty business was hit early in 1994 by the California earthquake and the severe winter storms in the Northeast, which generated more than $200 million in unanticipated losses, according to David A. Havens, an analyst at Standard & Poor's.
Because so many of Prudential's problems have been well documented, analysts had been expecting the company would report a big loss when it finally released its 1994 results.
As a consequence, the results released yesterday came as no surprise, they said.
"We knew it was going to be an ugly year," said Robert L. Riegel, an analyst at Moody's Investors Service. "These numbers are in line with what we thought would happen."
In a statement that accompanied the financial report, Arthur P. Ryan, who became Prudential's chairman and chief executive in December, said, "We faced up to substantial challenges in 1994, and we will be taking steps in 1995 to dramatically improve earnings and capital for this and subsequent years."
Larry Mayewski, a senior vice president at the A. M. Best Company, an insurance rating agency, said: "The loss of capital is very important. But looking forward, the key to Prudential will be its ability to rebound quickly, and bring its overall risk profile in line with its capital. That is a very significant challenge Mr. Ryan is facing."
In December, A. M. Best indicated that it might downgrade its rating on Prudential, placing it under review with negative implications.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Negotiating Teams Move To Night Round of Talks

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., March 1

 BODY:
For a sport that hasn't had a game for 202 days, baseball experienced a flurry of activity today. There were developments in several cities in two countries, but most attention was focused on possible developments in this city.
Nothing concrete was reported after a six-hour meeting between five-person negotiating teams at the golf club on Gainey Ranch, but from the comments made by the leaders for both sides, they seemed to be telegraphing grudging willingness to change what have been inflexible positions on the central economic issues. 
 Discussing the change in tone and effort, Donald Fehr, the union chief, attributed it to the fact that the season is approaching. "Hopefully," he said, "everybody wants to try and see if there's a deal that can be cut in time for that to happen in the ordinary course."
The negotiators were eager enough to find out that they decided to have another session, with even smaller groups, tonight.
"It's an indication that the parties believe there's some chance for a better dialogue in a smaller group," Fehr said of the meeting size, adding, "There's a mutual interest in continuing the discussions."
The negotiators, in effect, had a day-night doubleheader. In a night game in neighboring Tempe, the California Angels defeated the Arizona State University baseball team, 13-5, in the first spring training exhibition game, which also represented the first game using replacement players in major league uniforms. The first games between replacement teams are scheduled for Thursday in Florida.
In another development involving exhibition games, the Baltimore Orioles' first 12 games were officially canceled. The teams that were supposed to play the Orioles canceled them because the Orioles had said they would play the games only if those teams agreed not to use replacement players.
If the strike continues through the rest of spring training, the Orioles' other games also will be canceled.
"In essence, most teams plan not to play them and in essence they are canceled," Phyllis Merhige, an American League vice president, said by telephone from New York. "But we are taking them two weeks at a time. If there's a settlement, those games probably would be reinstated."
The Orioles' opponents acted at the direction of the commissioner's office and the operations committee, a 10-man unit that has been overseeing matters relating to the playing of the season without the striking players.
In a development related to the regular season, the Canadian Immigration Department also acted today, allowing the Expos to play games with replacement players in Montreal.
In exempting the Expos from a Canadian law that prohibits the use of foreign replacement workers during a work stoppage, the immigration department explained that the law is intended to protect Canadian workers from replacement by foreign workers. In the Expos' case, however, a spokeswoman said that the striking workers already were foreign nationals. The Expos, in seeking the exemption, argued that if the team couldn't play in Montreal, its Canadian employees would suffer.
Four of the teams that canceled games with the Orioles immediately scheduled games with other teams. The other teams will use split squads because they already had games scheduled for those days.
Other split-squad games have disappeared from the exhibition schedule. The American and National Leagues announced the cancellation of 12 split-squad games.
"Teams are worrying about the pitching more than anything," Merhige said. "We have been advised of some planned cancellations for the rest of the month, but it seemed counterproductive to cancel games that you might not have to cancel."
Some teams also could encounter problems with numbers of players generally. The union has made a concerted effort to induce minor leaguers not to play in exhibition games on the grounds that they would be considered strikebreakers.
Union officials held their third and final meeting tonight in Phoenix to explain their views to minor leaguers. Earlier in the day, the union's executive board voted to pay traveling expenses for minor leaguers who refuse to play and are sent home until the regular minor camps open later this month.
At the bargaining table, the players' and owners' representatives discussed in depth the issue of a payroll tax and revenue sharing among the clubs.
"We delved into the issues in a much deeper sense than we have before," Bud Selig, the acting commissioner, said. "We got right to the heart of the matter on a number of subjects."
Selig said it would not be accurate to say either side had changed its position significantly, but he added, "I do think that developing a better understanding could lead to that if we understand maybe to some degree what bothers them more on certain issues and they about us about some of the things they've done."
When Fehr was asked if the day session showed signs of a willingness to change, he hesitated, then said: "Yes, but the discussions were not being conducted in a way in which one could say all right, on this issue what's your range of flexibility, or on that issue. We're talking about things generally and there were, from time to time, some assumptions being thrown around."

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Concern on Japan Recovery Depresses Platinum Prices

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Platinum prices tumbled yesterday, hurt by concerns that the failure of Barings P.L.C. would hamper Japan's recovery. Silver and gold prices also fell sharply.
Japan's car and jewelry industries use large amounts of platinum and palladium. Silver, another industrial metal, followed those metals lower, analysts said. The collapse of Barings has helped to drag down stocks sharply in Tokyo, undermining investors' confidence in the Japanese recovery. 
 "Japan's expectations of an economic recovery have been defused a bit by the decline in their stock markets," said Bette Raptopoulos, a metals analyst with Prudential Securities Inc.
In other commodity activity, lumber prices steepened their slide while cotton and coffee futures rose sharply. The Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 commodities fell 0.78 point, to 233.47.
On the Commodity Exchange of New York, silver for May delivery fell 14.3 cents, to $4.422 an ounce. The April gold contract dropped $2.10, to $376.20 an ounce, after hitting a contract low of $374.50.
On the New York Mercantile Exchange, platinum for April delivery plummeted $7.90, to $403.70 a troy ounce, the lowest daily settlement for near-term deliveries since June 29. March palladium dropped $2.20, to $151.75 a troy ounce.
"Platinum is tied fundamentally to the Japanese demand situation," said David Rinehimer of Smith Barney Inc. "Certainly, there is a big question mark if the level of platinum demand in Japan can be maintained at last year's level."
Lumber prices steepened their slide on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange in reaction to Tuesday's report of a sharp decline in January sales of existing homes.
Spruce 2-by-4's for March delivery plunged $13.80, to $287.30 for 1,000 board feet.
Cotton futures roared to another record high on the New York Cotton Exchange, powered by speculative buying and signs of continued strong demand.
"From the point of view that high-quality U.S. cotton is the main reservoir of cotton now, the mills are just willing to bid up for it," said Walter Spilka, an analyst with Smith Barney Inc.
March cotton shot up 5.17 cents, to $1.1092 a pound.
Coffee rose sharply on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York on largely speculative buying. March coffee rose 5.35 cents, to $1.8635 a pound.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Supply-side recipe: restore Mexico's old exchange rate.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
WITH the wounded Mexican peso trading at roughly six to the dollar, why are influential Congressional Republicans still talking about a return to the pre-crisis exchange rate of 3.5 pesos to the dollar?
A plausible explanation is that the talk is a political freebie, a way to capitalize on the White House's embarrassment over the collapse of the peso without appearing to sabotage efforts to cope with Mexico's financial meltdown. But like many ideas from "supply side" conservatives, there is just enough common sense to give a life of its own to the notion that currency devaluation only worsens badly managed economies. 
 Mexico apparently got into trouble because its Government did not respond to investors' loss of confidence in the economy last year after the Chiapas revolt. Indeed, the Salinas administration concealed the fact that Mexico's central bank was spending billions of dollars a month last fall to prop up the peso while failing to prevent the surging growth of the domestic money supply.
The dam burst when the central bank ran out of foreign currency to buy back the pesos it had been busily pumping into the economy to keep interest rates down and business booming. The exchange value of the peso has since fallen by almost half, reducing living standards in an economy accustomed to cheap imports and leaving businesses that owed money in dollars near ruin.
Mainstream economists, including many with impeccable conservative credentials, view depreciation of the peso as part of the solution. If inflation can be kept in check -- a big "if" -- they argue that the new exchange rate will make Mexican exports more competitive, as well as making Mexican securities more attractive to foreigners. The supply-siders' alternative, using Mexico's new line of credit from the United States Treasury and the International Monetary Fund to restore the old exchange rate, is seen by Steve Hanke of Johns Hopkins University as "complete madness" -- and the very opposite of prudent policy.
But that has not stopped prominent Republicans including Jack Kemp and the Senate majority leader, Bob Dole, from wondering out loud why Mexico cannot be held to its old promises never to devalue. Nor has it stopped Jude Wanniski, the doyen of supply-side ideologues, from labeling devaluation as "a nitwit idea that comes deep from the heart of Keynesian philosophy."
Mr. Wanniski argues that devaluation is a breach of trust with the Mexican middle class, undermining both their savings and confidence in free markets. And he dismisses efforts to make exports cheaper by depreciating the currency as a failed nostrum that leads to inflation and more depreciation. His solution for Mexico (and other countries bullied by "the evil death star known as the International Monetary Fund") is to let it claw its way back to the pre-crisis exchange rate.
In theory that is possible if Mexico would be allowed to use its newly borrowed currency reserves to buy back all the pesos it is offered at 3.5 pesos to the dollar. But nonbelievers view revaluation as a recipe for disaster. For unless foreign investors are miraculously inspired to flood Mexico with dollars, the crunch on the supply of money as pesos are exchanged at the central bank for foreign currency would cut deep into consumption and investment.
Wages and prices would eventually fall, easing the cash crunch, making Mexican exports competitive and putting Mexicans back to work. Or maybe not: A long, bitter recession would surely tempt the ruling party's old guard to play the nationalism card, jettisoning the economic and political reforms that have given Mexico a shot at joining the affluent industrial world.
While mainstream economists are thus united in the opposition to revaluation of the peso, they don't agree on much else. Mr. Hanke argues that the most plausible way to restore the peso's credibility is to put monetary policy on automatic pilot. He favors the creation of a "currency board" that would exchange the peso for dollars at a fixed rate to all comers -- and lack the power to bail out either the Government budget or the banking system.
This approach worked in Europe's colonies in the 19th century, he says. And it is now working in Argentina, allowing that nation to shed a century-old reputation for currency mismanagement. Why not try the same in Mexico?
Jeffrey Sachs, an economist at Harvard, concedes that currency boards are a plausible last resort, but argues that the idea of putting the peso in a "straitjacket" is premature. Carefully modulated austerity combined with a new honesty and transparency in currency matters, he says, could do the job with less pain.
He had better be right. For that is plainly the direction the White House is pushing Mexico, and Congress is not about to provide the cash for yet another rescue attempt.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Steadies as the Mark Slips vs. the Pound and Lira

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar was steady against most leading currencies yesterday as a respite from political turmoil in Europe diminished the German mark's appeal as a haven.
The mark slipped against the British pound and Italian lira after rising to record highs against those currencies on Monday. The pound benefited from an improved outlook for Prime Minister John Major's Government, while the lira was bolstered by better prospects for the Government's budget. 
 "The mark's benefited from a flight to quality recently, but it seems a little overstated," said Steve Timcke, chief currency trader at the Bank of Montreal in London.
In late trading in New York yesterday, the dollar slipped to 1.4622 marks from 1.4625 marks on Tuesday. The dollar edged up to 96.76 Japanese yen from 96.75 yen, and to 1.2380 Swiss francs from 1.2375 francs. The British pound rose to $1.5865 from $1.5835.
The mark's weakness against the pound and the lira weighed it down against the dollar as well, currency dealers said. "The crosses are driving the market," said Paul Farrell, manager of strategic currency trading at Chase Manhattan Bank. Crosses are trades in two nondollar currencies.
Earlier this week, the rush to marks from other European currencies prompted many investors to sell dollars for marks as well, dealers and analysts said. The mark is considered a safe haven because the Bundesbank is seen as a more tenacious defender of its currency than other central banks.
Demand for marks ebbed yesterday as political crises in Europe eased. In Italy, expectations that Prime Minister Lamberto Dini would be able to pass his deficit-reduction package led dealers to believe the lira's fall this week was overdone.
The mark slipped to 1,132.39 lire from 1,135.39 lire late yesterday in New York. The mark set a record high of 1,165.92 lire on Monday.
The pound gained in anticipation of a victory by the Government in Parliament yesterday. The Government later won the vote on a motion criticizing its approach to European economic integration.
The pound rose to 2.3213 marks from 2.3164 marks, where it was quoted late yesterday in New York. On Monday, the pound fell to a record low of 2.2954 marks.

HEADLINE: Late '94 Growth Revised Upward to 4.6%, Showing Wind Is Still in Sails

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 1

 BODY:
The economy closed out 1994 with a bigger head of steam than previously estimated, suggesting it might take longer than expected to moderate the momentum.
But analysts insist that a slowdown has begun as consumers curtail spending in the face of higher interest rates and the damper put on United States exports by Mexico's peso crisis. 
 The Commerce Department said today that the economy expanded at a 4.6 percent annual rate in the fourth quarter, propelling 1994 to the strongest full year of growth in a decade. The quarterly advance was slightly more robust than the Government's earlier estimate of 4.5 percent.
One reason it may take longer than expected to slow the economy's galloping pace, analysts said, is that inventory buildup was much less than reported by the Commerce Department a month ago. Smaller stockpiles on store shelves could mean higher production to replenish supplies, analysts said.
But they predicted that growth in the current quarter would be around 3 percent as the economy heads down to a level the Federal Reserve believes can be sustained without inflation.
"The overall picture hasn't changed," said Sung Won Sohn, an economist for the Norwest Corporation, a Minneapolis bank. "The economy is slowing down. Today's figures only shift the timing."
The Commerce Department also reported that a drop in building single-family homes caused a dip of two-tenths of a percent in construction spending in January, the first decline in six months. Housing activity, which is particularly sensitive to interest rates, is considered an early sign of the economy's direction.
Also, the National Association of Purchasing Management said manufacturing grew in February at a much slower rate than the previous month, and fewer companies were paying higher prices for raw materials.
"The slowdown will be mostly in the second half of this year," said David Wyss of DRI McGraw-Hill, a forecasting firm in Lexington, Mass. "We still have mixed signals for the economy."
Gross domestic product, which measures the total goods and services produced in the United States, rose 4 percent for all of last year. That is the best showing since 1984, when the economy surged 6.2 percent.
The economy increased 3.1 percent in 1993.
Despite the fourth-quarter surge, inflation remained tame, with one price gauge tied to G.D.P. revised downward to show only a 1.3 percent advance instead of a previous 1.6 percent estimate. The index rose 1.9 percent in the third quarter.
Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, hinted in Congressional testimony last week that the central bank might actually lower interest rates at some point if signs of a slower economy accumulated. The Fed has doubled a benchmark short-term interest rate, from 3 percent to 6 percent, in seven stages since February 1994.
The smaller inventory buildup in the revised fourth-quarter G.D.P. report was more than offset by gains in net exports and sales, which surged 5.3 percent compared with 4.3 percent in the July-September quarter.
The Commerce Department said the economy's annual rate of growth over all was $60.2 billion in the fourth quarter compared with $52.9 billion -- or 4 percent -- in the third quarter.
Consumer spending accounted for most of the gain, led by big-ticket goods such as cars, computers and home appliances that are often purchased with credit.
Analysts said the spending spree was ending as rising interest rates sent borrowing costs upward.

(Source: Commerce Department)

HEADLINE: Essay;
Singapore Sling

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
In Singapore last year, 27-year-old Nick Leeson was fined $140 for indecently exposing himself before a group of women in a discotheque. But when he was running up $27 billion in financial-derivative trades that bankrupted a venerable merchant bank, what did the see-no-evil regulators of Simex, Singapore's swinging stock exchange, do? They shyly looked the other way.
"It would be much harder, nearly impossible, to work that kind of conspiracy in New York than in Singapore," says David Shulman, chief equity strategist at Salomon Brothers. Like Paul Volcker and Alan Greenspan, he cautions against making the new form of gambling -- the casino-style bets that are made on the movement of real securities and commodities -- the scapegoat for recent huge losses. 
 I have had my ear bent with how wonderful derivatives can be in sharing risk, and how swaps and hedges now bestraddling the financial world insure global traders against currency swings. Wall Streeters pass along dire warnings about "disturbing the cosmic rhythms of the universe"; about regulation driving up the cost of hedging's insurance. And there's quavering in the Quadriad about triggering fearsome credit contraction by slowing the derivatives' merry-go-round.
But it strikes me, after the sudden ruination of London's Barings bank by its Singapore slinger in a simple index-option gamble, that our financial sages are being a little too cool and comfortable.
Gerald Corrigan, former head of the New York Fed now with Goldman, Sachs, has a neat way of accepting Establishment soothing syrup and then pouring it down the drain: "Derivatives reduce the statistical probability of a systemic financial disruption," he tells me, "but with the complexity, speed, interdependence and leverage growing out of financial derivatives -- if you do have a systemic disruption, they would make it far more damaging than it otherwise would have been."
Translation: Although the new gambling may reduce the odds on a bust, it would turn any bust that does come into a global debacle. His Derivatives Policy Group, a suggestion of S.E.C. Chairman Arthur Levitt, issues a report next week.
But too many old guys don't know what the young guys are doing, or how to stop them before one huge loss gets computer-driven into a chain reaction that wipes out wealth, reputation and jobs.
What to do about a danger we can sense but do not comprehend?
First, investment bankers owe it to customers, owners and trainees to do a thorough "values check."
Their economic purpose is to assemble capital and provide it wisely for business development, an honorable service in which they can take pride and make profit.
Their purpose is not to use inside expertise gained from companies they underwrite to trade for their own accounts, while advising investment clients to follow them along and enhance their early positions.
Such "proprietary activity," as this dog-wagging by the trading tail is euphemized, is legal but dishonorable -- the banking equivalent of "honest graft" in politics. If the me-first, corporate-cultural sleaziness of high leverage and lightning-fast shuffling continues to grow, the business of investment banking will gain a stigma that will shame its practitioners and turn away its customers.
Next, in overseeing banking and securities, global exchanges and national regulators need to draw a line between legitimate risk and reckless endangerment.
That means getting the Bank for International Settlements in Basle, Switzerland (central bank for the G-10), to sit down with the International Organization of Securities Commissions in Montreal to plan now to avert a world financial crisis.
Working with the exchanges and reporting services, these too-sleepy bureaucracies could help set standards for managerial monitoring, public disclosure, leverage and firewalls in the interconnected marketplace. They could stimulate the creation of regulatory software to counter trading software, making transparent to accountants and regulators who is trading how much on whose account and on what margin.
My sources in the bourses say that's how to defeat secrecy in Singapore and combat rogue traders everywhere.

HEADLINE: Think of School Lunch Program as Business

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The attempt to dismantle the national school lunch program flies in the face of goals usually attributed to the Republican leadership. By any definition, the 40,000 lunch programs around the country are really 40,000 small local businesses. They produce a product, provide a service and operate in a most entrepreneurial manner. Dismantling, or reducing, school lunch financing will cause enormous economic damage and small-business dislocation:
* More than 200,000 school lunch employees will be laid off or disenfranchised. These are hard-working people who also pay local, state and Federal income taxes, contribute 7 percent of their wages to Social Security and pay for their health care. 
 * State and Federal govenments will lose these payroll and income taxes.
* All taxpayers will incur additional expense to cover the resultant unemployment compensation.
* Health benefit expenses previously covered by the employees will now have to be paid for by Medicaid.
* Local businesses, including bakers, meat wholesalers, produce suppliers and dairies will suffer and have to face laying off drivers, warehouse people and other employees.
* Manufacturers and distributors will lose sales of their food service equipment, supplies and foodstuffs, almost all domestically produced.
* Farmers, who have counted on this business for more than 40 years, stand to lose tens of billions.
The proposed $4 billion increase in defense spending would have a more beneficial impact on the economy if spent on the school lunch program.
I urge our representatives to keep the program intact and insure the viability and productivity of these 40,000 businesses and employees and the national economic benefits they generate.
 
PETER L. VIELBIG
President
School Lunch Computer Services
Princeton, N.J., Feb. 23, 1995

HEADLINE: AT HOME WITH: Michael Murphy;
Divine Reinvention

BYLINE: By BOB MORRIS 

DATELINE: SAN RAFAEL, Calif.

 BODY:
ONE of the first things that Michael Murphy did after he bought his Victorian house in San Rafael in Marin County, Calif., seven years ago, was to destroy the hot tub in the garden. That may seem rash for a founding father of the Esalen Institute, which is almost as renowned for its clothing-optional mineral baths as it is for being the birthplace of the human-potential movement that gave rise to the New Age.
But that hot tub had to go. 
 "I took it out because it was so divisive," Mr. Murphy says. "A lot of friends have hot-tub parties, and it always seems like there's an ideological necessity to jump in. But everybody changes in the hot tub. They become different beings."
Depending on your world view, you can either blame or thank Mr. Murphy for all the different beings who are now immersed in the New Age psycho-culture. After all, the Esalen Institute, which he co-founded in 1962 on his family's 165-acre ocean-front property in Big Sur, was a sort of cyclotron for gestalt and encounter therapy, where anthropologists, gurus and teachers of ancient Eastern religion and brand-new instant-enlightenment programs helped to get a generation of Americans into the all-consuming process of self-actualization.
Mr. Murphy, now 64 and a somewhat marginalized figure in a movement hungry for charismatic leaders and best-selling authors, continues to write about human potential. His "Future of the Body: Explorations Into the Further Evolution of Human Nature" (Tarcher/ Perigee Books, 1993) is a scholarly tome that promotes the concept of "self-transcendence" through cognitive, spiritual and physical avenues. "Transformative Practice," a how-to-evolve guidebook written with his longtime collaborator, George Leonard, is to be published in September by Tarcher, and "In the Zone," an updated version of "The Psychic Side of Sports," published by Viking in 1978, is scheduled for July.
In addition, Clint Eastwood is planning to direct the movie version of "Golf in the Kingdom" (Viking), Mr. Murphy's metaphysical novel about a golf coach who views the sport as a door into the higher self.
On this Saturday, Mr. Murphy had got up at dawn to meditate. Sometimes after meditating for eight-hour sessions, he finds himself, he says, talking to God in the manner of Tev ye in "Fiddler on the Roof." Today, after meditating two hours, he had become so emotionally raw that he had broken into tears of joy. Now, he's sitting it the kitchen drinking coffee, trying to avoid looking at an article in New York magazine about New Age New Yorkers, featuring a picture of Marla Maples Trump getting an aromatherapy massage.
"At one level, I cannot judge this," Mr. Murphy says with the thunderhead eyebrows of a sea captain and the enthusiasm of a young Jimmy Stewart. "If people are opened up by these things, great. There's always been a hunger for transcendence in this country. But when I see this," he adds, looking at a picture of Faith Popcorn meditating, "it's like the difference between Mozart and Mantovani. If you've read the Upanishads, it's a long way from 'The Celestine Prohecy.' "
Mr. Murphy is a combination intellectual, mystic and sports nut so fanatical he has had to lie down in the stadium during close San Francisco 49ers' games to keep from passing out. A well-connected good-old boy with a raging curiosity and the natural effervescence of a Northern Californian, he cross-references terms from Hindu, Buddhist, Christian and Jewish mystical traditions.
Call him in denial, call him terminally positive; he's a man obsessed with getting everyone to the sunny side of the street. Zohar, a concept from the cabala (the system of Jewish mysticism), is a word he uses all the time. It refers to the splendor of everyday life. "In this culture of veils and quick fixes, we have a genius for avoiding the Zohar," he says. "So I would say about all this New Age stuff, to the extent that it's grounded and sophisticated, great. But some of it's just yuck! I remember there was a book called, 'Winning Through Enlightenment.' Talk about getting things backwards. To get enlightened so you can make money?"
Mr. Murphy grew up the son of a lawyer in Salinas, Calif., where he was an Episcopal altar boy and later a golfer and "raging extrovert." His paternal grandfather had delivered John Steinbeck, who is said to have modeled the brothers in "East of Eden" on Mr. Murphy and his brother, Dennis, now a writer. At Stanford University in the mid-1950's, Mr. Murphy accidentally walked into a lecture by an Asian-studies scholar, Frederic Spiegelberg. "He said the word 'Brahman,' which means the ultimate reality, the divine, and I was his," Mr. Murphy says. "I took vows to myself and God that this is what I'd do for the rest of my life."
Money can sometimes make enlightenment a little easier. In 1956, after a stint in the United States Army, a check arrived from home ("a great love message from my father," he says), and he went to India to the ashram of Sri Aurobindo, a guru whose belief in ascending consciousness through the integration of mind and body still inspires Mr. Murphy's fixation on the divine.
Back in San Francisco a few years later, he hooked up with Richard Price, a Zen Buddhist. They leased the property owned by Mr. Murphy's grandmother in Big Sur and, in 1962, announced a series of academic seminars on "the human potentialities," a phrase coined by Aldous Huxley.
Esalen, named for the tribe of Indians that once inhabited the ruggedly beautiful cliffs of Big Sur, quickly attracted leaders of what Mr. Murphy calls "the consciousness revolution." Huxley, Gregory Bateson, Alan Watts, Fritz Perls and Abraham Maslow (he coined the terms "self-actualizing" and "peak experience") tested their theories there. Their workshops pushed people to break down emotional and sexual barriers more aggressively than in traditional therapy. Referring to total self-involvement as work was a notion whose time had come.
By the 1970's, with Jane Fonda, Tom Hayden, Jerry Brown and Joan Baez, Esalen's reputation became such that corporations sent employees for workshops. Mr. Murphy never imposed himself or any one dogma on the place, discouraging the cult atmosphere associated with other charismatic leaders of the day, like Werner Erhard, the EST founder, and the Rev. Jim Jones, who led followers to mass suicide in 1978.
In the 1980's, long after he had moved away to concentrate on writing, Mr. Murphy set up the Soviet-American Exchange Program at Esalen to help "demystify the Soviets." He assembled leading thinkers for seminars, like Boris Yeltsin on his first United States visit, in 1989.
But from a distance as a trustee who collects a salary, Mr. Murphy now views Esalen, which attracts 10,000 paying seminarians a year, as a place "for beginnings," not for the "transformative" practice he believes will help the human race in its further evolution. "The New Age literature is about beginnings," he says. "But the great task of the New Age is to create a comprehensive vision and adequate practices."
To that end, he and Mr. Leonard, his colleague, have arranged the financing for a "transformative-practice center" in Marin County. With backing from a chain of San Francisco Bay-area health clubs, it would be a kind of maintenance center for the metaphysically prone. Mr. Murphy describes it as a cross between a health club, a community center and an ashram, where no Walkmans would be allowed and everyone would be required to meditate before using the Nautilus equipment.
"I look around and see a wilderness of broken hearts out there," says Mr. Murphy, recently separated from his wife of 23 years, with whom he has a 10-year-old son. "But if we knew the joy we could find by living fully in our minds and bodies, and if we had a culture that encouraged us in contemplative practices, we wouldn't need Prozac. The Ramakrishna said that the winds of grace are always blowing, but you've got to raise the sail."
Later in the day, a fierce wind is blowing, and the sail of a 40-foot sloop is raised. Mr. Murphy is out with some friends on the San Francisco Bay. "We're natural voyagers of body and spirit," says Mr. Murphy, who raises his head to the sky, yells a thank you to God for the beauty of the day. He's big on the value of howling into the wind.
It's one of his typically exuberant gatherings, and the spiritual-socio-political wheels are spinning. A. Lawrence Chickering, an economist, is on board, as is James Ogilvy, whose Global Business Network helps develop "alternative scenarios" for profit-making. There's talk of alternative education; of the strong entrepreneurial impulses of the poor in third-world countries, and of banks that loan money to women in those countries rather than men (men spend the money on themselves, they say; women, on their children).
A flag whips in the wind, and the group sails on, a little Good Ship America of high-minded optimists. As the ship comes about through a puff of fog under a sunlit Mount Tamalpais, a seagull glides past Mr. Murphy's head.
"Michael Murphy and Jonathan Livingston Seagull," Mr. Ogilvy says.
"Oh, please," Mr. Murphy moans.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

LENGTH: 1306 words

HEADLINE: Is New York Ready for Nice?

BYLINE: By SUZANNE SLESIN 

 BODY:
CRATE AND BARREL, the home furnishings chain that is known for wholesome-looking stores that are filled to the rafters with nice merchandise and pleasant salespeople, is opening in New York on Wednesday.
So how will New Yorkers take to the Crate's brand of small-town ambiance, straightforward attitude and good values? Will a store that sets its tone with acres of knotty pine, goods packed with biodegradable cornstarch pellets and a "don't worry if you break something" approach be too . . . well . . . earnest for denizens of this attitudinal town? 
 After all, even with stores like the palpably pleasant Starbucks coffee bars that have sprouted on every corner, New Yorkers are famously unused to coping with well-trained and helpful employees, pristine displays, stores where customers are occasionally asked to wait outside so it won't be too crowded inside, and so much stock that when salespeople are asked to run to get an extra six-dozen glasses from a subterranean stockroom, they are thrilled. (There will be 15 employees in New York doing nothing but stocking shelves and straightening displays.)
The new 54,000-square-foot store, at the northwest corner of Madison Avenue and 59th Street, will have 95 smiling employees, on any given day, who have been trained to be out-of-town helpful. Thirty-five were hand-picked because of the communication skills they displayed a few weeks ago when they responded to advertisements that ran in Backstage, The Village Voice and New York Casting. Some lines heard at the auditions:
* "Hi, I'm Fleur. I do comedy and drama."
* "Hello, I'm Ivan. I'm an actor and in a ballet. I moved here from California three years ago."
The time seems right for Crate and Barrel. Conran's is no longer in business. The much smaller-scale Pottery Barn stores are busy championing all things well patinated or of iron wrought. ABC Carpet and Home is a completely different mind-set, with its eclectic and fancifully cluttered displays of old and new. Ikea is a destination in itself, a huge warehouse for bargain-seekers more than a cab ride away. And Bed Bath and Beyond is more of a warehouse than a style statement.
But the Crate, as the privately held company is known to habitues, should fit right in on the section of Madison Avenue between 59th and 61st streets: it will be cheek by jowl with the new high-style fashion and design superstores like Barneys New York, which is already established, and the Ann Taylor and Calvin Klein stores that will open this year.
For one thing, it has 33,000 square feet of selling space on two floors stacked with glasses, pitchers, platters, towels, potholders, napkins, straw mats, private-label peppers, chip and dip bowls, mugs, rugs, clocks, lamps, chairs and sofas -- the kind of easy-to-look-at merchandise you either can't live without or at least think you shouldn't have to.
Last year, more than two million glasses and more than 10,000 sofas were sold at the 55 Crate and Barrels that dot the United States. More than 75,000 brides drew up wish lists there. All of that resulted in gross sales of $274 million ($30 million through the catalogues that were sent, in five editions, to 20 million households.)
But can the chain -- described in the Dec. 12 issue of Business Week magazine as having acceptance "on the scale of Santa Claus" -- capture New York and the people that Gordon Segal, the affable owner and president, said the other day were "the most demanding and critical customers in America"?
Since Mr. Segal and his wife, Carole, opened their first store on Dec. 7, 1962, in the Old Town section of Chicago, displaying the merchandise on packing crates, he has fine-tuned, obsessed about and expanded on the selection of products and the way they are displayed.
The Manhattan store, which is to be followed this year on the East Coast by a 23,000-square-foot store in White Plains and a 18,000-square-foot store in Short Hills, N.J., has been four years and $10 million in the making.
"I'm a little nervous: New York is pretty overwhelming," said Barbara Turf, the executive vice president of Crate and Barrel, who for 20 years has been in charge of merchandising and marketing. That may be because although the Crate is considered on the cutting edge in many areas outside New York, some New Yorkers might perceive it as being a purveyor of more basic wares.
Yet, its greatest appeal for New Yorkers will be its irresistibly charming products: all the things one desperately needs when they are within hand's reach and reasonably priced. For example, a glass platter splashed with brightly colored flowers, a black iron Windsor chair, a shapely terra-cotta basket, khaki and white striped towels, a plain wood-handled toothbrush and big sofas and chairs in floppy white upholstery.
The overall mix of merchandise has become softer and -- sshh! -- trendier. There are some thick-wire vases with blown glass, distressed wood boxes in the shape of ducks, even some celadon-hued dinner plates and platters in frosted glass. Mr. Segal termed them "very avant."
"We're going toward a warmer feeling," he added. "If you had said five years ago that we would have tapestry runners, I wouldn't have believed it."
Or fake house plants. So many customers asked about the ones the store used as backdrops that the Crate decided to sell them as well.
Last week, as dozens of construction workers charged about getting ready for an onslaught of fixtures and merchandise, Mr. Segal and some visitors made their way through the subterranean stockrooms.
"Our motivation has always been to bring good taste to the table," said Mr. Segal, 55, as he took a long-stemmed wineglass from a shelf, then showed off a square Italian bowl decorated with fruit, a stack of pudding bowls, a three-compartment relish tray.
"That's $24.95," he said of the heavy glass dish. "Inexpensive we're not, but unusual quality for this value."
Many corner locations were considered:on Union Square, the Upper East Side, the Upper West Side and lower Broadway. The one at 59th and Madison clinched the deal, partly because it was visible from Fifth Avenue and within sight of the Plaza Hotel and could therefore be a tourist destination.
So did the economics, Mr. Segal said. The front footage at 59th and Madison, he said, is "prime and expensive and about $275 a square foot."
"But as you proceed back away from the corner," he continued, "then it's in the $120-a-square-foot range."
"And," he added with a gleam in his eye, "up on the second floor, we're talking about $40 a square foot. All of a sudden that blended rate is affordable. Not inexpensive, but affordable."
While the fancy location might deter bargain hunters, it will certainly attract people who can't resist a striped pitcher; a big cup decorated with blue knives, forks and spoons; a scalloped serving plate in sherbet hues; a lamp with a base in the shape of a lighthouse, or salad plates printed with leafy herbs. They will also be bowled over by the sheer scale of the store as they make their way past mountains of china and down alleyways lined with glasses.
But how does the store prevent people from knocking into the tantalizingly close-at-hand displays? "We don't," said Bette Kahn, the director of public relations, in Chicago. "We want to make it all accessible, to let you see how a glass feels and for you to imagine how it will look in your home."
Mr. Segal is counting on an onslaught of customers. "They change their car, their clothes, but they want their dinnerware to last forever," he said. "We are of the belief that every few years, people should change their dinnerware." And it is hoped, their furniture as well.
Mr. Segal looked around the huge store and said, "Now what we'll need is a lot of happy people."
In New York?

HEADLINE: THE 104th CONGRESS: NEWS ANALYSIS
Budgetary Posturing;
Substance Losing Ground to Politics

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 1

 BODY:
The impasse in the Senate over the balanced-budget amendment can be explained by this finding in the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll: 79 percent of Americans said they favored a constitutional amendment that would require the Federal Government to balance its books by 2002; but only 32 percent said they were in favor if it would require cuts in Social Security.
With an eye toward those numbers, the proponents of the amendment portray themselves as the champions of fiscal responsibility and their opponents as spendthrifts. Those against the amendment accuse the proponents of planning to raid Social Security and picture themselves as the guardians of retirement benefits. 
 Senators Kent Conrad and Byron L. Dorgan, the North Dakota Democrats who seem to hold the decisive votes, say they cannot vote for any constitutional amendment that threatens future Social Security benefits. The Republican leaders are desperately trying to find something they can offer to satisfy the North Dakotans. Whether they succeed or not, it will have nothing to do with actually balancing the budget.
If this sounds like the triumph of politics over substance, it is. The debate over the balanced-budget amendment is now and always has been almost entirely a question of political positioning.
Republicans and Democrats alike genuinely believe that the Federal deficit threatens the economic future of the next generation and that the budget should be put on a direct path toward balance. But that is not their highest priority.
For most Republicans, low taxes are more important. This is why every Republican in the Senate and House voted in 1993 against President Clinton's five-year plan to lower the deficit by $500 billion by reducing spending and raising taxes. And it is why Republicans in the House of Representatives are determined to push through the tax cuts that are part of their Contract With America before they address the question of how to balance the budget. 
For most Democrats, deficit reduction is not so crucial as maintaining the social welfare state. That is why so many of them are determined to keep Social Security out of the deficit calculations.
Much of what was said today on both sides bore no relationship to reality. Explaining his position, Senator Conrad declared this morning: "It's just fundamentally wrong to take Social Security trust fund surpluses to balance an operating budget."
In fact, the Social Security trust fund is nothing but an accounting device. These surpluses have been spent for the general purposes of government for years. That has made the deficit appear far smaller than it would have otherwise.
Other Democrats chimed in that they, too, were all in favor of balancing the budget as long as Social Security was excluded from the calculations. That is nonsensical, both as an economics and a practical matter.
In terms of economics, the budget runs a deficit whenever spending exceeds revenue. The Government must issue bonds to borrow the same amount of money to finance the deficit whether the spending is for pensions or battleships or food stamps or whether the revenue comes from taxes on incomes or payrolls or cigarettes.
It may be good policy to have money set aside to finance future Social Security benefits. But that has nothing to do with balancing the budget in this fiscal year or any other. When it comes to figuring the deficit, the money in the Social Security account is the same as any other.
As a practical matter, if the Social Security surplus is disregarded, balancing the budget by 2002, as the constitutional amendment would theoretically require, would be near impossible.
Including the surplus, the Congressional Budget Office has calculated, it would require some combination of spending reductions and tax increases totaling $1.2 trillion to bring Federal expenditures in line with Federal receipts in seven years. The advocates of the constitutional amendment have not offered a clue as to how they intend to bridge that gap.
The current surplus of Social Security revenue over payments is so large that if this money were excluded from the calculations, another $636 billion would be needed to balance the budget by 2002, an amount far beyond what even the most ardent budget slashers can find.
To entice Senators Conrad and Dorgan, the Republicans have suggested that they could agree to exclude Social Security from the deficit calculations required by the constitutional amendment sometime early in the next century.
That is what the Democrats fear most. According to current reckoning, the Social Security system will begin running a deficit in 2013. Presumably some steps will be taken between now and then to rectify the problem. But if not, there are only two possibilities: Social Security retirement payments will have to be abandoned, or the Government will have to borrow to finance them.
As for the Republicans, they continue to maintain that they have no intention of reducing Social Security benefits. Maybe not. But they also say they will balance the budget without raising taxes or cutting military spending. Hardly anyone who has run the numbers believes all those promises can be kept.
As if all this were not confusing enough, the balanced-budget amendment was further complicated on Tuesday when, in an effort to peel off a couple of Democratic votes, Republicans agreed to the stipulation that Federal courts would have no jurisdiction to enforce the amendment.
So what would happen if the time for balancing the budget arrived and the ledger was still out of whack? Well, said Senator Orrin G. Hatch of Utah, the Republican floor leader, the political pressure would be such that Congress would act to close the gap.
That was as close as anyone in the Senate has come this week to acknowledging that politics is what the whole debate is about.
