HEADLINE: THE 104TH CONGRESS: WELFARE;
House Leaders and Republican Governors Agree on an Alternative to Food Stamps

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 1

 BODY:
Under intense pressure from Republican governors, House Republican leaders partly reversed themselves today and agreed to let some states use Federal food stamp money to feed poor people in any way that state officials wanted.
Under the agreement, these states could set their own eligibility criteria and benefit levels, replacing the uniform national standards in the food stamp program. Low-income people now entitled to food stamps would not necessarily be entitled to food assistance under the new programs. 
 The agreement is the second major change on this issue by the Republican leaders in less than a week. It illustrates how they have been tugged back and forth by various constituencies as they try to pare social welfare programs established over the last half-century.
In the Contract With America, Republicans said they would replace nutrition programs, including food stamps, with a lump-sum payment of Federal money that states could use as they pleased for the general purpose of food assistance.
On Friday, the Republicans bowed to pressure from farm-state lawmakers and agreed to keep food stamps as a Federal entitlement program, paying benefits to anyone who meets certain eligibility criteria. Farm-state lawmakers like the food stamp program because it pumps more than $25 billion a year into the farm economy. Representative Pat Roberts of Kansas, the chairman of the House Agriculture Committee, said on Friday that it was "the ultimate social safety net."
Then on Tuesday night, two Republican Governors, John Engler of Michigan and William F. Weld of Massachusetts, persuaded Speaker Newt Gingrich to let states take control of the food stamp program if they met certain requirements intended to prevent the misuse of Federal money. To qualify for this option, states would have to dispense food assistance with plastic cards like those used in automated teller machines at banks.
Federal officials have been concerned about trafficking in food stamps, which are now sold in books of coupons that can be traded almost as easily as cash. The plastic cards, which are already being used in pilot programs, create electronic records of transactions, and Federal officials say such records help them detect fraud.
The sudden reversal by House Republicans illustrates two important points about the new Congress. In the current political climate, no entitlement program guaranteeing benefits to low-income people is secure. And House Republican leaders seek to placate Republican governors whenever possible, paying more attention to their views than to the concerns of Democratic members of Congress.
Governor Engler hailed the new agreement. "I was concerned last week to hear that the proposal for a food stamp block grant would not go forward," he said in an interview today. "What was worked out in our meeting last night, while not going as far or as fast as we would like, is extraordinarily helpful to the states. I'm now very comfortable with the progress being made by the House on welfare reform." Mr. Engler said that Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey supported the agreement.
But Robert J. Fersh, president of the Food Research and Action Center, a nonprofit anti-hunger group, said: "This could be the beginning of the end of the food stamp program. There's no guarantee that benefits will be available for needy people, especially in tough economic times."
The Mayor of Detroit, Dennis W. Archer, also opposed the idea of a block grant for food assistance, saying it "represents a fixed sum of money that will not expand as the need expands."
The number of people getting food stamps increased to 27.5 million last year, up from 20 million in 1990. More than half the people receiving assistance are children. When unemployment increases, more people qualify for food stamps, and the payment of such benefits automatically injects Federal money into states experiencing economic difficulties.
The compromise reached by Mr. Gingrich and the governors encourages the use of plastic cards in place of food stamps. Such cards are used to transfer money from a food stamp account to the account of a grocery store or other retailer. Under the Republican plan, if a state had a statewide system of "electronic benefits transfer," it could receive its food stamp money in a lump sum and could set its own eligibility criteria and benefit levels.
Under the new agreement, welfare recipients who find jobs in private industry and earn at least $350 a month could get food assistance in the form of cash rather than food stamp coupons.
"This would allow states to provide cash to food stamp recipients who are working in private-sector employment," Governor Engler said. "That's an important way to reward work. We would not ask them to spend that money on food." But Mr. Engler said experience suggested that people would use the cash for food.
Under the agreement with House Republicans, state officials could cut or eliminate food assistance and cash welfare benefits for adults who refused to work.
Under current law, states can penalize welfare recipients who refuse to work. But Mr. Engler said such penalties were often meaningless because food stamp benefits and rent subsidies automatically increased when a person's cash welfare benefits were reduced.
Neal H. Flieger, a spokesman for the Agriculture Department, said the new proposal was better than the block grant proposed last year in the Contract With America. But he said, "The Administration still opposes block grants for nutrition programs, including food stamps."
In an effort to fend off criticism of the program, Richard Rominger, the Acting Secretary of Agriculture, today proposed legislation to curtail food stamp fraud. He recommended tougher penalties for people who traffic in food stamps and stricter scrutiny of retailers.
Food stamps have been used to buy drugs, guns, alcohol and tobacco, with phony stores serving as fronts for laundering operations.
In a typical case, a food stamp recipient sells the coupons to a grocer for less than the face value, generally 50 to 70 cents on the dollar. The retailer is then reimbursed by the Government for the full amount of the coupons.

HEADLINE: Abortion Clinic Faces Eviction With Eight Years Left on Lease

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: GARDEN CITY, L.I., March 1

 BODY:
An abortion clinic here that was the target of death threats in January is now facing eviction, though it still has 8 years left on its 11-year lease.
The clinic's landlord issued "new rules and regulations" on Jan. 11 for the three-story building at 1103 Stewart Avenue, stating that tenants could no longer perform "any abortions or other medical services in any way related to pregnancy terminations." The notice came within days of a wave of anti-abortion violence at clinics around the nation, including the murders of two people at a Brookline, Mass., clinic. 
 A month later, the Garden City landlord sent the clinic, Long Island Gynecological Services, a notice of eviction.
The landlord, 1103 Stewart Avenue Associates, has declined to comment, but abortion rights advocates fear that the Garden City case may be part of a pattern they are seeing nationwide: as the anti-abortion protest movement has taken an increasingly violent bent, a growing number of businesses, hospitals and towns do not want the risk of being associated with abortion providers. These advocates say the Garden City landlord's action may violate a 1994 Federal law guaranteeing access to abortion clinics.
Representative Charles E. Schumer, a sponsor of the law, said he had written to Attorney General Janet Reno asking her to monitor the eviction effort, warning that similar measures of economic harassment elsewhere could undermine the law.
"I'm afraid this is a pattern not unique to Nassau County," Mr. Schumer said. "Those who are against the pro-choice movement have not been able to win with their old tactics, so they have decided to try to close down clinics by using new economic weapons. We're seeing landlords, suppliers and even plumbers facing veiled threats and not-so-veiled threats."
At the clinic here, signs were posted on the outside walls on the night of Jan. 7 reading: "Danger. This is a war zone. People are being killed here -- like Boston. You risk injury or death if you are caught on or near these premises."
The clinic has also been the site of anti-abortion demonstrations and the target of bomb threats.
In a letter dated Feb. 13, the landlord gave the clinic 10 days' notice of termination of its lease, citing "the continued performance of abortion procedures."
Clinic officials, fearful that the landlord would seize the clinic, have obtained a stay in State Supreme Court. Judge John Di Noto is scheduled to hear arguments on March 9.
The director of the clinic, Irene Sylvor, who has expressed fear for her own safety, declined to comment on the dispute. Ronald J. Morey, the president of 1103 Stewart Avenue Associates and the owner of radio station WDRE in Westbury, also declined comment. Mr. Morey's lawyer, Gary C. Hisiger, said he had advised his client not to discuss his reasons for trying to evict the clinic. "We are trying to keep this a simple landlord-tenant matter," Mr. Hisiger said.
But Donna Liberman, a lawyer with the New York Civil Liberties Union, said the effort to evict the clinic was "not just another landlord-tenant dispute."
"We are concerned that a lockout would cause irreparable harm to the patients who rely on the clinic for safe, legal and timely abortions, as well as the other reproductive health services the clinic provides," she said. The Federal law, she said, was enacted to prevent conduct that might interfere with people seeking to provide or obtain an abortion.
"A lockout or other interference would constitute such proscribed conduct," she said.
David Rosenberg, a lawyer for the clinic, said he remained hopeful that the matter could be resolved before March 9. "If not, the court will have to decide," he said.
Roger Evans, director of litigation for the Planned Parenthood Federation of America, said the eviction was "an example of the ripple effects that overt acts of terror have on contractors, property owners and everyday businessmen who come in contact with abortion clinics."
"Some may not care about abortion one way or the other but don't want their property harmed," Mr. Evans said. "Others may be opposed to abortion or may be pressured by others to take such action.
"Up until now, we have considered this a sort of sub-form of harassment," he said. "But typically, such as in Wisconsin last year, state courts have held that landlords cannot terminate a clinic's lease in midstream."
The Wisconsin case involved a clinic in Milwaukee threatened with eviction in 1993.

Signs warn against loitering and declare that anyone entering may be subject to inspection. (Steve Berman for The New York Times) (pg. B5)

HEADLINE: Singapore Defends Itself Over Barings

BYLINE: By EDWARD A. GARGAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SINGAPORE, March 1

 BODY:
Breaking silence for the first time since the collapse of the British investment bank Barings P.L.C. -- a result of catastrophic losses by a Barings trader here -- the Singapore Government defended the integrity of its trading markets today. But it also announced a sweeping review of the futures exchange and promised to enact tight new rules over trading companies.
Singapore's Finance Minister, Richard Hu, told this city-state's Parliament that the Singapore International Monetary Exchange Ltd., where the trading originated, was not at risk because of the Barings losses, which now exceed $1 billion. 
 But Mr. Hu acknowledged that the exchange had borrowed $300 million to cover any shortfall in meeting the remaining open futures contracts of Barings. He did not say how many such contracts there were.
Mr. Hu's statement came in response to a rising chorus of concern in Asia and elsewhere over the regulatory rigor and financial integrity of the Singapore exchange, which is widely known as Simex.
"Our futures exchange is not at risk as a result of the massive losses of the Barings Group," he said. "This is because Simex has a comprehensive set of checks and controls to safeguard the financial integrity of the exchange and those of its futures-broking members."
Other Asian exchanges have expressed concern about the failure of Simex to detect and prevent the Barings losses.
Leslie V. Hosking, the chief executive of the Sydney Futures Exchange in Australia, said in a telephone conversation that "there must have been an element of concealment and fraud that has gotten around the system," adding, "We're as intrigued as anybody to learn what happened."
Because the Simex was modeled on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, Mr. Hosking said, he was unclear how such uncontrolled losses could have occurred. But he said he inferred that "there was a clear lack of head office control by Barings."
"They don't have adequate controls that stretch from the Northern Hemisphere down to this region," he said of the firm. "It's happened before; it's not a new story. And as the derivatives market gets bigger, it will be of more concern."
In his statement to Parliament, Mr. Hu did not explain how the 28-year-old trader for Barings, Nicholas W. Leeson, managed to circumvent the exchange's system of safeguards. But he suggested that Mr. Leeson exercised control over both his trading and the back-office accounting operations.
Throughout the 24-day period beginning Feb. 1, during which Mr. Leeson was amassing immense positions in stock index futures and interest rate futures in the Japanese markets, Barings continued to meet each of Simex's increasing margin calls, Mr. Hu said. Margin calls are demands for additional funds to be used as security. The total involved amounted to $128 million, the Finance Minister said.
Some traders here said, however, that margin calls in February would result from deterioration of positions that Mr. Leeson had acquired in January.
Even while noting that Barings met the margin requirements, Mr. Hu contended that Mr. Leeson's "speculative positions were also concealed," because Simex was given to understand that the firm's "open positions were undertaken for arbitrage trading purposes, which involve less risks."
Mr. Hu said that the investigation into Mr. Leeson's activities was not complete and that he was unable to explain how the trader managed to circumvent exchange regulators. Mr. Hu did, however, acknowledge that the exchange had been influenced by the stellar reputation of Barings as a trading house and had not deemed it necessary to limit Mr. Leeson's swiftly accumulating open positions. And because Barings continued to meet margin calls, he said, there were no signs that the firm was in financial difficulty.
A spokesman for the monetary exchange, Charles P. K. Sng, echoed Mr. Hu's comments. "Barings has always been very respectable and up until February they always maintained sufficient margins," he said. "Barings has always had large positions. Their reputation is always taken into account."
Whether Mr. Hu's comments are enough to reassure investors and trading houses remains to be seen. Singapore's major financial daily, The Business Times, has sought to blame almost everyone but the local exchange. "No regulator could have such breadth of surveillance to detect such malpractice," the newspaper said in an editorial Tuesday, "nor would the financial markets wish for one."
But some bankers and traders here said that while Barings itself demonstrated a catastrophic failure of management, the regulatory mechanisms of the Singapore International Monetary Exchange proved woefully inadequate as well.
"How on earth did Simex not know what was going on?" asked a senior foreign banker who insisted on anonymity. "It is rather incredible that a firm like Barings could not know the position it is building up. And it is also incredible that this is not recognized by Simex."
Timothy Moe, the director of research for Salomon Brothers in Hong Kong, said that it remained unclear how Mr. Leeson was able to keep placing contracts even as he continued to lose money.
"It seems that there was some failure either in terms of position limits, monitoring, fraud or whatever," Mr. Moe said. "It is staggering that positions of that magnitude could be accumulated."
Regardless of what Mr. Leeson did, Mr. Moe cautioned, there is no guarantee that other trading houses will not sustain devastating losses just as easily.
"No one is immune from this kind of thing," he said. "You have some very hot instruments that can cut very quickly both ways. What is surprising is that Barings is meant to be this longstanding, stable and successful bank, very much the epitome of British merchant banking. That's what's shocking."

HEADLINE: Think of School Lunch Program as Business;
More Money, Not Less

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"The Return of Ketchup" (editorial, Feb. 24), on Republican efforts to reform Federal food and nutrition programs as part of our welfare reform proposal, is so inaccurate I can only conclude that it was written without reading the legislation. 
 I take a back seat to no one in my commitment to child nutrition. When past Republican administrations attempted to dismantle it, I worked to defeat those efforts, while many of my Democratic colleagues stood by and made trivial political statements about ketchup, behavior that has been recently repeated.
Speaking of ketchup, I note that the Administration's nutrient standard concept includes nutrients in ketchup when determining compliance with dietary requirements for children. I guess ketchup isn't all bad.
You state that the Republican proposal would give the school lunch program to the states "with a sharply reduced budget," but you fail to note the sharp reduction in paperwork and regulatory requirements, which school districts have complained about on numerous occasions before my committee.
The proposal would replace the volumes of detailed regulations by which the Federal Government micromanages every aspect of how school nutrition programs must operate. In place of those regulations, this proposal sets general guidelines and goals, and minimum requirements, leaving to states and local school districts some discretion in how best to meet the needs of individual and local circumstances.
States and local school districts can make these determinations without Washington's dictating every detail. We also believe that states and local school districts can make these determinations better.
The Republican proposal would increase spending on school nutrition programs by more than 4 percent a year over the next five years. Outside of Washington not many people would consider a 4 percent increase a "sharply reduced budget."
You also repeat the erroneous assertion made by some predictable opponents of anything Republicans would propose that we are "slashing funding" for the special supplemental food program for women, infants and children.
In 1995 the WIC program -- which I strongly support -- received an appropriation of $3.4 billion. The Republican proposal assumes that spending on the same program under the block grant will increase to $3.6 billion in 1996, with additional increases each year. These scarcely qualify as reductions.
The proposal also saves the Federal Government money. It does so by limiting the availability of funds to those children from economically disadvantaged families who are enrolled in family day care homes.
That is the same change the Clinton Administration proposed to help pay for its welfare reform program a little less than a year ago. Frankly, it is political hypocrisy and opportunism for President Clinton to suggest that these same cuts will mean that children will go hungry.
 
(Rep.) BILL GOODLING
Chairman, Committee on Economic
and Educational Opportunities
Washington, Feb. 24, 1995

HEADLINE: Dole Hammers on Yeltsin As U.S. Frustration Grows

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 1

 BODY:
The Senate majority leader, Bob Dole, lashed out against Boris N. Yeltsin today, likening the Clinton Administration's embrace of the Russian leader to the Bush Administration's refusal to abandon his predecessor, Mikhail S. Gorbachev.
The remarks by Mr. Dole, a leading contender for the Republican presidential nomination, reflect a growing frustration with Mr. Yeltsin by Republicans and Democrats in Congress, and even by the Administration. 
With no prospect for an end to the war in the Chechnya, the secessionist republic, the debate within the Administration about how closely the United States should align itself with Mr. Yeltsin has grown sharper and more acrimonious, with Secretary of State Warren Christopher even suggesting in a meeting Monday with Italy's Foreign Minister, Susanna Agnelli, that perhaps the West should be looking for an alternative.
But Mr. Dole's remarks elicited an almost immediate rebuttal from the national security adviser, Anthony Lake, who said the United States must try to bring Mr. Yeltsin and the reformers in Russia back together. Still, Mr. Lake did not attempt to defend the Russian leader.
Of all the recent criticisms of Mr. Yeltsin, Mr. Dole's was perhaps the most surprising. The Kansas Republican was one of the first members of Congress to support Mr. Yeltsin when the Bush Administration was clinging to the hope that the former Soviet President, Mr. Gorbachev, would survive.
"Let me be clear in saying that no one has been more supportive of President Yeltsin than I," Mr. Dole said today at the opening of a two-day conference at the Nixon Center for Peace and Justice here in Washington. "In June 1991, I went to Andrews Air Force base to meet President Yeltsin virtually alone, since the United States State Department believed Gorbachev was 'the only game in town.'"
Mr. Dole said: "The Clinton Administration's misguided devotion to a 'Russia first' policy -- which has turned into a 'Yeltsin first' policy -- resulted in the loss of a tremendous opportunity to state American concerns forcefully before thousands were slaughtered in Chechnya.
"Just as it was wrong to place too much focus on Gorbachev in 1991, it is wrong in 1995 to ignore the fact that President Yeltsin has made serious errors, has moved toward authoritarian rule and has lost the political support of virtually all reform-minded Russians."
Mr. Dole declared that United States policy toward Russia should be based on a "new realism" that the two nations are rivals, with conflicting national interests.
Despite his strong words about Mr. Yeltsin, Mr. Dole characteristically avoided any discussion of what the practical political effect in Congress should be.
He did not address the volatile issue of aid to Russia, although other leading Republicans, including the Speaker of the House, Newt Gingrich, and Senator Mitch McConnell, the head of the subcommittee in charge of foreign aid, have called for withholding aid unless Mr. Yeltsin cancels a $ 1 billion deal to build nuclear reactors in Iran.
Similarly, Mr. Dole criticized the Administration's handling of the crisis in the Balkans, but did not mention a bill he introduced in January to lift the arms embargo against the Bosnian Government.
And he omitted any discussion of the United Nations and peacekeeping, the most contentious foreign policy issue of this Congress, despite the fact that he himself has introduced a bill similar to one passed last month by the House to give Congress more control over peacekeeping.
After Mr. Dole's remarks, in which he also criticized the Administration for mistakes in dealing with North Korea and Iraq, the Administration struck back.
Briefing reporters in advance of Mr. Clinton's speech before the same forum tonight, Mr. Lake said, "To state that this is a Russia-first policy or that we have somehow failed to make known our concerns on Chechnya is simply wrong." But he acknowledged that the crisis in Chechnya "has started to drive a wedge between President Yeltsin and some of the reformers," and that it is crucial that the United States try to help "Yeltsin and the reformers to come together again."
In an earlier breakfast meeting with newspaper reporters, Mr. Lake cited Mr. Yeltsin's handling of the war in Chechnya as one of the reasons President Clinton has not decided whether to attend 50th anniversary celebrations for V-E day in Moscow in May.
Explaining why the decision was so difficult, Mr. Lake cited Mr. Clinton's busy domestic schedule, adding, "We are also looking at it in the context of events there -- and I don't just mean Chechnya -- and what our allies are going to do, who is going, who isn't, et cetera. It is a complicated decision."
As for Mr. Dole's charge that the Administration was timid because it had not threatened to veto any United Nations Security Council campaign to lift economic sanctions against Iraq, Mr. Lake told reporters in his afternoon briefing that Madeleine K. Albright, the chief American representative to the United Nations, had informed other Governments that Mr. Clinton was prepared to veto such a resolution.
"We do not need lectures on how to stand up to the Iraqis," Mr. Lake said.
Like Mr. Dole, Mr. Gingrich also criticized the Administration's handling of the crisis in the Balkans.
In free-flowing extemporaneous remarks this afternoon at the conference, he said it would be "juvenile" to believe the United States could have stopped the crisis in Rwanda, praised the Administration for "a pretty good job" in curbing pirating of American goods in China and predicted that it was "possible" that the accord to end North Korea's nuclear build-up would succeed.

CORRECTION-DATE: March 4, 1995, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
Articles on Thursday and Friday about foreign policy speeches by President Clinton, Senator Bob Dole, Representative Newt Gingrich and others misidentified the Washington research center at which the remarks were delivered. It is the Nixon Center for Peace and Freedom, not the Nixon Center for Peace and Justice.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Breaking the Bank
 Barings P.L.C. left itself open to trouble. Letting a rising young trader like Nicholas W. Leeson in essence police himself showed that the firm did not have effective controls to prevent the kinds of huge trading losses that brought it down. [Page A1.] 
 Nicholas W. Leeson was detained in Frankfurt by German border police. He is expected to appear before a magistrate today. [D14.]
 ING Group is in talks to acquire the assets of Barings P.L.C. The Dutch insurance and banking giant is reportedly negotiating to pay little or nothing for the collapsed British investment firm in return for the assumption of its liabilities. [D15.]
 
Markets
 The Federal Reserve tried to stem the dollar's slide against the German mark and the Japanese yen, and was partly successful. The Fed spent an estimated $250 million to $300 million in foreign currencies to buy dollars on currency markets. [D1.]
 Blue-chip stocks declined, although they closed up from their lows. The Standard & Poor's 500 index fell 0.52 point. [D6.]
 Treasury prices fell, dragged down by the dollar's slide and the Senate's rejection of a balanced-budget amendment. [D4.]
 Cotton prices tumbled from recent records. [D5.]
 
Companies
 Abbey Healthcare and the Homedco Group will merge in a
$1 billion deal. It would create the largest company in the business of providing medical services to patients at home. [D1.]
 I.B.M.'s chief strategist will retire at the end of the month. The strategist, James A. Cannavino, 50, had once been widely considered as leading candidate to be chief executive. His announcement follows a number of other executive departures at I.B.M. [D1.]
 The S.E.C. sued Bankers Alliance and related companies that promised returns as high as 15 percent a week. [D1.]
 Most big retail chains showed lackluster gains in sales for February. But Wal-Mart said same-store sales jumped 8.4 percent, while Sears said same-store sales rose 5.4 percent. [D3.]
 The S.E.C. accused Kemper Financial Services of profiting at the expense of investors in its mutual funds. [D3.]
 Cineplex Odeon and Cinemark USA will merge in a deal valued at $450 million, forming the world's biggest theater chain. [D3.]
 W. R. Grace's chief executive resigned abruptly after heading the company for a little more than two years. The executive, J. P. Bolduc, was an architect of a huge restructuring. [D3.]
 Time Warner is among the new investors in El Diario/La Prensa, the Spanish-language daily in New York City. [D2.]
 The maker of the ATR commuter plane said it misunderstood earlier problems with icing affecting the planes. [A1.]
 
The Economy
 Wall Street lines its pockets at the expense of taxpayers, a former Smith Barney employee contends. Michael R. Lissack, who earned millions of dollars in 14 years at the firm and says he is now "ratting on the industry," has been dismissed. [D1.]
 High deposit insurance costs could lead to the failure of some weaker savings institutions, the G.A.O. reported. [D2.]
 Sales of new homes rose 3.8 percent in January, despite higher interest rates. Personal income showed a strong gain. [D6.]
 
Today's Columns
 Shares of Canandaigua Wine have improved with age. Now with shares selling at 37.2 times earnings and the company cutting costs, some suggest it may be time to sell. Market Place. [D6.]
 Toys "R" Us is seeking to reinvigorate its results with an in-store promotion called Baby Fair. The annual program will include a media partner for the first time. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D2.]

HEADLINE: Demands of Simpson Case Land Prosecutor in Custody Fight

BYLINE: By TAMAR LEWIN 

 BODY:
The long hours that Marcia Clark has worked on the O. J. Simpson murder trial have made her a famous prosecutor, but they have also sparked a custody fight.
In court papers filed last week in Los Angeles Superior Court, Ms. Clark's estranged husband, Gordon Clark, argued that he should have primary custody of their two sons, because her grueling workload was harming the boys, ages 3 and 5. 
 Mr. Clark's filing said that while he commended his wife's "brilliance, her legal ability and her tremendous competence as an attorney, I do not want our children to continue to suffer because she is never home, and never has any time to spend with them."
"I have personal knowledge that on most nights she does not arrive home until 10 P.M. and even when she is home she is working," it said.
With more two-career couples and more fathers fighting for custody, the question of how a woman balances the tugs of profession and family has become a subject of court scrutiny in many divorces.
The Clarks married in 1980 and separated in January 1994. Ms. Clark filed for divorce on June 9, just three days before the slaying of Nicole Brown Simpson, and was granted primary custody.
Mr. Clark, a 36-year-old computer engineer, said in his filing that his children were so starved for affection that when he was with them -- two evenings a week and on alternate weekends -- they did not want to let him go.
When Ms. Clark sought an increase in child support last December, she told the court she was working "a six- or seven-day week for as many as 16 hours per day" during the trial, which could last for months more.
Mr. Clark said she worked similar hours whenever she was on a trial. "There is absolutely no reason why the children should not be with me instead of continually being with baby sitters," his court papers said.
In a prepared statement issued yesterday, Ms. Clark said, "I am devoted to my two children, who are far and away more important to me than anything."
Yesterday, her boss, District Attorney Gil Garcetti of Los Angeles County, expressed outrage at news reports on "one side of a very sensitive and very private issue involving very small children" and suggested that the Simpson defense team had disclosed the custody battle to keep Ms. Clark from focusing on the murder trial.
Much of Mr. Clark's filing concerns his objections to Ms. Clark's December request for increased support payments, based on her need for more child care, and more expensive clothing and hair styling during the Simpson trial. Ms. Clark earns $96,829 a year; Mr. Clark earned $54,586 last year, according to court papers.
The California Supreme Court, like courts elsewhere, has specifically rejected the idea that working mothers are inherently bad parents. Still, divorce lawyers said that the work schedules of both mothers and fathers were often raised in custody fights and that many professional women contemplating divorce feared that their careers will count against them.
Some lawyers, and even some groups that support fathers' rights, expressed concern about Mr. Clark's filing for custody, if it is based on a temporary change in his wife's schedule.
"There shouldn't be a new battle every time there's a shift in the wind," said David L. Levy, president of the Children's Rights Council, an advocacy group in Washington. "Maybe during the trial, the parents, or a mediator, should work out that the father gets more time. But court battles are not good for kids."
Mr. Levy said that generally the recent trend toward shared custody -- the kind of arrangement the Clarks have, with both parents spending large chunks of time with the children -- has allowed many fathers to maintain an active role in their youngsters' lives.
"Fathers used to lose custody because they worked," Mr. Levy said, "but when both parents are working, who gets the kids, the baby sitter?
"In states like California, where there is joint custody, both parents can remain actively involved, which is what's best."
In September, Capitol Hill was rocked by a court decision ordering Sharon Prost, a counsel to Senator Orrin G. Hatch, to surrender her two sons to her former husband. The judge portrayed Ms. Prost as a workaholic, while her former husband was described as a doting father who put the children first.
Father's rights groups hailed that decision as a breakthrough. But many family lawyers and feminist groups maintained that the Prost case -- coming soon after a Michigan case in which a mother lost custody of her daughter because she put the child in day care while she attended college classes -- illustrated how courts hold women to a tougher standard than men.
"In the Prost case, the husband was unemployed for a substantial period, and the kids were still in day care full time," said Nancy Polikoff, who teaches family law at American University in Washington. "If a woman did that, it would count against her. But in that case it was treated as a neutral fact.
"There is a double standard. When I began going through the cases, years ago, I saw decisions where women were penalized for their work, even where the hours were not extraordinary, and their husbands were treated very differently."
Ms. Polikoff said judges should not base custody decisions simply on the number of hours a parent spends with the children.
"Many women who hold full-time or full-time-plus jobs still do most of the work of parenting," she said. "They're the ones who know what the child needs, even if they send the baby sitter to buy it.
"I'd like to know how many men have told the judge they can't stay late for a hearing because they have to get home to their kids, as Marcia Clark did last week."
On Friday, Ms. Clark told the Simpson trial judge, Lance A. Ito, that she could not stay for a proposed evening session because of her child-care needs. And when Mr. Simpson's lead trial counsel, Johnnie L. Cochran Jr., said this week that she had done so to delay the testimony of Rosa Lopez, an important defense witness, Ms. Clark angrily responded that she was "offended as a woman, as a single parent, as a prosecutor."

HEADLINE: At the Bar;
Suing dictators (and similar types) here for violations committed elsewhere.

BYLINE: By Neil A. Lewis 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Just as he was about to be handed a degree from the Kennedy School at Harvard University in 1991, Gen. Hector Gramajo was served with papers charging him in a Federal civil suit for his role in torturing people in his homeland, Guatemala.
Clad in his academic gown, General Gramajo regarded what was happening to him as a foolish affront. The next day, when he was served with a second set of papers in connection with the rape of a nun by soldiers under his command, he spat on the process server. 
 A year later, a Federal court ruled in favor of the eight Kanjobal Indians and the nun who sued with the help of human rights lawyers.
The action against General Gramajo was but one recent episode in a remarkable development in American law that has accelerated this year: the use of United States courts to enforce international human rights standards. Federal courts are being used to bring torturers and dictators in uniform to account.
In recent months there has been a series of developments in cases against a former Philippine dictator, a former Argentine police general, a former Ethiopian military commander, a former Haitian President and the leader of the Bosnian Serbs.
The phenomenon dates to 1980, when the Center for Constitutional Rights in New York won a suit on behalf of Dr. Joel Filartiga and his daughter, Dolly, who charged that a police inspector-general of Paraguay, who was then living in Brooklyn, had tortured their son and brother Joelito to death. A Federal trial judge ruled that while torture was indeed horrible, United States courts had no business getting involved when it happened elsewhere. But the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, in New York, in a landmark ruling, said such victims could seek redress in Federal courts if the torturer had taken refuge in the United States.
The principal legal basis for that case and many subsequent ones has been the Alien Tort Claims Act of 1789, enacted by the first Congress to punish piracy on the high seas.
If it seems a stretch to sue people in the United States for violations committed elsewhere, consider a scenario in which you are visiting England and are hit by a car; the driver visits the United States and you sue him here for the accident.
Perhaps you could have brought suit in England, but you choose to serve the driver while he is here on vacation. In the human rights cases, the plaintiffs are rarely able to bring suit in their home countries.
The trick is that today's global economy and the attractiveness of the United States means that many human rights defendants come here, or move some assets here.
Last month, for example, the United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit, in Atlanta, heard arguments on whether to uphold a suit brought by Edgegayehu Taye and two other Ethiopian immigrants. While working as a waitress at an Atlanta hotel, Ms. Taye saw a former Ethiopian Government official working as a bellman. The former official, she said, had supervised hours of interrogation and torture while she hung upside down from a pole in a prison in Addis Ababa.
The former official, Kelbesso Negewo, was held liable for $1.5 million in damages.
Former President Ferdinand Marcos of the Philippines, who died in 1989, brought himself and much of his fortune to the United States. Ralph G. Steinhardt of the George Washington University Law School has been both an author of an important law review article detailing how to use the Filartiga precedent, and a lawyer in one of several successful suits against Mr. Marcos for human rights violations. The suits against the Marcos estate have yielded damage awards nearing $2 billion.
Professor Steinhardt said settlement talks would be held later this month in Hong Kong among representatives for the Marcos estate, the victims and the Philippine Government, which has taken custody of many Marcos family's assets.
The main criticism of the practice of suing a dictator or torturer in the United States is that even if the lawsuit is successful, getting any money out of the defendants is rare.
But Michael Ratner of the Center for Constitutional Rights, who has been involved in many of the major lawsuits, said there are other benefits: victims feel better, and defendants suffer consequences. More important, he said, such defendants are branded as outlaws, and "can never come back to the United States or go to any country where we might collect their assets."

INDICTED OFFICER 'SYMPATHETIC FIGURE'

HEADLINE: Report From Giuliani Shows an Erosion in Some City Services

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani issued New York City's latest statistical report card on itself yesterday, and it showed an erosion of municipal services ranging from dirtier parks to bridges needing repairs, and fewer inspections for housing, recycling and drinking water.
In releasing the report, Mr. Giuliani highlighted other statistics, however, saying the survey proved his budget policies were working, making the government leaner and less expensive. And indeed the report showed improvements ranging from cleaner streets to more welfare recipients finding jobs. 
 But throughout the Mayor's Management Report there were indications that Mr. Giuliani's budget cuts over the last year -- including the reduction of 14,000 employees in the city's work force of 216,000 and the first round of a budgeted $2 billion in spending reductions -- had begun to strain the delivery of services in agency after agency.
The number of parks and playgrounds rated acceptably maintained dropped to 35 percent, from 42 percent a year ago and 52 percent under Mayor David N. Dinkins. In the Bronx, only 21 percent received a rating of acceptable. The Department of Parks and Recreation, whose staff of 2,900 was cut nearly 20 percent this year by Mr. Giuliani, also fell behind in pruning trees and removing stumps.
The number of fire hydrants broken on any given day skyrocketed to 1,237, from an average of 981 last year, while the time it takes the Department of Environmental Protection to repair major water main leaks has grown to 26 days, from 5 days, and backlogs on sewer and catch basin complaints also increased.
While one of the biggest successes of the Giuliani Administration has been the steep drop in crime, the increase in arrests has strained the legal system, the report showed. The average time between a suspect's arrest and arraignment in court has risen to 29.4 hours from 25.8 hours. By law, suspects are supposed to be arraigned within 24 hours.
Nonetheless, Mr. Giuliani, the first Republican mayor in a generation, used the report to back up his contention that his effort to slash spending and reduce the work force had not affected services as much as many elected officials and advocates had warned it would.
"I think the most remarkable thing about this report is how little effect that all had on services -- not at all the level in which people opposed to those reductions claimed, suggested or argued," Mr. Giuliani said as he unveiled the report in the old Board of Estimate chamber in City Hall.
"To the extent that there are some things that require readjustment, we'll do that," he added. "Some of the readjustments have already been made."
The report, which is required by law and has been issued twice yearly since the city's fiscal crisis of the 1970's, is the first to quantify fully the budget policies under the Administration. The last report, issued in September, covered the 1994 fiscal year, which straddled Mr. Dinkins's last year in office and Mr. Giuliani's first.
The report does not, however, reflect the second and third rounds of spending cuts -- totaling $1 billion -- that the Mayor imposed halfway through the current fiscal year. Nor does it take into account the cuts that Mr. Giuliani has proposed in his budget for the fiscal year that begins in July, which includes the deepest reduction in spending since the Great Depression.
The City Council responded by saying that the report showed the negative impact the cuts have had in many areas and underscored the need for still more careful negotiations between the Mayor and the Democrat-controlled Council as new cuts are debated.
"The statement that the Administration makes that you can cut funds and maintain services is no longer valid," said John H. Banks, the deputy director of the Council's finance division. In the budget ahead, he added, "we hope the Administration will recognize there is an impact."
The report also offered a view of the economic trends in the city. Employment in the city grew by 24,000 jobs between July and December 1994, compared with the same period a year before. The delinquency rate on property taxes, however, rose to 7.24 percent in the first four months of the fiscal year, from 5 percent, suggesting that a growing number of homeowners are struggling to make ends meet.
The city faced still more serious social burdens. The number of people receiving welfare benefits rose 11,000, to 1.15 million, while those receiving food stamps increased 21,000, to 1.44 million. The number of families seeking emergency shelter also grew.
Mr. Giuliani said the Administration was continuing to develop strategies that would streamline services and agency bureaucracies, maintaining or improving services even as he continued to cut spending.
In the report, he noted that the contract made with the sanitation workers last fall allowed the city to increase the average amount of garbage collected to 9.1 tons, from 8.3 to 8.6 tons. He also cited planned consolidations of revenue collections and the permit and licensing process in agencies like the Department of Buildings.
There was, in fact, good news in the report.
The percentage of streets rated acceptably clean, for example, rose to 74.4 percent -- to the level under Mr. Dinkins in 1993 -- after dropping to 71.6 percent last year. The Department of Transportation found that 82 percent of the city's streets were in good repair, but it also has completed far fewer repairs so far this fiscal year. The number of parking meters in working order has also declined, from 99 percent under the last year of Mr. Dinkins to 89 percent now.
The report made it clear that the reduction of workers -- planned to reach 18,000 by June -- has taken a particular toll on agencies.
The Department of Buildings, which lost 8 percent of its 654 workers a year ago, now takes an average of 21 days to examine a new building, compared with 18 days in the previous fiscal year.
A reduction of positions at the Department of Consumer Affairs has resulted in a decline in new investigations into licensing and consumer protection. Similarly, lower staffing levels have resulted in longer backlogs of complaints at the Civilian Complaint Review Board and at the Human Rights Commission.
The staff cuts in the Department of Social Services have also resulted in delays in processing new claims for public assistance, as well as the final approval of adoption of foster children.
One of the changes in the latest report is the inclusion of specific goals and objectives for each agency, providing a sort of benchmark for services in the year ahead. The report, for example, calls on the Department of Housing Preservation and Development to decrease the number of buildings under city control from 30,358 to 27,955 by the end of the fiscal year, by selling or turning them over to private hands.
Chris Meyer, a lawyer for the New York Public Interest Research Group, said the inclusion of such goals would make it easier to evaluate a mayor's policies in the future. In the meantime, he said, the latest report card played down the negative impact of cuts, in part by leaving out some indicators that reports in the past included.
"This report is business as usual: Bury the bad news," he said.

HEADLINE: A G.O.P. Attack Hits Bit Too Close to Home

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SEATTLE, March 2

 BODY:
Sacred cows, it has been said, make the tastiest hamburger. But Representative Scott L. Klug of Wisconsin may have given his fellow Republicans in Congress more than they can chew with his crusade to eliminate subsidies that have gone untouched for nearly half a century.
From helium reserves in Texas to dairy price supports in his own state, Mr. Klug has taken literally his assignment by Speaker Newt Gingrich of Georgia to come up with a list of things that Government should not be doing. 
 Nowhere has he stirred up more trouble than in the Northwest, where nine new Republicans were swept into Congress last fall on a unified promise to reduce government. They abruptly lost their enthusiasm for the task when Mr. Klug proposed to get rid of the ultimate sacred cow in their region: low-cost electric power furnished by Federal dams.
In proposing to sell off the Bonneville Power Administration, which provides some of the nation's cheapest electricity to more than half of the 10 million residents of the Pacific Northwest, Mr. Klug argues that the Federal Government should not be in the utility business. Selling Bonneville, and the four agencies in other regions that market and transmit electricity, could bring in about $5 billion, he says.
Mr. Klug has also introduced a separate bill to sell the Tennessee Valley Authority, the nation's largest utility. Both proposals, some Democrats say, have exposed a vein of hypocrisy among Republicans who are zealous for every form of Federal reduction except as it relates to their own districts.
"This is a fundamentally Republican argument," said Mr. Klug, who was a television investigative reporter in Seattle before returning to his native Wisconsin more than 10 years ago. "And anyone who is intellectually honest about this has to question programs in their own backyard, like subsidies to the dairy industry in my own state."
The test for Mr. Klug on this issue will be when the farm programs, which make up about $12 billion in subsidies, come up for renewal in Congress this year.
Last fall, Idaho, Oregon and Washington sent nine new Republicans to Congress, all saying it was time to eliminate some of the major functions of the Government. Representative Linda Smith, for example, who defeated a liberal Democrat to take a seat in southwest Washington, has called for the elimination of four Cabinet-level departments and for deep cuts in welfare and support for the arts.
But last month, Mrs. Smith and the other freshmen Republicans from the Northwest put up a solid wall of opposition to Mr. Klug's suggestion that the power agency be sold. Aluminum factories in Mrs. Smith's district, which rely on the Federal dams for low-cost electricity, and residents would be severely hurt by higher rates that would likely follow a sale, she said.
"I've always supported privatization," Mrs. Smith said, "but not if it's going to destroy the economy of our region." She said two-thirds of the basic industries and 80 percent of the residents of her district would be affected by the sale.
Electricity in the Northwest, most of it generated by Federal dams along the Columbia River, costs residents about $1 a day, less than half the national rate, according to Federal figures.
"From a national perspective," Mr. Klug said, "many more people will win if we privatize these agencies. What you've done is given certain corners of the country a permanent advantage. Maybe selling Bonneville would raise rates in the Northwest, but it might reduce rates in California."
By law, Bonneville, the nation's largest power marketing agency, cannot raise electric rates beyond what it needs to cover its costs. It owns about 15,000 miles of high-voltage transmission lines and acts as the wholesale marketer of power from 30 Federal dams and a nuclear plant.
"The Pacific Northwest is very much a creation of the Federal Government," said Steve Forrester, an editor of a political newsletter about the Northwest based in Astoria, Ore. "Without the dams, which in turn brought aluminum factories, and Boeing, and big-time farms, we wouldn't be where we are. What you had before the dams was basically an agrarian economy."
The dams also led to the decimation of Pacific salmon, which die in the dam's turbines. In trying to restore those salmon runs, as required by Federal law, Bonneville is spending more money per year -- an average of nearly $300 million -- than the entire budget of the National Marine Fisheries Service.
In an incidental way, the fight over saving Bonneville has made Republicans allies of the Endangered Species Act. Northwest Republicans are working hard to weaken the law. But they also argue that no private company would want to buy Bonneville because of the headache of having to restore the salmon. In essence, they say, the law is protecting Bonneville from being sold.
"I don't think you could find a buyer," said Representative Jennifer Dunn, Republican of Washington. "There are so many complications."
Ms. Dunn has picked one of her first philosophical fights with fellow Republicans in the battle over Bonneville. "I normally agree with Scott Klug on 9 out of 10 of his suggestions," Ms. Dunn said.
She said taxpayers would get a better deal if the debt left over from the half-century of building the dams -- nearly $7 billion, owed by Bonneville to the Treasury -- were refinanced from its low interest rates to a higher market rate. That would bring new payments to the Treasury of nearly $45 million a year, she said.
Two months ago, the Clinton Administration floated the idea of selling the agency but has since changed its mind.
Representative Peter A. DeFazio, Democrat of Oregon, said: "We had a rather angry meeting with members of the Administration. When logic failed, we used the political argument that if they wanted to alienate the few remaining Democrats in Congress from the Northwest, fine, sell Bonneville."
Mr. DeFazio, backed by Republicans from this region, has challenged Mr. Klug to a debate on the merits of selling Bonneville. Mr. Klug has accepted.
"There are certain things that the Government does well and are unique functions of Government," Mr. DeFazio said. "And, it's a myth that people up here are getting all this cheap electric power and they aren't paying for it. We do pay for it. The Government is getting paid back every penny."
Mr. Klug says that, thus far, he has not been persuaded to back down. "All these things are said to be sacrosanct," he said. "But we've got to send a clear signal that the climate has changed."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls to New Low and Fed Intervenes

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 2

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve stepped in to prop up the dollar on international currency markets today, in a partly successful effort to halt the dollar's monthlong slide against the Japanese yen and the German mark.
The dollar touched a record low of 94.90 yen today, before the Fed began spending foreign currencies to buy dollars on currency markets in the afternoon. 
 Traders and analysts, seeking to explain today's sharp drop, cited rumors about the investment policies of a Japanese savings institution, large "sell" orders by an unidentified large bank and comments by a senior Fed official, Lawrence B. Lindsey.
Mr. Lindsey told Jiji Press, a Japanese news agency, in an interview late Wednesday afternoon that he did not believe the dollar had fallen to crucial levels against the yen. Electronic news services began reporting on the interview early this morning.
Some traders interpreted Mr. Lindsey's comment as a crucial signal that the Fed would not intervene to support the dollar. But other traders dismissed the impact of the remark, noting that it came many hours before the dollar began to sink quickly.
The dollar partly recovered when the Fed began buying dollars, but then it drifted lower again. In late afternoon trading in New York, it stood at 95.22 yen, down from 96.76 yen on Wednesday. The dollar also fell against the mark, to 1.4435 marks from 1.4622 marks.
David DeRosa, director of foreign exchange trading in New York for the Swiss Bank Corporation, said the dollar remained weak after the intervention by the Fed. "It still doesn't look so good," he said.
Currency traders said the intervention was conducted on a fairly modest scale by the Fed's standards, with one currency dealer estimating that the Fed bought $250 million to $300 million of dollars. The dealer, who insisted on anonymity, said that with the possible exception of the Bank of Japan, foreign central banks did not participate in the intervention today.
By contrast, the Fed spent $2.6 billion the last time it intervened, on Nov. 2, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York recently disclosed. Today the Fed followed its policy of declining to comment on currency movements in progress.
Some analysts said the broader trend of a falling dollar reflected a growing view among investors that the Fed would not raise interest rates again soon as the American economy slowed. That has made the higher interest rates in Europe seem more attractive.
The Treasury Department asked the Fed to intervene, said a Treasury official who declined to discuss the scale of the intervention.
The intervention today is politically awkward for the Clinton Administration, because the United States is partly using money from the Exchange Stabilization Fund -- the same fund from which the Administration plans to make up to $20 billion in loans to prop up the Mexican peso. The Treasury Department has been trying to reassure Democratic and Republican members of Congress in the last month that there is plenty of money in the $36 billion fund to help Mexico and still support the dollar when necessary.
The expectations of traders for little change in American interest rates were based in large part on comments made last week by the chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, to the Senate Banking Committee that the Fed might reduce interest rates if the economy ran into trouble. While Mr. Greenspan did not rule out further increases in interest rates if the economy remained strong, his comments were interpreted as a signal that the Fed would not act to do so again soon.
The main effect that economists fear from a falling currency is higher inflation, as imports become more expensive. But economists played down the possibility that the drop of the dollar today against the German and Japanese currencies would lead to rising prices in the United States.
They pointed out that the dollar remained strong against the currencies of some of the nation's biggest trading partners, like Canada and Mexico.
"It's much more accurate and revealing to portray this as the German mark and the yen being strong -- just ask a Mexican if the dollar is weak, or ask a Canadian," said Neal M. Soss, an economic consultant in New York.

HEADLINE: Fred J. Borch, 84, Chairman Of General Electric in 1960's

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
Fred J. Borch, who was chairman of the General Electric Company for 10 years in the 1960's and early 1970's, died on Wednesday at age 84 in the Moorings Park Health Center near Naples, Fla.
The cause of death was heart disease, Joyce Hergenhan, a spokeswoman for the company, said. 
 Mr. Borch was chief executive of the diversified products company from 1963 to 1972, when he stepped down at age 62.
During his tenure, G.E.'s sales doubled, from less than $5 billion to more than $10 billion, and its earnings increased to $530 million, from $272 million. In achieving these increases, he chose to make big investments in computers, nuclear power and commercial jet engines.
Not all of them were successful. G.E. has become the largest supplier of jet engines to airlines, but the company abandoned the computer business and greatly scaled back its nuclear power operations.
Mr. Borch was born on April 28, 1910, in Brooklyn, where his father was an electrical engineer with Brooklyn Edison, a company that was later absorbed into the Consolidated Edison Company. In 1918, The family moved to Ohio, and most of his education took place in the Cleveland area.
He joined General Electric's light bulb business in 1931 after graduating from what is now Case Western Reserve University with a bachelor's degree in economics. In 1954, he was named vice president for marketing services. He was named vice president of the company's consumer products group in 1959, and executive vice president for worldwide operations in 1962.
He became president and chief executive in 1963 and moved up to chairman in 1968.
During the time he was chief executive, G.E.'s headquarters were in Manhattan, and Mr. Borch was active in civic affairs as a member of the Committee for Economic Development, the Industry Council of New York and the Center for Inter-American Relations. He was chairman of the Business Council in 1969 and 1970.
Mr. Borch married Martha Kananen in 1934; she died in 1969. In 1970, he married the former Lucia McNutt Lowles, who died in 1992.
He is survived by a daughter, Kay B. Otterstrum of Brentwood, Tenn., and a son, Richard F. Borch of Pittsford, N.Y.; four grandchildren, and three stepsons, David Lowles of San Jose, Calif, Thomas Lowles of Lake Oswego, Ore., and Alan Lowles of Canandaigua, N.Y.

HEADLINE: Accuser in the Muni Bond Industry

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT 

 BODY:
In 14 years at Smith Barney, Michael R. Lissack earned millions of dollars. He advised local governments on bond issues worth tens of billions. And, he contends, he helped Wall Street line its pockets at the expense of taxpayers.
Last month, according to Mr. Lissack, he told his bosses at Smith Barney that he would no longer remain silent in grand jury testimony about what he considered the firm's misdeeds. He was dismissed. 
 Mr. Lissack contends that Smith Barney -- along with other securities firms -- often charged artificially high and potentially illegal prices for securities that they sold to local governments in complex bond deals. The extra markups were a big profit generator for many firms' municipal bond departments in the early 1990's, he says. But, he adds, those profits resulted in losses to the Treasury of hundreds of millions of dollars.
Mr. Lissack said he called officials in the Justice Department at the end of 1993 to alert them to some little-known practices in the municipal bond market.
Since then, he said, his personal life has been turned upside down. His talks with the department were interrupted by a bout of severe depression, a suicide attempt and a divorce. He took a six-month leave of absence from his firm.
In the meantime, Mr. Lissack has received four Federal subpoenas to present testimony and has been granted immunity from prosecution for anything he may disclose.
"I'm ratting on the industry," Mr. Lissack said earlier this week before he testified to a grand jury in Boston looking into bond deals in that state.
Smith Barney denied all allegations of wrongdoing by Mr. Lissack. Robert Conner, a Smith Barney spokesman, described Mr. Lissack as a once "brilliant" banker with personal problems who became disgruntled with reductions in his pay and responsibilities.
Government regulators have not made any formal accusations against investment firms for their role in operations described by Mr. Lissack. But they are clearly interested in Mr. Lissack's testimony about an arcane side of the bond business that they acknowledge they had long neglected.
In contrast, the Justice Department and the Securities and Exchange Commission are aggressively pursuing charges that Wall Street firms made improper payments to local government officials or others to gain preference in issuing new bonds. Last week, Joseph C. Salema, who was chief of staff to Gov. Jim Florio of New Jersey in 1990, pleaded guilty to securities fraud for sharing in $200,000 in kickbacks from a large New Jersey bank.
The story Mr. Lissack has to tell is more complicated than straightforward bribery. But it involves far more money than the sums Wall Street showered on politicians.
The handling of the special accounts "has been one of the most lucrative parts of the municipal bond business for years," said Christopher A. Taylor, executive director of the Municipal Securities Rulemaking Board.
According to experts in municipal finance, the way in which Smith Barney and other prominent firms on Wall Street invested the proceeds of many new bond issues accounted for half or more of all their profit in the municipal bond market.
Essentially, the securities firms are exploiting Federal tax laws aimed at preventing local governments from earning too much interest on the proceeds of tax-exempt bonds they have sold. In the process of refunding old, high-interest bonds, local governments put the proceeds of new, lower-rate issues into temporary escrow accounts. Those accounts consist of securities that cannot reap a higher return than the new bonds' interest rates.
Commonly, the issuers buy a mix of ordinary Treasury securities and special zero-interest or very-low-interest Treasury paper issued specifically for escrow accounts. But the securities firms sometimes sold Treasuries to the accounts at artificially high prices, creating a profit for themselves that would otherwise have gone to the Federal Government.
The practice -- known in the industry as "burning yield" -- is illegal only if the prices charged for Treasury notes and bills are unfair. It is Mr. Lissack's contention that securities firms often do charge unfair prices but get opinions from outside firms that they are, in fact, reasonable.
"Securities firms would write the opinions for each other," Mr. Lissack said in an interview. "We even kept track of who we did opinions for and who owed us." He contended that, when he wrote opinions, he insisted on limiting the markup to a single "point," or $10 per $1,000 bond.
While the written opinions were required to satisfy lawyers, Mr. Lissack said, few of them would stand up to close scrutiny. "Few people would look at the numbers to see what was really going on," he said. If they did, he said, they would see that providing securities for the escrow account was a more profitable activity than the underwriting and selling of the new bonds.
For underwriting new issues, securities firms earn roughly $8 for every $1,000 bond. But that fee has to be divided among different firms, which must share their cut with brokers who sell the bonds to investors. By contrast, when a firm marks up the prices of escrow securities, also typically by around $8 per $1,000, it keeps the entire amount.
In defense of the marked-up prices dealers say that the higher prices are needed to protect themselves from the risk that for some reason, the new bond issue might be canceled and they would have to buy back the escrow securities.
Mr. Lissack contended that this risk was grossly overstated. As proof, he pointed to the willingness of dealers to keep their markups below $1 per $1,000 bond for larger, more astute borrowers such as New York City that insist on playing by the rules.
In one case where local government officials did pay attention, they did not like what they saw. A memo on Oct. 21, 1992, by the staff of the Kentucky State Office of Financial Management and Economic Analysis said that the investment firm Lazard Freres refused state officials' request for bids from at least three underwriters and insisted that it be the sole provider of securities for an escrow account. Then, the memo states, when Lazard proposed a price list, a Kentucky official got quotes from another firm that were as much as $6 cheaper per $1,000 bond. In response, Lazard said the National Association of Securities Dealers had investigated the bond deal and had given the firm a clean bill of health.
Federal regulators, intrigued by Mr. Lissack's accusations, say they are increasing their scrutiny of the way money from municipal and state escrow accounts is invested. Officials at the Securities and Exchange Commission recently asked the staff at the Municipal Securities Rulemaking Board to start making proposals that would require the public disclosure of who is handling escrow accounts and how much they are being paid.
Richard A. Walker, regional administrator of the S.E.C.'s New York office, said the commission wanted to know more about the handling of the escrow accounts. Another regulator, who requested anonymity, said fuller disclosure would make it harder for Wall Street firms to make improper payments to public officials. "When there is so much money sloshing around and being poured from one bucket to another, some of it is sure to spill," he said.
Mr. Lissack said his motivation was a mixture of revenge and a desire to help correct some improper practices.
"I'm doing a Samson -- blowing out of the industry and pulling down the walls as I leave," he said, mocking his baldness and imagining the turmoil his actions could cause. He readily admits that he feels wronged by Smith Barney, which reduced his bonus last year to $60,000 from $465,000 in 1993 and cut back on his duties "so that there would be no way I could perform and maintain my earnings."
"I might as well help clean up the industry on my way out the door," he said, adding that he hoped the publicity he generated would attract a publisher to a book of social criticism he has written and a novel he has in the works.
Even greater riches are possible if Mr. Lissack's information about escrow arrangements in refunding bond deals enables the Federal Government to collect fines against various securities firms. When asked if he has filed a lawsuit under the Federal False Claims Act, which rewards informants who help the Government recover funds owed it, Mr. Lissack declined to comment.
That law pays whistle-blowers 15 to 30 percent of the money the Government recovers as a result of their information. Whistle-blower lawsuits are sealed by the courts and claimants forbidden to discuss them.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Michael R. Lissack has found himself in a fight with Smith Barney. (Michael Quan for The New York Times)
 
Chart: "Turning Bond Escrow Into Big Profits"
 
1. NEW BONDS FOR OLD
 New municipal bonds are often issued to refinance old ones. Usually there are restrictions on when the old bonds can be "called" or retired early, so the issuer may have to wait a while before using the new bond proceeds to retire the old bonds. During that time the money remains in escrow, earning interest.
 
2. AIMING LOW
 Under Federal law, the escrow account cannot be allowed to earn a higher return than the interest rate paid by the new bonds. Municipal bonds generally pay lower interest rates than most other kinds of investments, so the underwriters are faced with the unusual job of making sure the escrow money earns a below-market return.
 
3. MIXING IN SLUGS
 To keep the escrow account's return low, the funds are invested in a portfolio combining ordinary Treasury bonds with special Treasury bonds called slugs that pay little or no interest. Slugs, short for State and Local Government Series, exist only for this purpose, and since they provide money to the government very cheaply, they are a boon for the Treasury. Holdings of the two kinds of securities are mixed so that the yield is no greater than the interest cost of the new bonds.
 
4. BUMP THE BONDS, SKIMP ON THE SLUGS
 The proportion of slugs to ordinary Treasuries needed for a given escrow portfolio depends on the yield of the Treasuries, and that is where the potential trouble lies. A Wall Street firm could sell Treasuries to the escrow account at an artificially high price, keeping the markup as a profit. The higher price makes the yield on the bonds lower, so the escrow portfolio needs fewer slugs to bring its average yield under the legal maximum.
 
5. WHO WINS, WHO LOSES
 Using this tactic, an underwriter might make $8 or $9 on each $1,000 of Treasury bonds sold to the escrow account, instead of the $1 or $2 per $1,000 if the bonds had been priced fairly. The loser is the Treasury, which is denied the benefit of some low-cost money it should have been loaned in the form of slugs. The original issuer of the new municipal bonds neither gains or loses.

HEADLINE: Sales of New Homes Rose 3.8% in January

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 2

 BODY:
Sales of new homes rose in January despite higher interest rates, while the incomes of Americans posted a solid advance that exceeded increases in spending.
Nevertheless, analysts said the economy was slowing and there was little cause for financial markets to worry that overheating would generate inflation. 
 The Commerce Department said today that sales of new homes rose 3.8 percent in January to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 679,000, the highest in three months.
"It's fairly strong, but it's off the peak," said Cynthia Latta, an economist for DRI-McGraw Hill, a forecasting firm in Lexington, Mass. Adjustable-rate mortgages have helped the market, she said, as has warmer-than-usual weather.
But she noted that another report this week showed that sales of existing homes dropped in January to their lowest level in nearly two years and that housing starts were also down. "We're on a slowing growth track," she said.
Jim Irvine, president of the National Association of Home Builders, agreed. "It's kind of an erratic spike in the numbers," he said. "All the trends indicate there is a loss of momentum."
Thirty-year fixed-rate mortgages averaged 9.15 percent in January, but have since fallen to less than 9 percent. The rates are still up from less than 7 percent before the Federal Reserve began forcing up interest rates in early 1994.
A jump from 7 percent to 9 percent would add $209 to the monthly payment on a $150,000 mortgage.
In another report, the Labor Department said the number of new claims for jobless benefits fell 13,000 last week to a seasonally adjusted 331,000.
The income gain in January, although no surprise, was the biggest in three months. It was more than twice the four-tenths of 1 percent increase in spending.
Analysts pointed to a drop of 1 percent in spending for big-ticket durable goods as a sign that the economy was cooling, even though the durable-goods decline was more than offset by higher spending for services and nondurable goods like food and fuel.
The latest spending data point to "a sharp slowdown in the first quarter," said Bruce Steinberg of Merrill Lynch & Company. "February consumer spending will probably also be roughly flat."
Consumer spending represents two-thirds of the country's economic activity and has been a key to recent robust growth.
Bolstering the new income figures were earnings for overtime and some special factors, including raises for Federal workers and cost-of-living increases that drove up benefits.
The Commerce Department said incomes climbed seven-tenths of 1 percent in December, revised from an earlier estimate of eight-tenths of 1 percent. Spending increased one-tenth of 1 percent in December.
Disposable income -- income after taxes -- rose seven-tenths of 1 percent in January after gaining eight-tenths of 1 percent the previous month.
The combination of incomes and spending meant that Americans' savings rate climbed to 5 percent of disposable income in December, from 4.7 percent the previous month. The savings rate is the highest in nearly two years.
Income rose to $5.94 trillion in January and spending was at $4.77 trillion.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices Drop After Senate Vote

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities dropped yesterday, as the market reacted to the falling dollar and the Senate's failure to pass a balanced-budget amendment.
Anthony Chan, vice president and chief economist at Banc One Investment Advisors Corporation in Columbus, Ohio, noted that even if it had been approved, the amendment would face years of consideration by state legislatures before passage. 
 Still, he said, the defeat yesterday sent a message to the market "that the institution that controls the purse strings is not willing to risk its neck to save us from the eight-foot waves of red ink that will be coming in the future." Mr. Chan added, "It is this sobering message to bond market participants that has pushed bond market prices to these lofty levels in recent weeks."
Another negative factor was the dollar's slide against the German mark and the Japanese yen, after Lawrence B. Lindsey, a Federal Reserve governor, told Bloomberg Business News that he was surprised by the dollar's decline in currency markets. Mr. Lindsey rejected the idea that the Fed should intervene in the markets to stabilize the dollar's value, suggesting that the markets should set prices, including exchange rates.
Traders said the only thing that had been protecting the dollar lately had been concern about intervention, and that faded away with Mr. Lindsey's remarks. When the dollar is weak, dollar-denominated investments like Treasury securities become less attractive to foreign investors.
Fresh economic data may also have slightly influenced traders. Sales of single-family homes for January rose a stronger-than-expected 3.8 percent, to 679,000, the Commerce Department reported. Analysts said the strong number seemed to contradict speculation about higher interest rates slowing down the housing market.
However, the market largely ignored the weekly jobless claims and the January personal income and expenditure figures, which came in as expected.
The 30-year bond fell 15/32 , to a price of 10123/32 for a yield of 7.48 percent, up from 7.44 percent on Wednesday.
"The economic numbers were strong," Mr. Chan said. "It means we are continuing to get mixed signals from economic indicators, and I think this mix proves beyond a reasonable doubt that the economy will be a little strong in the first half of this year and then slow significantly in the second half."
He said he thought this would reduce the probability of a near-term Fed tightening, though the central bank would still have to tighten at least one more time to insure that the whole process of slowing the economy continues smoothly.
The Treasury yesterday sold $17.25 billion of new one-year bills in auction at an average rate of 6.16 percent, down from 6.59 percent last month and the lowest since November, when it was 6.09 percent.
Elsewhere, municipal bond prices also tracked Treasury securities lower, although few bonds were traded. Investors have apparently begun to question whether the three-month-old rally in the municipal market will last. The short supply of new issues has generally kept municipal bonds from falling less than Treasury securities.
