HEADLINE: PRO FOOTBALL;
Deal With Browns? Simms Passes, for Now

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY W. SMITH, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BEREA, Ohio, March 2

 BODY:
The white Cleveland Browns banner with the orange helmet was raised to half-staff behind a dais that contained four chairs. The team's owner, Art Modell, vacationing in Florida, had done a dry run on the telephone that was placed on the table in front of the chairs.
Inside a makeshift sound stage complete with klieg lights at the team's practice facility here, the scene was set, literally, for the Browns to announce the signing of Phil Simms, the 39-year-old former Giants quarterback. 
 At 5:10 P.M. today -- 40 minutes after the Browns had scheduled a news conference -- Mike Lombardi, the team's director of player personnel, and David Fishof, Simms's agent, emerged through a back door and took their seats. Bill Belichick, wearing a brown suit -- a rarity for the Browns' head coach -- stood at the door.
Simms was not there.
Then, without fanfare, Fishof and Lombardi sheepishly announced that after two hours of touring the facility and talking numbers, there was no deal. Belichick slipped out the door. After being out of football for a full year, Simms is still an ESPN television analyst. For now.
"I'll take a wild stab at speculating that maybe economics had something to do with it," Modell said.
Apparently, the two sides are hung up over the financial terms and structure of the contract. Modell said the breakdown was on Simms's side.
"It's an honest difference of opinion on both sides," Modell said. "Nothing criminal about what they're doing. They're really good people."
Fishof would not discuss the specific disagreements.
Later, Simms said that while he didn't know if he was going to be announced as a backup to the Browns' starter, Vinny Testaverde, he wanted to meet the news media in Cleveland and tell them that he wanted to join the team.
"Yeah, I am disappointed, absolutely," Simms said, regarding the strange turn of events, after widespread reports and bulletins and talk-show chat about him wearing a Cleveland uniform next season.
It all seemed to indicate that Simms and the Browns had reached a tentative agreement and that his trip here was merely a formality of signing on the dotted line. Simms met with Belichick in New Jersey at a hotel in Hackensack. Belichick, an assistant coach under Bill Parcells during Simms's glory years with the Giants, convinced him to visit the Browns and try to work out a deal.
Simms, who had shoulder surgery last March, thought about it for a day, liked the idea of returning to football and traveled to Cleveland this afternoon on a private jet. Obviously, concrete numbers were not discussed before Fishof and Lombardi met.
Maybe they should have. But the two sides said the visit was nothing more than a feeling-out process, much the same as every free agent is going through right now.
"Phil and I came here to work out an agreement with the Cleveland Browns," Fishof said. "We were here for a couple of hours touring the facility and talking and we couldn't reach an agreement."
Fishof and Lombardi promised to pick up the negotiations on Friday morning by telephone. Simms and Fishof returned to New York.
"Like any deal, some take longer than others," Lombardi said. "We understand the parameters. We have to work some kinks out in terms of salaries."
Lombardi later added: "We wanted to bring Phil in and show him the facilities and talk formally with David. We expected David to go back and think about it."
Fishof would not talk about the financial differences. Early last season, Simms considered playing for Arizona. After a weekend of hot and heavy negotiations, the deal stalled. The Cardinals offered him $1 million a year as a starter. Simms wanted $3 million over two years and he wanted most of it up front.
That kind of money could be stalling the deal for the Browns, especially if Simms wants most of it up front and especially if Cleveland views him as a backup. The Browns signed Mark Rypien as a backup last year and paid him a base of $950,000. Now, Rypien is a free agent.
"Unequivocally our only interest in Phil is as a backup," Modell said. "Just like Mark Rypien was last year. I want to make that crystal clear. Vinny knows that. Bill knows that. Art Modell knows that."
Does Modell, who said he has high regard for Simms, think a deal can be struck within 24 hours?
"I don't think anything will be done within the next 24 hours," he said. "That doesn't mean it can't happen within the next 48 hours."
Fishof said: "We'll work our hardest to try to get it done. There's no sense of there being a deadline."
 
Redskins Sign a Cowboy
 ASHBURN, Va., March 2 (AP) -- James Washington, a safety and one of the stars in the Dallas Super Bowl victory two years ago, signed with the Washington Redskins today.
Washington, a seven-year pro, joins the N.F.L.'s second-worst defense with a three-year contract worth $4.5 million, according to his agent, Ted Updike.

HEADLINE: Home Video

BYLINE: By Peter M. Nichols 

 BODY:
Most straight-to-video movies are clearly just that, but now and then one comes along that starts arguments. In December, for example, Turner released "The Desperate Trail" on videocassette without a run in movie theaters. The move still angers the movie's director, P. J. Pesce. It also still makes perfect sense to Turner.
Between the two viewpoints lies an interesting case history. A gritty and bloody western, "The Desperate Trail" won Mr. Pesce the award for best director at the Hamptons International Film Festival last fall and earned favorable reviews, if not raves. Some critics said they were reminded of the work of Howard Hawks and Sergio Leone. 
 The movie stars Sam Elliott, who is appreciated by video dealers for his western roles, and Craig Sheffer, another popular actor. What's more, "The Desperate Trail" also stars Linda Fiorentino, who recently won the New York Film Critics Circle award as best actress for her role in "The Last Seduction" and may be the hottest female star in movies today.
In October, "The Last Seduction," directed by John Dahl, opened to acclaim in theaters. Two months later, "The Desperate Trail" appeared in video stores. Mr. Pesce says that film, too, should have opened in theaters. "Turner had no idea who Linda Fiorentino was," he says.
Turner, he adds, was only interested in Mr. Elliott and home video. In 1993 Mr. Pesce was shooting "The Desperate Trail" when the project ran out of money. "I would have dealt with Satan," he says.
Instead, along came Turner Home Entertainment, which bought out the $2.4 million film with, Mr. Pesce says, the stated intention of showing it on TNT, a Turner cable television network. Later, he says, Turner decided the film wasn't heroic or moralistic enough for television and consigned it to video stores.
Turner never pursued a theater release but allowed the film's producers to seek one on their own. Then, Mr. Pesce says, Turner turned down all offers from distributors.
Stuart Snyder, a Turner senior vice president, says the company was well aware of Ms. Fiorentino and other attributes of "The Desperate Trail," but these factors weren't reasons to change plans. In any event, because Ms. Fiorentino's success in "Seduction" and the "Trail" video release came virtually on top of each other, there wouldn't have been time.
"It's great to play Monday morning quarterback, but the planning stage for video comes six months before release," he says.
As a video title, Mr. Snyder adds, the tape ranks No. 4 in number of rentals per cassette.
Allen Sabinson, TNT's senior vice president of programming, says the company's plan for the film was always home video first and television second, with no provision for movie theaters.
"We let P. J. and the producers screen this for possible theatrical distribution," Mr. Sabinson says. "There was some moderate interest, but nothing that made economic sense to us. Whatever possibilities existed, they weren't sufficiently attractive to go off our game plan."
"The Desperate Trail" will be shown on TNT in July, he says.
 
NEW VIDEO RELEASES
 
The Lion King
1994. Disney. $26.99. 88 minutes. Closed-captioned. G.
Without a classic fairy tale to adapt (Snow White's, for example), the Disney team makes up a story of its own about a little lion who grows into his job as king of the jungle. Disney may be no Brothers Grimm, but the vibrant animation more than compensates for the obviously calculating turns of plot. Young Simba (the voice of Jonathan Taylor Thomas) withstands the loss of his father (James Earl Jones) and the schemes of his Uncle Scar (Jeremy Irons) to become an adult (Matthew Broderick) and ruler. In the end, this is a film, Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times, "contrived with a spirited, animal-loving prettiness that no child will resist."
 
Sunday's Children
1993. First Run Features. $59.95. 118 minutes. Swedish with English subtitles. No rating.
Daniel Bergman makes fine work of a screenplay by his father, Ingmar, that has strains of other films directed or written by the elder Bergman. Central to this film is the relationship between a boy named Pu (Henrik Linnros) and his loving but remote father (Thommy Berggren), a clergyman and pastor to the Swedish royal family. In rich scenes of country life, Pu and his siblings endure their little wars. Darker are the quarrels between his parents, and darker still is the bond between father and son. What results may not be so novelistic as other Bergman films, but it is "so full of mirrors, so magically placed, that the film manages to reflect the future while also revealing new interpretations of the past" (Vincent Canby).
 
Andre
1994. Paramount. $95.92. Laser disk, $34.98. 94 minutes. Closed-captioned. PG.
With a nod to "Free Willy," this film by George Miller chronicles the adventures of a runaway seal and the hearty Maine folk who love the creature and wait for its return. Little Toni Whitney (Tina Majorino) faithfully stands by with a bucket of fish while her father (Keith Carradine), a hearty harbor master, combs local waters and asks things like "What're you tryin' to tell me, Andre?" Compared to the seal, though, "none of the human actors in this too-too-cute family film has a flipper to stand on" (Maslin).
 
Princess Caraboo
1994. Columbia Tri-Star. $95.92. Laser disk, $34.95. 96 minutes. Closed-captioned. PG.
The year is 1817, and in Bristol, England, a penniless young woman (Phoebe Cates) wearing a turban and calling herself Caraboo is taken into a high-born household on the strength of her claim that she is the daughter of a king. "I know you are an impostor and I spit in your soup," hisses an imperious butler (Kevin Kline). Investigating the case are a dogged reporter named Gutch (Stephen Rea) and an Oxford professor (John Lithgow) who falls in love with Caraboo in a "gentle, charming family comedy, a romp whose strength is in its enchanting cast" (Caryn James).

HEADLINE: More S.& L. Failures Are Seen by Agency

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 2

 BODY:
The General Accounting Office said today that high deposit insurance costs could lead to the failure of some of the nation's weaker savings institutions, prompting two senior members of Congress to declare that Congress should act to prevent it.
The two, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, the New York Republican who is the chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, and Representative John J. LaFalce, a New York Democrat who is a senior member of the House Banking Committee, did not propose any immediate remedies. 
 But Mr. D'Amato said: "I am concerned that another thrift crisis is looming on the horizon. This poses an ominous development for the American taxpayer if Congress is not able to correct this potential problem."
The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation is preparing to cut bank insurance premiums to 4 cents for every $100 of deposits by the end of this year, but plans to leave savings and loan premiums at 24 cents for every $100 of deposits until at least 2002.
The savings industry's insurance fund has not yet recovered from the collapses of the 1980's, while the banking industry's insurance fund has done so. Officials worry that the disparity between the fees will undermine savings institutions.
In response to the gap, the Great Western Financial Corporation, the nation's second-largest savings and loan, said on Wednesday that it would seek to avoid the higher costs by applying for bank charters and opening bank offices in its savings and loan branches.
Great Western, of Chatsworth, Calif., said that it was seeking national bank charters in California and Florida so as to take advantage of the lower deposit insurance rates available for banks.
While such a move could cut costs for individual financial institutions, it could compound the problem for the remaining savings and loans, since fewer deposits would be assessed premiums for their insurance fund.
All possible solutions to the deposit insurance problem have powerful opponents. The banking industry, for example, strongly opposes any merger of the two deposit insurance funds.
Representative LaFalce said that the solution of merging the funds "might be the best one ideally, but it might be the most difficult one politically."
James Chessen, the chief economist at the American Bankers Association, criticized the idea of a merger. "There's absolutely no justification to asking the banking industry to bail out the obligations of a primary competitor," he said.
The accounting office warned of possible trouble if the F.D.I.C. lowers deposit insurance premiums for banks and not for savings institutions. "The cost increase associated with the premium rate differential would increase the losses of institutions already experiencing losses," the report said. "Prolonged periods of losses deplete institution capital and can lead eventually to failure."
Federal law virtually requires the F.D.I.C. to reduce bank deposit insurance premiums once the bank fund reaches a certain level. The F.D.I.C. estimated in January that the fund would reach this level late this summer.
The savings industry insurance fund has only begun to recover from the financial scars of the 1980's. The industry is shrinking and nearly half of its insurance premiums each year are used to pay interest on bonds that were issued as part of the Government takeover of failed savings institutions. The bank insurance fund has no comparable liability.
Executives at surviving savings institutions say they should have no special responsibility for a problem created by failed institutions.

SECTION: Section A; Page 26; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 537 words

HEADLINE: A Bad Idea, Buried

 BODY:
The Senate's rejection of the balanced-budget amendment by a narrow margin yesterday provides cheering evidence that Senate Democrats have the capacity to stop the worst excesses of the Republican revolution in the House. The proposed amendment was foolish and fiscally reckless when it emerged from the House; it became a cynical charade through last-minute tinkering designed to secure passage in the Senate.
The amendment was always cursed by a heavy dose of posturing. Many politicians would rather change the Constitution to require that the budget be balanced in the future than to cut popular programs right now. But as it passed through the Senate the posturing became extreme. 
 To win the support of Senators Sam Nunn of Georgia and John Breaux of Louisiana, the majority leader, Bob Dole, added a provision early this week that would prohibit the courts from enforcing the amendment. Mr. Nunn demanded the revision to protect the principle that legislators, not justices, raise taxes and cut spending. But stripped of judicial oversight, the amendment became simply a gesture -- an exhortation to Congress to do what it has avoided doing for more than a quarter-century. Tampering with the Constitution simply to play political word games became indefensible.
The amendment, which would have required supermajorities in Congress to approve running a deficit, would have hampered the Government's ability to fight recessions with deficit spending and larded the Constitution with unneeded, ill-defined terms. Rejection was the soundest response.
But voters need not swallow the misleading explanation many Democrats gave for voting no. Instead of acknowledging that they sought to protect programs from mindless cutting, they trumped up a supposed need to protect the integrity of the Social Security trust fund. But the trust fund is not really a fund, rather an accounting device that masks the use of Social Security taxes to pay Government's bills and thereby reduce the deficit. When the baby boomers retire, the Treasury will repay the trust fund from new taxes. The trust fund does not protect retiree benefits or insulate future taxpayers from rate hikes.
Though debate was specious, yesterday's vote made it clear that Senate Democrats can hold together in enough strength to support a Presidential veto should future legislative struggles come to that. The margin needed to sustain a veto is the same that is needed to block the amendment.
Other political ramifications are less clear. Some Republicans savor the opportunity to run in 1996 by blaming Democrats -- especially those who promised to vote otherwise -- for scuttling the seemingly popular amendment. But supporters of Mr. Dole worry that his, and the G.O.P.'s, Presidential ambitions were wounded by his unsuccessful leadership. Meanwhile, Democrats relish posing as champions of Social Security.
With the budget amendment derailed, Congress has no excuse to duck the real work ahead. If it surprises the electorate by controlling the deficit without destroying invaluable programs, then it will make heroes out of those senators who promised to make fiscally prudent decisions without a constitutional gun in their faces.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (93%);

HEADLINE: House Committee Completes Plan to Overhaul Welfare

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 3

 BODY:
The House Ways and Means Committee today finished work on sweeping legislation to redesign welfare programs that provide cash assistance to more than 15 million people. But last-minute procedural objections by Democrats forced the panel to delay its final vote to next week.
For the last four days, House Republicans have crushed Democratic objections to the bill and voted down Democratic amendments intended to liberalize it. 
 Just as the panel was about to vote, two of its most liberal Democratic members, Representatives Jim McDermott of Washington and Pete Stark of California, raised a point of order, demanding an opportunity to review the actual text of the legislation before voting on it. They cited a House rule that says proposals must be "reduced to writing on the demand of any member."
Until that moment, the committee had been working from a detailed description of the bill, not from the formal legislative language, many details of which are incomprehensible to laymen.
The chairman of the committee, Representative Bill Archer of Texas, banged his gavel in an effort to silence Mr. Stark so the vote could proceed. Another Republican threatened to call the sergeant-at-arms. Mr. Stark said the Republicans were using tactics reminiscent of Nazi Germany to ram the bill through the committee.
Ultimately, by voice vote, the committee instructed staff lawyers to prepare legislative language to carry out the policy decisions made by the panel in the last four days.
Mr. Archer said later that the protest reflected "the dying hysteria of Democrats attempting to defend the welfare state."
In an interview, Mr. Stark said the chairman was thin-skinned and unsure of the rules because he was "a little new at presiding" over the committee. Moreover, Mr. Stark said that Mr. Archer "was in a hurry to ram this through because he has a schedule handed down" by Speaker Newt Gingrich.
Mr. Archer said the committee's vote on the bill next week would be perfunctory because "our work has all been done."
The bill, a major element of the Republicans' Contract With America, would abolish the program of Aid to Families With Dependent Children, under which people are entitled to benefits if they meet certain eligibility criteria. States would get a lump sum of cash, or block grant, which they could use in any way they wanted to assist low-income people. Families now entitled to welfare benefits would not necessarily be entitled to assistance under the bill. The block grant would be set at $15.3 billion a year, the amount spent by the Federal Government for welfare benefits in 1994, with no allowance for changes in population or the economy.
In a rare moment of bipartisan agreement, the committee today endorsed tough new measures to force fathers to meet their child-support obligations. Democrats said they had prodded Republicans to include these measures in the bill. Administration officials and members of Congress said the changes would revolutionize enforcement of child-support orders.
"It's very easy now for the noncustodial parents to avoid child-support obligations, especially if they live in a different state" from the children, said Representative Benjamin L. Cardin, Democrat of Maryland. "This bill makes clear that child support is a national priority."
While deploring other parts of the bill, Elisabeth Hirschhorn Donahue, a lawyer at the National Women's Law Center, said the provisions on child support were "an enormous victory for mothers and children."
Under the bill, the Federal Government would establish a nationwide system to match child-support orders with records showing the locations of all people hired by public or private employers after Oct. 1, 1997. Using such information, a state where a mother and child reside could send an order to the father's employer requiring the employer to deduct child-support payments from the father's wages. Some parents now escape child-support obligations when they change jobs because the orders do not follow them.
The same procedures could be used to make women pay child support for youngsters living with their fathers. But more than 80 percent of the children in single-parent households live with their mothers, Ms. Donahue said.
The Ways and Means Committee rejected a Democratic proposal that would have required states to suspend or restrict drivers' licenses and professional licenses of parents who refused to pay child support.
The welfare bill would prohibit the use of Federal money to provide cash assistance to legal immigrants, unmarried mothers under the age of 18 and children born to women already on the welfare rolls. Representative Harold E. Ford, Democrat of Tennessee, said these provisions were "mean and cruel" because they punished youngsters for the parents' behavior.
The Congressional Budget Office estimated that the bill would save the Government more than $30 billion over five years, mainly by denying cash benefits to immigrants and to several hundred thousand children who were previously found to have mental or physical disabilities.
Republicans say there is overwhelming evidence of abuse in the disability program, known as Supplemental Security Income. Democrats say the proposed remedy goes far beyond any abuse and will cause hardship for children with disabilities like mental retardation and cerebral palsy.
The Senate Finance Committee will begin hearings on welfare next week. Mr. Archer said he had not discussed the House bill with the chairman of the Finance Committee, Senator Bob Packwood of Oregon.
The ranking Democrat on the Senate panel, Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, has said he will fight the House bill because he regards it as "an attack on Social Security," and he notes that cash assistance for poor children was part of the original Social Security law in 1935.

HEADLINE: Excerpts From the President's News Conference

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 3

 BODY:
Following are President Clinton's opening statement at a news conference the President held today at White House and excerpts from his exchanges with reporters, as transcribed by the Federal News Service:
Good afternoon. Ladies and gentlemen, now that the vote on the balanced-budget amendment has passed, it is time for Congress to go forward, to write a disciplined budget that brings the deficit down, cuts unnecessary Government spending and continues to invest in our future. 
 Two years ago, 27 days after I became President, I presented such a budget to the Congress. It has succeeded in reducing our deficit by over $600 billion while still increasing our investment in our children, in education and in our economic growth.
As of today, it has been 58 days since the new Republican majority took office. Congress has a deadline for passing a budget resolution of April the 15th. The American people now are entitled to see this work go forward. When the Congress proposes their budget and passes their resolution, of course I will work with them. As I have said repeatedly, we can get more deficit reduction and responsible health care reform, but I learned last year that that is clearly something we must do working together with both parties.
The debate that is going on in Washington today is about more, obviously, than simply the deficit and the budget, it is also about the role of Government, and you can see it running through every issue, from the laws being debated now in the Congress to the question of the rescission legislation before the Congress. The old Washington view, I think it's fair to say, is that the Federal Government could provide solutions to America's problems. The Republican Contract view reflects in many cases an outright hostility to governmental action, although in some cases a curious willingness to increase the Federal Government's control over our daily lives. My view, what has loosely been called the new Democratic view or the New Covenant view, is to be skeptical of Government but to recognize that it has a role in our lives and a partnership role to play.
We have made the Government smaller. We have given more power to states and localities and to private citizens. Our proposals would further accelerate those trends. We have, as you learned here in this room just a few days ago, been working for months on a serious effort to reduce the burden of unnecessary regulation. But we believe Government has important work to do, to expand opportunity, to give people the tools they need to make the most of their own lives, to enhance our security. That's why we support adding 100,000 police. That's why we support more affordable college loans. That's why we supported the family-leave bill. That's why I support the minimum wage legislation now before Congress, and why I do not want to reduce our investment in education in our future.
The Republicans now have proposed to cut education, nutritional help for mothers and school children, anti-drug efforts in our schools, and other things which to me appear to target children in order to pay for tax cuts for upper-income Americans. I do not believe that that is consistent with our interests as we build America into the 21st century and we move into this new global economy.
So my job, it seems to me, is to continue to push my view, what I believe is the essence of the New Covenant: More opportunity. More responsibility. Reform welfare, but don't punish people. Require work. This is the sort of thing we need more of. And I look forward to this debate. I think it's healthy, I think it's good for the American people. And I would like to begin now by answering your questions.
 
QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS
 Q. Mr. President, did you try to talk Senator Campbell out of jumping ship? What does it portend for the Democratic Party? And what does it mean in terms of your leadership?
A. Well I talked to him this morning because he called the White House and said he wanted to talk to me, and so I called him. And we had a good conversation. And he pointed out that he had voted with me over 80 percent of the time in the last two years, that he essentially supported our economic policies, our education policies and our social policies, and that he would not change that. It was obvious to me that there were some Colorado-specific factors at work. I wish he hadn't done it. I think it was a mistake. But I hope he will continue to vote in the way he has in the past. . . .
Q. Mr. President, forgive me for pressing you on this, but if I'm not mistaken, you have always been in favor of affirmative action and, in fact, you have practiced it. Why now the hesitation?
A. I'm glad you asked. I have always practiced it, but let's look at how I practiced it. Look at my court -- look at my appointments to the Federal bench, ones for which, I might add, I've been regularly and roundly attacked for trying to achieve diversity here in this community.
I read something in the paper about once a month, people jumping on me because I've appointed more women and more minorities to the Federal bench than my predecessors combined at this point in our terms -- my last three predecessors combined. "And oh, by the way," they sometimes say, "his appointees also have the highest rating from the American Bar Association of the last three Presidents."
I have practiced affirmative action here the way that I perceive the United State military has practiced it. I have made an extra effort to look for qualified candidates who could serve with distinction and make a contribution to this country and make the Federal bench reflective of the American population. I have not done it with any quota system in mind, and I have not guaranteed anybody a job. I have made an extra effort to do that. The military starts before that -- they have made an extra effort to develop the capacities of people who come to them with great raw ability, but maybe a disadvantaged background.
Is that wrong? I don't think it is, and I'm not backing off of that. The question is -- here is the narrow question -- the question is: If we're not for quotas in results, and we are for developing everybody's capacities, what do we do with all those rules and regulations and laws that really are in a gray area. . . . I want to review those. I do not want to see us stop trying to develop the abilities of all Americans. I do not want to see us move away from trying to concentrate our resources in the areas of greatest need. But I would say again I think most minorities have been helped most by the programs in this country that have been targeted toward broad-based needs.
And ironically, if you go back to the beginning of this whole affirmative-action debate, it started in the late 60's and many civil rights leaders at the time argued against affirmative-action programs because they thought we'd wind up in the debate we are now having 25 years later. I think we need to look at the programs, look at the facts, and ask the questions I just asked. How does this work, is it fair, is it necessary, is there an alternative way to achieve the objective?
But in terms of taking aggressive initiatives to develop the capacities of people, should we keep doing that? You bet we should. How should we do it in the law? That's the question.
Q. Mr. President, returning to the issue of Russia, given the continued fighting in Chechnya and the apparent stall in Russian reforms, can you give us some measure of your confidence level in Boris Yeltsin, or your lack of confidence? And how do you read his failure to conclude this situation in Chechnya?
A. I think it's obviously a very difficult problem for him, and I think that -- you know, I hesitate to comment on it in great detail because I'm not sure that I know everything there is to know about it. . . .
Now, I believe that he has made the major policy decisions there. I think that he is in control of the policy there and I have dealt directly with him in urging a change and a moderation of policy there and I will continue to do that. And my confidence level in him is strong. If you ask me, do I think he is still the effective president of Russia and is he making those decisions, yes that's what I believe is the case.
Q. Back on politics, the -- you say it's too early for you to become consumed by re-election? It might not be too early for someone within the Democratic party who might choose to challenge you. Do you expect a challenge from within your own party, and do you think that would be destructive for Democrats?
A. Well, I don't expect it. I don't not expect it. I don't know what will happen. I hope there won't be one, I think it would be a mistake for the Democratic Party. . . .
The country's better off than it was two years ago. I get tickled -- I laugh every time I see one of my Republican -- one of the Republican aspirants -- they have a big fund-raiser and they give them a bunch of money because a lot of them are angry that we raised income taxes on the top 1.2 percent of people to bring the deficit down, but I'll bet you everybody going to those fund-raisers for those Republicans is doing better under our economic policies in the last two years than they were before.
So, my job is just to do the best job I can, reward work, support families and communities, offer opportunity, demand responsibility in these changes and keep moving forward.
That's what I'm going to do. And this is a difficult, tumultuous time, but this country is doing better, and I am determined to keep fighting for the interest and the values of middle class people and I'm going to let the election take care of itself, as I believe it will.

HEADLINE: House Endorses Deep Cutbacks In Regulations

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 3

 BODY:
The House of Representatives today completed its work on a series of antiregulatory measures, bundled them into a package with enormous implications for the current system of Federal environmental controls, and sent it to an uncertain fate in the Senate.
The package, which passed on a vote of 277 to 141, would temporarily suspend most new regulations; subject proposed rules on health, safety and environmental protection to elaborate scientific reviews; override the health considerations in existing laws with economic calculations of regulatory costs and benefits; compensate private landowners when regulations reduce their property values, and generally honor the Republicans' promise to roll back Federal regulations, a centerpiece of their 1994 campaign manifesto, the Contract With America. 
 Even if only some of those provisions survive the political fight that lies ahead, they would considerably limit the Clinton Administration's powers to enforce many statutes, from the Clean Air Act and Clean Water Act to the Endangered Species Act and the Superfund law on cleaning up toxic wastes.
While the bill's sponsors, flanked by representatives of major business groups, celebrated by ceremoniously snipping a ribbon of red tape from a mock-up of the Statue of Liberty, its opponents, nursing the worst wounds the environmental movement has suffered in years, hoped the bleeding could be staunched in the Senate.
There, committees are still reviewing the implications of what the House has done in the last two weeks, and Democrats are still considering whether to continue the tactics of prolonged debate and parliamentary maneuver that they have relied on so far this year.
Even the most ardent supporters of the Republican regulatory program concede that it will probably be moderated in the Senate. And Administration officials said they hoped the moderation would be adequate to stave off a veto of the anti-regulatory package.
The House Speaker, Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, said, "What you'll find, I think, as we negotiate with the Senate and as this thing goes to hearings in the Senate, is we'll find a common ground which will create more respect for private property while still maintaining the vast bulk of the Government's powers to save the environment and to insure public safety and public health."
The House strengthened its hand by bundling all the major antiregulation measures it has approved into a single package. That way, if the Senate passes only part of the package, the House negotiators will be able to try to restore the missing elements in a conference committee where differences between the two houses would be resolved.
The last of the series, a bill to pay landowners when their property values are reduced because development is blocked to preserve wetlands or endangered species, passed by a vote of 277 to 148. In an amendment, the House raised the threshold for claiming compensation to situations in which land declined in value by at least 20 percent because its use was regulated.
Even so, the measure opens up the prospect of incalculable cost to the Government for compensating landowners unless regulatory agencies decide not to enforce laws like the Clean Water Act or the Endangered Species Act, which are already on the books and under which the courts can demand regulatory actions.
The prospective costs of the legislation, which have not yet been estimated by the Congressional Budget Office, raised the possibility that budget rules could be raised as an objection to such a bill coming before the Senate.
The Budget Act requires that Congress finance new expenditures either by offsetting spending cuts or tax increases. The House Rules Committee waived those provisions but, under Senate rules, they can only be waived with the approval of 60 senators.
For the next week or two, parliamentary maneuvering could well be the only action on the deregulatory bills in the Senate. The decisions by Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the majority leader, will be especially important to the eventual outcome in the case of the risk-assessment and cost-benefit bill, the most comprehensive of the antiregulation measures passed by the House.
There are competing versions of similar legislation working their way through the Senate. One of them, a less sweeping measure sponsored by a Delaware Republican, Senator William V. Roth Jr., would probably be acceptable if enacted, Administration officials said, especially if it could be softened a bit.
But another version, sponsored by Senator Dole, would probably be vetoed; it more closely resembles the bill that passed the House, which the Administration says would effectively roll back the health protections contained in a generation of environmental laws.
With its antiregulation agenda out of the way, the House is moving quickly on other bills to reverse environmental priorities of the past.
On Wednesday, the House Appropriations Committee adopted a measure that would greatly increase logging on Federal land, maintaining that this would be a good way to prevent overgrown forests from being destroyed by fire or pests.
Lawmakers in both the House and the Senate who support the logging industry are pushing the proposal, but environmental groups oppose it because it limits their rights to review and appeal logging plans.
The bill would increase immediately by about three billion board feet a year the amount of timber salvaged from areas deemed unhealthy by the Forest Service, a part of the Department of Agriculture. The Administration favors an increased harvesting of timber on overgrown public lands but opposes the idea of fixing targets for the timber harvest or suspending the application of environmental laws to permit more logging.
Proponents of the bill are trying to increase logging by recalling the catastrophic wildfires of recent years. They contend that the best way to head off future conflagrations is to thin out the forests, especially in areas where many trees are already dead or dying. Opponents say this would open roadless areas to new logging, increasing erosion and stream damage.
 
THE BILL AT A GLANCE
Antiregulation
 
BILL Job Creation and Wage Enhancement Act (H.R. 9)
 
HIGHLIGHTS The bill combines antiregulatory measures that would temporarily suspend most new regulations; subject proposed rules on health, safety and environmental protection to elaborate scientific reviews; override the health considerations in existing laws with economic calculations of regulatory costs and benefits; compensate private landowners when regulations reduce their property values, and generally honor the Republican promise to roll back Federal regulations.
 
POLITICS Restricting Government regulation, a favorite measure among business groups, is a cornerstone of the Republicans' Contract With America, and some Democrats endorse the idea as well. But environmentalists -- and many Democrats -- say the legislation goes too far.
 
COST Impossible to calculate, but if the Government continued to issue regulations, could be enormous.
 
STATUS
 
 House: Passed on Friday.
 
 Senate: Comparable measure is under consideration by several committees.
 
 White House: Has threatened a veto, saying the legislation would roll back a generation of environmental progress.

HEADLINE: Business Digest

 BODY:

Markets
 
The dollar continued to slide despite a concerted effort by the Federal Reserve, the Bank of Japan and European central banks to prop up the value of the currency. Even strong words from Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin proved no match for a wave of speculation against the dollar, which tumbled to another record low against the Japanese yen. [Page 33.]
 
Stocks advanced, despite the weak dollar. Technology stocks, including I.B.M., led the rally. The S.& P. 500 rose 0.29 point. [34.]
 
The falling dollar dragged down Treasury prices. The dollar's slide raised fears that the Federal Reserve might be compelled to raise short-term interest rates to support the currency. [44.]
 
Copper prices surged on signs of strong European demand. [43.]
 
 
International
 
Britain began an inquiry into whether the collapse of Barings was a result of fraud that reached into its headquarters. The investigation opened as talks continued between bankruptcy administrators and ING over the sale of the investment firm. [33.]
 
Japan's securities industry is battling its bleakest period in recent history. Indeed, with sharp job cutbacks and slumping stocks, the industry is facing the possibility that it may be hollowing out. [33.]
 
Mexico seized the nation's eighth-largest bank, Banpais, in the first such takeover since its financial crisis began. [45.]
 
 
Companies
 
A Mercedes-Benz executive praised American auto makers as the world's most efficient manufacturers. The chief of Mercedes-Benz's car operations, Jurgen Hubbert, said that he no longer looked to Japan for guidance, as he did in the 1980's. [33.]
 
Intuit disclosed new flaws in some of its tax programs. The company notified users of its Connecticut and Indiana state tax programs of possible errors. The disclosure came after Intuit said some users of its Turbotax and Macintax programs might be affected by minor flaws in the tax preparation software. [33.]
 
National Gypsum rejected a $1.12 billion takeover bid from BPB Industries of Britain. Analysts expect the bidding for National Gypsum to intensify, and its shares rose sharply. [35.]
 
An Italian eyewear maker offered $1.12 billion for U.S. Shoe, the parent of Lenscrafters, the largest American optical chain. [35.]
 
Beneficial National Bank dropped a lawsuit against the I.R.S. [35.]
 
Ford Motor posted strong sales of light trucks in February. Ford said its results showed that the market remained firm. [35.]
 
Losses are seen for the brokerage firms that did business with the bankrupt Adler Coleman & Company. But most of the 60,000 customer accounts are likely to find new homes next week. [45.]

 
The Economy
 
The Government's chief forecasting gauge indicated a slowdown ahead. The index of leading indicators was flat in January. In a separate report, factory orders rose a modest 0.6 percent. [45.]
 
 
Your Money
 
A foreign fund has managed to avoid financial trouble spots like Japan and Mexico. The iconoclastic approach has produced stellar returns for the fund, GAM International. [32.]
 
Rising yields should not tempt investors to put money for retirement into money market accounts and bank deposits. Advisers warn that the yields are still low for long-term growth. [32.]

HEADLINE: Mexican Government Seizes Banking Company

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, March 3

 BODY:
Mexican authorities today seized the company that owns the country's eighth-largest bank, Banpais, citing "irregularities."
 The Finance Ministry said it took over Grupo Financiero Asemex-Banpais S.A., known as Banpais, after the company's banking and insurance units failed to meet capital and reserves requirements. 
 The takeover is the first of a banking company since Mexico's crisis began on Dec. 20, when the peso was devalued. The intervention also represents the first time the Government has taken over a bank that has shares traded in markets abroad.
 American depository receipts of Banpais have traded on the New York Stock Exchange since last June. Today, the A.D.R.'s fell 6.25 cents, to 68.75 cents. Each A.D.R. represents six shares.
 Mexican banks have faced intense pressures in recent months as the peso tumbles and interest rates soar, making it more difficult for businesses, homeowners and farmers to make loan payments. The size of Mexico's bad loans is expected to grow rapidly in coming months, stretching many banks' already weak financial condition. If weaker banks go under, more Government interventions are likely, worsening the nation's recession and swelling the current-account deficit despite the financial rescue package orchestrated by the United States.
 Banpais's banking unit had been seen by analysts as particularly vulnerable. Indeed, the Standard & Poor's Corporation lowered its crediting rating on Banpais's foreign-currency debt twice in the last two months.
 "The downgrade reflects Banpais's vulnerability to the heightened risk confronting the Mexican banking industry caused by tightened liquidity and the recession," S.&.P said in its most recent revision.
 In announcing today's seizure, the Government said that regulators had "detected that Banpais had irregularities, such as lack of capital and reserves, that put in jeopardy its financial health and operation."
 Regulators also discovered a lack of sufficient technical reserves and capital at the company's two insurance companies. Banpais owns the nation's fourth-largest insurance company, Aseguradora Mexicana S.A
 The Government said its bank insurance fund would protect depositors and creditors.
 The Government also ousted the management of the bank and insurance companies.

HEADLINE: Whitewater Counsel Is Urged to Investigate Hiring of Ex-Justice Official's Wife

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 3

 BODY:
A Republican Senator has asked the Whitewater independent counsel to investigate the White House's role in a decision by the Interior Department to reinstate the wife of former Associate Attorney General Webster L. Hubbell to a political job.
Last year Mr. Hubbell's wife, Suzanna, took an unpaid leave from her job as special assistant to Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt after Mr. Hubbell left the Justice Department to defend himself in the Whitewater investigation. 
 She was reinstated last month to a comparable job, at an annual salary of $59,022, after the department received a telephone call at her request from Bruce Lindsey, the deputy White House counsel.
In December, Mr. Hubbell pleaded guilty to two felony counts of mail fraud and tax evasion, and is to be sentenced next month by a Federal judge in Little Rock, Ark., for stealing $396,000 from his Arkansas law firm. As part of a plea agreement, he promised to assist the counsel's office in its investigation of President Clinton's personal and campaign finances.
Last Tuesday one of Mr. Clinton's bankers, Neal R. Ainley, was indicted on charges that he conspired to violate Federal banking laws in a scheme that also involved Mr. Lindsey, who was the treasurer of Mr. Clinton's 1990 re-election campaign as Governor of Arkansas.
Mr. Lindsey, who has said he did nothing improper, has not been charged with any wrongdoing. He and the Hubbells have been friends for many years.
But his role in the re-appointment of Mrs. Hubbell was criticized by Senator Lauch Faircloth, Republican of North Carolina, who wrote a letter this week to the Whitewater prosecutors asking that the incident be investigated to determine if it suggested witness tampering and obstruction.
Officials at the White House and the Interior Department presented slightly different accounts of how Mrs. Hubbell happened to be re-employed. But by both accounts, Mr. Lindsey played no significant role.
Abner J. Mikva, the White House counsel, said today that there was nothing improper with Mrs. Hubbell's return to the Interior Department. He said that shortly after she applied to return to the department it contacted Leon E. Panetta, the White House chief of staff, who then asked the counsel's office to review the appointment. It found no legal or ethics restrictions to her re-hiring.
"It was handled absolutely by the book," Mr. Mikva said.
He said that on Feb. 6, Mr. Lindsey placed a telephone call to B. J. Thornberry, Mr. Babbitt's deputy chief of staff, at the request of Mrs. Hubbell after it appeared to her that the appointment might be delayed. But, Mr. Mikva said, by the time Mr. Lindsey placed the call the re-appointment had already been cleared by the counsel's office.
"Bruce made one phone call, was told it had already been worked out, said, 'Thank you very much' and he hung up," Mr. Mikva said.
Kevin J. Sweeney, a spokesman for the Interior Department, gave a slightly different version of events. He said Mrs. Hubbell had told officials in January that she would like to resume her job on Feb. 6. He said department officials had tried several times to get clearance from the White House, but their calls were not returned.
Mr. Sweeney said that Mrs. Hubbell appeared at the department on Feb. 6 but was told by Mr. Thornberry that she could not sit in a staff meeting because the White House had not cleared her appointment.
At that point, Mr. Sweeney said, Mrs. Hubbell called Mr. Lindsey and Erskine Bowles, a White House deputy chief of staff, to find out what was delaying the clearance. Mr. Sweeney said that after Mrs. Hubbell discussed the matter with Mr. Lindsey, Mr. Thornberry got a call later in the day from Mr. Bowles telling him that the department could re-hire her.
"Suzie Hubbell did a very good job for us last year, and she will do a good job for us this year," Mr. Sweeney said. "To expect her to be pushed into unemployment because of other people's actions is wrong."

HEADLINE: World News Briefs;
Ukraine Accepts Terms For Loan From I.M.F.

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: KIEV, Ukraine, March 3

 BODY:
Signaling a strong commitment to overhaul its ailing economy, Ukraine agreed today to conditions set by the International Monetary Fund for a $1.8 billion loan.
The aid, expected to be formally approved later this month, would help Ukraine to cover its payments deficit, reduce inflation and mobilize other Western aid for the transition to a free-market economy. 
 In a detailed memorandum, the Government promised to keep the budget deficit low, end price controls and open borders to exports.
After delaying reforms for three years and suffering a deep recession, President Leonid M. Kuchma introduced new economic programs in October when Ukraine received its first I.M.F. loan, $371 million.
Today's agreement will help Ukraine to lobby Western Governments at a meeting March 21 in Paris to provide $900 million in bilateral aid to help cover a $5.5 billion payments deficit this year. The United States has agreed to provide more than $100 million but the European Union and Japan have not committed any aid.

HEADLINE: Two Letters and Excerpts From Book

 BODY:
Following is a statement from Pat Robertson, founder of the Christian Coalition, to The New York Times yesterday regarding assertions that his book "The New World Order" (Word Publishing, 1991) includes an anti-Semitic message:
"The New World Order" was written at the height of the Gulf War to answer Bush Administration officials who were announcing that America had entered "The New World Order" under the aegis of the United Nations. 
 My book, "The New World Order," does not embrace a conspiracy theory of history, and it certainly is not anti-Semitic. I would never embrace theories that would cast doubt upon the Jewish community. The central thrust of the book is to show the dangers to the sovereignty of the United States of America and the security of the state of Israel that was implicit in a foreign policy under the direction of the United Nations.
I deeply regret that anyone in the Jewish community believes that my description of international bankers and use of the phrase "European bankers" in my book refers to Jews. As chairman of one of the nation's largest and most widely respected cable television companies whose stock is traded daily on the New York Stock Exchange, it has been my experience that the international financial community is very diverse and can hardly be characterized as Jewish. Further, I have never intentionally used what some would describe as code words to portray Jewish business interests. I condemn and repudiate in the strongest terms those who would use such code words as a cover for anti-Semitism.
If my statements were misunderstood, I offer my sincere regrets. I never intended to offend my Jewish colleagues who I consider to be dear friends and allies. However, I do feel that only someone who is desperately attempting to cause mischief would make the unfounded allegations about me or my book that have recently appeared in The New York Times.
All who know me, Jewish and Christian, recognize that I have been one of the strongest friends of Israel anywhere in the world. In 1974, when Israel appeared threatened and alone as a result of a worldwide oil crisis, I made a vow that I have kept to this day: I promised to use my influence, and that of the institutions I founded, to vigorously support Israel and the Jewish people. I have kept my vow. My comments on my daily television program have been pro-Israel. In fact, during the Gulf War, I was one of the few voices in America speaking out regularly in support of Israel.
I have lobbied for Israel, and donated hundreds of thousands of dollars to Jewish interests and organizations. By every public word and deed, I have kept my promise.
The book, "The New World Order," was carefully researched and contains seven single-spaced pages of bibliography from original historical sources. At the time of its publication, my book rose quickly to No. 4 on The New York Times nonfiction best sellers list, and became the No. 1 best-selling Christian book in America. With that wide a circulation in 1991, no one raised the specious objections to the book that are currently being brought forward by the radical left in America desperately looking for an opportunity to discredit the role of religious conservatives in politics.
Following is a letter from Abraham H. Foxman, the national director of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith, to Pat Robertson regarding the criticisms of Mr. Robertson's book:
Dear Pat:
I write because of the recent attention given your book "The New World Order" and specifically the conspiracy theories contained therein which trouble me. A major national figure can hardly maintain mainstream credibility when he is associated with such discredited notions.
To my knowledge, Pat, you have never responded to critics of the book. It seems to me that it would serve all sides if you clarified the views expressed in it and repudiated its message of a worldwide Jewish conspiracy (chapter eight, for instance, suggests that Jewish bankers funded a "plan for world revolution" that came to include the French and Russian Revolutions and the creation of Communism). It would certainly help relations between our communities.
Please let me know your thoughts about this matter.
Following is an example of a passage from Mr. Robertson's book that critics say reflects anti-Semitism:
PAGE 61 Later, the European economic powers began to see the wealth of North America as a great treasure, and some of them still wanted to get their tentacles into America's economy. They eventually did so not by force but by investing their money here, by sending people, and by buying land. Europe could not defeat the United States by military force, but the European financiers knew that they could control the United States economy if they could saddle us with an American equivalent of the German Bundesbank or the Bank of England. Their efforts failed until 1913, when a German banker, Paul Warburg, succeeded in establishing the Federal Reserve Board, America's privately owned central bank.
Following is an example cited by Mr. Robertson as evidence that the book includes pro-Israel and pro-Jewish sentiments:
PAGE 256 It is also clear that Satan's strategy will include a frontal assault on Israel. Rest assured that the next objective of the presently constituted new world order, under the present United Nations, will be to make Israel its target. The precedent has been set by the action against Iraq.
A recalcitrant nation whose action does not accord with United Nations policy may be disciplined by military force. That is the newest law of world order. The United Nations General Assembly has already voted to brand Zionism as racism. Surely we can expect, sooner or later, an unreasonable demand for Israel to vacate control of the West Bank and the half of her capital city in East Jerusalem.

HEADLINE: A Slowing Economy Is Indicated

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 3

 BODY:
The Government's economic forecasting gauge is pointing to a slowing economy this year, while shrinking factory orders indicate that the robust manufacturing sector may join the trend.
 The Commerce Department said today that its index of leading indicators, which is intended to forecast conditions six to nine months in advance, was flat in January. 
 And in a separate report, the department said orders to factories rose six-tenths of a percent in January. Although the advance was relatively strong, it was weaker than gains of 2.7 percent in November and 2 percent in December.
 After remaining unchanged in September, the leading indicators fell one-tenth of a percent in October and then edged up just one-tenth of a percent in November and two-tenths in December.
 Mark Zandi, an economist for Regional Financial Associates in West Chester, Pa., said the index "is showing that the slowing in the economy will continue at least through the summer." But he did not foresee a recession.
 The Federal Reserve, in its yearlong effort to curb economic growth and hold down inflation, has made seven increases in short-term interest rates, pushing them up to 6 percent from 3 percent, and the effects of the effort have shown up in slowing retail sales and housing starts.
 Five of the 11 forward-looking economic indicators rose in January, 5 fell and one was unchanged.
 The positive components included higher orders for plants and equipment, a rise in unfilled orders for durable goods, higher stock prices and a gain in the money supply.
 The negative indicators included a decline in building permits, faster delivery times that suggested declining orders, higher weekly initial claims for unemployment insurance and a drop in an index measuring consumer confidence.
 New orders for consumer goods edged up and prices for raw materials dipped slightly, but the report said their contributions to the index rounded to zero. The average workweek was unchanged.
 The Commerce Department said factory orders, considered a crucial gauge of the manufacturing sector, totaled a seasonally adjusted $301.3 billion, up from $299.5 billion in December. The increase was the smallest in three months.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Ford's Sales Rose in February; Nissan's Fell

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DETROIT, March 3

 BODY:
Contributing to the cacophony of signals about the condition of the auto market in the United States, the Ford Motor Company reported today that its sales of vehicles rose in February, while the Nissan Motor Company said its sales fell during the month.
 Most auto makers reported their sales on Wednesday. Altogether, sales of cars and light trucks fell 4.1 percent, compared with a strong period a year earlier. Light-truck sales edged up, while car sales fell more than 7 percent. 
 Ford said its results showed that the market remained firm. "There's nothing in these numbers that I can see that supports the Chicken Littles of the world," said Joel Pitcoff, Ford's market analysis manager.
 Ford's car sales declined last month, but its strong truck sales -- a company record for February -- more than compensated for that drop. Ford's Windstar mini-van had its best monthly sales so far while its newly redesigned Explorer sport utility also posted strong gains.
 Those results came in contrast to the Chrysler Corporation's. On Wednesday, Chrysler reported strong car sales but surprisingly weak sales of light trucks, with mini-van sales plummeting by almost a third and sport utility sales falling 14 percent.
 Chrysler attributed its weaker mini-van sales to a rebate program on the Windstar, and it now seems likely that the Windstar did gain at Chrysler's expense. In addition, some die-hard Chrysler buyers may be postponing mini-van purchases because of advance publicity for Chrysler's new models, due out this spring.
 The success of the Ford Explorer is in line with strong sales reported by the General Motors Corporation of its redesigned Chevrolet Blazer sport utility. Those freshened vehicles may be making inroads on Chrysler's older Cherokee and Grand Cherokee models.
 Despite the Windstar's strong February, Ford is planning to close next week the Oakville, Ontario, plant where the Windstar is assembled, saying that dealers were cutting back inventories because of higher interest rates. Many auto industry analysts, however, believe the mini-van is not selling as well as the company hoped.
 Nonetheless, shares of Ford rose 25 cents today, to $25.625. But Chrysler shares fell 75 cents, to $40.75.
 In another sign of softness in the auto market, Chrysler today announced new rebates of up to $1,500 on its LH series of midsize sedans, good through June 30, and extended a rebate program for its Neon subcompact car until the same date.

HEADLINE: Democrats Lose Senate Seat With Switch by Coloradan

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 3

 BODY:
Ben Nighthorse Campbell, the only American Indian in the United States Senate, startled and puzzled the political world today by bolting from the Democratic Party and joining the Republicans.
He suggested that the Democrats no longer represented his views. But in a typically ambiguous statement, he said he would continue to vote as he had in the past, which has been with the Democrats and President Clinton 78 percent of the time, according to tallies by Congressional Quarterly. 
 "I can no longer represent the agenda that is put forth by the party," Mr. Campbell told a packed news conference here this morning, "although I certainly agree with many of the things that Democrats stand for."
Those who know Mr. Campbell, a sartorial maverick who wears bolo ties and his hair in a pony tail, said that his defection had more to do with growing personal antagonisms he had experienced within the Democratic Party in Colorado than with any ideological split.
They said Mr. Campbell had become increasingly estranged from his party since last year, when he got into a bitter public dispute over personal finances with his former chief of staff, Sherrie Wolff, who was running for secretary of state. Party officials blamed Mr. Campbell for costing her the race.
"He has a very, very sharp temper and has a hard time controlling it and he will lash out at real or perceived slights," said Lawrence Dodd, director of the Center for the Study of American Politics at the University of Colorado at Boulder. "When he gets in fights, he tends to settle them publicly."
Mr. Campbell only alluded to his internal party problems today, saying, "I have not been able to live up to the expectations of the Democratic Party, so it's just very clear that we go our separate ways."
The well-kept secret of his defection outraged Democrats in Colorado as well as his staff in Washington, most of whom quit on the spot when they heard the news this morning. "We're Democrats, not Republicans," one said.
Republican leaders in Washington cautiously welcomed Mr. Campbell into the fold, his addition swelling their ranks to 54 and leaving 46 Democrats. But no one seemed under any illusion that Senator Campbell, 60, who roars around town on a highly accessorized Harley-Davidson, would necessarily hew to the Republican line.
Indeed, President Clinton said that when Mr. Campbell called him this morning to report his switch, he told the President "he essentially supported our economic policies, our education policies and our social polices and that he would not change that." Mr. Clinton said that he hoped Mr. Campbell would continue voting as he has since his election to the Senate in 1992.
Mr. Campbell is viewed as a fiscal conservative and a social liberal, a Democrat who supports a balanced budget amendment and a capital gains tax cut but also supports abortion rights. He has sided with developers and the timber and mining industries, earning the enmity of environmentalists.
"I've always been considered a moderate, to the consternation of the left wing of the Democratic Party," he said today. "I imagine my continued moderacy will be now to the consternation of the right wing of the Republican Party."
Partly because of his insistence that he would not change his stance on issues, Mr. Campbell said he had no intention of resigning and standing for re-election as a Republican. But the Colorado Democratic Party, which is meeting this weekend, is sure to call for his resignation, said Howard Gelt, chairman of the party.
There is precedent both ways. Senator Phil Gramm of Texas stepped down and ran again when he switched parties, but Senator Richard Shelby of Alabama did not. Mr. Campbell is up for re-election in 1998. Colorado limits its senators to two terms.
Don Bain, chairman of the Colorado Republican Party, said he saw no reason for Mr. Campbell to quit only to run as a Republican. "The people of Colorado voted more for Campbell as a personality than as a representative of one party or the other," Mr. Bain said.
"His image is one of Western independence, the Lone Ranger kind of Indian image, the guy out there all alone on the Western plains staring into the horizon," Mr. Bain said. "He ran that way, as the rags-to-riches success story who has some kind of Olympic medal and makes jewelry and rides a motorcycle."
There has been speculation in Colorado that Mr. Campbell has already decided not to seek a second Senate term in 1998, partly because he was unhappy in the Senate and might run for governor that year.
"People think he won't run again because he hates the Senate so much, with its prima donnas, and he's such a loner there," said Bob Drake, a Denver pollster.
But these ambitions do not necessarily explain his switching parties, since the governor's race is expected to draw strong Republican contenders. Others said the switch occurred primarily because Mr. Campbell's personal feuds had made staying in the Democratic Party untenable. Most recently, he endorsed an opponent of the Democratic mayor of Denver, Wellington Webb.
In Washington, Mr. Campbell is better known for his unorthodox lifestyle than for any legislative accomplishments. Perhaps his most notable achievement has been to bring about the renaming of the Custer Battlefield National Monument in Montana, a name the Indians found offensive, to the Little Bighorn Battlefield National Monument.
Mr. Campbell spent part of his early years in an orphanage and has attributed his independence to not having a family. "It made me very self-reliant and independent," he told his biographer, who was writing the book at Mr. Campbell's request. "If you have nobody to rely on, then you have got to do it yourself."
His mother, who was Portuguese, died of tuberculosis, and his father, a Northern Cheyenne who was an alcoholic, placed the children in orphanages. The Senator, who was born Ben Marshall Campbell, did not accept his Indian heritage until adulthood, after he learned that his grandmother's half brother, Alex Black Horse, was a leader of the Northern Cheyenne and that some of his ancestors fought at Little Big Horn. He keeps a knife from the battle in his Capitol Hill office. He was given the name Nighthorse by the tribe in 1980.
A high-school dropout who later put himself through San Jose State University by driving a truck, Mr. Campbell was captain of the United States judo team in the 1964 Olympics. He was elected to the Colorado Legislature in 1982 and to the United States House in 1986. Even his jewelry-making is unconventional. While most Indian jewelry is made with turquoise and silver, his includes gold, diamonds, sapphires and rubies.
Mr. Campbell is the eighth American Indian to serve in Congress and the only one at the moment. He once said he wished there were a lot more or none at all "because it's damned tough being the only Indian."

HEADLINE: DIARY;
Developments in Washington

 BODY:

HOUSE -- The House completed its work on a series of antiregulatory measures, bundled them into a package with enormous implications for the system of Federal environmental controls and sent it to the Senate, where its fate is uncertain. The package, which passed 277 to 148, would temporarily suspend most new regulations and subject proposed rules on health, safety and environmental protection to new cost-benefit and risk assessments. It would also compensate private landowners when regulations reduced their property values, and it would honor the promise to roll back Federal regulations, a central part of the Republicans' Contract With America. 

Representative David M. McIntosh, Republican of Indiana, accused the head of the Environmental Protection Agency of illegally lobbying against such measures, but agency officials said they believed they had complied with the law.
 
Another important element of the Republicans' agenda moved forward as the Ways and Means Committee approved a bill to eliminate the 60-year-old Federal guarantee of cash assistance for millions of poor people. The measure would abolish Aid to Families With Dependent Children and give the states a lump sum of cash, or block grant, that they could use in any way they wanted to aid low-income people. The block grant would be set at $15.3 billion a year, the amount spent by the Federal Government for welfare benefits in 1994, with no allowance for changes in population or the economy.
 
SENATE -- Senator Ben Nighthorse Campbell of Colorado, who voted on Thursday in favor of the unsuccessful effort to amend the Constitution to require a balanced Federal budget, switched to the Republican Party from the Democratic. "I can no longer represent the agenda that is put forth by the party, although I certainly agree with many of the things that Democrats stand for," he said.
 
WHITE HOUSE -- President Clinton said that Republicans appeared intent on cutting children's programs to provide more rewards for upper-income Americans and pressed them to disclose how they would pay for the tax cuts they have promised. His comments came in a press conference a day after the defeat of the Republican-backed balanced-budget amendment, a result the President said made it incumbent on Congressional leaders to show how they would cut spending and reduce the deficit in the coming year.

HEADLINE: Clinton Challenges the G.O.P. To Detail Its Spending Plans

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 3

 BODY:
President Clinton said today that the defeat of the balanced-budget amendment meant it was time for Republicans to spell out their spending plans, and warned that they seemed intent on cutting aid to children to benefit the well-to-do.
Mr. Clinton's call for more specificity came a day after the Republicans failed in their quest to pass the balanced-budget amendment. He said that result made it incumbent on Congressional leaders to show how they would cut spending and reduce the deficit in the coming year. 
 But with the attention of the political world already turning to the next Presidential election, Mr. Clinton also used a news conference this afternoon to appeal for reason. Saying he was committed to working even with those already eyeing his office, the President said the American people would be badly served if all-out campaigning began soon.
"We can't have everybody all torn up and upset about playing politics here for the next six, seven months," Mr. Clinton said in an answer to a reporter's question. "We've got a lot of work to do. And I think we should relax and do it."
Mr. Clinton's warning about the Republicans' intentions underscored the central point that the White House hopes to drive home in coming weeks as it scuffles with Congress about the shape of this year's budget proposal.
Seizing on Republican proposals to cut the budgets of some educational and nutritional programs and to shrink anti-drug education efforts in the schools, Mr. Clinton accused his rivals of seeking "to target children in order to pay for tax cuts for upper-income Americans."
But because the Republicans have not yet presented a budget proposal of their own, the President began his first solo news conference of the year by saying that it was time for them to set aside the abstractions of the balanced budget debate and put their specific plans on record.
Some Democrats have urged Mr. Clinton to move forward on his own with recommendations for specific cuts in spending beyond those he proposed in his own budget last month. But the President said today that he believed the next step was for the Republicans to take.
"I am going to wait now until they do their constitutional duty, which is to present a budget, which is something that has not happened," the President said, scoring his own political points even as he appealed for pre-election year gentility. "Then I am going to work with them."
In fact, it is Federal statute, not the Constitution, which sets an April 15 deadline for Congress to produce a budget plan. But because Republicans in the House and the Senate have not yet produced that proposal, Mr. Clinton was able to base his criticisms today on a broad amalgam of ideas spelled out in the Republicans' Contract With America, by individual Republicans and from actions already taken by the Republican-controlled House.
Those Republican proposals have in common a vow to cut taxes for millions more Americans than would benefit under Mr. Clinton's tax-cut plan, whose greatest rewards would be limited to Americans making less than $70,000 a year. But in an argument that he will repeat on Saturday in his weekly radio address, Mr. Clinton cited the budget cuts now being pushed by House Republicans as evidence that the effect of the party's efforts would be extremely harmful to the young and the poor.
"I do not believe that that is consistent with our interests as we build America into the 21st century and we move into this new global economy," Mr. Clinton said.
In a year in which his political troubles continue to be compounded by Federal inquiries into the Whitewater affair and the conduct of members of his Cabinet, Mr. Clinton also used the news conference to suggest again that his Administration was being held to an unprecedentedly high standard.
Mr. Clinton did not directly answer when asked by a reporter whether he would demand the resignations of Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown or Transportation Secretary Federico F. Pena if inquiries into their conduct were expanded with the appointment of a special prosecutor. Already, the Administration is contending with three separate such investigations: one into the Clintons' conduct in the Whitewater matter and unrelated accusations against former Agriculture Secretary Mike Espy and Henry G. Cisneros, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development.
But Mr. Clinton defended his own conduct and that of his aides, and noted that little more than a specific accusation against a top Government official now set off the appointment of a special prosecutor.
"If you look at the rules and you look at the facts instead of the number of investigations," Mr. Clinton said, "man, there's no way to control that under that new law."
In answer to another question at the 46-minute session, which was held in an auditorium in the Old Executive Office Building, Mr. Clinton said the criticism by several African-American leaders would not deter him from combing through Federal programs to determine whether some affirmative-action initiatives were no longer necessary.
Mr. Clinton dodged a question about whether he favored Federal laws that required that certain contracts to be set aside for minority-owned businesses. But he defended the idea of providing enhanced opportunities for minorities and children, and he pointed out that he had practiced affirmative action himself in filling jobs within his Administration.
After a week in which Senator Phil Gramm of Texas and Lamar Alexander formally declared their candidacies for the Republican Presidential nomination while Senator Richard G. Lugar of Indiana all but did so, Mr. Clinton was most revealing when asked about his own plans for the 1996 race.
He said he hoped he would not face a similar challenge from within his party, and contended that his own record of achievement would make it difficult for a Democrat to run against him. And when reminded that the Senate majority leader, Bob Dole, another Republican aspirant, had voiced blunt criticism of him this week, Mr. Clinton replied with a plea against name-calling.
"It's March of 1995," Mr. Clinton said with apparent disbelief. He added: "I can see right now, every day, everybody that wants to run for this job is going to be trying to make some remark or some move that runs everybody else halfway up the flagpole. We've got enough politics in this town on a regular basis without injecting that into it."
