HEADLINE: Technology Issues Fuel Stock Market Advance

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Stocks closed higher yesterday as strength in technology issues countered the impact of the dollar's slide to a new low against the Japanese yen.
 The Dow Jones industrial average rose 9.68 points, to 3,989.61, but it finished the week down 22.13 points. The broader Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks edged up 0.29 point yesterday, to 485.42. 
 The dollar touched a record low of 93.75 yen before settling at 94.14 yen, even as the Federal Reserve, the Bank of Japan and European central banks bought dollars in an unsuccessful effort to prop up the value of the dollar.
 A weaker dollar makes American stocks and bonds less attractive to foreign investors, and yesterday's slide unnerved the bond market. Treasury prices tumbled, sending the yield on the 30-year bond up to 7.54 percent from 7.48 percent on Thursday. But stocks gained despite the weak dollar and rising interest rates, which make corporate borrowing more expensive.
 Given the dollar's drop, stocks held up impressively well, traders said.
 "The market in my opinion is acting like a champion here," said Timothy Straus, manager of institutional sales at Hancock Institutional Services.
 The advance in the Dow was led by I.B.M., which surged 2 5/8, to 79 7/8, its highest price in two and a half years.
 Indeed, buying yesterday was focused on the technology companies, which are viewed by Wall Street as potential leaders as the economy slows.
 "People are paying a premium for the sustainable revenue growth, and that's the techs," said Jay Ferguson, market analyst at Ferguson, Andrews & Associates.
 Along with I.B.M., Compaq Computer rose 1, to 34 5/8, Dell Computer gained 1 3/4, to 42, Intel was up 257/64 , to 81 7/8, and Texas Instruments jumped 3 1/8, to 86 1/2.
 "With the dollar coming down, these companies will continue to do well," Mr. Straus said. "They have unique proprietary technology with positions globally."
The Nasdaq composite index, virtually a barometer of technology stocks, rose 5.11 points, to 798.79, as it approached its record closing of 803.93 set on March 18, 1994.
 Among the biggest gainers on the Nasdaq market was P-Com, a maker of short-haul radio systems, which made an initial public offering at 15 a share and surged 8 5/8, to close at 23 5/8.
 Software Artistry Inc., another initial public offering, climbed to 20 3/4 from its starting price at 14.
 In Tokyo early yesterday, stocks ended slightly higher. The Nikkei index of 225 issues closed up 76.44 points, or half of 1 percent, at 17,039.62, after falling as low as 16,792.30.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Intervention No Help As Dollar Sinks Again

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 3

 BODY:
The dollar hit another record low against the Japanese yen today as coordinated intervention in currency markets by more than a dozen central banks and strong words from Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin proved no match for a wave of speculation against the currency by traders around the globe.
 The Federal Reserve, the Bank of Japan and a dozen or more European central banks bought dollars and sold other currencies today in an effort to brake the dollar's fall, currency dealers said. It was the first coordinated intervention by central banks to support the dollar since June 24. 
 But the dollar fell anyway, dropping as low as 93.75 yen, passing the previous record low of 94.90 set on Thursday in New York trading. The dollar settled today at 94.14 yen, down from 95.22 yen on Thursday. The dollar's slide prompted a sell-off in the United States bond market, where prices tumbled. [Page 44.]
 Mr. Rubin responded to the dollar's slump with an emphatic statement.
 "A strong dollar is in our national interest," he said. "That is why we have acted in the markets in concert with others. The Administration is continuing its work on strengthening economic fundamentals, including bringing down the budget deficit further."
 Mr. Rubin's comments, particularly his identification of the dollar as a national interest, were more strongly worded than statements on the dollar by his predecessor, Lloyd Bentsen. Before leaving office in December, Mr. Bentsen had given the impression on several occasions that he favored a lower dollar so as to make American goods more competitive in Japan. Mr. Bentsen urged the Fed last summer not to raise interest rates at a time when the dollar was also in trouble.
 But Mr. Rubin's comments did not appease currency traders. Nor did the purchases by the Fed, which appeared to be spending $500 million or more today, currency dealers said, considerably more than its estimated $250 million foray into the markets on Thursday but still less than its broad intervention last November.
 The dollar's fall this week leaves the Administration with an uncomfortable decision to make next week. Its choices are: to continue intervening, which could be expensive; to urge the Fed to raise short-term interest rates, which could send the economy into a recession, or to do nothing, and risk a further drop in the dollar that might eventually feed inflation.
 C. Fred Bergsten, who was a Treasury official in the Carter Administration, played down the seriousness of the dollar's plight. Some weakness in the dollar is understandable when interest rates here are stable or slightly falling, he said.
 "You only need to worry about a decline in your currency when it is juxtaposed with a significant rise in your interest rates," he said. Such a combination means that investors are so unhappy with a country's economy that they do not buy its currency or securities even when the investment returns are improving.
 President Clinton declined to discuss the dollar and interest rates at his internationally televised news conference today. "You know, one of the things I've learned since I've been here is that anything I say on this subject is wrong," he said. "So the Treasury Department is taking appropriate action today, and I don't think I should say anything else."
 The comment disappointed some traders who had hoped for another statement of Administration resolve to defend the dollar.
 Traders and economists generally agreed that the dollar's fall mainly reflected speculation and political issues, like perceptions of the Clinton Administration's weakness, rather than broad problems in the American economy. "There's no question the move reeks of being highly speculative in nature," said Stephen Flanagan, a currency trader at Credit Agricole in New York.
Unlike Wall Street traders, top Fed officials have traditionally been more concerned about the dollar's overall strength against the currencies of all of the United States' trading partners. The Fed has long watched for broad and deep drops in the dollar's value before concluding that imports would become more expensive and might feed inflation.
 The dollar has fallen 5.72 percent in value against the yen in the last month, and 6.71 percent against the mark. But the dollar has risen against the currencies of two of its largest trading partners, Canada and Mexico. In the last month, the dollar has risen 19.53 percent against the peso and 0.41 percent against the Canadian dollar.
 In other trading, the dollar fell as low as 1.4232 German marks, its lowest level since October 1992. It settled at 1.4244 marks, down from 1.4435 marks.
 According to the latest quarterly report by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, the Fed spent $1.3 billion worth of foreign currencies on Nov. 2 and another $1.3 billion on Nov. 3 to prop up the dollar. Half the money each day came from the Fed's own reserves and half from the Treasury's Exchange Stabilization Fund.
 Mr. Flanagan of Credit Agricole and other traders mentioned a concern that the $36 billion exchange stabilization fund might run short on money to support the dollar because the Clinton Administration had offered to lend as much as $20 billion from the fund to Mexico.
 Lawrence H. Summers, the Under Secretary of the Treasury for International Affairs, sought to address this concern in a speech this morning defending the American assistance. "I can assure you that the Administration would not have contemplated this action if we were not completely confident that the resources of E.S.F. will still be sufficient to engage in any foreign exchange market interventions that may prove to be necessary," he said.
 The Fed also has $33 billion worth of lines of credit from foreign central banks that it can tap when needed for the dollar's defense.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Copper Rises a Third Day On Firm European Demand

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Copper prices rose yesterday for the third consecutive session as falling warehouse inventories showed strong demand from European manufacturers.
 "In other parts of the world, outside the U.S., demand has been firming," said Bette Raptopoulos, an analyst with Prudential Securities in New York. "In Europe, there has been continued strong demand." 
 On other commodity markets, lumber prices fell while gasoline rose. The Commodity Research Bureau index of 21 commodities fell 0.56 point, to 232.11.
 Copper inventories in London Metal Exchange warehouses in Europe and Asia plunged 3.4 percent this week to their lowest level since August 1992 as copper in Commodity Exchange warehouses in the United States fell to its lowest level in more than four months.
 Copper prices were also bolstered after Germany's most powerful union, IG Metall, said on Thursday that it would return to the bargaining table on Monday after a weeklong strike. The announcement prompted expectations that demand for copper from German factories might not suffer from prolonged labor disruptions.
 Copper for March delivery jumped 2.4 cents, to $1.367 a pound, on the Commodity Exchange of New York. The contract has risen 5 percent in the last three days. The actively traded May contract gained 1.10 cents, to $1.3275 a pound.
 Lumber prices fell close to a three-month low on signs of a sluggish housing market.
 While the Commerce Department yesterday reported a surprising 3.8 percent gain in sales of new single-family homes during January, traders said the market would be weaker this year than last.
 "We're in a bear market," said Greg Riley, a lumber trader with the Bloch Lumber Company, a distributor in Chicago.
 The May lumber contract fell the exchange-imposed $10 trading limit, to settle at $294.70 for 1,000 board feet, on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, the lowest for the active contract since Dec. 15.
 Gasoline rose on concern that inventories, already 3.5 percent smaller than last year, may fall further as refiners begin slowing production to perform seasonal maintenance.
 April gasoline rose 0.35 cent, to 55.94 cents a gallon, on the New York Mercantile Exchange, while crude oil for April delivery gained 28 cents, to $18.63 a barrel.

HEADLINE: Japan Securities: A Downhill Ride

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 3

 BODY:
Minoru Yoshida laughs nervously about his annual income falling to $40,000 from $180,000 a few years ago, but he points to fellow brokers who have it even worse: they do not get any paychecks at all, and even have to reimburse their employers for insurance contributions.
 "The securities world in general is suffering," he said. "Some people say that the reason the stock market is down is that the industry is kuu-dooka." 
 It is a startling choice of words. Kuu-dooka, or hollowing out, is the Japanese term for dying industries. It used to apply to some Japanese manufacturing sectors, as rising costs forced companies to move their factories abroad, leaving just the shell of the company in Japan.
 Now, times have become so rough for brokers in the securities industry here that they are resorting to the same phrase to describe their plight. For Mr. Yoshida and others, it is a radical change from the heady days of a few years ago, when the Tokyo stock market hit its peak and was perhaps the most active and alluring in the world. Now, the market has fallen to less than half its record high, and the industry is not only battling its bleakest period in recent history, it is facing the possibility that it may be hollowing out.
 Burdened by regulation and years of losses, the securities industry is nudging tens of thousands of people off payrolls and leaving scores of firms wandering fitfully in a market that seems more like an abandoned ghost town than a securities exchange.
 "They should turn them into tennis courts -- it would be much more profitable," Alicia Ogawa, an analyst at Salomon Brothers Asia Ltd., said of the Japanese securities companies.
 The pitfalls of the Tokyo stock market became all the more evident in the last few days when a stock trader in Singapore lost more than $1 billion on bets that prices on the Japanese market would rise. Yet many executives in Japan fear that the consequences here of the failed bet -- the collapse of the British investment bank Barings P.L.C. -- will be more regulation of the Tokyo market. That, they argue, would only add to the cost of doing business in Japan -- and thus to the risk of a hollowing out of the stock market.
 Foreign corporations are already fleeing. Of the 127 foreign companies that used to be listed on the Tokyo Stock Exchange, 34 have taken their shares off the exchange since the peak, half of them delisting last year. And Chinese and other Asian companies are angling for listings in New York and London, rather than Tokyo.
 Investors and foreign brokerage firms are taking their Japanese business overseas, and Japanese securities operations are doing brisk business abroad while everything is shrinking at home. Moreover, since Japanese banks are forbidden from engaging in equity trading in Japan, they have gone abroad to set up trading subsidiaries in London, Singapore and elsewhere.
 "This is the beginning of the crisis, not the end," said Tsugio Tajiri, a finance professor at Tokyo International University. Mr. Tajiri said that Government measures in the stock exchange had stifled liquidity in the market. "It means the death of the stock market," he said.
 The funereal orations may be hyperbole, and some experts not only deny that kuu-dooka is taking place but assert that the Japanese market now has nowhere to go but up. Others argue that painful losses and consolidation in Kabutocho, or Tokyo's Wall Street, will only make the Japanese securities industry more formidable.
 But a recent survey of 350 top Japanese corporate executives reflected fear, not confidence, concluding that the securities markets are in a "crisis situation." Some of their comments were blunt: "The securities market is like a sick person." "The market has reached a terminal stage." "The market is paralyzed."
 The news these days echoes the gloom. Japan's largest securities firm, Nomura Securities, surprised the financial community last month by announcing disappointing earnings results for the first 10 months of this fiscal year. And CS First Boston announced recently that it would shut down equity trading operations in Tokyo.
 Foreign brokerage firms have been hurt because of the cost of maintaining expatriates in Tokyo. An apartment for a top executive can cost $20,000 a month or more, and the rent bills come even when the clients do not. Commissions in Japan are essentially fixed and transaction costs are high.
 So some foreign brokerage firms have scaled down their operations in Tokyo, in some cases leaving the market altogether.
 Hardly anyone has been trading. Volume sank to an average of 342 million shares a day last year, compared with levels of more than a billion shares a day in 1988. Many brokerage firms cannot break even at the reduced levels.
 Everyone is hoping that this is just a long bear market, yet many fear that the problem runs deeper than that. "I think this is an industry that has a lot of structural problems," said Robert Alan Feldman, chief economist at Salomon Brothers Asia Ltd.
 In the dark halls of the Finance Ministry, in the same tiny offices where officials once aspired to make the Tokyo market No. 1, much of the talk now is about how to improve market conditions. But deregulation has been slow because it will make it harder for small and medium-sized domestic brokerage firms, which make up most of the stock exchange's membership, to thrive.
 The ministry has helped coddle the industry of 277 brokerage firms for so long that many companies simply do not know how to compete, critics say. Small firms have not yet developed specialties, while larger houses need further diversification of their sources of income, these critics contend.
 Now, many small firms are looking for a bailout, but since the ministry is not going to be able to save everyone, they have had to look elsewhere. Century Securities, a medium-sized brokerage firm that has had losses in the last five years, is essentially being rescued by the Brunei Government, which is acquiring a 20.5 percent stake in the firm.
 Critics also say that the ministry's practice of leaning on large domestic institutional investors to support an artificial floor in the market is counterproductive. Such policies and others discourage the development of new products, Western analysts say, so that the types of securities traded, like equity derivatives, are less sophisticated versions of those traded in New York and London.
 A new agreement between Japan and the United States may help to change that by broadening access to a range of financial services in Japan, and there are hopes that the accord might revive the industry and lead to potentially lucrative new markets, like one in asset-backed securities.
 But ministry officials say change is unlikely to come with the suddenness of the May Day deregulation of the United States stock market in 1975 or the so-called Big Bang deregulation of the London financial markets in 1986.
 "A Big Bang is not suitable for our society," said a Finance Ministry official who insisted on anonymity. "But in the long run, we can see a bang. In a 10-year period, we can say it will be a kind of a bang."
 Some foreign firms are hoping the mini-bang will come sooner and are eyeing the Tokyo stock market now. Smith New Court Securities and Paribas Capital Markets last month announced that they would buy seats on the stock exchange that were vacated by Prudential Securities and Kidder, Peabody. And economists say that a buoyant market could do wonders for the general mood.
 "Why are the capital markets in Japan not good? Because the Japanese economy is not good," said Hirohiko Okumura, chief economist at Nomura Research Institute. "If growth comes back to 3 percent, everyone will rush back."

HEADLINE: Helmsley Sells Brokerage In '94 Kickback Scandal

BYLINE: By By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
Brown, Harris, Stevens, a real estate brokerage and co-op management company that was engulfed in a kickback scandal last year, has been sold by Harry Helmsley to the heirs to two of New York City's real estate dynasties.
 Two of the four buyers, Arthur Zeckendorf, 36, and Kent Swig, 34, confirmed the sale in an interview yesterday, although they would not disclose the terms. 
 Mr. Zeckendorf, a member of the buying group along with his brother, William Lie, 36, is the son of William Zeckendorf Jr., who was one of the most active builders of New York City office towers and condominiums in the 1980's.
 Mr. Swig's family owns the Fairmont hotel chain and has built several Manhattan office buildings. His business associate David Burris, 40, is the fourth buyer.
 Brown, Harris, Stevens, which had been owned by Mr. Helmsley since 1964, is the management agent for 128 Manhattan buildings, including The Dakota, on Central Park West; the Fifth Avenue co-op building where Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis lived until her death last year; and dozens more of the most expensive co-ops on Fifth and Park Avenues.
 Mr. Swig said yesterday that Brown, Harris, Stevens was "very strong financially." But real estate sources have said attorneys and business managers for Mr. Helmsley, who is 85 years old and in ill health, have been trying to sell the company for at least four years, in part because of its recent legal troubles and Mr. Helmsley's.
 Mr. Helmsley was indicted for income tax fraud in 1988 but was found mentally incompetent to stand trial; his wife, Leona, served 30 months in prison for her 1989 conviction on charges she evaded $1.2 million in income taxes.
 Last year, 17 employees or former employees of Brown, Harris, Stevens were among more than 80 New York City co-op management agents who were charged by the Manhattan District Attorney with extorting million of dollars in kickbacks from contractors and suppliers.
 Brown, Harris, Stevens dismissed the agents and settled a civil lawsuit that grew out of the case by making more than $1 million in restitution to the owners of co-ops that it managed.
 Mr. Swig said yesterday he considered last year's kickback scandal to be history that will not be repeated, adding that he saw no threat that the firm would lose any of the exclusive Manhattan co-ops on its client list. The firm's president, Roger Tuckerman, and other top managers will be retained, he said.
 "This a gem, a great firm," Mr. Swig said, adding that he and his partners plan no changes in a business strategy of "focusing on management of upper-end co-ops." But he said his buying group also hoped to expand Brown, Harris, Stevens' business as a broker and manager of commercial office space.
 The sale brings together some of the most prominent members of what has been called the next generation of real estate dynasties. The Zeckendorf brothers and Mr. Swig are among more than a dozen men and a handful of women, from 25 to 40 years old, who have taken control of the city's largest family-owned real estate development companies at a time when the weak economy has slowed construction nearly to a standstill.

HEADLINE: The Shrinking Welfare State

 BODY:
Gov. George Pataki announced this week that he wanted to move even faster than planned to dump supposedly able-bodied New York State recipients from the Home Relief rolls. He and New York City's Mayor, Rudolph Giuliani, also want to reduce Home Relief and other welfare benefits outright. Their goal of ending welfare as a way of life is laudable. But punitive acts against people who need help to survive won't take them there.
Driving people off the rolls and cutting welfare benefits rest on a popular but false assumption that New York is a welfare free-spender. The Mayor and Governor point out that the total spent in New York State on the main welfare program, Aid to Families with Dependent Children (A.F.D.C.), is greater than what is spent by every other state except California. But that is simply because New York has more poor people eligible for welfare than any other state except California. There are now about 1.1 million people on welfare in New York City, of whom 586,000 are children. 
 As the Mayor acknowledges, the maximum monthly benefit of $577 for a family of three in New York makes it the seventh most generous state. The proposed cutbacks in A.F.D.C. payments to $539 would make it tenth. But since rents and other costs are much higher there than in other states, New York is not really out of line.
Besides, adjusted for inflation, welfare payments in New York have been eroding for two decades. The Citizens Budget Commission, a fiscally conservative group, calculates that total spending for A.F.D.C., Home Relief, emergency assistance and aid for the aged, blind and disabled in the city declined in real terms by 17 percent from 1975 to 1992. Two decades ago the goal of welfare was to keep a family at poverty level. Today, even with food stamps, those families are well below it.
The rising cost of Medicaid for poor people, on or off welfare, does pose a threat to the city's solvency. But welfare grants do not. The cost of grant payments for A.F.D.C. and Home Relief in New York City have remained at about 4 percent of city tax revenues for more than a decade.
Governor Pataki is right in looking for ways to stop the system from perpetuating teen-age pregnancies, illegitimacy and dependency. Work requirements have proved effective in many cases, and the Governor and Mayor should be encouraged to expand those efforts. But people with experience in welfare say most adults on welfare cannot work because of mental and physical problems or because there are no jobs. Time limits and benefit cuts for such people will not change those facts.
New York will probably find what other states have found, that moving people from welfare rolls to payrolls requires a mixture of economic incentives and services for people who need help to find and hold down jobs. The city and state should be prepared to bear the cost of those services. Whether that means expanding the government bureaucracy or contracting out to others remains to be decided. But imposing cuts arbitrarily in the allowances for poor families with children is cruel and dangerous. It will almost certainly mean hunger, homelessness and the breakup of families among the poor.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Players Accept Important Part of Owners' Proposal

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., March 3

 BODY:
In the roller-coaster world of strike-bound baseball, just when talks between the owners and the players appeared to be on the verge of collapse, the players took a stunning step today and laid the groundwork for another possible major step.
 With Bud Selig, the acting commissioner, back in Milwaukee and speaking with fellow owners by telephone, the negotiating team he left behind heard the players' negotiators say they would accept the clubs' revenue-sharing plan in the form the players had long rejected. 
 In another critical economic area, the players proposed a 25 percent luxury tax for three years on portions of payrolls over a certain threshold. The players did not specify a threshold, but suggested it be negotiated.
 That seemed to be a significant step, too. When the players gave their "best" plan to Bill Usery Jr., the Federal mediator, at his request during a round of talks in Washington last month, they suggested a 25 percent tax on payrolls beyond $59 million.
 Donald Fehr, the union chief, said today that the players were prepared to "move off that substantially," but he also cautioned that "any luxury tax would have to start at a threshold substantially above the average payroll," which the union has computed at $40.6 million.
 If the owners should agree to the 25 percent tax rate, the two sides would have to find a compromise threshold somewhere between $40.6 million and $59 million. They almost certainly will have a difficult time finding that compromise.
 Negotiators held three sessions today and will resume talking on Saturday.
 The players' action, which the owners cautiously applauded, revived the talks, changing their status nearly 180 degrees from 24 hours earlier when Selig angrily told the players, in effect, that he was taking his ball and his bat and going home.
 A Wednesday night session had angered the owners because they felt the union was stalling.
 But union officials, according to a person on the players' side, had to re-evaluate their position after learning that evening that they had received conflicting information from the mediator.
 John Harrington of the Boston Red Sox, chairman of the owners' negotiating committee, followed Selig out of town early this morning. That left Jerry McMorris of the Colorado Rockies as the reluctant team leader for the owners at today's bargaining sessions, which Fehr did not attend.
 "Accepting the revenue-sharing agreement for five years is no small step," Fehr said at a news conference. "It is not an agreement we like at all, but it's one the owners have made clear is the price of any agreement. They now have it."
 The union, he added, found the plan somewhat easier to accept after the owners acknowledged that it placed a drag on salaries, a view the owners long had rejected.
 McMorris, following Fehr, said the owners "appreciate the fact that we apparently now have put the revenue-sharing plan to rest." He called it a "positive step" but not "earthshaking."
 Under the plan, the clubs would generate $58 million from high-revenue clubs to be given to low-revenue clubs. The players proposed a phase-in period, matching the owners' previous proposal of raising 40 percent of the money the first year, 60 percent the second and 80 percent the third, with the plan taking full effect in the fourth.
 The players' opposition to the revenue-sharing plan had been based on the way the clubs would generate money to be allocated to low-revenue teams. It would come from high-revenue clubs, and the players contend that those clubs therefore would spend less on salaries.
 The players view the payroll tax on a short-term basis because they feel the industry's economic position will change significantly by 1998.
 "When we recognize that in 1998 you should have a rebuilding of central revenues and expansion money," Fehr said, "we should be in position to get through this period of time where the clubs have felt the need to reorder their finances."
 McMorris offered no immediate response to the players' 25 percent tax rate. The owners had disliked the players' most recent tax proposal so much that they never responded to it. Presented Feb. 4 in Washington, the proposal called for a three-tiered tax based on a threshold of $40.6 million, the average 1994 payroll as computed by the union.
 But the clubs were disdainful of the top tier, 25 percent, because that threshold, $65 million, is a level no club ever has reached. As with the players' previous proposals, the owners said that one did not place enough of a drag on salaries.
 Showing what they meant by a drag on salaries, the owners three days earlier had proposed a 75 percent tax on the portion of payrolls over $35 million and a 100 percent tax on everything beyond $42 million.
 Under the owners' plan, the Yankees would have paid $14 million in tax on their 1994 payroll had the season been played in its entirety; they would have paid $1.5 million under the players' proposal.

HEADLINE: New York City Can't Solve Its Budget Crisis by Confronting Albany

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Esther R. Fuchs's advice to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani (Op-Ed, Feb. 22) on how to deal with the budget crisis is based on a series of ill-founded assumptions, irrelevancies and wishful thinking. New York has spent more on services than other cities because, unlike many of them -- Chicago, for example -- it has no separate county government structure on which it can dump some of the costly functions. New York also spent more because it had more. With its economic base eroded, the capacity to spend more has gone. 
 "Spreading the pain" is an attractive slogan but practically it means raising taxes, something no one has suggested. Spreading the pain by cutting programs that benefit the middle class and rich is a dry hole because the bulk of services -- police, fire, sanitation and debt service -- serve all citizens relatively equally. The beneficiaries of almost all of the rest of the budget -- youth services, social services, housing, homeless, welfare, health and hospital care and even education (the rich go to private schools), transportation (the rich take cabs) -- are poor. Cuts must come from these services because, in Willie Sutton's famous words, that is where the money is.
Most of Professor Fuchs's other recommendations -- state takeover of Medicaid, welfare, court maintenance and corrections, and more money for education and transportation -- have been on the city's agenda for years. The Mayor's predecessors, who were political allies of two of the three power centers in Albany, were unable to accomplish them. The assertion that Mayor Giuliani can, in the next four months, achieve what his predecessors couldn't in 20 years is unrealistic, even assuming the Mayor has potentially great power in Albany.
The same is true of the proposed changes in state law concerning the city's relationship with its employees. These proposals have been on the agendas of one or another Democratic mayor, or perhaps all, for 20 years. A budget-cutting program based on these proposals would be derided by the rating agencies, the bond market and the press. Moreover, the Mayor will probably have more success with the collective bargaining process in his own backyard than with the State Senate.
Professor Fuchs urges the Mayor to confront Albany, to go to Albany and fight. Fighting and confronting won't solve this year's budget crisis.
 
 WARD N. COSTIKYAN
New York, Feb. 27, 1995

HEADLINE: For Lakehurst, More Bad News

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LAKEHURST, N.J., March 2

 BODY:
Hard luck dogged Lakehurst long before this week's recommendation by the Pentagon to close the Naval Air Warfare Center here. Just when it seemed the town's fortunes were riding high, something would bring it all crashing down.
 That was literally the case in the Hindenburg disaster. 
 The huge German zeppelin, nearly three football fields long, burst into flames and crashed, killing 36 people, as it tried to moor at the Naval Air Station in Lakehurst on May 6, 1937. The crash ended the era of lighter-than-air passenger service and tainted Lakehurst's nickname as Airship Capital of the World, though Navy blimps from Lakehurst continued to patrol the Atlantic until the 1960's.
 Before the dirigibles brought the first trans-Atlantic air passengers, Lakehurst was a bustling railroad town, with the steam locomotive Blue Comet stopping here several times a day to take on water and blast its whistle. For a while the town was a resort, attracting guests to the multiturreted Pine Tree Inn, advertised in New York newspapers as a pine-scented haven, a real tonic for the city dweller's health.
 But the inn was torn down the same year the Hindenburg exploded, and the Blue Comet ran out of steam long ago.
 Still there was always the Navy base to bolster the local economy and keep the town on the map. That, too, now seems just another casualty for Lakehurst. Unless the White House or Congress intervenes, the Navy will transfer the Air Warfare Center and about 600 civilian engineers and 16 military personnel to bases in Maryland and Florida. Some 500 civilians and 50 sailors will remain in Lakehurst to operate four mile-long tracks used to test aircraft carrier catapult and landing arrest systems.
 The jobs of 1,800 other civilian workers now employed at the base will be terminated under the plan.
 Rumors about the shutdown circulated months ago but were hard to believe, workers said, because the center's research, development and testing work on aircraft launching and landing equipment did not exist at any other base. They told each other that since aircraft carrier fleets were at the heart of America's ability to project military power around the globe, it was inconceivable that Lakehurst and its $100 million payroll -- the largest in Ocean County -- would disappear.
 All the logic came crashing down in flames with Secretary of Defense William Perry's recommendation to the Defense Base Closure and Realignment Commission.
 "It's a crying shame," said Tom Reidy, a middle-aged technician employed by the Navy, after hearing the news. "It'll affect younger people more than me, and I feel for them. I've had plenty of years on the job."
 The Navy will not close Lakehurst's gates overnight. The base has two years to plan for the move and six to complete it. Capt. Leroy A. Farr, the base commander, said his best guess was that the change would be accomplished by the end of the decade.
 The delay was of small comfort to those who live in Lakehurst, population 3,000, or to those in the area who depend on the daily flow of civilian base workers.
 "Once the base is closed, there'll be nothing left around here but menial work," said Cliff Muliero, 55, a barrel-chested man who fled the Bronx for Lakehurst 20 years ago to work in construction. He sat at the bar in the Airship Tavern, a popular place for Navy workers at the close of a shift, bent over a bottle of beer and dreading the future.
 "If that happens, everyone will leave -- whooosh!" he said, moving his arm along the bar like a scythe through wheat.
 "The stores will close with no customers, and property taxes will go up," Mr. Muliero said, the anger rising in his voice. "If that happens, guys like us will just walk away from our mortgages because our houses won't be worth anything, isn't that right, Eddie?" Mr. Shaw asked, turning to the man on the next stool, Eddie Shaw, now retired from his job in Jersey City. Mr. Shaw nodded in sullen agreement.
 Alton Tilton, the gentle-mannered Mayor of Lakehurst who worked for 23 years at the base as a parachute rigger, is not as pessimistic. "Something new has always come along in Lakehurst to provide jobs," said Mr. Tilton, now 68.
 Ocean County, with nearly 40 miles of coastline, has always had thriving summer tourism. But industry lagged even as the population, spurred by retirement communities and middle-class housing sprouting in the piney woods, jumped from 56,000 in 1950 to nearly 450,000 today.
 The largest employer in the county used to be the Toms River Chemical Company, taken over by the Ciba-Geigy Corporation and eventually shuttered in the late 1980's after a series of clashes with the Government and environmentalists over the dumping of hazardous wastes.
 "When Ciba-Geigy moved away, we thought at least the good old Navy was going to be around as long as we were," said Ray Reiss, another former Bronx resident who owns Lakehurst Photo Center, a camera and film supply shop. Faced with the potential loss of some 1,700 engineers, technicians and workers, Mr. Reiss said he didn't know how long he could stay in business.
 "It looks like it's going to be the seniors or nothing," he said with a smile, referring to the retirement communities ringing the base.
 But Michael Caruso, a former chief aviation machinist at the base who now sells real estate, said he thought the closing would stop the flow of military retirees into the area because they would no longer have the post exchange, commissary and medical services to use.
 Yet there are those who see bright linings, even opportunity.
 Rich Headley, program manager in the base's prototype and manufacturing department, said he was in contact with private investors who might be interested in buying or leasing his operation from the Government. His section works out of a $73 million plant, making flight deck cables used to catch a Navy jet's tailhook as it lands at 150 miles per hour, stopping it in under three seconds.
 "The taxpayer paid for this facility, why just tear it down?" he asked.
 The western half of the boomerang-shaped base will remain active because that is where the jet-powered sleds and long tracks used for testing are. What becomes of the eastern half will be resolved in coming years.

Borough Gets Some Good News

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE VAN GELDER 

DATELINE: CARTERET

 BODY:
Color the future a little rosier for this borough after the Legislature voted to designate it an urban enterprise zone. "This could mean the rebirth of Carteret and the surrounding areas," said Mayor Peter J. Sica. "Carteret is an old industrial area, but many of the industries have moved out. So this is a heck of an attraction to bring new business and industries back here." Among the lures are reduction of the sales tax, from 6 to 3 percent, on all purchases in the community; elimination of sales taxes on materials purchased by new businesses; a $1,500 corporate tax break for new businesses that hire people from Carteret, and a 50 percent reduction in the unemployment insurance rate.

HEADLINE: WORD & IMAGE;
Innumeracy<2>

BYLINE: By MAX FRANKEL 

 BODY:
NEWSPAPERS AND newscasts that would never permit reports on "President Bill" and "Mayor Rudy" without their family names seem to have no compunction about regularly omitting the family names of vital news statistics -- the denominators without which most numerical facts are just mush. So Bill has reduced the Federal payroll by 98,000 jobs: yes, but out of how many? Is that an impressive saving or a drop in the bucket? And yes, Rudy has vowed to close a gap of $2.7 billion: in how large a budget? In a whole page about the deficit one day last month, The Times never said.
That gap, by the way, is only a projected deficit -- dependent on estimates of future tax collections, about which Rudy was wrong last year. It is also dependent on future Federal and state subsidies, about which President Bill and Governor George must still bargain with Congress and the New York Legislature. The gap will be further affected by inflation and maybe also by Yankee batting averages (if Owner George and his colleagues permit a proper pennant race that will draw crowds). 
 America needs baseball back, if only because that's the only way it learns to handle rates (batting averages), probabilities (who expects to live long enough to see 61 homers again?) and context (how come the team with the lowest wages had the best record before the strike?).
Deploying numbers skillfully is as important to communication as deploying verbs, but you won't find many media practicing that philosophy. Most schools of journalism give statistics short shrift and some let students graduate without any numbers training at all. How can such reporters write sensibly about trade and welfare and crime, or air fares, health care and nutrition? The media's sloppy use of numbers about the incidence of accidents or disease frightens people and leaves them vulnerable to journalistic hype, political demagoguery and commercial fraud.
THANKS TO NORMA SOSA, A Times editor who often goes on numbers patrol in the paper's columns, I have at hand a few examples of such sloppiness, which, I choose to believe, occurs in this newspaper much less frequently than elsewhere. About a year ago, The Times reported the startling conclusion of a study published by The Journal of Clinical Psychiatry that depression was costing America $43.7 billion a year -- "on a par with heart disease." One element in that total was the alleged loss of "lifetime earnings" by one year's 18,400 suicides -- magically rendered as $7.5 billion ($407,608.69 each?). Days lost from work were more modestly reckoned as worth about $11.7 billion and "impairment of work from symptoms" while people continued on the job was said to have cost $12.1 billion. The rest was the cost of psychiatric care, generously omitting unnecessary medical tests and other "hidden" charges.
I dwell on this example only because it combines adding apples and oranges with false precision and pure guessing in what was surely meant to be a helpful warning about a major health problem. Some other examples in the Sosa file were less complex but equally unhelpful. The Times described a plan to put a 10 percent surcharge on taxable incomes above $1 million as a "10 percent surcharge on millionaires." It reported that Russian miners were demanding a "150 percent pay increase" (in one paragraph) and wanting their salaries "increased by two and a half times" (in the next). It reported that China's clothing sales to the United States might be reduced "by more than $1 billion," without a hint of whether that's a billion paid to the Chinese or charged at retail, and what portion of China's business was at risk.
THE TIMES AND other good papers, I'm sure, are slowly raising the numeric consciousness of their staffs. But the dirty secret about the media's contribution to American "Innumeracy," first examined in a delightful book by that title by John Allen Paulos, is about to be revealed in his sequel, "A Mathematician Reads the Newspaper." Wittily, but also sometimes obscurely, Paulos demonstrates how mathematical thinking might have enhanced the public's understanding of the news or at least avoided egregious error and simplistic conclusion. "Mathematics," he reminds us, "is not primarily a matter of plugging numbers into formulas and performing rote computations. It is a way of thinking and questioning that may be unfamiliar to many of us, but is available to almost all of us."
By far his most elegant example -- relevant to a great number of news articles -- shows how easily unthinking writers or readers will be misled by "conditional probability," as experienced in a test to discover disease:
Suppose that a test for disease D is celebrated as 99 percent accurate -- meaning that if you have the disease the test will be positive 99 times out of 100 and if you don't it will be negative 99 times out of 100. And suppose that 1 of every 1,000 people actually has this disease. Now assume the test for D is given to 100,000 people; 99 of them will both have the disease and test positive. But of the 99,900 healthy people, 1 percent or 999 will also test positive -- falsely. In other words, of the 1,098 (99 plus 999) who tested positive, only 9 percent, a mere 1 out of 11, will actually be sick. And that small number, remember, in a test that was rightly called 99 percent accurate!
How many newspapers reporting such a study could correctly instruct their readers in the meaning of "99 percent accurate" and thus prevent panic among the positives? How many physicians could? How many of us had the wit to question, as Paulos does, the judgment that proportionately more blacks (95 percent) voted for David Dinkins because he is black than whites (75 percent) voted for Mayor Giuliani because he is white? Noting that 80 percent of New York's blacks normally vote Democratic while only 50 percent of whites normally vote Republican, Paulos says it could also be argued that only 15 percent of blacks voted racially as against 25 percent of whites.
Paulos urges that shrewdly chosen numbers would offer healthy context to otherwise alarming news. While "drugs are an undeniable scourge," he notes, the biggest killers are tobacco (400,000 deaths annually) and alcohol (90,000), not cocaine (8,000) or heroin (6,000). Through all the years of anxiety about some 2,000 Americans missing in action in Vietnam, he asks, who remembered that about 8,000 were left missing in Korea and nearly 80,000 in World War II?
More focused instruction, particularly for anyone writing about health, is available in a manual, "News and Numbers," by Victor Cohn. He, too, begins with a lecture on "the certainty of uncertainty," a warning that most scientific information, like the morning weather report, is of a probable nature. And like other students of this subject, Cohn cautions against semantic as well as numerical confusion in the handling of statistics -- between, say, the incidence and prevalence of a disease. ("If incidence is like an entering class" at one period of time, "prevalence is the whole school.")
In one year alone, Sosa found The Times using shortfall ("the quantity or extent by which something falls short") to mean shortage, decline, unpaid bill, difference, unmet budget request, debt, remainder and deficit. And then there was the Broadway critic who observed that bludgeoning the audience into laughter with fast and furious action was one director's response "to the comic shortfall."
Fast and furious action is usually how the media distract from a vast numeric shortfall.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 55; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 1698 words

HEADLINE: Pied Piper

BYLINE: By Molly O'Neill 

 BODY:
The appeal of a savory pie (on a cold winter night, with a blizzard in the forecast) is not a primitive one. Making pastry crust, after all, is an expression of a settled (and presumably civilized) society, requiring time to confect and a flame to bake.
Nevertheless, the urge to envelop a hearty filling in dough and bake it until it's bubbly hot is almost universal. The British have their steak and kidney pie, the French their quiche Lorraine, the Italians their calzone. Even Americans can lay claim to a crusty morsel, that nostalgic favorite: chicken pot pie. That these pies endure says something about their satisfying, one-dish efficiency. They're also an ode to their tribe. In the medium of a savory pie, the flavors of a culture are layered and baked, then offered up for a communal experience. 
 There is something immensely comforting about seeing a hot tart cooling on the dinner table, its crust waiting to be breached, so that its complex flavors can be revealed. In this regard, the appeal of a savory pie, is extremely sentimental, like seeing a loaf of bread on a cutting board.
Building a pie requires the foresight and patience it takes to build a stew, just more so. While it is usually possible to correct the seasoning and even the balance of ingredients while a stew simmers on the stove, with a pie, the die is cast, so to speak, when you close the oven door.
So the cook must be careful that all the ingredients flatter one another, and that the textures are nicely varied. You must also bear in mind that a pie will be eaten forkful by forkful, so the ingredients must be finely chopped and not unwieldy. Finally, the pie must be properly seasoned before any baking begins. This requires that you know how the flavors will ultimately change and coalesce.
Making a pie, like concocting a stew, takes time -- the kind of time that seems plentiful in winter. But should you begrudge the effort, consider the economies of scale. Proceeded by a peppery green salad like watercress and arugula and followed by a light dessert (never pie or cake but a poached fruit with cookies, ice cream or custard sauce), a winter tart makes a thoroughly delightful meal.
To create the crust, these recipes use a yeasted dough enriched with olive oil. The dough can be made ahead of time and frozen for up to two months but should be defrosted in the refrigerator 24 hours before baking. The dough, of course, is by no means limited to the recipes below. Use it to envelop a panoply of fillings, born serendipitously, from the contents of your refrigerator. You will find the act of creating such a judicious ragout, and then wrapping it in crust, almost as soothing as consuming it. These rustic-looking pies -- not quite pizza, not quite calzone, far removed from pot pie and quiche, in nature and flavor -- are anything but humble.
 
Savory Pie
 
 1 cup warm water
 1 package ( 1/4 ounce) active dry yeast
 2 1/2 to 3 cups all-purpose flour
 1 teaspoon kosher salt
 1 teaspoon olive oil
 1 filling (see recipes)
 1 egg beaten with 1 tablespoon water.
1. Combine water and yeast in a mixing bowl and stir until yeast dissolves. Stir in 1 cup of flour. Stir in salt and a second cup of flour. Sprinkle some of the remaining flour over a work surface and your hands. Scrape dough out of the bowl and onto work surface. Gradually knead in additional flour, until dough no longer feels sticky.
2. Coat large bowl with olive oil. Shape dough into ball and rotate in the bowl to coat with oil. Cover bowl tightly with plastic wrap and set in warm, draft-free place until doubled in bulk, about 1 hour. Punch dough down and knead for about 1 minute. Return dough to bowl and let rise until doubled again, about 45 minutes. Punch down dough.
3. Preheat oven to 400 degrees. Lightly flour back of baking sheet and place dough on it. Roll dough into 12-inch circle, letting dough rest for a few minutes when it becomes too elastic to roll. Place filling in the center of dough and spread out, leaving a 2-inch border. Fold edge of the dough in over filling, making a pleat every 2 inches.
4. Brush rim of pie with egg mixture. Bake until lightly browned and cooked through, about 25 minutes. Let cool slightly, cut into wedges and serve.
Yield: Four servings.

Potato-Leek Filling With Canadian Bacon
 
 Olive oil spray
 3 large red potatoes, halved and thinly sliced
 1 teaspoon olive oil
 2 medium leeks, white and light green parts only, halved lengthwise and cut across into thin slices
 1/2 onion, peeled and diced
 2 cloves garlic, peeled and minced
 2cups sliced mushrooms
 1 teaspoon kosher salt
 Freshly ground pepper to taste
 1/4 cup chopped Italian parsley
 4 slices Canadian bacon, cut into 1/4-inch-thick strips.
1. Preheat oven to 450 degrees. Spray 2 baking sheets with olive oil and divide the potatoes between them, in a single layer. Roast until tender, about 20 minutes.
2. Meanwhile, heat oil in a large nonstick skillet over medium heat. Add leeks and onion and cook until soft, about 7 minutes. Add garlic and mushrooms and cook for 5 minutes longer. Remove from heat and toss in potatoes, salt, pepper and parsley. Assemble the pie as above, sprinkling bacon over the top before baking.
Yield: Four servings.

Squash Filling With Rye Crumb Topping
 
 1 teaspoon roasted garlic oil, optional
 1 butternut squash, halved lengthwise
 1/2 spaghetti squash
 3 teaspoons kosher salt
 Freshly ground pepper to taste
 1 tablespoon thinly sliced fresh sage leaves
 2 slices stale rye bread, broken into pieces
 1/2 cup walnuts
 1 tablespoon chopped fresh rosemary
 1 large clove garlic, peeled and finely chopped
1/2 cup chopped Italian parsley.
1. Prepare the dough as above, using the garlic oil in place of the olive oil, if desired. Preheat the oven to 350 degrees. Place both squash, cut side down, on a baking sheet and bake until soft, about 45 minutes. When cool enough to handle, scrape the insides of the butternut squash into a bowl and stir in 1 teaspoon of salt and pepper to taste. Set aside.
2. Scrape spaghetti squash into a sieve and drain. Place in a bowl and stir in 1 teaspoon of salt, pepper and sage. Set aside. Pulse bread, walnuts, rosemary, garlic and 1 teaspoon of salt in food processor until finely chopped. Stir in parsley.
3. To assemble pie, spread butternut squash over dough as above. Top with 3/4 cup of the crumb mixture. Top with spaghetti squash and then the remaining crumbs. Bake as above.
Yield: Four servings.

Red Cabbage, Bacon And Stilton Filling
 
 1/2 medium head red cabbage, cored and thinly sliced
 2 teaspoons kosher salt
 2 strips thick-cut bacon
 1/2 medium red onion, peeled and chopped
 1 Granny Smith apple, peeled, cored and thinly sliced
 1/2 cup currants
 1/2 teaspoon caraway seeds
 1/4 cup red wine
 Freshly ground pepper to taste
 1/2 cup crumbled Stilton.
1. Place cabbage in large bowl and toss with 1 teaspoon of salt. Let stand for 15 minutes. Meanwhile, cook bacon in large skillet over medium-low heat until crisp, about 10 minutes. Drain, reserving 1 teaspoon of fat. Crumble bacon and set aside. Wipe out skillet and add reserved fat. Drain cabbage.
2. Saute onion over medium heat until soft, about 5 minutes. Add cabbage to the skillet in batches; as the cabbage wilts more will fit in the pan. Stir in apple, currants and caraway seeds and cook for 10 minutes. Stir in wine, lower heat, cover and cook until soft, about 30 minutes.
3. Stir in the remaining salt, the pepper and bacon. Cover and cook for 10 minutes more. Let cool. Assemble the pie and bake as above. Sprinkle the cheese over the top and bake for 5 minutes longer.
Yield: Four servings.

Three-Bean Chili Filling
 
 1/4 cup each red kidney, black and pinto beans, soaked in water overnight and drained
 3 cups water
 1 bay leaf
 2 large jalapenos, seeded and minced
 1 teaspoon ground cumin
 1 teaspoon olive oil
 1/2 large onion, peeled and diced
 1 small green bell pepper, cored, deribbed and diced
 1 medium carrot, peeled and diced small
 1 rib celery, diced small
 2 cloves garlic, peeled and minced
 1 14-ounce can crushed tomatoes with puree
 1 teaspoon dried oregano
 1 teaspoon kosher salt
 Freshly ground pepper to taste
 1 cup grated Monterey Jack cheese
 1/3 cup chopped fresh cilantro.
1. Place beans, water, bay leaf, 1/3 of jalapeno and 1/4 teaspoon of cumin in a large saucepan and bring to boil. Lower heat to simmer, cover and cook until beans are soft, about 2 hours. Drain well and discard bay leaf.
2. Meanwhile, heat olive oil in large nonstick skillet over medium heat. Add onion and green pepper and saute 5 minutes. Add carrots and celery and cook until softened, about 10 minutes. Add garlic and remaining jalapeno and cook 3 minutes longer.
3. Stir in beans, tomatoes, oregano, remaining cumin, salt and pepper. Lower heat, cover and cook for 20 minutes. Cool. Assemble pie and bake as above. Sprinkle cheese over the top and bake for 5 minutes longer. Top with cilantro before serving.
Yield: Four servings.

Smoked Turkey And Basil-Goat-Cheese Filling
 
 2 medium baking potatoes
 4 ounces goat cheese
 1/4 cup heavy cream
 1/3 cup plus 2 tablespoons fresh basil leaves, coarsely chopped
 1 clove garlic, peeled and minced
 2 teaspoons olive oil
 1 medium onion, peeled and diced
 2 roasted red bell peppers, diced
 2 cups cubed smoked turkey
 1 1/2 teaspoons kosher salt, plus more to taste
 Freshly ground pepper to taste.
1. Boil potatoes whole until just tender. When cool, peel and cut into 3/4-inch dice. Set aside. Meanwhile, pulse cheese and cream in a food processor until smooth. Add 1/3 cup of basil and garlic and pulse to combine. Set aside.
2. Heat oil in a large nonstick skillet over medium heat. Add the onion and saute until soft, about 5 minutes. Add the potatoes and cook 5 minutes. Stir in peppers and turkey. Stir in the goat cheese mixture, salt and pepper and cook for about 2 minutes. Cool. Garnish the baked pie with the remaining basil.

HEADLINE: THEATER;
Peter Brook Voyages To Inner Space

BYLINE: By BENEDICT NIGHTINGALE; Benedict Nightingale is chief theater critic of The Times of London.

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
AFTER THE SUCCESS OF Peter Brook's nine-hour version of "The Mahabharata," the most massive project that has yet emerged from his International Center for Theater Research in Paris, everyone he met seemed to assume he would tackle another mythological epic. "Give us your 'Beowulf,' " he remembers people saying, "Give us 'Mahabharata 2.' "
But Peter Brook wouldn't be Peter Brook if he repeated himself. To keep moving, seeking, changing and growing remains a basic article of his faith as he approaches what will likely be a characteristically unfussy 70th birthday on March 21. Mr. Brook is probably the English-speaking world's most eminent director, with productions as pivotal as the Paul Scofield "King Lear" and books as influential as "The Empty Space" among his legacies. But he is most apt to be found quietly chatting in a Left Bank bistro in Paris, where he lives, than going by limo to a champagne reception at the George V. 
 So his decision back in 1987 was unsurprisingly surprising. He determined that after the "Mahabharata" mountain would come a theatrical molehill or, rather, molehole. After venturing among Hindu gods and archaic space wars, he would go burrowing deep into the human head. After "The Mahabharata," which he brought to the Brooklyn Academy of Music nearly eight years ago, would come his company's adaptation of Oliver Sacks's collection of clinical anecdotes, "The Man Who Mistook His Wife for a Hat."
Beginning on Saturday and running through April 9, the production will be staged at what could be called Mr. Brook's American home away from home. Change the audience's language, and BAM's Majestic Theater (remodeled into what looks like a decaying structure) might almost be the shabby old Bouffes du Nord, Mr. Brook's theater in Paris. Indeed, the Brooklyn playhouse was fashioned after the Paris original for the opening of "The Mahabharata."
The delay in bringing "The Man Who," as the piece is now called, to New York tells its own story. The work runs a sixth as long as "The Mahabharata" yet took almost the same amount of time to create. After all, how do you make a coherent evening out of symptoms as diverse as unstoppable nonsense-talk, the inability to register anything to the left of your nose, frantic spasms and outbursts of obscenity, and a fixed belief that it is forever 1945? In his time Mr. Brook has reduced Bizet's "Carmen" to a spare chamberwork in a circle of sand, staged "A Midsummer Night's Dream" on stilts and trapezes, and performed a 12th-century Sufi poem called "The Conference of the Birds" in Australian quarries. But dramatizing Dr. Sacks's bizarre case studies was an awesome challenge even for him.
Dr. Sacks is the British-born, New York-based neurologist who came to notice in 1973 with "Awakenings," his description of patients who made what turned out to be sadly short recoveries from pathological lethargy. The book inspired a missionary fervor in Harold Pinter in particular. Even before the dramatist drew on it for the play "A Kind of Alaska" in 1982, he was excitedly recommending it to the guests at a birthday party for John Gielgud. Mr. Brook, who was among them, read and admired it, met and liked Dr. Sacks; and when "The Man Who Mistook His Wife for a Hat" appeared in 1986, got what he calls "a hunch, a feeling of 'ahhh,' a sense not even of how, where or when, but just that this was something we had to do."
Why? Well, Mr. Brook has long been fascinated by brain, mind and what, without being pious about it, he is prepared to call spirit or soul. All his recent work, from "La Tragedie de Carmen" to his similarly spare version of Debussy's "Pelleas et Melisande," has attempted to penetrate beneath the surface of things, intuit human mystery, and find ways of embodying life's invisible, inscrutable aspects.
"The worst disease today is reductionism," he said on a recent visit to his native London. The question of the spirit "is simply laughed out of court, and I think many people want it back. Certainly, that sort of materialism sets off a deep wish in me to go in the opposite direction."
He found support for that wish in his reading of the more adventurous mathematicians and scientists, starting with Dr. Sacks, who is as much a philosopher and metaphysician as a neurologist. But "The Man Who Mistook His Wife for a Hat" has an obvious emotional appeal, too. The feeling it communicated to Mr. Brook was of modern Homeric heroes battling fearsome tricks of destiny.
"So in a totally different way," he said, "I hoped to achieve what Greek tragedy does. These illnesses show you a situation, more intense than normal, where the question 'What is fate?' is no longer an intellectual subject for debate. And the extraordinary thing is that, when they do so, you're strengthened, with this mysterious, cathartic effect. You can simultaneously face the terrors of human existence and its amazingly positive side."
TAKE THE EXAMPLE OF IAN, A Yorkshireman who as a 19-year-old butcher's apprentice cut his finger, developed a fever and emerged with no feeling at all from his neck down. For a time he was a rag doll who lay in bed and let his mother look after him. But then he discovered that by using his eyes and exercising his will he could make his senseless limbs move. Feeling nothing, he learned to stand, walk, build up an entire repertory of movements and gestures. Last year he went to a party at the National Theater in London, where "The Man Who" was playing, telling Mr. Brook afterward that he had taken a big risk in doing so. For the first time he had abandoned his sneakers for black shoes, making it hard to see his feet and monitor them as he walked upstairs. "Well, I couldn't come to a first night in white shoes, could I?" he said.
But that was in 1994, after the French version of "The Man Who" had played in Paris and the English version had successfully toured Europe. The problem in 1987 was doing theatrical justice to the pain and courage of people like Ian. Mr. Brook's aim was not only to combine mystery with clarity but to express extreme complexity with the extreme simplicity for which he is renowned. But how? "We didn't want documentary," he said, "because that hasn't the energy of theater, and we didn't want fiction, with good doctors and grumpy doctors, Scottish doctors and mid-European doctors, because that hasn't truth. We wanted a piece that would have the closeness of reality and the distance of myth, because if there is no distance you aren't amazed, and if there is no closeness you aren't touched."
Mr. Brook's company tried performing bits of Dr. Sacks's book, only to find the material too literary for the theater. They went to hospitals, met patients and doctors, did improvisations, yet still found the results tended to get showy and false. Since showy and false are the rudest words in the International Center's vocabulary, the project repeatedly got shelved, postponed or, as Mr. Brook now says, put in the drawer that blocked writers reserve for their toughest work. Instead, he turned to the relative security of completed scripts: "Woza Albert!" and "The Tempest."
NEVERTHELESS, KEY decisions gradually got made. The somewhat improbable model for the show would be Ta-Da-Da, the evenings of vaudeville sometimes staged at the Bouffes du Nord but this time with clinical sketches substituting for songs. The original 14 actors, each of whom naturally wanted a fair share of the show's 100 minutes, were reduced to a more manageable four, each playing several roles, including an unobtrusive doctor. The humane and authoritative voice of Dr. Sacks was excluded.
"We tried putting in some beautiful passages from the book, and we tried explaining the diseases," Mr. Brook said. "But we found it was going against what we wanted, which was not to provide a lecture for the cultivated mind, not to be didactic or polemical, but to touch spectators with direct, unfiltered experiences and let them ask their own questions."
And not only questions about alien beings with abstruse afflictions. "The Man Who" -- note that odd, unsettling, vaguely interrogative title -- is "not about mad people, but about you and me," said the director. It is an attempt to fulfill "the ultimate aim of theater, which is to put you in front of something out of life which makes you question something about yourself." It also wants its audiences "to look at something they've taken for granted since they were born, which is a mind, as if it were a great dawn or Everest. Everything in life conspires to take away our sense of wonder. The purpose of a work of art at its best is to feed it."
From another person, those claims and hopes might sound pretentious. From Mr. Brook, they come across as an earnest, mild, shy summing-up of almost 50 years of experience and experiment, first in Britain, latterly mainly in Paris. In his open-necked shirt and sweater he seemed a lot less suited to the rococo grandeur of the Hyde Park Hotel in London, where he started this particular conversation, than to the London underground where, stuck among swaying commuters, he finished it.
That lack of affectation is one reason theater people like and respect him. For Paul Scofield, impressed as he was "by the incredible economy, dignity and compassion" of "The Man Who," he remains a director in whose judgment an actor can put complete trust. Adrian Noble, the director of the Royal Shakespeare Company, speaks of "an extraordinary mixture of inspiration, vision and down-to-earth nuts-and-bolts practicality." Richard Eyre, who runs the National Theater, talks with equal admiration of Mr. Brook's "spiritual quest, his determination to find the most expressive way of telling a story, and his refusal ever to be satisfied or to 'finish' a piece of work, his lack of ego."
Certainly, Mr. Brook himself mistrusts directors with concepts or stances to impose on plays. He is equally uneasy with dramatists who substitute fixed points of view for contradiction and complexity, and so seldom himself directs contemporary texts. "I'm more interested in what we can discover as a group," he said. "My job is to try to refine and structure what we create collectively. I'm not for passive directing, but I react very badly against the illusion, which goes back to the early days of the cinema, of the director as a von Stroheim figure in riding boots with everyone else his servants."
MR. BROOK AND THE playwright Jean-Claude Carriere put together the final script of "The Man Who"; but the actors played a full part in its creation. One went to a convention in Houston, Tex., of people with Tourette's disease, that is to say, with unstoppable tics. There he met every grade of sufferer from the terrified and suicidal to the droll and charming, among them the syndrome's hero, an American physician who can fully control his compulsive spasms in the operating theater, a man who appears in Dr. Sacks's new book, "An Anthropologist on Mars."
The other actors, too, draw on direct experience, and that alone. They realized very early that they could not rely on their imaginations to embody, say, Parkinson's disease or an epileptic fit. Rather, it was a case of observing, mimicking and, always with the group's help, trying to deepen the portrait: working from the outside in, from physical imitation to internal feeling, rather than in Method style, from the inside out.
This meant that many of Dr. Sacks's case studies were omitted, among them a hilarious description of a group of aphasiacs, unable to understand speech but hyper-responsive to phony body language, who were found falling around with laughter in front of a television from which then-President Reagan was delivering a smiling speech. But the company was able to dramatize an example of an affliction not descried in the original book, a young Parisian convinced that everyone he meets is part of a long dream he hopes will soon be over, "because I want to be home for Christmas."
In other short, gritty sketches, the company -- the same one in America as toured Europe -- offers glimpses of the white-haired man who thinks he is 27, the young man who believes his own leg is an amputated limb placed in bed as a practical joke, and the musician who really does try to use his wife's head as a hat.
Mr. Brook's job was what it always is: to strip away theatrical ado, to distill and concentrate, to insure that the production was fresh, spontaneous and natural yet not lacking in intensity. "Americans should be prepared for the fact that our aim is anti-histrionic," he said. "They shouldn't expect violent illustrations of suffering and torment. What we're doing goes in the opposite direction. Our view is that the more talented the actor, the more he just is, the more the devices of acting wither away.
"Sometimes people have said to our actors, 'Have you ever acted before?' and they are half-furious but also half-delighted. Because we want to show people straight from life. We're trying to create a different kind of acting, what we call transparent acting as against virtuoso acting."
What next for this septuagenarian pioneer? Not "The Man Who 2," that's for sure. Mr. Brook's career has been a long attempt to get down to theatrical basics, and later this year he plans to do so in the most conscious way possible.
"For some time we have been researching the conflicting influences that have played on the theater in the 20th century," he said. "Stanislavsky, Brecht, Meyerhold, Gordon Craig, the great, great figures. Our theme is the nature and process of theater itself. What is the theater, what are we doing with it, does it matter? Theater reflecting on theater. But I can't tell you any more about the project because I don't know myself. Once again we are starting from zero."
