HEADLINE: CHOICE TABLES;
In San Diego, Eating Well Without a Tie

BYLINE: By BRYAN MILLER; BRYAN MILLER is a reporter for the style department of The Times.

 BODY:
IT is little exaggeration to say that just 10 years ago in the sun-blessed port city of San Diego some of the better dining was found aboard Navy ships based in the expansive harbor. Of course, you had to enlist to join that eating club.
San Diegans explain their mundane food history by pointing to the splendid weather, which encourages outdoor activities (including cookouts) at the expense of fine dining, and a tradition of entertaining at home. 
 Today, however, that is changing. With its renovated Old Town historic district, the waterfront convention center, a more diversified economic base and a population growing at more than 10,000 annually, a small but conspicuous crop of ambitious restaurants has taken root.
From Coronado Island in the south to Rancho Santa Fe in the north, the San Diego area now offers diversified dining opportunities, not only in French, American and Italian, but also in Korean, Thai, Vietnamese and other Asian cuisines (most of these are storefront affairs in the Kearny Mesa neighborhood).
With a few exceptions, one thing is certain about San Diego dining: it is informal. When a restaurant describes itself as semicasual (the word formal is not in the local lexicon), that means men probably should wear shirts with collars. Casual means you can arrive directly from mowing the lawn (just shake off clippings on your shoes); very casual indicates you don't even have to dry off from swimming.
 
Cilantros
Given the surprising paucity of authentic Mexican food in San Diego, many residents opt for rousing, tequila-fueled hybrids like Cilantros, which serves both Mexican and Southwestern fare. Cilantros is among the better of the genre, a hip, loud place with a bar done in bold Aztec colors where you may have to wait for a table. One could easily compose a meal from the "Southwestern tapas" menu at the bar, which includes tamales, soft tacos, spit-fired chicken wings with jalapeno-honey mustard, and duck-and-wild-mushroom quesadillas. On the main menu, posole, the Mexican chicken-and-hominy soup, needed a trip to the seasoning cabinet; Dungeness-crab-and-corn cake was rather lackluster, served with a peppery chipotle aioli and unnecessary citrus salsa.
One of the more vibrant main courses sampled was barbecued pork tenderloin with a zesty tequila-chili relish and garlic mashed potatoes. Pepper-rubbed ahi tuna was well prepared also.
The dessert list reads as if it were devised by 13-year-olds, that is, no-holds-barred rich. The aptly named La Bomba is a softball of chocolate mint chip gelato layered with cookies, draped with chocolate sauce. Dinner for two runs from $70 to $90.
 
George's at the Cove
On a typical resplendent, sunny day, La Jolla, about 20 minutes north of downtown, is the kind of place that tempts visitors to shred their return airline tickets and toss them into the surf. Prospect Street, high above the coastline, is La Jolla's main strolling thoroughfare, crowded with cafes, boutiques and galleries.
One of the more popular spots for lunch is 11-year-old George's at the Cove, a multilevel affair with a casual open-air terrace on the roof, a cafe in the middle and a more ambitious dining room on the bottom. The affable proprietor, George Hauer, is a welcoming host.
Diners in the main restaurant face a giant window that frames the undulating ocean, suggesting the lounge of an ocean liner. It is done in beige wood, with well-separated tables and rattan chairs. Lunch is a relative bargain in this trendy enclave, about $60 for two (dinner is about $90 for two).
A recent lunch began with the chef's signature soup, a creamy black bean with the unlikely but appealing addition of broccoli and smoked chicken; a rabbit punch of Tabasco and peppers came up out of nowhere. Less assertive is the deep bowl of steamed mussels in a saffron-tinted broth. Fettuccine tossed with superbly sweet rock shrimp, tomato concasse and Parmesan was a harmonious combination, too. Main courses, in staggering portions, include everything from meat loaf with horseradish potatoes and jerk chicken to au courant seafood preparations like whitefish encased in a potato crust.
One fish to try is thresher shark, a cousin of mako, which was remarkably sweet and flaky, sauteed and set over white beans and sliced tomatoes. Considering the portions, trim your sails for dessert with superior tropical sorbets or fresh berries poached in red wine.
 
Marius
One of the few formal places in the city is Marius, in the Le Meridien Hotel at Coronado, about a 10-minutedrive from downtown. Marius is a Provencal style restaurant with a Vietnamese-born chef, Rene Herbeck, who trained in France. The dining room, done in soft ocher toneswith Provencal accents, is comfortable and hushed, and service is unremittingly attentive. Mr. Herbeck cooks straightforward Provencal fare with few hints of his Asian background. Recommended starters include the lush wild mushroom ravioli glossed with herb butter, excellent foie gras sweetened with the intensely fruity wine, Muscat de Beaumes-de-Venise and grapes.
Seafood entrees were winners: grilled sea bass fillet brightened with fennel and surrounded by a delicate saffron sauce; sauteed John Dory, firm and meaty, on a bed of mashed potatoes with sweet roasted shallots. Duck breast encrusted with rosemary was a nice idea, and it was offset by a lavender honey sauce.
Marius has one of the more comprehensive wine lists in the city, and prices are in line for an establishment of this type.
Desserts are artfully turned out, especially the splendid cookie cornucopia filled with raspberries and light cream, and hazelnut chocolate mousse with a terrific praline custard.
 
Mille Fleurs
About a 40-minute drive from downtown is the bucolic community of Rancho Santa Fe, where well-heeled residents clomp by on horseback under drooping eucalyptus trees. Ensconced in this insular little village is what I found to be far and away the best restaurant sampled in greater San Diego, Mille Fleurs.
Owned by a flamboyant Frenchman, Bertrand Hug, it is a romantic lair of stucco, oak-trimmed windows, brick fireplace, flowers and Portuguese tiles. The chef, Martin Woesle, is a classicist with a contemporary style and an innovative touch. A terrine of rabbit-and-root vegetables in aspic was perfectly seasoned; slices of rare duck breast were fanned over thin potato slices and celery root, moistened with a subtle raspberry-tinted dressing.
Among entrees, a superb dish is the tender roasted rabbit perched on a mound of mashed potatoes and ringed with a luxuriant truffle sauce with cubes of sauteed foie gras. The herb-crusted saddle of lamb swathed in French mustard, with Savoy cabbage, was also excellent.
Mille Fleurs offers an expensive, well-chosen, mostly French and Californian wine selection. Desserts emphasize flavor over flair: fresh apple strudel with raisins, cinnamon and rum sauce; orange creme bruee, and wonderful sorbets. A three-course dinner for two runs from $110 to $130.
 
Sally's
Just a jicama's toss from San Diego harbor is a breezy new American restaurant called Sally's -- part of the Hyatt Regency Hotel a short walk away. It's a terrific place to have lunch on a sunny day, especially if you sit outside at umbrella-shaded tables facing the bobbing pleasure boats. The snazzy restaurant is done in ocher tones with a high black ceiling, high-tech accents and handsome wooden booths.
Crab cakes are a good way to start, meaty, moist, well-browned and garnished with scallions. A gazpacho gussied up with shrimp was one dimensional, tasting only of tomatoes. The caesar salad entree with grilled chicken over it was nicely seasoned and fresh. Another appealing warm weather entree is poached salmon served over fanned cucumber slices in a sweetish vinaigrette that complimented the fish; grilled swordfish seasoned with thyme arrived just a tad overcooked but was otherwise tasty over peppery angel hair pasta with shiitakes and red peppers.
For dessert there are satisfying fruit tarts in almond crust and a surprisingly good creme brulee flavored with Grand Marnier (although the sugar crust was too thick). Lunch for two with a glass of wine runs from $50 to $75.
 
Cerveceria Santa Fe
One might reasonably assume that San Diego, a 30-minute drive from Tijuana, would be teeming with good Mexican restaurants. Curiously, this is not true. Mexican cuisine, by and large, seems to be considered one step up from Taco Bell. One can find superior individual dishes here and there, but, according to avid San Diego diners, no one place stands out.
If you are touring the city's downtown waterfront, Cerveceria Santa Fe, a year-old restaurant near the trolley depot, is worth a stop. The popular lunch spot is housed in a soaring industrial space that has been artfully softened with desert colors and palms.
The open air main dining room is breezy and pleasant about 10 months of the year; plastic flaps help in winter.
One of the house specialties is lobster tacos, in which the buttery lobster chunks are garnished with lettuce, cilantro and a creamy dressing. A spicy ceviche of fish was exceedingly vinegary and soupy; the ceviche of octopus and shrimp would be a better choice.
Garlic fans should head for the yellowtail flounder, well cooked and served with refried beans and yellow rice. Desserts are nondescript.
A three-course meal for two with a glass of beer or wine runs from $50 to $75.
 
Winesellar and Brasserie
You need the persistence of Lewis and Clark to find the Winesellar and Brasserie on the second floor of a building in an office park, above a wine shop. It is a modest, nondescript place with an open kitchen. Based on a recent visit, the contemporary French bistro fare is generally pleasing, although seasonings sometimes fall short. Service can be loopy.
For starters, charred eggplant with oven-dried tomatoes and herbed goat cheese was a nice combination, mitigated only by the ice cold vegetable. Ravioli of potato and leek with shiitakes were lackluster; a better choice would be the basil-cured salmon with sweet mustard sauce.
A good selection of mostly California wines is offered, although with this kind of menu more wines under $25 would be welcome.
Entrees were the best offerings, especially a succulent confit of duck leg presented over well-seasoned braised green lentils with a chicory salad. Grilled black angus filet mignon was exceptional, too, with a truffle-enriched red wine sauce and potatoes gratin.
Two rich but irresistible desserts are the warm caramelized apple clafoutis and a hazelnut cannoli filled with caramelized banana-mascarpone.
A three-course meal for two with a glass of wine costs about $80.

HEADLINE: Q and A

BYLINE: By Terence Neilan

 BODY:

Crater Lake Park
 Q. I would like to visit Crater Lake National Park and have been told that an historic lodge there is being renovated. Can you give me any details? -- Don H. Chin, M.D., Portland, Ore. 
 A. After a $15 million, four-year renovation and reconstruction, the Crater Lake Lodge is scheduled to reopen on May 20. Built in 1915 as part of a larger project that was never finished, the lodge fell victim to high operating costs and a gradual decline in business through the Depression years of the 1920's and 30's.
The harsh climate at Crater Lake -- an average of 530 inches of snow falls there each year -- also took its toll on the buildings, which because of the developer's inexperience were not built to withstand the weight of the 15-foot snow drifts that are common there each winter.
Closed for most of World War II, the lodge reopened in 1946 but gradually deteriorated through the 1950's and 60's. It was acquired in 1967 by the National Park Service, which shut it down in 1989 after it was declared structurally unsafe. After some prodding from the Historic Preservation League of Oregon, renovation work began in 1991.
The lodge, which is on the National Register of Historic Places, stands on the rim of Crater Lake, a 21-square-mile expanse of blue water in the caldera of an extinct volcano on the summit of the Cascade Range.
The lodge, which is run by Crater Lake Lodge Inc., a concessionaire, will be open from May 20 to Oct. 14. Room rates range from $99 to $119 for one or two people and $169 for loft suites, for up to four people.
For reservations and more information write or call Crater Lake Lodge, Post Office Box 2704, White City, Ore. 97604; (503) 830-8700.
Two hundred yards west of the lodge is Rim Village, which is open all year. The Llao Rock Cafe there serves sandwiches, burgers and soft drinks. Gift shops sell postcards and souvenirs. In the winter Rim Village is a cross-country ski center, with skis and snowshoes for rent. There are no overnight accommodations.
Camp sites in the park are available from late May through mid-October, weather permitting, for $11 a night. Other overnight accommodations are available in Medford and Klamath Falls, the two towns nearest to the lake.
More information: Crater Lake National Park, Post Office Box 7, Crater Lake, Ore. 97604; (503) 594-2211.
 
 
Irish Exchanges
 Q. I would like to participate in a house swap with an Irish family this summer. Do you know of an agency I can contact? -- M. A. Hansen, Amagansett, L.I.
A. The two most active house exchange agencies in Ireland report that that they do business with two groups in the United States, one in California and one in Florida. They also say Americans should have no problem finding a swap in Ireland because so many of their clients want to vacation in the United States.
Intervac, based in San Francisco, was founded in 1951 and is therefore the oldest of the groups in the United States. It has 9,400 subscribers.
For a $65 fee, members receive three catalogues a year, published on Dec. 1, March 1 and May 1. Another catalogue is issued in June and costs an extra $19. There is an $11 charge for including a photo of any property you want to advertise. Houses in 36 countries are listed, including the British Isles, North and Central America, western Europe, and Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic.
More information: Intervac, Box 590504, San Francisco, Calif. 94159; (415) 435-3497 or (800) 756-4663.
The Vacation Exchange Club, which began in 1960, published its 394-page January 1995 book in December. Four others will be published this year.
Karl Costabel, the club's owner, said there were 7,000 entries in the January book, half with pictures. Two-thirds are in Europe, including Ireland; the rest are in North America, Mexico and Hawaii. A listing, plus the five books for 1995, costs $65. The charge for a horizontal photo is $15; a vertical photo is $20.
More information: Vacation Exchange Club, Box 650, Key West, Fla. 33041; (800) 638-3841.
 
Hong Kong to Singapore
 Q. I am planning a trip to the Orient in May or June and am interested in finding out about how to get from Hong Kong to Singapore in as economical a way as possible. -- Michael Meskers, Brooklyn
A. Unless you have unlimited time or a fear of flying the most feasible way of going is by air. When you book a ticket ask for New York to Singapore round trip, with a stopover in Hong Kong. And given a choice, go in May, which is in what airlines call the shoulder season, rather than June, when the high season begins and fares are increased.
Some airlines, including Northwest, Japan Airlines, United and Cathay Pacific, will give you the Hong Kong stopover without extra charge. On others, like Singapore Airlines, it will cost $75.
In economy class the lowest fare quoted in late February on a regular scheduled airline for May was $1,175 round trip plus $35 tax on Northwest. The fare is good for Monday to Thursday ($100 extra for travel on Friday, Saturday or Sunday). You would fly nonstop from New York to Tokyo and then be routed back through Hong Kong and Singapore.
If time is on your side and you would like to look into the possibility of taking a boat from Singapore, the following should be able to help:
Jecking Tours and Travel, Seventh Floor, China Insurance Building, 48 Cameron Road, Tsim Sha Tsui, Kowloon, Hong Kong; (852) 739-1188, fax (852) 721-2748.
Swire Travel, 18th Floor, Devon House, Taikoo Place, 979 King's Road, Quarry Bay, Hong Kong; (852) 579-6699, fax (852) 590-0099.
 
A Swiss Spa
 Q. In 1985 my wife and I spent some time in Chur, Switzerland, and visited Bad Ragaz, which had a thermal spa and a golf course. I would like to go there again but no one seems able to give me any information about it. Can you help? -- Seymour P. Gersten, Lake Worth, Fla.
A. Bad Ragaz, famous for its thermal springs since the Middle Ages, is a year-round resort with everything from luxury hotels to family-run pensions, a tennis center, ski slopes and horse racing in October. It is situated on the Rhine River, some 50 miles southeast of Zurich, with indoor and outdoor thermal pools and a casino.
A 48-page booklet in English and German called "Bad Ragaz," listing hotels and excursions, is available free of charge from the Swiss National Tourist Office, 608 Fifth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10020; (212) 757-5944. The office also publishes a 74-page guide to spas that includes a section on Bad Ragaz.
 TERENCE NEILAN

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Question

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (93%); IRELAND (77%);

HEADLINE: Live-In Help Is Living In Style

BYLINE: By TRACIE ROZHON 

 BODY:
HILDA Botero's employers just bought her a one-bedroom apartment on the first floor of their posh Greenwich Village town house co-op.
Adele Woods's employers gave her a choice of an exquisite third-floor suite or the bedroom across the hall from their own bedrooms in a 12,000-square-foot mansion on Albemarle Road near Prospect Park in Brooklyn. 
 A 24-year-old Frenchwoman considers herself luckier than her other au-pair friends because she has her own college-dormitory-sized suite on a floor below her employer's multimillion-dollar apartment in a luxury Fifth Avenue condominium building recently redesigned with separate staff quarters. She said her separate rooms give her "liberty -- and they have their privacy, too."
Live-in maids, gardeners, nannies and housekeepers may seem like characters out of P. G. Wodehouse -- or yet another reprise of "Upstairs, Downstairs" -- but New York City has thousands of them, and, to a certain extent, their happiness, and that of their employers, has played a role in the design, renovation, construction and use of many luxury apartments and buildings in New York City.
"In the old days, maids were into servitude," said Dolly Lenz, Sotheby's International Realty's top-selling agent, "and their employers wanted them underfoot; they got you every little thing you wanted. Now you're dealing with specialized and highly paid staff who want privacy; they're certainly not content with a little room in the back, off the kitchen."
Indeed, several top brokers said that using the existing maids' rooms in prewar apartments may not be possible -- and can be frowned upon -- for a variety of reasons.
Practically, many people who buy apartments with the traditional maid's room next to the kitchen want to knock the wall down and enlarge the kitchen, brokers say, following the trend in suburban houses to make bigger kitchens that supplant the more formal living room as a social center for the family.
Then, many people, while wanting live-in help, feel guilty about housing them in back of the kitchen. "It's perceived as inhumane," one employer said. "In the 90's, having the maid live off the kitchen is like scratching your fingernail across a blackboard," said Christopher Thomas, who manages William B. May's two Brooklyn offices.
Mr. Thomas said that in Brooklyn Heights, where the prices of town houses have soared in the last two years, buyers look for houses that have a ground-floor apartment, with a separate entrance, that they can use for the help, not for rental income. "The economics have changed," he said. "Now the rental income is below the threshold to make it an income-producing investment. They forgo the income to have the convenience of live-in help." Buyers also look for living quarters for staff over a garage or carriage house.
The staff, too, can be very selective about where they live. Far more staff people, of course, live out than live in. But those willing to live in -- either the young au pairs and nannies, sometimes from foreign countries, or the older woman or man whose children have long gone -- want their privacy. The young want to date, and the older staff may want their free time uninterrupted.
"It's not the same feeling, that the staff is a member of the family," said Jack Heller, the developer of a luxury condominium at 1049 Fifth Avenue, a reconstructed 1920's hotel at 86th Street, redesigned with 18 200-square-foot staff rooms on the third floor. "I grew up with live-in help and we had the same housekeeper and cook since I was born until I went to college. But today, there's a lot more turnover."
Mr. Heller sells his maids' rooms for $135,000; and, according to Ms. Lenz of Sotheby's, "people are begging for more." At 955 Fifth, she said, there are separate staff rooms off the lobby level and off some of the upper-floor corridors.
In condominium apartments -- Ms. Lenz's specialty -- there are separate quarters at 40 East 78th Street, a white brick building off Madison Avenue. There are 10 staff rooms behind the mailboxes and down a few steps from the first floor. "They're all spoken for," she said. There are also separate maid's quarters at 860 and 870 United Nations Plaza and 444 East 57th Street. James Heller, who is no relation to Jack Heller, said he had seven 300-square-foot staff rooms in the post-war co-op apartment building he manages, Plaza 400, at 56th Street and First Avenue. They are available for apartment owners on a "first-come, first-served basis," he said; there is a waiting list for the spaces, which rent for $550 a month and contain a living room, full bath, small utility kitchen and closet.
Many of the city's most elegant pre-war buildings -- 825 Fifth, 1111 Park, 840 Park (where Apartment 7B, with maid's room on a separate floor, is currently on the market for $1.35 million), 850 Park, 30 East 71st, 3 East 77th, 781 Fifth, 950 Fifth, 990 Fifth and many more -- still retain separate staff quarters, usually on a lower, and less salable, floor.
At 1 East 66th Street a one-bedroom on the fifth floor with a maid's room on the second floor is being offered for $325,000.
Many of the staff rooms in pre-war buildings, however, have been converted to other uses. At 31 East 79th Street and 260 West End Avenue, series of rooftop rooms have been strung together to create penthouses; lower-floor spaces in other buildings have been transformed into offices, gymnasiums, darkrooms, wine cellars and even a huge walk-in humidor.
One co-op board reportedly told a woman who wanted to use one of these pre-war maid's rooms for her housekeeper that the use was a thing of the past. Others disagree, and say there is a need for much more separate staff space. One well-known real estate broker, who would speak only on condition of anonymity, said that developers had started designing separate staff quarters on lower floors because "they don't want to give them any space in the apartment -- they'd rather sell the space on the lower floors, where nobody wants to buy apartments."
DONALD Trump, the developer, said that when buying a two- or three-bedroom apartment, "it's tough to give up one of the three bedrooms" to the help. "Many people don't really know the maid," he said, "and it feels different to have someone sleeping in the apartment at night." He said that the maids' attitudes also were different these days: "They don't like walking through a back hallway to go to their room."
At Trump Palace, at 200 East 69th Street, Mr. Trump has sold 10 of the least desirable of the building's 100 studio apartments as maid's quarters for $150,000 to $175,000 each. Ms. Lenz labeled them "real nice, with windows," adding that the original asking prices for these apartments had been $300,000 to $500,000, but they had actually sold for the lower figures. "That building was built before the maid's-room era really took off," she said.
Although the studio apartments were not originally designed as staff quarters, Mr. Trump said, their sale for that use "changed my mind." Nevertheless, he had already built seven staff suites on the 29th floor of Trump Tower, where his own housekeeper, Marcela Baudreau, lives. He said that he would incorporate an undetermined number of separate staff apartments on the lower floors of the new Trump International Tower and Hotel at Columbus Circle. "They're really a modern-day necessity," he said.
When rented out by their owners, he said, the staff rooms lease for $50 to $60 per square foot, or $12,500 to $18,000, a year. If sold, they average $400 to $500 per square foot for the 250- to 300-square-foot apartments.
DESPITE the cost, some employers say they feel it is cheaper, safer, and just plain more convenient to have live-in help. Dr. Lawrence Frank, a Brooklyn dermatologist who has employed Adele Woods for two years, points to the fact that Ms. Woods, besides cleaning the house, makes breakfast for him "every morning at 6:30, and you can't do that with outside help." While Ms. Woods lives on the second floor near the Franks' bedroom, her brother, Cyril Baptiste, who helps with the gardening in exchange for rent, lives in a room in the basement.
The live-in maids, nannies and housekeepers generally receive from $200 to $500 a week, according to the employers interviewed. The average salary for a live-in housekeeper among those interviewed is about $350 -- exactly what Ms. Woods makes -- a figure employers say is cheaper than they would pay someone who lives out, because they generally deduct something for room and board.
One employer, an executive in a prominent stock brokerage firm, said she paid her live-in housekeeper/nanny $390 a week, "which I think is pretty reasonable." Her friends who use day nannies pay around $500 a week, she said, "with overtime added on, and if you ask them to stay after dark, you have to pay for a taxi, too."
The separate spaces for live-in help are not easy to find -- especially when one is looking for the perfect apartment to go with them.
"It took me a year -- I saw 160 apartments -- before I saw the one I wanted," said one 33-year-old woman, a South American banker who has taken time off to raise her children. "I wanted three bedrooms and three baths, an eat-in kitchen and separate maid's quarters."
The woman said that the apartment she found on Park Avenue in the summer of 1993 had the traditional maid's room off the kitchen, and that she wanted to rip it out to make a large kitchen. But that wasn't the only reason she wanted separate a staff room.
"I wanted a live-in and I wanted both of us to have some privacy," she explained. "My housekeeper loves it because she has her own little territory." In her search, she said, she saw apartments with separate maid's rooms: "a couple in the 70's off Madison, one on 72d Street between Park and Lexington that had a maid's room off the lobby on the first floor." Most, she said, were on the lower floors.
She was delighted to find that the Park Avenue building had a room allotted to her apartment, but she was surprised when the board balked at letting her use it for its original purpose. "They were using them for storage and offices," she said. Ultimately, she persuaded the board to let her renovate the seedy space for a maid's quarters, "but they did it only as a concession, with the condition that if I want to sell it, it would not be advertised."
The reason for the board's resistance may be security -- people living in a separate apartment in the building who have not passed a board review -- or it may be because of a fear that the staff will bring in forbidden cooking appliances that might constitute a fire hazard. "I check the room all the time," the banker said. "I know what she has in there."
"The board claimed it was the trend not to use these rooms for help," she said, "but I feel it is just the opposite; the demand for these rooms is high."
Deanna Kory, the Halstead Property Company's 's top selling agent, said she was trying to find separate maid's quarters for a client. "They're living in a six-room apartment and they bought a one-bedroom in the same building on the first floor for staff," Ms. Kory said. "Now they want to move to a bigger apartment and they want their housekeeper to live in a separate apartment so they can maintain the same arrangement."
She said her clients want to furnish the separate space because "by doing so, they get the loyalty and commitment they don't get otherwise."
In the Eldorado, a co-op on Central Park West at 90th Street, Ms. Kory sold a previously unsalable unit that had been cut off decades ago from the back of a large apartment.
It was bought by a man who lived on a different floor in the building and who is boarding his housekeeper. Ms. Kory said she occasionally sold first and second floor "regular" apartments to employers for their live-in help.
That is exactly what Larry E. Condon and his sister Diane did for their housekeeper of nine years, Hilda Botero.
When a one-bedroom apartment on the first floor of the wide brownstone in which they live on East 11th Street became available, the Condons considered buying it for Ms. Botero, who had been commuting from her two-bedroom apartment in Queens, where she had lived for 27 years.
"Larry asked me if I would come live here if he bought the apartment," Ms. Botero said. "Before, I had to get up at 6, take a shower, walk to Queens Boulevard and take a subway. Now I can get up at 7, 7:30."
THE first time she saw the 600-square-foot apartment, she was not exactly delighted.
"This wall was brown," she said, gesturing to the 22-foot-long expanse from the front windows, which face on the street, to the back of the new kitchen, with its white formica cabinets and white range. "The furniture was brown, the cabinets were yellow, everything was dirty."
The Condons bought the apartment, which has a wood-burning fireplace and a $470 monthly maintenance, for $95,000 -- and proceeded to invest an additional $60,000 to redo it completely. They painted and wallpapered the whole apartment and brought in some of their own furniture. Ms. Botero moved in three months ago.
"Now, I don't change for nothing; I love it," the housekeeper said. "I was supposed to move to California with my son -- he's an actor -- but I said, 'No, leave me here.' "
For Mr. Condon, who heads the Joyce Mertz-Gilmore Foundation, the one-bedroom apartment is a good investment. "But it's more of an investment in life," he said. "We go to the farm market together and I took her to ABC Carpet and Bed, Bath and Beyond, and she's found a church here, where she goes to Saturday mass.
"It's been absolutely perfect since the first day."

HEADLINE: PERSPECTIVES;
Prescriptions for Housing Programs

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER 

 BODY:
NO city comes close to New York in its spending for housing development. Focusing mainly on restoring the tax-foreclosed housing stock for low-income people, the city has spent $3.6 billion over the last eight years.
The results are visible in far-flung neighborhoods, where once-abandoned apartment buildings have been restored. In addition, hundreds of new houses have gone up on vacant city-owned land. 
 A new report called "Building in Partnership: A Blueprint for Urban Housing Programs" says the programs that produced this housing have made the city's neighborhoods the "world's largest and most diverse laboratory for testing innovative strategies in housing development and finance."
The report was written by Kathryn Wylde, president of the New York City Housing Partnership, one of the key participants in city housing programs, and funded by the Robert Sterling Clark Foundation. Extracting from what it finds to be both successes and failures in these strategies, Ms. Wylde makes the case for two basic propositions: Structured programs that bring in competitive development proposals are superior to subsidy packages tailored to individual projects or developers, and nonprofit intermediaries and community-based organizations should take part in designing and implementing housing programs.
Advice abounds: Cut development costs (six ways to do it); speed the development process (nine suggestions); maximize the contribution of nonprofits (four suggestions); attract more private investment (eight suggestions).
One point that comes through loud and clear is that new production for those least able to afford its cost -- very low-income people and the homeless -- is likely to subside drastically once rehabilitations of tax-foreclosed buildings subsides. Very low-income households are the ones that need the most financial assistance per housing unit built, since they have the least capacity to repay the true cost through rent. More private investment is needed to "leverage" public money, the report makes clear. That suggests that the beneficiaries must be people better able to pay back the cost, whether in rental or for-sale housing.
At least one objective advocated in the Housing Partnership report has already been taken up by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. He announced it under the acronym "Anchor" in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn in December.
Anchor stands for Alliance for Neighborhood Home Ownership and Revitalization. Its goal is to bring job development and retail facilities to an area that has already had a burst of new city-assisted home development. The Anchor district is bounded by Atlantic and Bushwick Avenues and Malcolm X Boulevard, where Bushwick, Ocean Hill and Bedford-Stuyvesant meet. Over the last two years almost 2,000 new housing units have been built within or near it, but the commercial vacancy rate is 40 percent.
The Anchor concept is hardly novel, but it does call attention to the often repeated axiom that new housing cannot stand alone. Supplementary facilities, services and jobs must accompany or soon follow new housing in depopulated areas, or the housing itself ultimately will be threatened.
MORE immediately, the Department of Housing Preservation and Development is focused on its Building Blocks program to transfer to nonprofits, private owners or tenants the 30,000 housing units in mostly occupied tax-foreclosed buildings that are currently under city management. The units would also be rehabilitated with city loans or grants.
The capital cost of rehabilitating the buildings is now estimated by city officials at $50,000 a unit, or $1.5 billion for all 30,000. This projection is much higher than city officials provided for a similar program under the Dinkins administration. At $50,000 a unit, the cost would be far above normal in private-sector buildingwide improvements to mostly occupied buildings. These costs usually range between $25,000 to $30,000 a unit.
The Partnership report says that the most significant housing trend in New York City in the 80's was the rising rate of owner-occupancy. During the decade, the percentage of households who owned their home or apartment rose to 30 percent from 27 percent.
Another trend was occurring at the same time -- the rise of the homelessness issue. Fully 72 percent of the city money for production spent from 1987 to 1993, or $2.3 billion, was for this low-income or no-income population. To operate it the city taps Federal community development block grants, often at a level of about $3,000 an apartment a year. Tenant rent pays the rest of the $5,000-a-year needed.
"Rehabilitations for very-low-income people will be extremely difficult over the next few years," said Carol Parry, who runs the community development group at Chemical Bank, a lender to assisted-housing efforts. "We will still be able to do the home ownership projects, and the rentals that require less subsidy per unit."
One form of indirect subsidy available to the city, not discussed in the Partnership report, is tax relief to private rental buildings with low-income tenants. Those buildings -- often unrehabilitated and burdened by one or more mortgages -- lose tenants to the handsomely rehabilitated low-rent buildings financed by the city, which pay no taxes and often have no mortgage debt either. Overtaxation of low-income private rentals also feeds the tax-foreclosure pipeline.
Another approach that could be given greater emphasis involves low-interest loans for moderate rehabilitation of occupied rental buildings. Such programs have long been in use but in recent years the capital budget has focused instead on major renovation of the city-owned stock.
THE Housing Partnership report shows that different types of new housing will have widely varying costs, depending on site conditions, project design and financing mechanisms. The least expensive on a per-unit basis is the Nehemiah program of small-home construction, operating on large, cleared tracts in East Brooklyn and the South Bronx. This church-sponsored low-overhead operation benefits also from interest-free construction loans from church sources. In the Bronx, the report says, Nehemiah is building 422 single-family and condominium units at an average cost of $77,250 a unit, which includes a city subsidy per-unit of $15,000.
That compares with higher costs when the developer is building on scattered sites, and higher still when the housing type is a multiple dwelling using tax-exempt financing. At one rental development in Queens serving roughly the same income population as the Nehemiah houses, for instance, the development costs were $108,000 a unit, which includes a city subsidy of $59,000 a unit.
Construction costs are critical, since to the extent that they can be reduced, less public assistance is needed. But in New York City economic barriers are built into the development process itself. The Partnership report notes that building and fire code requirements combined with handicapped-access rules "make new construction of four-story, three-family homes almost impossible under existing programs."
Similarly, reviewing agencies are in a position to impose unrealistic conditions on private development. The report cites the Soundview Peninsula development in the Bronx, which had weak sales and defaulted on its loan from a bank. The project is still obliged to build an expensive shorefront esplanade and meet other approval conditions although it was "marginally feasible in the first place," the report says.
Regulatory impediments to private development have been a major concern of the City Planning Commission lately. "We have to clarify and simplify the zoning code," said Joseph B. Rose, the chairman. "We are mapping more areas for mixed-use zoning. The current rate of new housing production is not adequate."

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut;
A Plan for Housing the Homeless, With Counseling

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

DATELINE: STAMFORD

 BODY:
AN application is expected to be filed here this week for a zoning amendment that would pave the way for a comprehensive program to house and counsel homeless single men and women. The proposed zoning change is part of a statewide effort to address the homeless problem. Twelve sites in nine Connecticut towns and cities have been targeted for the creation of a total of 400 apartments, financed and managed cooperatively by 6 state agencies, 21 nonprofit organizations and a variety of philanthropies and corporations.
If the Stamford zoning amendment is granted, it would permit the construction of 41 studio and one-bedroom apartments at 85 Franklin Street, and 25 similar apartments at 44 Ludlow Street. 
 A public hearing on the amendment, which defines supportive housing as a permitted use and calls for a special exception to allow it at the two sites, will be scheduled within 60 days.
The two buildings are to cost a total of $2.5 million. For at least half the tenants, their home will be a halfway house since some of them will be coming out of recovery programs for psychiatric disorders and substance abuse. A few will have AIDS.
The other half will be low-income working people unable to afford decent housing in the city. Stamford's two shelters for the homeless currently accommodate a total of 500 to 600 people a night.
Tenants in the new buildings who earn half or less of the median income of $27,000 for a single person in Stamford will pay 30 percent of their incomes in rent. With Federal subsidies, a tenant could pay as little as $125 a month.
Most importantly, these will be permanent dwellings. As long as the tenant pays rent and behaves responsibly he or she can stay for a lifetime. If incomes rise, so will the rent. The tenant may move out, but no one can be evicted because of higher earnings.
An equally important feature is the built-in support system. Each building will have a live-in counselor with an office equipped to arrange treatment for tenants through cooperating state agencies. According to the Corporation for Supportive Housing, a Manhattan-based nonprofit organization that provides planning and seed money for this type of housing, the program closes the revolving door of temporary shelters, sporadic health care, possible jail terms and hospital stays, and does so at lower cost.
"Institutionalizing a homeless person with a disability can cost upwards of $100,000 a year," said Julie Sandorf, president of the corporation. "A shelter bed costs about $21,000 a year, while supportive housing costs between $10,000 and $15,000 a year. We have 3,000 units occupied or under construction nationwide and 2,000 more in the pipeline."
The corporation was founded in 1991 with $10 million from a coalition of the Pew Charitable Trusts, The Robert Wood Johnson Foundation and The Ford Foundation. It has since helped to create 2,000 units in New York City, 700 in the San Francisco Bay Area, 1,000 in Chicago, and smaller amounts in Phoenix, Atlanta, and Minneapolis-St. Paul.
THE Connecticut program is the first statewide application. An initial $450,000 was provided by The Melville Foundation, a family philanthropy set up by the owners of the Melville Corporation of Rye, N.Y., whose main business is its 10 department stores.
Unlike the units in Stamford's two new buildings, the others will be installed in existing hotels and apartment houses. Renovation is cheaper than new construction and recycling for the same or similar use is less likely to require zoning amendments.
All of the housing in the program will be a far cry from shoddy single-occupancy hotels with baths down the hall, violently deranged occupants and seedy drunks sleeping in hallways. Prospective tenants must demonstrate their ability to live independently within acceptable parameters of behavior.
Each apartment will be equipped with a kitchen, bathroom and window blinds and partially furnished. Most buildings will have common rooms with kitchens for group functions, laundries and, when possible, landscaped seating areas outdoors.
The focus on single people resulted from research showing that 85 percent of the homeless are single, and that support services were essential for the 75 percent who are identified with chronic disabilities.
"We were invited to Connecticut two years ago by the Weicker administration," said Ms. Sandorf of the Corporation for Supportive Housing, "to see how state housing money might be used more effectively."
Ten of the 12 projects will be eligible for a share of $20 million in bonds authorized under the Weicker administration for supportive housing in fiscal 1995 ending June 30, according to Lynn Aronson, director of housing resources for the Department of Mental Health, one of the participating state agencies. The other two projects will come on line later.
"Each project was selected by the state's Housing Department," she said. The owner-developers are state-designated, nonprofit organizations. "They must apply individually for bonding and pass muster with Connecticut Housing Finance Authority in order to secure a mortgage loan."
A bond application for the Stamford project will be submitted by its sponsor, St. Luke's Community Services, in May or June. Last September, $2.2 million in bonds were issued by the state's Department of Housing for a project in Middletown, sponsored by The Connecticut Fund and St. Vincent de Paul Place, both local philanthropies. The state's Housing Finance Authority provided an additional $500,000 for the project, which calls for the creation of 40 apartments and two stores in the former Arriwani Hotel.
IN Bridgeport, a late 19th-century apartment house listed on the National Register of Historic Places and known as the Edinburgh Crescent Building at 431 Washington Avenue and a vacant apartment house at 2450 Main Street are to be renovated by the Central Connecticut Coast Y.M.C.A. to produce a total of 64 units. The remaining sites are in Hartford, Meriden, Windham, New Haven, Bristol and New Britain.
Underwriters for the mortgage loans are the state's Housing Finance Authority and its Department of Housing. "Based on the figures coming in for development and property acquisition," said Lenward Gatison, vice president for housing development and mortgage financing at the housing-finance agency, "The $20 million in bonds will fall short. The Department of Housing will ask for $5 million more in this session of the General Assembly."
Once the buildings are occupied, the tenants will be served by the state's Departments of Mental Health, Social Services and Public Health & Addiction Services. Rent subsidies will be provided by the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development; operating expenses and contingency funds will be supplied by private investors. "Obviously, the tenants cannot generate enough rental income," said Janice Elliott, director of Supportive Housing's Connecticut program, based in New Haven.
"Federal tax credits," she noted, "make it a worthwhile investment for corporations and foundations, guaranteeing a 17 percent return annually over a 10-year period."
Connecticut, according to "Cities Without Suburbs" by David Rusk, published in 1933, ranks first in the nation in the degree of economic separation between its cities and suburbs. Statewide figures on the homeless who used shelters in 1993-94 totaled 17,693 different people, not repeaters.
Regardless of the perceived need, and the work that has gone into the supportive housing program to date, there is concern about its future under the conservative fiscal policy of Gov. John G. Rowland.
Ten of the 12 projects designated by the state for supportive housing, including two each in Stamford and Bridgeport and one in Middletown, have received preconstruction loans of $75,000 to $150,000 from the Corporation for Supportive Housing. But only the Middletown project has secured state bonding.
"The Governor is chairman of the bonding commission," said James A. Sullivan, a section director in the Office of Policy and Management. "He can delay, approve, or not bring this before the commission at all. Authorization is not allocation."

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Garages;
As an Investment, Parking's Attractive

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
A DECADE ago, when Rockefeller Center began assembling land at Seventh Avenue and 49th Street, it had in mind a 1.6 million-square-foot office tower. Four months ago, it opened a parking lot instead.
Edison Parking, which has the contract to manage it, agreed to a 30-day cancellation clause. That means that Rockefeller Center can quickly revert to Plan A as soon as it pre-leases enough space in the proposed building to warrant breaking ground. 
 "Sure, we'd rather have a building, but for now a parking lot is nice income," said William J. Maloney, president of the Rockefeller Center Development Corporation.
Parking, the bane of Manhattan drivers, is becoming a boon to all manner of Manhattan business people. Developers, investors and garage operators, many of whom treaded water in the recession, are again pursuing garage properties and contracts.
"When a garage comes on the market these days, it spikes huge interest," said Robert A. Knakal, president of Massey Knakal Realty Services, a sales broker.
"Well-located parking properties definitely command a premium," said Edward S. Gordon, the real estate executive who owns a controlling interest in Myers Parking.
Parking's attraction is understandable. It is a cash business. And it does not require an educated workforce or a lot of computers.
"Parking is commercial real estate in its most simplistic form -- renting space to a car," said Benjamin Fox, a partner in the New Spectrum brokerage.
Of course, that is an oversimplification in itself. Many garage buildings include stores, so their owners must deal with complicated retail leases. Large parking chains do have elaborate accounting systems. And since a bomb exploded in the World Trade Center garage two years ago, many have tightened their security procedures.
(The Trade Center, not surprisingly, has the tightest security of all. The Twin Towers garage is closed to the public. Pictures of tenants and their vehicles are on file. No one else can drive a tenant's car into the garage, and tenants cannot, without prior arrangement, drive another car in themselves.)
But such modern-day wrinkles are not dissuading garage owners or operators. Indeed, unlike in the 80's, when garages and lots were purchased with an eye to building something else on their underlying land, today they are attractive on their own.
"A lot of people outside the business are bidding for properties now," said Saul P. Schwartz, president of Kinney System. "They learned that garages that were built to service a building often yield better cash flow than the building itself."
That is one reason owners of parking properties are rarely in a hurry to sell. According to the Real Estate Board of New York, 11 parking properties changed hands in 1993, for a total of $6.1 million. Even in 1987, when money chased any kind of property, only 28 parking facilities changed hands, for a total of $53.2 million.
"We're seeing a lot more transactions today, considering there were virtually none between 1990 and 1992," said Jonathan S. Miller, executive managing director of Grubb & Ellis New York, who specializes in investment sales.
WOULD-BE buyers, in contrast, are champing at the bit. Rolls-Royce recently closed its dealership at 407 East 61st, and the building is on the market. Mr. Knakal, who is handling the sale, said he had already received several inquiries. He believes that a garage is the "highest and best use" for the building, which is in an area not zoned for residential development. Mr. Miller is not so sure. He said that limousine services and even a large discount retailer had asked him to make inquiries about the building.
Meanwhile, garage operators are starting to buy properties as well as lease them. The Mallah family, one of New York's largest garage managers, is about to buy the garage at 10-20 West 48th Street that Kinney, looking to reduce debt from a leveraged buyout, sold to a developer in 1990. The developer later lost it to his lenders.
Kinney, with a cleaned-up balance sheet, also is back in acquisition mode. "Foreclosed garage properties make for fertile ground," Mr. Schwartz said.
Even speculative investors are warming to the income stream that parking provides. La Salle Partners has raised $76 million for an Income Parking Fund, which has already acquired five garages. One is in New York, on 50th Street near Lexington Avenue.
"Some of our parking properties may turn into development sites some day," said Wade W. Judge, La Salle's managing director. "But in the 90's secure cash returns have more appeal than hope certificates."
Mr. Wade says that the Manhattan garage was by far the fund's most expensive investment. It may also be the most risk-free, in that garage space is virtually certain to remain scarce here. City officials, worried about pollution and congestion, stopped granting permits for free-standing garages more than a decade ago. Parking lots require large land parcels -- not exactly amply available in Manhattan. And they require a cumbersome community board approval process.
"The city fathers are being really stupid," said Abraham Hirschfeld, a garage builder who has dabbled in politics himself. "A well-managed garage can really revitalize a neglected block."
Indeed, ever since the recession squelched development, parking lots and garages represent the only life on some Manhattan stretches. The numerous lots on Avenue of the Americas, from 23d to 32d Streets, were supposed to house office towers long before now. The blocklong enclosed garage at Eighth Avenue and 50th Street was once slated for development.
Conversely, the Silverstein Properties site on 42d Street between 11th and 12th Avenue had an existing parking lot when Larry Silverstein bought it in the 80's. Unlike other would-be Times Square developers, Mr. Silverstein did not put up a "taxpayer" -- a short, stand-alone retail building that's quick and cheap to erect -- while he sought zoning changes to allow him to put up a bigger building there. "A taxpayer would have provided better money, but we always figured we'd be building sooner rather than later," Mr. Silverstein said.
The lot remains there to this day. "It's not a terrific source of income, but it helps to cover the taxes," Mr. Silverstein said.
What is just frosting to developers who still dream of skyscrapers is the entire cake for Edison, Myers, Kinney and the other operators whose entire business revolves around parking. The dearth of new garages means they must find new ways to expand.
One way is to get management contracts for municipal garages, hospital lots, or other parking facilities that are run by the not-for-profit sector. "Privatization is a big goal in this industry," said Marsha Williams, director of membership services for the Washington-based National Parking Association.
Another is to market more extensively. Many garages offer special promotions like "early bird specials" or tie-ins with restaurants and theaters.
BUT the most prevalent way is to go after each other's contracts. And building owners are capitalizing on the fierce competition. "There is no shortage of competitors willing to pay top dollar for a garage lease," said Adam R. Rose, executive vice president of Rose Associates.
Mr. Rose, like many landlords, is cracking down on the operators of his garages. And he is not just arguing over fees.
For example, when the lease at the Rose-managed co-op at 45 East 89th Street came up for renewal, Mr. Rose refused to renew until the operator, who had been there 25 years and was paying about $1 million annually in rent, agreed to put $250,000 into renovations. Rose Associates kicked in $2 million itself. The garage will soon have customer bathrooms, better lighting and signs, and a refurbished waiting area.
The new lease spells out how the garage must be maintained. "We've even specified how many times it must be cleaned and what uniforms the staff must wear," said Mr. Rose, who refers to himself as "garage obsessed."
It is an obsession with a logical underpinning. During the last few years Rose Associates has renovated nine lobbies and countless corridors, built 13 model apartments and paid for numerous newspaper ads, all to woo buyers to the co-ops it manages.
"It was ridiculous to then let people form their first impression of a building from its shabby garage," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Parking lot on Seventh Avenue at 49th Street was planned site of tower. (Chang W. Lee for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: Decision Affects Nonpurchasing Rent-Stabilized Tenants;
State Agency Grants Rise In Rent at New York Co-op

 BODY:
Applications for rent increases in co-op apartments occupied by rent-stabilized tenants are expected to increase following the grant, for the first time, of a "comparative hardship" increase by the New York State Division of Housing and Community Renewal.
The decision, issued late last year in a case filed in 1985, involves a 149-unit building at 203-205 East 72d Street. The applicant for the increase, the sponsor of the building's co-op conversion, had retained unsold shares for 75 rent-stabilized apartments. 
 The hardship application requested a 53 percent rent increase amounting to $73,182 a year. The state agency, which administers rent-regulation laws, awarded $20,160 a year, which comes to $5.54 a room a month, retroactive to June 1, 1987. The retroactive portion has been stayed pending the outcome of a request for reconsideration filed by the tenants. "In my opinion, the die is cast," said Jeffrey Turkel, the Manhattan lawyer who represented the applicant.
Eliot Zuckerman, a Manhattan real-estate lawyer, said that "there are lots of buildings where sponsors still own blocks of apartments, and many may now file an application for an increase." The "comparative hardship" increase, Mr. Zuckerman said, is given when an owner can prove that the profit he or she is making or should be making on a rent-stabilized apartment has been diminished or wiped out by the effects of rent stabilization. To prove the need for such an increase, he said, the owner must compare income and expenses over a three-year "base period," usually the first three years of ownership, with a three-year "test period," typically the three years immediately preceding the filing.
Martin Heistein, a Manhattan real estate lawyer, called the decision "a major plus for the owners." He said he had received a "tremendous number" of inquiries and had "already begun the process of filing a large number of hardship applications."
Tenant advocates denounced the decision. "It allows somebody who is not even the owner of a building to selectively apply for rent increases on top of the regular increases he gets and basically price nonpurchasing tenants out of the building," said Michael McKee, director of development for the New York State Tenant and Neighborhood Coalition.

HEADLINE: WESTCHESTER GUIDE

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:

A HAND FOR THE HUNGRY
Helping Hands for the Homeless and Hungry, a Rye-based nonprofit organization, will benefit from the Winter in Rye Antiques Show, today from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. at the Rye Middle School on Route 1.
Sixty-five dealers will participate, and the admission of $4.50 will be reduced to $4 for anyone taking a can or box of food. 
 Variety is the spice of this show. A sampling of the unusual merchandise includes Wallace Nutting prints, kerosene and other vintage lighting, oyster plates, 18th-century French armchairs, a pre-1820's museum-quality quilt, medical and dental items, black history items, vintage watches, English majolica sunflower plates, Victorian inlaid necktie presses, prison art, bird cages and writing boxes.
In addition, there will be estate jewelry, linens and laces, bottles, rugs, toys, paintings, china and glass.
Yellow and black signs point the way to the school, off Exit 19 of Interstate 95.
 
WHITHER WHITE PLAINS?
 A discussion of economic development in White Plains is to be held at a meeting of the Building Owners and Managers Association of Westchester on Thursday at 5:30 P.M. at the Crowne Plaza White Plains. The topic will be "Downtown Revitalization: A Catalyst for Economic Growth."
Joseph R. Potenza, planning commissioner for White Plains and executive director of its Urban Renewal Agency, will talk about an updated comprehensive plan for the municipality. The plan includes improvement of the downtown shopping district and completion of the Central Urban Renewal Project.
Offering a view from Stamford -- White Plains's retailing rival -- will be Sandra Goldstein, a director of the Stamford Downtown Consortium, the Chamber of Commerce and the Mayor's Multicultural Council and a former president of the Stamford Board of Legislators. Her subject will be how the redevelopment of Stamford's downtown was accomplished.
The cocktail reception, dinner and two speeches cost $50. The number to call for reservations and information is 328-9703.
 
AUSCHWITZ MEMORIES
 The train ride to Auschwitz, how Joseph Mengele selected his victims and death marches are to be recalled in a talk by Livia Krancberg, a 76-year-old survivor of the concentration camp at Auschwitz.
The program will be held tomorrow at 1:30 P.M. in Reisinger Auditorium of Sarah Lawrence College in Yonkers.
Ms. Krancberg's testimony is included in the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum's Archives and the Yale University Archives, among others, and she is participating in the oral history recording of "Survivors of the Shoah Visual History Foundation," produced by Steven Spielberg.
She has lectured in many colleges and high schools in the New York City area and was honored by her community, Woodbridge, N.J., for her contributions to preserving Holocaust history.
Her lecture is part of Sarah Lawrence's commemoration of the 50th anniversary of the liberation of Auschwitz. Admission is free. For information and directions, the number is 395-2411.
 
H-TWO-OH!
 Water, water is everywhere at the "Sea and Shore" exhibition opening today at the Hopper House Art Center in Nyack. The 10-artist invitational show will run through March 26.
Streams, rivers, oceans, ponds and lakes are depicted, "making visual the certainty that spring is just around the corner," said D. Robert Brebbia, the show's curator and one of the exhibiting artists. The other painters are Allan F. Avery, Janet F. Avery, Elwood G. Bengert, Beverly B. Colgan, James Harrington, Martha L. Heatley, Henri Jatho, Sally Spivack and Edward M. Warzala.
The paintings are soothingly traditional, executed in watercolor, oils or acrylics.
The center, at 82 North Broadway in Nyack, was once the boyhood home of the painter Edward Hopper.
A reception will be held today from noon to 5 P.M. Regular hours thereafter are Fridays from 5 to 8 P.M. and Saturdays and Sundays from noon to 5 P.M. Admission is free, or by donation of $1. More information is available by calling 358-0774.
 
SINGING OUT
 The Boys Choir of Harlem, founded in 1968 as a small church group, has become a major musical institution with an infectious, irresistible style. Under the guidance of its director, Dr. Walter J. Turnbull, the choir has toured Europe, the United States and Asia, entertaining at the White House, the United Nations and in Manhattan's concert halls.
The choir will appear in concert on Saturday at 7 P.M. in the Academic Arts Theater of Westchester Community College in Valhalla, performing a wide-ranging repertory of sacred music, gospel, ragtime, jazz and spirituals. Tickets at $15 and $10 for children and people 65 and older can be reserved by calling 785-6567.
 
MUSIC FOR YOUNGER SET
 Joanie Bartels's performances on Nickelodeon and the Disney Channel have earned the approval not only of young viewers but also of Parents magazine and Child magazine.
She will appear today at 1:30 P.M. at the Tarrytown Music Hall, 13 Main Street, in a concert of music that moves from Brahms to the Beatles, her own compositions, rock 'n' roll and Broadway show tunes. Singing and strumming her guitar, she puts on a choreographed show that appeals to many parents. Her audiocassette called "Lullaby" won a gold record.
Tickets are $12 at the door. The number to call for information is 693-7898.
 
THE CREATIVE CHILD
 The College of New Rochelle will begin a five-week program for creative children from 4 to 12 years old on Saturday mornings. The sessions will last an hour and a half, and there will be two sessions each Saturday at 9 A.M. and 10:30 A.M., starting this week.
Children will be divided into three age groups from pre-kindergarten through sixth grade, and they may choose from subjects like science, art, drama, architecture, computers and business. One five-week course costs $80, and children who sign up for both courses will be charged $140. Discounts are available for more than one child in a family.
Dr. Susan Baum, assistant professor of education of gifted and talented children in the college's graduate school, developed the program, she said, because of "budget cuts in many Westchester schools that have done away with gifted and talented programs."
The college is at 29 Castle Place in downtown New Rochelle. The information number is 654-5330.
 
DO-IT-YOURSELF
 If the extent of your home maintenance skills is limited to changing a light bulb, you might want to attend a series of three free workshops aimed at making you handier around the house and saving money on repair bills.
Sol Berkowitz will conduct the workshops, sponsored by the Cornell Cooperative Extension of Westchester, at the downtown New Rochelle Public Library off North Avenue. "Leaky Faucets" will be the program this Wednesday from 2 to 4 P.M., followed by "Simple Home Repairs" on March 22 and "Lamp Repairs" on April 5. The registration number is 632-7878. ELEANOR CHARLES

HEADLINE: At Work;
A Level Playing Field, for Just $121

BYLINE: By Barbara Presley Noble 

 BODY:
THE degree to which companies have trouble complying with civil rights legislation on behalf of disabled people appears to have more to do with their cultures than with the demands of the law. In an assessment of compliance at Sears, Roebuck & Company, Peter D. Blanck, a psychologist at the University of Iowa who has studied people with disabilities, found that the large retailer had little trouble bringing its own efforts into sync with the Americans With Disabilities Act of 1990 and spent little money doing so. The law bans discrimination and requires employers to make "reasonable accommodations" to employees and job applicants with a range of illnesses and disabilities.
Trade associations and business groups have long complained that the law opened up a potentially infinite horizon of expense, especially burdening small business. Disability rights groups argue that the "reasonable accommodation" clause of the law by definition prevents the Government from imposing ruinous requirements on business. Most accommodations, they contend, can be made with little cost. 
 The report on Sears, which has sponsored a program to match disabled people and jobs since 1972, appears to support that contention.
From 1978 to 1992, according to Mr. Blanck's report, Sears made 436 accommodations, at a total cost of some $53,000. More than two-thirds of them cost nothing; 28 percent cost less than $1,000. Thirteen, or 3 percent, cost more than $1,000. The average cost of an accommodation was $121. The accommodations involving little or no cost included flexible scheduling, training, back-support belts, rest periods and changes in employee work stations. The largest single cost, at $14,500 each, went for special Braille computer displays for visually impaired employees.
Mr. Blanck said employers need to think of the law as "evolutionary, not revolutionary. For companies with a culture of diversity and inclusion, the A.D.A. doesn't change much. They've been doing it all along."
In a related article, published in the Iowa Law Review, Mr. Blanck reported that the incomes and employment opportunities of some mentally ill adults are on the rise. While the majority -- 59 percent -- of the 1,110 people in the study showed no employment movement from 1990 to 1993, a quarter of them improved the quality of their employment. The unemployment level for all participants dropped 3 percentage points, to 33 percent in 1993 from 36 percent in 1990. The unemployment rate in Oklahoma, where Mr. Blanck's subjects live, rose in that period. The gross annual income of all participants went up.
Mr. Blanck also saw good news in the finding that more of the mentally disabled are speaking out for themselves. "There is a ninefold increase in participation in self-help programs," he said. "There's a tremendous growth in awareness of rights." The improvements were greater for women than men and for younger than older people.
The Sears report includes case histories companies may find useful. Copies are available from the Annenberg Washington Program, where Mr. Blanck is a senior fellow, at 202-393-7100; fax: 202-638-2745, T.D.D.: 202-393-4121.
 
Helping Women
 Any woman who feels as if she has to dress her personality in corporate drag to succeed may want to think about attending a summer leadership program in California. Now in its second year at Stanford University and its third year overall, the Summer Executive Institute on Women and Leadership is offering eight-day courses to female executives. The program is sponsored by the Institute for Research on Women and Gender at Stanford.
Leadership is gender-neutral, say the course teachers, Margaret O'Keefe Umanzio and Paola Gianturco, who have experience in advising companies on organizational redesign, the glass ceiling and communications strategies. But many women and people of color, in particular, feel they have to assume an uneasy -- competitive, controlling, confrontational -- identity to make their mark. Corporate change is opening up opportunities, the two teachers say.
"Structure, order, hierarchy: they are all coming apart," Ms. Umanzio said. "You can't hide behind roles, titles, status, position. It no longer works."
Last year the course drew a cross-section of accomplished women, from age 30 to 55, with a range of degrees and credentials. "The managerial skills were all in place," Ms. Gianturco said. "Many were about to assume additional responsibilities and wanted to expand their competencies."
The eight days include lecture/seminars, "homework" in the form of written exercises, creativity exercises in classes and a real-world project to be completed back at work after the course is over.
This summer there will be three sessions: June 15-23, July 13-21 and Aug. 17-25. The first session will be held at a conference center in Monterey, the July and August sessions at Stanford. Tuition is $6,000; participants are typically sponsored by their companies.
For information, call 415-221-4545.
 
A Show of Power
 To encourage companies to put more women on their boards and generally to recognize female talent, a group of women in the financial industry is sponsoring "Women Investors Day" on March 14. The group is organizing a mass mailing to investment companies of letters from investors and stockholders urging companies to consider women for openings on boards and in top management positions. There will be receptions for participants in Washington, San Francisco and New York.
For information, contact the Women Investors Committee, P.O. Box 1783, Murray Hill Station, New York, N.Y. 10156-0611; (703-978-2491); or Dale Grant, vice chairman of the Segal Company in New York, at 212-251-5016. The Internet address is wominv@worldweb.net.

HEADLINE: Business Diary: February 26 - March 3

BYLINE: By Francis Flaherty 

 BODY:

INTERNATIONL
 
Barings P.L.C.: 28-Year-Old Brings Down 233-Year-Old
Robert L. Citron. Joseph Jett. And now, Nicholas W. Leeson. The 28-year-old, a trader in the Singapore office of Barings P.L.C., has joined the gallery of those charged with larger-than-life investment mistakes. By betting $29 billion on derivatives in the Japanese markets and losing more than $1 billion, Mr. Leeson managed last week to sink Barings, a 233-year-old British investment firm that financed the Louisiana Purchase and oversaw royal fortunes. Mr. Leeson, at right, bet that Japanese stocks and interest rates would rise. Both fell, and then the story sped up: the Bank of England tried to rescue Barings and failed, Barings went bankrupt and on the block, Mr. Leeson was on the lam until his arrest in Frankfurt. When the dust settles, one issue will stand out: What has happened to finance that individuals can bring huge institutions to their knees? 

Flamboyant Financier Dies
Bernard Cornfeld, the controversial American financier, died in London last week at age 67. His death, from stroke and pneumonia, sparked the same divided views he inspired in the 1960's and 1970's when he sold mutual funds and other investments to Americans abroad through his company, Investors Overseas Services. "He championed taking a buck from anybody, without scruples," said a securities lawyer. "He was a brilliant, absolutely brilliant, innovator," countered a mutual fund manager. But, with his French castle and retinue of models and celebrities, one fact is indisputable: Bernie, whose empire was worth $2.5 billion at its height, had color.
 
Piracy Accord: Paper Tiger?
The United States and China finally sealed a deal last week over piracy of "The Lion King," Microsoft MS-DOS and other intellectual property, and the terms looked pretty stiff: China would start a six-month crackdown on violators and would bolster its customs officers' powers. But cautious executives said success hinges on strong enforcement. "This is the beginning, not the end," said one. Still, while piracy surely pays, China has strong reasons to mollify America. Of the two nations' $45 billion in trade, $37 billion is Chinese exports. And America can help China get something it dearly wants: entry into the World Trade Organization.
 
Sour Notes, Second Thoughts
The $20 billion Mexican rescue package may be signed, but clouds are gathering fast. On Monday, Banamex, the Mexican bank, announced layoffs of up to 35 percent of its 33,000 employees. On Wednesday, former President Salinas blamed current President Zedillo for the crisis, saying his advisers should have kept mum about their plans to prevent a drain on Mexico's money reserves. And, up north, discontent with the bailout led the House to ask for all the Administration's Mexican files. "Pessimism all around," said one analyst.
 
ECONOMY
 
Gunning for Glass-Steagall
Get ready for the firm of Salomon, Chemical & Aetna, or somesuch. Efforts are growing in Washington to allow mergers among banks, securities companies, insurers and other enterprises, thus discarding the 60-year-old Glass-Steagall Act and other limits on financial institutions. On Monday, Treasury Secretary Rubin sketched out the Administration's plan, with Alan Greenspan generally approving of it the next day. Then come the Republicans' two Congressional bills on the issue. But the proposals' details differ, and critics warn that consumers and small businesses may be hurt by such mergers. "Cross-ownership at the expense of Main Street," one opponent called the idea.
 
Dollar Dives; Fed Buys
No, the peso is not the only currency on the rocks. After sliding lower all year, the dollar hit a record low against the yen last week and, for the first time in four months, the Fed intervened. On Thursday, the central bank bought $250 million to $300 million of dollars with foreign currencies, and, yesterday, it and other central banks tried again. But the dollar sat at only 94.14 yen at Friday's close and, with it also declining greatly against the mark and other currencies, more Fed action may be in the offing.
 
The Taxman Cometh, Sometime
The I.R.S. wants you to blame someone else if your tax refund is delayed. Last week, Commissioner Margaret Milner Richardson told Congress that the agency wants to ferret out citizens who fraudulently claim the earned-income tax credit, a benefit that allows many Americans not only to pay no income tax but to get Federal dollars back in the bargain. The I.R.S. initiative will mean that 7 million taxpayers -- guilty or not -- may get their refunds late, the commissioner said. Electronically filed returns raise the agency's biggest suspicions. While such returns make up just 12 percent of all individual returns, they account for 43 percent of all fraudulent claims.
 
Balanced Budget: No Cigar
What a difference one Democrat makes. The long push for a balanced-budget amendment failed in the Senate last week when the Republicans could not sway either Byron L. Dorgan or Kent Conrad, two North Dakota Democrats and potential swing votes, to side with the measure. So, although Senator Bob Dole paved the procedural way for another vote this year or next and House Speaker Newt Gingrich vowed vengeance at the polls, Washington can keep its checkbook unbalanced for now. Will it do so? Well, President Clinton's budget proposal last month forecast lots more red than black: namely, annual budget deficits of $200 billion through the end of the decade.
 
COMPANIES
 
Now, That's News!
Well, it's not man bites dog, but some cynics may see a parallel. The Securities and Exchange Commission sued an Atlanta investor last week for fleecing nine big brokerage firms out of $13.5 million. The investor, Michael J. Morse, placed orders to sell stocks that he neither owned nor borrowed. Like all short sellers, he was hoping to profit from a fall in these equities' prices, the S.E.C. said, but when prices rose instead, some Wall Street biggies were left holding the bag. Among the losers: Goldman, Sachs; Smith Barney and Lehman Brothers.
 
Quilting Bees? Hardly
High rollers, take note. Last Sunday, 15 women from homey Beardstown, Ill. -- 6,200 people, one cash machine -- gathered to autograph a book of their advice. The topic, though, was about as big-city as you can get. "The Beardstown Ladies' Common-Sense Investment Guide" (Hyperion) chronicles how, in their 11 years as an investment club, the women have earned an average annual return of 23.4 percent. That's about double what the S.& P. 500 earned during the same period -- which explains why the book is now No. 3 on The New York Times "how-to" best-seller list. How'd they do it? As the title says, common sense. When they saw how full the parking lot was at the local Wal-Mart, for instance, they bought the stock. That was back in 1990. The stock has risen nearly 60 percent since then.
 
Will the Planes Be on Time?
At precisely 6 A.M. on Tuesday, as United Flight 1062 pushed back from the gate, Denver International Airport opened -- 16 months late and $2 billion over its $2.9 billion budget. A perennial work-in-progress, the airport often made headlines over accusations of boondoggling and over its troubled baggage system, which initially shredded luggage instead of conveying it. But not all the bad news is past. Many air fares are $20 higher each way at the new airport, to defray landing fees that are three times as high as those at the old one.
 
Movie Chains to Link Up
When you buy popcorn in bulk, it's cheaper. That's one reason behind a merger, announced last week, that will create the world's largest movie chain. Worth $450 million in cash and stock, the deal will join the 1,625 movie screens of the Cineplex Odeon Corporation and the 1,164 screens of Cinemark USA. The new company, Cineplex International, will have theaters stretching from Chile to Canada -- 11 percent of the world's capacity and about 600 more screens than United Artists, the next largest competitor. If the new company's buying clout lowers the costs of candy, film rental and the like, will ticket prices drop, too? That remains to be seen.
