HEADLINE: Triple Murder Causes Alarm About Hate Groups' Growth

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER 

DATELINE: SEISHOLTZVILLE, Pa., March 5

 BODY:
Along Walker Road here, Mark Thomas's compound of hate is easy to find.
Amid the trash, mud, rusted vehicles and sagging buildings a little more than a mile off the main road, the 44-year-old Mr. Thomas operates a ministry for racists where he teaches weapons skills on a rifle range and where, last April, he played host to a weekend Hitler Youth Festival that attracted 200 neo-Nazi skinheads and other white supremacists. Mr. Thomas also publishes The Watchman, a monthly newsletter that in one issue last year preached, "It is the trademark of the Jew to make us feel dirty and unworthy." 
 Although well known to the police and state authorities in the Lehigh Valley, Mr. Thomas is now attracting more intense scrutiny as the result of a gruesome triple murder that the police say was committed by two brothers, both neo-Nazi skinheads who were said to have visited the compound many times. The religious doctrine taught there, known as Christian Identity, says anyone who disagrees with white supremacy is a traitor who must be destroyed.
The murders and the existence of Mr. Thomas's camp are focusing state officials' attention on the swift growth of white-supremacy groups in Pennsylvania. The number of hate crimes more than doubled in five years in Pennsylvania, to 417 in 1993 from 181 in 1988, according to the State Human Relations Commission.
The brothers, 18-year-old Bryan and 16-year-old David Freeman, are charged with beating and stabbing to death their father, Dennis Freeman, 54, their mother, Brenda, 48, and their youngest brother, Eric, 11. The police have also charged Nelson Birdwell 3d, an 18-year-old cousin who was in the Freeman home at the time of the attack but denied taking part, with a lesser offense.
The brothers' home in Salisbury Township, outside Allentown, is a 20-minute ride from Seisholtzville. Brenda Freeman had told officials at the human relations commission, Allentown city officials and a former organizer for the Aryan Nation, a racist group in Idaho, that her sons were frequent visitors to Mr. Thomas's compound.
In an interview over the weekend, Mr. Thomas acknowledged that Bryan Freeman visited once, last October, for an Oktoberfest celebration. "There was a bonfire," Mr. Thomas said. "There were marshmallows. It was a family kind of thing."
But he said he never met the muscular teen-ager, who is over 6 feet tall, sported a swastika tattoo on his neck, wore high black boots and fatigues, and shaved his head. Mr. Thomas denied teaching a philosophy of hate and said he was "on sabbatical" from white-supremacy organizing. The crimes the Freeman brothers are accused of cannot be laid at his door, he said.
"I never heard of either of them until this happened," Mr. Thomas said.
But a teen-ager who spent a lot of time at the compound and was interviewed in January by the human relations commission, described an atmosphere of paranoia and intimidation there. A Nazi flag hangs in a makeshift chapel inside an old trailer on the grounds, according to a transcript of the interview. Food is stockpiled in the basement of the main wood-and-stone house in preparation for a "racial holy war," and Mr. Thomas built a bomb shelter out of a bus he buried on his land, the teen-ager said. Skinheads were welcome at the compound, the teen-ager said, and Mr. Thomas spent hours teaching Christian Identity.
"Their whole religion is based mostly on the first chapter in the Bible," the teen-ager said. "Thomas claims that Jewish people are descended from Cain who was a descendant of the devil snake and Eve. He claims white people are descendants of Abel who was a descendant of Adam and Eve. He claims there are two main races, Jews and white people. Everyone else is classified under beasts of the field. They say we need the help of the beasts of the field people to overcome the evil Jewish race."
That such extreme teachings are finding a growing audience in Pennsylvania is a source of alarm, but not surprising, state officials said. Ann M. Van Dyke, an investigator with the human relations commission, said Mr. Thomas, who once earned a living as a trucker, is now tilling the fertile fields of racial tension and economic dislocation in the Lehigh Valley and Pennsylvania generally.
The state's dominant industries -- coal mining, steel production, heavy equipment manufacturing -- collapsed in the 1980's, Ms. Van Dyke explained, throwing thousands of blue-collar workers out of work. The new high-tech engineering, medical and information industries, based mainly in Philadelphia and Pittsburgh, demand a different set of skills and education.
Ms. Van Dyke also said that turmoil in the big cities of the Northeast, including New York, is causing members of minority groups to flee to places like Allentown, where the once white-majority school population is now more than half Hispanic and black.
Five months ago, in a move that city officials said seemed to encourage race divisions, the Allentown City Council approved a law directing municipal documents to be published only in English.
"In this state there is wage stagnation," Ms. Van Dyke said. "There is resentment of affirmative action and an across-the-board fear that their job is going to be taken by somebody who didn't work as hard or deserve it. The kids feel that fear, and known racists are exploiting it."
The neo-Nazi skinhead culture, which glorifies violence, made its way to the United States from England in the early 1980's, according to the Southern Poverty Law Center, a civil-rights group in Alabama. Sixty-four white supremacist and neo-Nazi groups are active in Pennsylvania, according to the state, more than any state in the East and perhaps the largest number in the country.
Hate-group literature and recruiting fliers for white-supremacy groups are now common in schools through the state, said Richard B. Anliot, the director of Education and Community Services at the human relations commission.
Barry Morrison, the Philadelphia regional director of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith, said the increase in hate crimes -- defined as assaults, violence, threats and other incidents motivated by racial tension -- in the last few years in Pennsylvania reflected a national trend of intolerance and violence. His group counted more than 2,000 incidents against Jews nationally last year, the most since 1978. Last month, in the latest incident in Pennsylvania, a pig's head was stuck on the door of a synagogue in York, south of Harrisburg.
In the Allentown area, the hate-related incidents have been more vicious. In January, two Asian teen-agers, honor students from nearby Quakertown, made Molotov cocktails, dressed in military fatigues and firebombed the home of a white teen-ager who had insulted one of them. The mother of the white teen-ager was seriously injured when she leaped from the second floor of her home to escape the flames.
Even more worrisome to the authorities has been the growing number of skinheads who have been involved in especially brutal crimes. Before the Freeman killings, skinheads had been convicted of three murders in Pennsylvania and 30 others nationwide since 1987.
Last year, Mr. Morrison said, skinheads in Shamokin captured and buried up to its neck the dog of a white family that had opposed skinhead activity in the town. They filled the dog's mouth with firecrackers and blew its head off.
The motive for the killing of the Freeman family has perplexed the police. Before her slaying a week ago, Mrs. Freeman was desperately searching for help. Family members said the boys once tried to smother their mother with a pillow and another time pinned her down while one stood over her with a hatchet. Several students said this week that they heard the boys say they hated their parents and wanted to kill them. About two weeks ago, both had their foreheads tattooed. Bryan's tattoo said "Berzerker" after a skinhead rock group, and David's said "Seig Heil."
"Brenda Freeman called and said she was losing control of her boys and her household," Floyd Cochran, a former Aryan Nation spokesman and organizer in Idaho, said in an interview. "She said they went numerous times to Mark Thomas's compound with their cousin. These were emotionally disturbed kids. They were the kind of kids I used to recruit."

HEADLINE: Markets Are Holding Up Despite Dollar's Drops

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Unless the value of the dollar goes into a free fall against major currencies, economists and portfolio managers say they do not expect its latest bout of weakness to have much impact on prices in American financial markets.
That assessment would have been unthinkable during the latter 1980's, when Japanese investors financed a large chunk of the United States' soaring trade and budget deficits through purchases of everything from financial assets to real estate. In those days, bond traders looked at any prolonged period of dollar weakness against the yen with genuine alarm. 
"The slightest possibility of a tumble in the dollar would have caused a problem for financial markets" back then, said Allen Sinai, chief global economist for Lehman Brothers.
But times have changed, and the American stock and bond markets have not only withstood the downward pressure on the dollar, but flourished, to the amazement of some analysts.
"I don't understand how two-year Treasury notes can possibly be yielding 6.87 percent with the dollar collapsing," said David Buchen, a managing director at Citibank who is in charge of the bank's foreign exchange operations. "And I don't understand why, if people like marks so much, that 10-year German bonds are yielding about 7.35 percent while 10-year Treasuries are yielding just about the same thing. Asset markets and currency markets have been delinked."
Since December, when the latest round of dollar-selling began, bond yields have fallen and stocks have risen to new peaks in the United States. Meanwhile, markets in Germany and Japan, the big countries with the world's strongest currencies, have either languished or slumped.
Mr. Buchen and other analysts pin the dollar's recent slide on a number of developments.
"The currency markets didn't like Alan Greenspan suggesting last month that the Fed might be done raising rates," said David Hale, chief economist at Kemper Securities. "It doesn't like the deal the United States did to rescue Mexico. And political problems elsewhere in Europe have been pushing a lot of money into German marks."
But analysts say that a number of factors seem likely to protect American markets from feeling the sting of the dollar's slide.
Most important, the analysts say, is that the United States has become less dependent on one main source of foreign capital to finance its deficits. Over the last few years, Japan has been replaced by central banks from a range of newly industrialized countries, many of them Asian, whose currencies are linked to the dollar.
"In the 1980's, we needed the Japanese to finance the deficit; that is no longer the case," said Neal M. Soss of Soss & Cotton Enterprises, a New York money management firm. "We have different bankers now, who for a range of reasons seem pretty content to stay tied to the dollar. I would be much more concerned if the dollar were much weaker against emerging-market currencies."
Then, too, because of shifting trading patterns, Mr. Soss and other analysts said market fears of the inflationary effects of a weaker dollar were much less real now than before. The inflationary effect of a lower dollar would be much more profound if countries with strong currencies like Germany, Japan and Switzerland, were America's most important trading partners. They are not.
Indeed, Canada and Mexico, which last year ranked first and third, respectively, in terms of bilateral trade with the United States, have currencies far weaker than the dollar. Moreover, to maintain market share, foreign companies based in strong-currency countries have either squeezed profit margins drastically or moved operations to the United States.
All these factors, coupled with signs that the pace of economic expansion in the United States is slowing, make it very unlikely that the Federal Reserve Board will raise interest rates to support the dollar.
"In a slowing economy, a falling dollar is a good thing," Mr. Sinai said, "because it helps boost exports and damps import demand."
And William H. Gross, a managing director at the Pacific Investment Management Company, a Newport Beach, Calif., money management firm with $60 billion in fixed-income assets under management, said the recent weakness in the dollar was a "negative for holders of long-term Treasuries, but not a negative for the overall level of interest rates."
Dollar-related jitters may rattle in the credit markets for a short while, said David H. Resler, chief economist at Nomura Securities International. Despite near-term caution, Mr. Resler said he remained a fan of dollar-denominated financial assets.
"We were moving toward another month of improving prices and falling yields," he said. "But if I am a dollar-based investor, I want to keep my money invested in the U.S. stock and bond markets this year. Earnings look good, and interest rates will continue to come down as the economy continues to slow."

HEADLINE: The Clamor in Mexico: Sullied Name Stirs Salinas

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, March 5

 BODY:
Former President Carlos Salinas de Gortari is assured of a place in Mexican history, but the baffling events of the past week make it almost certain that it will not be the place he so desperately tried to attain.
Close friends of Mr. Salinas are puzzled by his recent actions, but they say that he has long been driven by a sense of destiny. That helps explain why he would take such unusual measures to defend his name, including breaking a long tradition of silence by former Presidents and undertaking a hunger strike. 
 In a brief interview inside the chilly cinder-block house in the northern city of Monterrey where he staged his 44-hour-fast, Mr. Salinas said he had stopped eating in order to defend his honor, just days after his brother was accused of having plotted a major political assassination.
"My decision is above all a moral one," he said, denying his action was intended to provoke his successor, President Ernesto Zedillo. Asked if he had confidence in Mr. Zedillo, he answered, "I have confidence in Mexico."
Specifically, he demanded that the federal Attorney General recognize that the Salinas administration had not tried to stand in the way of the investigation into the assassination last March of Luis Donaldo Colosio, the governing party's candidate who had been handpicked by Mr. Salinas. He also wanted to be publicly absolved of responsibility for having caused the economic crisis that now engulfs Mexico.
Mr. Salinas's threats deeply embarrassed Mr. Zedillo, who after just two days agreed to the conditions his predecessor had laid down. On Saturday night Mr. Salinas had a bowl of soup and ended his strike.
The bleak rooms in Monterrey were a world away from the imposing Legislative Palace in Mexico City where just over three months ago Mr. Salinas handed the red, white and green presidential sash and all the power it represents to President Zedillo.
At that time, Mr. Salinas seemed destined to accomplish his dream of being recognized as one of the most successful Mexican presidents, a bold reformer who had signed a free-trade agreement with the United States and Canada, who had restored Mexico's long-suspended relations with the Roman Catholic Church and who had undertaken significant reforms to make authoritarian Mexico more democratic.
The success of his anti-poverty program, Solidarity, was acknowledged around the world and he had the strong backing of the United States to become the first secretary general of the World Trade Organization. As he prepared to leave office, his staff delivered to reporters piles of books documenting his achievements.
"You have to understand that in the career of President Salinas there was not a single mistake or failure, almost from the beginning," said one Government official who worked with Mr. Salinas and who asked not to be identified. "He came from a very prominent family, he went to Harvard University, he came back to Mexico with a very high position and then had an uninterrupted string of success after success that led straight to the presidency of Mexico when he was just 40."
"It would be very difficult to detect a single point of rupture or failure in that career except for what happened since he left office," the official added. "Perhaps he was simply not prepared for it."
Another official who worked with Mr. Salinas said the former President "had no tolerance for failure."
Mr. Salinas's world changed abruptly just after dawn on Dec. 20 when the Zedillo administration announced that it had been forced to devalue the peso 15 percent, setting off a chain reaction that has plunged Mexico into an economic emergency for which most Mexicans, according to public opinion polls, blame Mr. Salinas. The devaluation also virtually destroyed his chances of heading the World Trade Organization.
Revelations by Mr. Zedillo's Attorney General that the investigation into Mr. Colosio's slaying had been manipulated raised suspicions that somehow Mr. Salinas's office had been involved.
Then last Tuesday came another crushing blow, when Mr. Salinas's elder brother, Raul, was arrested on charges of having ordered the murder of Jose Francisco Ruiz Massieu, secretary general of the governing Institutional Revolutionary Party, the PRI. Investigators now say that evidence implicating Raul Salinas was removed deliberately from official files during Carlos Salinas's administration.
Within minutes of the arrest, Mr. Salinas made a telephone call to a popular midday news program to defend his record. The call ended a tradition dating from the 1930's, in which former presidents silently accept public scorn to strengthen their successors. Jose Lopez Portillo, another former President, told a Mexican newspaper on Friday that the function of former Presidents consisted of "shutting up and not creating more problems for the next President."
Whether he believed Mr. Zedillo was attacking him personally, or simply that he was being accused unfairly, Mr. Salinas showed he was going to fight back. On Thursday night, he said he would not eat until the suspicions against him were proved to be unfounded.
In Mexico, hunger strikes are a common form of protest for everyone from aggrieved taxi drivers to Samuel Ruiz Garcia, the Catholic Bishop who recently fasted for peace in the troubled state of Chiapas.
Although he had been a master of the art of image during his term in office, Mr. Salinas failed to strike a convincing pose. The overwhelming reactions to his hunger strike were derision and total bafflement, especially after he suspended it Friday night and then resumed it briefly on Saturday.
Friends of the former President say that in the last year Mr. Salinas lost nearly all his closest allies, beginning with Mr. Colosio. The political turbulence of 1994 forced other confidants to either flee the country or retire from public life, leaving Mr. Salinas without a trusted sounding board. After public opinion turned against him, other friends and associates abandoned him.
When Mr. Salinas showed up in Monterrey in the dark hours of early Friday morning searching for a place to stage his hunger strike, he was accompanied only by a bodyguard.
Negotiations with an emissary from Mr. Zedillo had resulted in a public statement by the federal Attorney General exonerating the former President in the Colosio investigation, and a promise from Mr. Zedillo to clarify the actions taken last December in handling the economy. Mr. Salinas ended his hunger strike Saturday night.
After six years in office, Mr. Salinas's legacy is evident all over Mexico. The thousands of streets that were paved with Solidarity money and miles of highways built by private investors remind millions of Mexicans of his vision.
But which of Mr. Salinas's many images will survive? The neighborhood where he staged his brief hunger strike was a garbage dump until Solidarity money built houses and paved streets. But now, just months after he left office, even the painted Solidarity signs around the corner from the house where Mr. Salinas slept for two uneasy nights are already beginning to fade.

HEADLINE: New Roll of Dice For Atlantic City's Development Plan

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER 

DATELINE: ATLANTIC CITY

 BODY:
An ambitious plan to make the casino district a more attractive vacation destination for families and nongamblers is in peril, and accusations are flying that two of the biggest casino interests in town are trying to scuttle it because they don't want the competition.
The original design for the project created a landscaped corridor with a new 1,000-room hotel, amusements and retail pavilions reaching from a state-financed $254 million convention center, under construction at the eastern end of the Atlantic City Expressway, to the casino district on the boardwalk and ocean five blocks away. Weedy lots and dilapidated buildings -- the first things a visitor to the island resort now sees -- would be eliminated in the corridor, and hopes were riding high that these improvements would encourage private investment in adjoining downtrodden neighborhoods. 
 All the key players -- casino operators, state and city officials -- appeared to embrace the idea after it was introduced in 1993, when there was confidence that $500 million in public and private financing was available.
But now there are complaints that casino operators are acting to limit the scope of the project by opposing key features that moved tourists and conventioneers farther away from their own casinos and hotels.
Hired to mastermind the project was one of the nation's most respected urban tourist planners, the Rouse Company of Columbia, Md., developer of the South Street Seaport in New York, Faneuil Hall in Boston and Harborplace in Baltimore.
But cracks developed both in the plan and the spirit of cooperation after two hard-driving casino operators were appointed last summer to the board of the Casino Reinvestment Development Authority, the public agency that oversees the corridor project.
This month the debate over the project escalated from squabbling to accusations that the new board members, Arthur M. Goldberg, chairman of Bally Entertainment Corporation, and Nicholas L. Ribis, who runs the three Trump casinos in Atlantic City, were acting together to sabotage the project and advance their own interests.
Mayor James Whelan, who also sits on the board, was one of those raising questions about whether the pair's actions constituted a conflict of interest.
"There are a lot of strong-willed folks on the board now and they aren't shy about articulating their views," the Mayor said.
"Things have reached a point where it's easy to throw up one's hands and call it a disaster," he added. "We can't allow the hotel to go down the drain. If it does, the state will have wasted $250 million for a new convention center that will be left sitting out in the middle of nowhere."
Mr. Goldberg and Mr. Ribis said their major complaint is that private financing for the entertainment complex and the convention headquarters hotel was inadequate. Their only motive in raising these issues, they said, was to impose some restraints on a project that had grown too ambitious for the money stream available to underwrite it.
But Mr. Goldberg, in particular, drew fire when he disclosed several weeks ago that Bally had purchased the vacant property next door to its Park Place casino for $7.5 million and planned to spend another $150 million to add 60,000 square feet of gambling space and build its own "entertainment center." It was the same land that the development authority had paid Rouse some $1 million to study as the site for Monopoly Square, which was to be the corridor's main retail and amusement attraction, based on the board game.
That same day, at a development authority meeting, Mr. Goldberg ridiculed Rouse officials as "clowns" and persuaded the board to suspend payments to the company. In addition, the 13-member board delayed the start of work on the hotel, which had already been scaled back to 500 rooms to cut costs. Some said the delay would hold up the hotel's opening at least six months after the convention center's scheduled completion in early 1997.
Another wrinkle was added when Mr. Goldberg approached Original Ventures, a small development planner little known in a field dominated by Rouse, encouraging it to propose the conversion of the city's existing boardwalk convention hall into a multi-level entertainment attraction and huge indoor wading pool. The old structure, best known as the site of the Miss America Pageant, is flanked by two Trump properties, Trump Plaza Hotel and Casino, and Trump Regency Hotel, and has figured in Rouse's plans.
Rouse Company officials said they were perplexed by criticism that the company was moving too slowly.
"We've met every scheduled deadline and the C.R.D.A. has been informed of every step taken," said Robert Minutoli, a Rouse senior vice president in charge of the Atlantic City project. "Any periods of delay have occurred when the ball was in the court of the public sector."
While saying Rouse "would never attribute ill will toward anyone or call anyone names," Mr. Minutoli defended his company's reputation and said the current crisis was the product of "posturing" by individuals "advancing what they think best for various constituencies."
"I still believe we will sort out the issues," Mr. Minutoli said. "Our plan may be changed and others may change their minds, but we can still work something out."
James Kennedy, C.R.D.A. executive director, said Mr. Goldberg informed the authority on Feb. 24 that he will recuse himself on any further matters involving Rouse, Monopoly Square and boardwalk development. "Our counsel tells us he is not legally obligated to refrain from voting on these matters but Mr. Goldberg says that will be his position from now on," Mr. Kennedy said.
The authority director also said Mr. Goldberg has personally assured him that he will not stand in the way of the hotel project and that it will be built once private financing is secured.
Thomas Scannapieco, a partner in the group selected to build the convention headquarters hotel, said he questioned the sincerity of the assertions by Mr. Ribis and Mr. Goldberg that they used their positions of public trust only to assure sound financing in the corridor.
"The board members leading the opposition to the hotel are the same whose casinos would be the disproportionate beneficiaries of every dollar diverted from it that goes into entertainment dollars invested near the boardwalk at their casinos," he said in a telephone interview.
The development agency was formed by the Legislature in the administration of Gov. Thomas H. Kean to redirect some of the money earned by the casinos into urban renewal projects, especially in their home base of Atlantic City. Since the inception of casino gambling in New Jersey in 1978, the casinos have paid the state an 8 percent tax on gross revenues. That tax has gone into programs to help the elderly and disabled. The development agency took another 1.25 percent bite for bonds that would be redeemable by the casinos far in the future, and set a $2 casino parking fee to help offset the cost of the corridor.
As bond interest rates climbed, and projections of parking revenues fell, the project was reduced in scope to about half its original estimated cost of more than $500 million.
Mr. Ribis and Mr. Goldberg said they had no intention of killing off the headquarters hotel to steer conventioneers to their own rooms. It will be built, they said, even if they have to fund it themeselves.
"This controversy came about because of the perception that the casinos are trying to stop something," said Mr. Ribis, who several years ago led an unsuccessful effort to locate the new convention hall closer to the boardwalk. "But the reality is that it's our money going into the corridor. At the moment there's not enough private money to do all the things people want."
At the very least, the recent bickering, coming after so much talk of harmony, has disillusioned people who thought Atlantic City was finally on the road to becoming more than a fiefdom for casino owners.

HEADLINE: A U.S. Look For Lessons In Barings

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

DATELINE: CORAL GABLES, Fla., March 5

 BODY:
Whether the failure of Barings P.L.C. was a regrettable but instructive accident or a sign of a growing weakness in the world's financial system was the subject of an uneasy debate this weekend by regulators, financiers and academicians who gathered here for an annual Federal Reserve conference on markets.
The Barings collapse, involving losses of $1 billion from speculation about the direction of the Japanese stock and bond markets, followed precisely a script that had been the biggest worry of many regulators: a trader careens out of control and in a matter of weeks loses enough money to bankrupt a major financial firm. 
 While the demise of Barings has not led to a cascading disaster that many have feared, the regulators were still concerned that the financial system had been tested so much in the last year. The Barings disaster was preceded by the insolvency of Orange County, Calif., and the sudden and unexpectedly large losses at banks, corporations and even mutual funds from various innovative financial deals.
What disturbed regulators most was not the knowledge that such huge losses could occur -- that has been clear for some time as derivatives and myriad other financial innovations have developed -- but that seemingly well-managed firms had handled them in ways that seemed preventable.
"In most, not all, of the cases, the problems involved individuals and institutions that by any rule of reason, were probably quite sophisticated," said E. Gerald Corrigan, the chairman of Goldman, Sachs International Advisers, and the former president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. "Yet they appear to have forgotten the elementary relationship between risk and reward. If you see a 16 percent instrument in an 8 percent market, something has to tell you it's not right."
This is by no means a new observation. Derivatives are side bets, contracts whose cash value changes with some underlying market like stock prices or interest rates. As government and industry groups have studied derivatives, they have uniformly concluded that their use is essentially no riskier than investing in the underlying stocks or bonds themselves, except for the matter of speed. Derivatives can turbocharge an ordinary investment portfolio in the same way that a new V-8 can help a jalopy.
"The one thing the Barings episode illustrates," said Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, "is the productivity for making losses has gone up very significantly in the last 25 years. You couldn't write the execution slips fast enough 25 years ago to lose as much money as was lost by one individual, aided by terrific technology."
The speed, flexibility and low cost of derivatives is often useful to investors and corporations navigating the world's rocky markets, and it would probably be counterproductive -- not to mention nearly impossible -- to ban technological innovation.
As a result, Mr. Greenspan and other regulators around the world have argued that the proper response to derivatives is the rough equivalent of driver safety education. They have repeatedly urged banks and brokers that sell derivatives -- and their customers -- to keep a close eye on where they are driving with derivatives and not to go so fast that they would be hurt if forced to make a sudden stop.
The appropriate control procedures are well established, and Barings, the oldest member of London's financial establishment, knew full well that it was not considered proper practice to have one person in charge of both trading and accounting for the trades. Yet Nicholas W. Leeson, the 28-year-old trader blamed for losing the $1 billion by trading futures in Singapore, was apparently assigned both tasks.
One explanation for this stunning lack of controls is stinginess in management, said Richard C. Breeden, the former chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, who is now the head of the financial services practice at Coopers & Lybrand. "Most chief executives can't spend enough on traders and trading systems, because these add to their bottom line, but they see controls as overhead to be cut. It's like building a car with a very powerful engine, but no brakes."
Regulators -- including the Bank of England, which looked after Barings -- try to conduct the financial equivalent of brake inspections, auditing internal controls of all sorts. Clearly, it was not enough.
Yet some regulators see instructive value in the Barings demise, arguing that such an event every now and then provides useful warnings of the dangers of excess.
Eugene A. Ludwig, the Comptroller of the Currency, who oversees national banks, quoted what he called a bank regulators' prayer: "God, let there be a failure, but a small one."
Barings, he said, "wasn't a small one, but the effect was salutary."
Not everyone was so sanguine.
"It's nice to see that when some failures occur, the system has been resilient," said Steven M. H. Wallman, a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission. "On the other hand, one has to wonder if there are more and more failures occurring, is there something to be concerned about?"
Mr. Wallman said he was concerned about the effect of such collapses on public confidence. "There is a psychological ripple effect to the failure of a firm involved with retail investors," he said. "It is important for people investing to feel secure about the financial system in this country."
But no one at the conference offered any concrete suggestions.
"There aren't any easy answers," said Joseph E. Stiglitz, a member of the President's Council of Economic Advisers. "It's not obvious that just because there is a problem there is a solution."
So regulators were left again with little more to do than urge bankers not to give the car keys to joy riders.
"The gut feel of the 55-year-old trader," Mr. Greenspan said, "is more important than the mathematical elegance of the 25-year-old genius."
To which Mr. Corrigan added, "The one thing we need more of, to put it succinctly, is gray hair."

HEADLINE: Law Lets Midwives Supervise Only Low-Risk Cases

BYLINE: By EMILY M. BERNSTEIN 

 BODY:
The increasing use of midwives at many public hospitals in New York City comes as there is renewed interest in the age-old profession across the country. Their focus on the most natural and least invasive methods of childbirth is attractive to women who are put off by the more clinical approach of some doctors.
They have become popular among some healthy, young middle-class women who can expect uneventful pregnancies and deliveries that are not likely to require the technology available in modern maternity wards. 
 Administrators in New York's public hospitals say they believe their patients are more comfortable with midwives, who are almost all women and more likely to be from minority groups than are obstetricians. As a result, the patients may be more likely to seek and continue prenatal care.
The appeal of midwives is also economic. Midwives at public hospitals are paid an average of $61,000 a year, while obstetricians receive about $150,000, so the hospitals can hire more midwives and assign them to spend more time with each patient.
Only certified nurse-midwives are allowed to practice in New York. They are registered nurses who have graduate degrees in midwifery and pass a national certification test. Of the 500 midwives registered in New York State, a quarter work in the city's public hospitals, where they handle 22 percent of the deliveries. In private hospitals, midwives handle about 5 percent of the deliveries.
Although midwives have delivered babies in New York for centuries, it was not until 1992 that the Legislature established midwifery as a separate profession with its own licensing board. The law gave midwives the right to prescribe certain drugs and order laboratory tests, and required them to work in consultation with physicians.
A woman whose pregnancy and delivery are handled by a midwife may never see a physician. But midwives, both in private practice and in hospitals, must work under formal guidelines arranged with obstetricians. And by law, midwives are allowed to manage only the "normal pregnancies" of "essentially healthy women."
But the 1992 law and its predecessors do not define those terms. As a result, there is a wide range of opinion about the types of patients midwives should be handling, as well as who should be classified as "high risk" and beyond the expertise of midwives.
"The term 'high risk' is totally misused," said Dr. Patricia Burkhardt, associate clinical professor of midwifery at New York University, who helped draft the law. "It's not the same as a complicated history."
For instance, a woman who developed diabetes during one pregnancy could be managed by a midwife in another pregnancy, she said, as long as the diabetes does not recur. The fact that a woman may have a statistical risk of developing a complication should not disqualify her from the care of a midwife, said Dr. Burkhardt, who has a doctorate in public health.
As midwives have grown in popularity, tension has developed between them and some doctors, who fear that midwives may take on cases they are not trained to handle.
Dr. Kenneth J. Leveno, the director of obstetrics at Parkland Memorial Hospital in Dallas, said he often found himself at odds with midwives who take on complex cases.
"It's sort of like putting a pilot who flies a Piper Cub in a 747," said Dr. Leveno, an author of Williams Obstetrics, a reference book widely used by doctors. "When patients get into the airplane, they need to be told who's in the pilot's seat." Midwives are important, he said, "but they need to be part of a team that has a 747 pilot."
Some midwives say that doctors' fears are misplaced and that sometimes doctors don't want to spend the time necessary to deal with troublesome -- and bothersome -- patients, leaving them to be treated by midwives. This is particularly true at public hospitals, Dr. Burkhardt said.
"When patients are complicated," she said, "the doctors don't want to bother with them."

HEADLINE: Europeans Devalue 2 Currencies

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Monday, March 6

 BODY:
In a move expected to doom efforts to create a single European currency in the next few years, finance officials of the European Union agreed at an emergency meeting early this morning to devalue the Spanish and Portuguese currencies against those of eight other European countries.
The two Iberian currencies have come under enormous pressure as concerns about Spanish politics, and the broad global uncertainty about the Mexican financial crisis and the recent collapse of the British investment bank Barings P.L.C., have led investors to turn to German marks in a search for a safe haven. 
 The uneasiness in the foreign-exchange markets has extended to the dollar, which fell this morning to a postwar low of 92.95 yen in Tokyo trading, before rising in late trading to 93.40, still down from its close in New York on Friday of 94.14 yen.
The dollar's plunge came despite large purchases of dollars on Friday by the Federal Reserve of the United States, the Bank of Japan, the Bundesbank of Germany and several other European central banks -- and despite an additional intervention by the Bank of Japan this morning.
But unless the dollar goes into a free fall, American economists and portfolio managers say they do not expect its bout of weakness to have much impact on United States financial markets. [Page D4.]
Economists said the dollar's slide reflected investors' nervousness about the Fed's willingness to fight inflation, as well as other issues.
The lack of confidence in some currencies and the deep differences in the economic strength of many European countries have created the third wrenching of the European monetary system in three years.
After their 11-hour meeting in Brussels ended early this morning, the finance ministers announced a 7 percent devaluation of Spain's peseta and a 3.5 percent devaluation of Portugal's escudo. The decision would seem to make it impossible to stabilize and align Europe's leading currencies into a single currency within the next two years, as called for under the Maastricht Treaty of 1992, and almost impossible to achieve the goal by the end of the century.
"If anyone was still around believing that monetary union was possible by 1997, here is a glaring example of divergence that still exists between European countries and why monetary union is so impractical," said Richard Reid, chief economist at the Union Bank of Switzerland in Frankfurt.
Economists argue that monetary union will significantly reduce the costs to businesses of dealing in multiple fluctuating currencies; politicians see it as a way to bring the union's members closer together politically.
Under the concept of monetary union, member countries would impose on themselves nearly identical fiscal disciplines in a preliminary step toward a single European currency. In the Maastricht Treaty, members agreed not to have budget deficits of more than 3 percent of gross domestic product or accumulated debt levels exceeding 60 percent of G.D.P. Without meeting such guidelines, a country cannot enter monetary union.
But Germany and the tiny country of Luxembourg are the only countries now able to meet those strict tests. Moreover, with a significant break in currency stability occurring in Europe about once a year, economists say it is difficult to foresee monetary union anytime soon.
Throughout Sunday evening, as the representatives of finance ministries and central banks of the 15 European Union countries met behind closed doors, speculation was high that Spain and Portugal might even drop out of the currency system, which establishes limits that restrain the relative value of the currencies. Ten of the 15 member countries of the union participate in the currency system.
On Friday, the peseta fell almost to the lower limit of its permissible trading band, closing at 88.43 to the German mark, 3.5 pesetas away from its floor against the mark of 91.91. Portugal, whose economy is closely linked to that of Spain, had also seen its currency hit by traders.
The devaluation was the fourth in two and a half years for the peseta and the third for the escudo.
Though Spain has kept inflation under control, it has been very slow to privatize Government-controlled businesses and to eliminate the enormous costs of Government employment and social programs, creating a large budget deficit. That deficit, and recent accusations that the Government of Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez financed a covert war against Spanish terrorists, have weakened confidence in Spain's ability to keep up with economic stalwarts like Germany.
In a communique issued by the ministers, Spain promised to limit its current budget deficit to no more than 5.9 percent of its gross domestic product.
"Structural reform to improve the efficiency of the economy will be a high priority, including privatization of public enterprises and labor market reform," the communique said of Spain's promised improvements. "The Spanish Government will evaluate labor market reforms adopted in 1994 and will determine whether further measures are needed."
The Maastricht Treaty says that if a majority of the 15 countries meet the economic standards by the end of 1996, they can create a single currency beginning in 1997. If there is no majority, the countries that meet the requirements can form a monetary union two years later. But economists say it is unlikely that a majority will meet the 1997 deadline, or that a significant number will do so by 1999.
Indeed, Europe's recent history of currency instability has been fraught with failed attempts to maintain artificial price ranges for currencies and as divergent economic realities in the countries send currencies in different directions.
In 1992, after the Maastricht Treaty was signed, international turmoil forced both the British and Italian Governments to pull their currencies from the European Monetary System.
A year later, currency traders again tested the narrow trading limits set by European monetary officials. And again the system broke down. Officials were forced to greatly widen the parameters, to permit a 15 percent swing in value for any one currency, from swings of between 2.25 percent and 6 percent.
In addition to the peseta and escudo, the other currencies now in the system are the German mark, the French franc, the Belgian franc, the Luxembourg franc, the Dutch guilder, the Austrian shilling, the Irish pound and the Danish krone.
But weak currencies are not the only problem for the grid and, by extension, a future monetary union. Some currencies, especially the German mark, are seen as too strong.
Indeed, as investors have worried about recent developments in Mexico and at Barings, there has been a flight to safety in the German mark, which has been setting new postwar highs weekly against a basket of 18 world currencies.
Because of the Bundesbank's almost impeccable record on using interest rates to stop inflation, the mark is now the preferred global currency for those seeking safety amid uncertainty.
And economists were predicting further flight to safety by investors, saying that in addition to pressure on the dollar, there would also be pressure on the currencies of Italy and France because of problems of rising budget deficits in those countries.
The Bank of Japan confirmed that it was buying dollars early this morning to prop up the currency. The bank said it injected 300 billion yen, or about $2.8 billion, in early trading to support the dollar.
Analysts argued that there was little at this point to argue for buying dollars, since the latest statements by the Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, indicated that the Fed thought the economy might have peaked and that it saw little reason to push interest rates any higher.

HEADLINE: House Republicans Propose Using a Work Requirement to Help Cut Food Stamp Costs

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 5

 BODY:
House Republicans said today that they wanted to cut $16.5 billion from the food stamp program over the next five years by establishing strict new work requirements for recipients and by trimming the growth in benefits.
The proposal represents a fundamental shift in the design of the program, which serves as the ultimate safety net for more than 27 million poor Americans. 
 It is one piece of a huge bill intended to free poor people from dependence on Government while vastly increasing the power of state officials to run their own welfare programs free of Federal supervision. Democrats say the overall bill is cruel to women and children because it would, for example, scrap the national school lunch program and give the money to the states as well as bar the use of Federal money to provide cash assistance to unmarried teen-agers.
The food stamp proposal would cut $16.5 billion, or 11 percent, from the $149 billion that would otherwise be spent on food stamps in the next five years.
The Republican plan would require hundreds of thousands of able-bodied adults without children to find work within 90 days of getting food stamps. It would also reduce the annual cost-of-living adjustment for food stamp recipients, which provides additional benefits to match increases in food costs.
Republicans say the changes are needed to control the cost of the program. Democrats call the proposed cutbacks Draconian, and they say the work requirement would end benefits for many people who are unable to find jobs.
More than 27 million people receive food stamps, up from 20 million in 1990. The economy has improved significantly in the last few years, and unemployment has fallen. But the number of people on the food stamp rolls keeps rising, as does the cost of the program, $25 billion last year.
The Republican plan, to be considered this week by the House Agriculture Committee, is likely to win approval in the full House. The outlook in the Senate is less clear.
Under the plan, food stamp spending would still rise from year to year. But recipients could not buy as much with their coupons because the monthly food stamp allotment would not keep pace with inflation.
Food stamps are described as the ultimate safety net because eligibility is based almost entirely on a person's income and assets. Single people and childless couples with low incomes can get food stamps but usually cannot get cash benefits under other Federal welfare programs like Aid to Families With Dependent Children.
The new proposal supplements a Republican plan, already modified several times, that would give states the option of running their own food assistance programs in place of food stamps. States choosing that option would get a lump sum of Federal money roughly equal to the value of their food stamp benefits in 1994, with no adjustment for inflation in food prices.
But the Federal Government would still set policy for the national food stamp program. And the Republican plan says that able-bodied food stamp recipients from 18 to 50 years old "will be required to find work."
"These persons will be ineligible for food stamps after three months unless they are employed at least 20 hours per week or are participating in a workfare program," it says.
In workfare programs, people must do public service work in return for food stamp benefits. But the Republican proposal would not require states to operate such programs or provide money for them. Only a half-dozen states have workfare for food stamp recipients, and the programs are all small, with fewer than 100,000 participants nationwide.
Robert Greenstein, director of the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, who was head of the Food and Nutrition Service in the Carter Administration, said, "These proposals would eliminate the only part of the safety net that remains for large numbers of indigent people who receive no other Government assistance."
The bill, he said, "would end food stamp benefits after just three months for hundreds of thousands of people who wanted to work and searched for jobs but couldn't find them."
The current food stamp program does have a work provision. It generally requires food stamp recipients to search for jobs, to accept training and to take any jobs they can find, but it does not require people actually to have jobs.
The whole question of work requirements for welfare recipients has generated intense conflict between Democrats and Republicans. House Democratic leaders attacked other parts of the Republican welfare bill, saying that those portions should have much more stringent requirements that people work as a condition of receiving cash assistance. At the same time, the Democrats demanded money to pay for education, training, child care and work programs, and in general they would not deny benefits to people who are willing to work but unable to find jobs. The Republican food stamp proposal would impose the new work requirements without the additional money.
Under the Republican proposal, Congress would set an annual limit on food stamp spending. The Republicans would deny food stamps to most legal immigrants for at least five years. After that, immigrants could get food stamps only if they applied for United States citizenship.
A pervasive theme of the Republican proposal is to reduce or eliminate adjustments in food stamp benefits that reflect rising costs of food, shelter and other necessities. The bill would freeze the shelter deduction and the standard deduction allowed to food stamp recipients. Such deductions are used in computing household income. Families with more deductions get more benefits.
Food stamp allotments are increased each year to reflect changes in the price of a low-cost diet known as the thrifty food plan. The Republican proposal says, "The annual increase in the thrifty food plan will be curtailed." The amount of the cutback has not been decided. It will be set at whatever level is needed to help lawmakers achieve their overall goal of $16.5 billion in savings over five years.
The food stamp bill is part of an ambitious Republican effort to limit the growth of welfare spending and free poor people from dependence on Government. Other House committees are working on legislation to transform school lunch, child nutrition and cash assistance programs. Speaker Newt Gingrich of Georgia says he will package the measures in one big bill to be considered by the full House this month.
The original Contract With America, the Republicans' 1994 campaign manifesto, would have replaced all Federal food assistance programs, including food stamps, with a block grant. States could have used the money in any way they wanted to feed low-income people. Republicans on the House Agriculture Committee rejected that idea.
The lawmakers, from farm states, made this argument: If poor people receive cash instead of food stamps, there is no guarantee that the money will be spent on food. Sales of milk, pork, wheat and other commodities will decline, and the potential for fraud and other abuse may increase.
Groups involved with preventing hunger joined farm lobbyists in urging Congress to keep food stamps as a Federal program with uniform national eligibility criteria and benefits.
But several Republican governors demanded that House Republican leaders keep the promise made in the Contract With America. The governors, led by Gov. John Engler of Michigan, said they could run food assistance programs better than the Federal Government and wanted to coordinate food aid with other welfare benefits.
In a partial reversal, House leaders agreed to let states run their own food assistance programs if they replaced food stamp coupons with a system of "electronic benefits transfer." That system helps investigators detect fraud because it makes an electronic record of every transaction in which a person uses Federal money to buy groceries.

HEADLINE: Why Microsoft and Justice Dept. Settled

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Microsoft Back in the Dock" (editorial, Feb. 20) reflects an apparent misunderstanding of the antitrust investigation of Microsoft. The phrase "in the dock" refers to a holding area in British courts for people accused of criminal conduct. This is a civil, not criminal case. 
 Both the Federal Trade Commission and the Antitrust Division of the Justice Department have sweeping powers and formidable resources to collect and marshal evidence and to apply law and economic principles to that evidence to determine if there is a reasonable basis for an antitrust claim against a target company.
During a four-year investigation, the Government received information, both documents and testimony, covering potential allegations from Microsoft and dozens of third parties. It analyzed the evidence and negotiated a consent decree based primarily on allegations regarding Microsoft's licensing practices.
The Justice Department negotiated about licensing practices because, as Assistant Attorney General Anne K. Bingaman stated in court, that was the only case she thought she could prove. Although Microsoft did not violate antitrust laws, we were willing to accommodate the Government's concerns in the licensing allegations to end the investigation and avoid protracted and expensive litigation.
Under the Tunney Act, designed to insure against influence peddling in antitrust investigations and negotiations, the judiciary reviews the consent decree to determine that it provides adequate relief for the concerns in the Government's complaint. To require the Justice Department to reveal its entire investigation would discourage target companies from agreeing to a consent decree, denying the Government a principal tool of enforcement.
To second-guess whether a regulatory agency should have pursued other allegations than those in its complaint is an unjustified invasion of the executive branch's prosecutorial discretion. If private parties disagree with the Government's decision, they are free to commence a private action.
Other allegations were raised in a book about Microsoft that the judge read on vacation and relied upon during his deliberations. Similar allegations were reiterated by the 11th-hour third parties in these proceedings. However, the Justice Department represented to the court that it could not make a case on those allegations.
The trial court's decision is before the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia. It is Microsoft's hope that upon full judicial review, the consent decree will be entered, a result you seemed to anticipate in a July 21, 1994, editorial that extolled the consent decree.
 
WILLIAM H. NEUKOM
Senior V.P. & General Counsel
Microsoft Corporation
Redmond, Wash., March 2, 1995

HEADLINE: Chinese Leader Says 'Mistakes' By Government Fueled Inflation

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER 

DATELINE: BEIJING, March 5

 BODY:
Prime Minister Li Peng acknowledged today that "mistakes" made "at all levels" of his Government had allowed inflation to reach its highest point since Communist rule began in 1949 and that this increase last year had "aroused great resentment among the masses."
The declaration, in Mr. Li's opening address to this year's National People's Congress, appeared to lay the groundwork for an overall retrenchment of the economic reform program that was begun by Deng Xiaoping in 1979. 
 It may have also set the stage for long-rumored personnel changes that would dilute the power of Zhu Rongji, the Vice Prime Minister who has overseen economic policy since assuming control of the central bank in 1993.
Speaking to 2,811 deputies gathered in the Great Hall of the People, Mr. Li reported that overall inflation reached 21.7 percent in 1994, a rate that was double the level he pledged to maintain a year ago.
Consumer price inflation, the main indicator of the effects of price increases on Chinese citizens, was 24.1 percent. The prices of many basic foods and grains, however, increased by 60 percent.
The last peak in consumer prices was in 1988, when inflation reached 19 percent and contributed to an outpouring of popular anger toward the Government during the democracy protests of the following spring. Since then, consumer inflation had been a negligible factor in the economy, reaching 3 percent in 1991 and 5 percent in 1992 until the rate rose to 13 percent in 1993.
"Practice has proven that in a Socialist market economy, the Government must carry out necessary regulation and management in pricing for the major commodities, which have a great bearing on the national economy and on the people's livelihood," Mr. Li said.
At the same time, he said, while economic reform will continue, it will come under greater control.
The United States Ambassador, J. Stapleton Roy was among the foreign diplomats who attended today's session and he said, "My instant analysis is that they are more focused on domestic issues than they were last year."
In addition to inflation, the issues of crime, corruption and a decline in agricultural output dominated the Prime Minister's address. Of all the concerns that have seized the generation of leaders who will succeed Mr. Deng, inflation and corruption are pre-eminent. Mr. Li said combatting corruption was a "matter of life and death for our nation."
But his exhortations to greater vigilance against corruption were focused on local party officials, not the ranks of senior party officials and military officers where corruption is believed to be endemic.
His emphasis on "mistakes" in economic management seemed aimed at Mr. Zhu, whose power over the economy has vaulted him above Mr. Li in influence at times over the last two years.
Mr. Li's case was simple. He said price liberalization measures and a weak harvest had sent prices of many commodities soaring, but that "the mistake we made was that we had underestimated the repercussions of these measures."
"The Government took no emergency measures to stop these practices and launched no overall austerity program," he said, because some officials were trying to "prevent a sharp decrease in economic growth."
China's economy grew at 11.8 percent in 1994, compared with the 9 percent Mr. Li had sought. His comments implied that a timely austerity program could have headed off inflation and brought growth down to a manageable level.
Mr. Zhu, seated two rows behind Mr. Li during the speech, held his posture ramrod straight, never glancing at the text of the speech before him, while other vice prime ministers scribbled and underlined the document.
During his speech, Mr. Li said China would seek to slow its economic growth rate of 12 to 13 percent of the last three years to 8 to 9 percent.
The central Government plans to slow the pace of investment, and reduce the number of national construction efforts so that financing can be made available for major projects that are already under way, like the Three Gorges Dam on the Yangtze River, the largest hydroelectric project in the world.
The annual session of the congress gives the 53 million members of the Communist Party the opportunity to display its strength, with delegates from every province and from each of China's 55 minority groups. But the body itself lacks any real legislative powers and serves to ratify the decisions made by the party's 170-member Central Committee, whose chairman is President Jiang Zemin, the party's general secretary.
Five years ago, Qiao Shi, chairman of the National People's Congress and a member of the Politburo, was considered a contender to succeed Mr. Deng as paramount leader but was edged out by Mr. Jiang and has since lost other important party posts.
Mr. Li's power in the inner circle comes from his long association with the conservative wing of the party, whose most hard-line members have begun to grumble that Mr. Deng's economic reforms have created such destructive forces as unemployment, inflation and corruption.
At the same time, Mr. Li's health has declined. A heart attack in early 1993 removed him from leadership responsibilities for four months, and Mr. Li has reportedly been working less to conserve his energy.
Today, minutes after he began speaking, a page quietly brought a chair to the rear of the broad wooden podium so Mr. Li could discreetly support himself during the speech.

CORRECTION-DATE: March 8, 1995, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Monday about the opening of the National People's Congress in Beijing referred incorrectly in some editions to recent rates of Chinese inflation. Inflation, a major concern of the congress, last peaked in 1988, not 1989; the rate then was 19 percent, not 17.5.

HEADLINE: Subway Bomb Suspect in Lineup

BYLINE: By GEORGE JAMES 

 BODY:
The suspect in a subway firebombing, Edward J. Leary, was identified in a police lineup yesterday by 12 of 17 people, some of whom were on the train that was firebombed last December, his new lawyer said.
Earlier in the day, Mr. Leary made an unscheduled appearance in State Supreme Court in Manhattan, where he was ordered by Justice Rena Uviller to shave his beard for the lineup so that he appeared the way he did on the day of the firebombing. He and 47 other people were injured on Dec. 21, when a car on a No. 4 train erupted into flames in the Fulton Street station in lower Manhattan. 
 Mr. Leary, a 49-year-old unemployed computer technician, also appeared in court to confirm a request by his wife to change lawyers from Stephen G. Murphy to Ira D. London.
Mr. London, the new president of the New York State Association of Criminal Defense Lawyers, received widespread attention defending Joel Steinberg, who was sentenced in 1989 to eight and a third to 25 years on a reduced conviction of first-degree manslaughter in the death of 6-year-old Lisa Steinberg, whom he had raised.
He accompanied Mr. Leary, who had grown a scraggly beard while recovering in the hospital, to transit police headquarters in Brooklyn, where the lineup was held.
Mr. Leary is accused of carrying jars with flammable liquid attached to a timer onto the train.

HEADLINE: Stocks Recover From a Blow by the Dollar

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
At first, the battered dollar dragged down the stock market yesterday, sending the Dow Jones industrial average plunging as much as 34 points in the first 15 minutes of trading.
Nervous currency traders turned to stronger foreign currencies, like the German mark, lessening the value of dollar-denominated assets, like stocks. Bond prices fell, and long-term interest rates rose. 
 "The biggest bang for your buck was in the mark," Kevin J. Lawrie, foreign exchange manager for the Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh, said.
Still, the Dow rebounded strongly, closing at 3,997.56 points, up 7.95 points, and the broader Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks, rose 0.21 point, to 485.63. Analysts said, however, that the rebounds on both indexes are misleading.
Shares of the Walt Disney Company accounted for six points of the Dow's rise. Oil stocks, after a favorable article in the financial weekly Barron's, also rose, accounting for most of the jump in the S.& P. 500.
The rest of the market was down. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index fell 1.02 points, to 797.77. On the New York Stock Exchange, almost two stocks fell for every one that rose, with 785 gaining and 1,453 declining.
What has happened since the Dow broke the 4,000-point level and set a high of 4,011.74 just nine days ago on Feb. 24? Analysts say not much, as far as the performance of the American economy. Inflation is low, growth is moderate and corporate earnings are surprisingly strong.
But expectations by all financial markets about the near future have changed because of currency traders' sudden nervousness.
The dollar has fallen sharply since March 1, establishing postwar lows as it falls. The dollar closed yesterday in New York at 92.69 Japanese yen, down from 94.14 yen. The devaluation of the Spanish peseta and Portuguese escudo yesterday did not help, because the resulting flight to German marks further buckled the dollar and hurt bonds.
The proximate cause is Mexico, where political scandal, civil unrest and uneven economic performance have upset the expectations of its partners in the North American Free Trade Agreement, the United States and Canada.
It also did not help that Federal Reserve officials last week seemed to indicate that economic concerns were more important than defending the dollar. Traders then viewed last week's $3 billion intervention by the Treasury and the central banks of Germany, France, Belgium, Switzerland and Sweden as half-hearted.
And adding to the anxiety were market rumors that Japanese investors were repatriating billions of dollars in investments not only for accounting purposes when the Japanese fiscal year ends March 30, but also to rebuild the earthquake-damaged regions around Kobe.
The Dow has gained 4.25 percent this year in terms of dollars, but fallen 2.63 percent in terms of yen and dropped an even worse 5.43 percent in marks.
Shares of the 3Com Corporation, a maker of computer networking products, rose 3, to 57 3/4, after a Paine Webber analyst said that the company's earnings in the third quarter ended Feb. 28 would be better than expected. Xcellenet shares rose 2 3/4, to 29, after the AT& T Corporation chose an Xcellenet software product as part of its "Virtual Workplace" program of approved products and services.
Class A shares of the National Western Life Insurance Company fell 3 to 33, after its fourth-quarter earnings fell to $1.08 a share from $5.25. Harley-Davidson shares fell 2 7/8 to 24, after posting fewer sales for recreational vehicles.
Auto stocks fell after analysts began to question the 1995 profitability of the Big Three. Stock in the Chrysler Corporation, for example, hit a 52-week low of 39 7/8 a share, down 7/8.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; National Desk

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
DOLLAR CONTINUES TO PLUNGE AS U.S. PONDERS STRATEGY

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 6

 BODY:
The dollar plunged more than 1 percent today to a new post-World-War-II low against the Japanese yen and briefly touched a historic low against the German mark as the currency accelerated a decline that began in the middle of last month.
The dollar's weakness is clearly worrying the Clinton Administration, as demonstrated by the effort it led on Friday, when more than a dozen central banks bought dollars in currency markets to try to support the value of the currency. But that coordinated effort failed. And as officials scramble for a strategy that would revive the dollar without running the risk of tipping the American economy into a recession, they appear to be running out of palatable options. 
 The recent plunge seems to have been driven by an odd melange of concerns. One is that the Administration will get sucked deeper into Mexico's crisis, which worsened today as the peso fell to its lowest point against the dollar since the crisis began in December. [Page D1.]
Fear that the Mexican crisis could spread to the rest of Latin America is also weighing on the dollar. In addition, there is some concern that the failure of the balanced-budget amendment in the Senate last week presages continuing huge deficits.
But the solution that the markets appeared to be demanding, another increase in interest rates to lure foreign investors to buy dollars again, is fraught with economic and political problems for the Federal Reserve and the White House.
In past sharp declines in the dollar -- most recently, in June -- the Fed consistently resisted any effort to prop up the dollar with higher interest rates, maintaining that interest rates should reflect domestic economic conditions, not fluctuations in the currency markets.
Federal Reserve officials have repeatedly hinted in recent weeks that their yearlong increases in interest rates have been just about enough to assure a "soft landing" for the American economy, in which the economy slows to a moderate pace but avoids a downturn.
Many economists fear that another big increase could slow the economy too much. If a downturn came as a result of action by the Federal Reserve, it would probably become clear to the public about nine months to a year from now, or as one Administration official noted ruefully today, "just around the time of the primaries."
The dollar dropped 1.5 percent, to 92.69 yen today, from 94.14 on Friday, the third consecutive daily low. The dollar also fell 1.5 percent, to 1.4037 marks, from 1.4244 marks, and during the day traded as low as 1.3860 marks, its record low, last touched in September 1992. For the year, the dollar is off 6.9 percent against the yen and 9.4 percent against the mark.
There was no evidence of any effort by the United States to intervene today by buying dollars.
And the White House and the Treasury, apparently acknowledging the unhappy choices they face, said nothing about the startling drop. The new Treasury Secretary, Robert E. Rubin, did not repeat his statement of Friday that "a strong dollar is in our national interest." On Mr. Rubin's advice, President Clinton is steering clear of even the vaguest comments about the financial markets.
For Administration officials, the problem is not so much a declining dollar as the possibility that the currency could suddenly, sharply fall, unnerving the stock and bond markets even more and creating a broader financial crisis that they would have to respond to quickly.
The decline of the dollar has a variety of impacts. The most immediate pain will be felt by American tourists in Germany, Britain, France, Switzerland and elsewhere where the dollar has plunged, making vacations more expensive.
For American exporters, however, the weaker dollar can be good news because it makes their products less expensive abroad. But for European manufacturers selling to the United States, the weaker dollar means their goods -- like automobiles -- become more expensive and harder to sell. Mercedes-Benz, for example, estimates that it loses 3 million marks for each one-penny rise in the value of the mark, based on its revenues last year in America.
Such rising costs could force foreign auto makers to raise prices, which would be a boon for American auto makers. But some foreign companies said they thought the current extreme weakness of the dollar was temporary, requiring no response.
Another fallout is that the higher prices of imports could add to inflation. But this impact might be muted by the fact that two major trading partners of the United States are Canada and Mexico, whose currencies have been falling against the dollar.
Those trade links, however, may be undermining the dollar. Traders suggested that the currency markets, which often operate on a theme rather than any substantive change in economic fundamentals, regard Mexico, Canada and the United States as an economic union in trouble.
"I think what is happening is that the North American continent is looking hopelessly in debt," said David F. DeRosa, a director of foreign exchange trading at the Swiss Bank Corporation in New York. "And the worst problem is in Mexico."
Indeed, the markets are apparently believing the oratory the Clinton Administration employed to win support for its $20 billion aid package for Mexico's troubled economy, especially Mr. Clinton's insistence that the Mexican and American economies were intertwined. Today, with the Mexican Government racing to take over failing banks and to stabilize a tumultuous political situation, the peso dropped to a new low of 7 to the dollar, closing at 6.555. That means that after a brief rise over the past month, the peso is now weaker than it was when the Administration announced an international rescue package totaling $50 billion, intended to keep the Mexican economy from collapse.
The speculation in the markets now is that the package may not be enough to do the job -- and that even if it is sufficient, the economic downturn in Mexico will spill into southern Texas and California.
The result in markets where image is often more important than reality is that the dollar is being dragged down by the peso. And in the absence of other safe harbors, traders are putting their money into the German mark and the Swiss franc, both of which have soared.
"The rise of the Deutsche mark and the fall of the peso are almost mirror images of each other," said John Mueller, the chief economist at Lehrman Bell Mueller Cannon Inc., an investment advisory firm with strong conservative leanings. "And the Germans and other Europeans take the view that Mexico is our problem, and if we want to keep it from affecting the dollar we should just raise our interest rates."
Some believe that the Administration may be reluctant to expend the resources it would need to defend the dollar: Mexico's $20 billion in loans and loan guarantees account for more than half the assets of the United States Exchange Stabilization Fund, which is usually used to maintain order in foreign exchange markets.
The Administration has repeatedly said that if the markets think the reduction of the fund's size will make the United States reluctant to intervene, they are mistaken. "The remaining resources in the E.S.F.," Lawrence G. Summers, the Under Secretary of the Treasury, said last week, "are sufficient to engage in any exchange-market interventions that may prove to be necessary."
But currency traders around the world seemed confident today that no amount of intervention would reverse the flow. So they are willing to go on selling dollars until they think there is some reason, like an increase in interest rates, for the dollar to reverse its downward course.
But today the Fed's vice chairman, Alan S. Blinder, hinted that he was satisfied with the current domestic economic performance, leading many to conclude that he did not believe another rate increase was merited. He said he saw signs that the economy was slowing to a sustainable rate of growth after its brisk expansion last year.
