HEADLINE: Where a School Lunch Is Food, Not a Policy Issue

BYLINE: By SARA RIMER 

DATELINE: LACROSSE, Wis., Mar. 2

 BODY:
For Gloria Brown and her daughters, free lunch at Franklin Elementary School is a big deal. The meals are well-balanced, and Heidi, age 7, and Samantha, age 10, like them.
Like many parents at Franklin, Mrs. Brown, who works the 3 A.M. shift at Hardee's, does not understand why the Republicans want to scrap the national lunch program and instead give a lump sum of money to states for school meals. 
 "What are they -- plain stupid?" said Mrs. Brown, who earns $6 an hour, and whose husband, Daniel, makes $5.75 an hour stacking lumber. "The Republicans don't have to worry about their kids eating lunch. They have a lot of money."
Free and reduced price lunches are not only for families on welfare and are not served only in inner city schools. They are also for working people like the Browns, and for many other parents at Franklin, at Jefferson Elementary, a couple of miles away, and at the 14 other public schools in the LaCrosse district here in the urban heart of dairy country.
Throughout LaCrosse County, people are angry. They consider themselves lucky to have jobs -- at Heileman's Brewery and LaCrosse Rubber Mills and the Trane air conditioning factory -- but in today's economy they are only scraping by. If the factory shuts down they go to work at Hardee's. If one job doesn't feed their families, they get two. For 59 cents they buy the Kraft Macaroni and Cheese dinner in the blue box that serves four and add hot dogs so it will serve six.
Now some of them are writing protest letters to their Congressman, Steve Gunderson, a moderate Republican, whom they helped elect last fall. "I just think this whole business is so mean-spirited," said Terry Witzke, the principal at Franklin Elementary School and a Democrat. "They are victimizing the children of this country. It almost makes me ashamed of our leaders."
Kim Lang, a single parent and a nurse, has two sons, Robert, 8, and William, 11, who eat reduced-price lunches at Franklin. "To me, it's something parents have always counted on," said Ms. Lang, who grew up on free lunch as one of seven children raised by a mother who worked as a waitress.
Now, suddenly, with the Republican majority working to pare long-standing social programs as part of its Contract With America, the school lunch program that feeds 25 million schoolchildren daily has entered the public debate alongside such contentious issues as welfare and Social Security reform.
In February, a House committee approved legislation that would give states new discretion to design their own school lunch and breakfast programs. Federal nutrition standards for school lunch would be eliminated; states would set their own standards. The Republicans said the amount of money in the block grant would increase from $6.7 billion in 1996 to $7.8 billion in 2000.
Under the House bill, each state would get a fixed sum of money each year, an amount that would not increase in response to a state recession or high unemployment. Under current law, Federal spending for school meals increases in hard times because all children in families with incomes that meet the program's criteria are automatically entitled to free lunches. The House bill would eliminate that guarantee.
Moreover, the amount of money available for meals could be further reduced by the stipulation in the House bill that 20 percent of the block grant could be used for programs other than school food.
Public health experts, along with school officials here and elsewhere, say they are worried that some states might end the free meals that studies have linked to improved academic performance. Or, they say, states might try to cut costs with less nutritious meals.
"I don't know much about the Federal deficit, but by God leave this alone," said Richard Swantz, the superintendent for LaCrosse, which has 16 schools with 8,000 students, 82 per cent of whom are white and the majority of the others African-American or Asian. "This is not just a program for poor kids. It's an investment for the entire country. Are these going to be America's children? Or are they going to be Mississippi's children, and Oregon's children?"
Republicans said the change to block grants would not cut the program but would make it more efficient and reduce the paperwork required by Federal regulations. School officials here concede that they have often complained about the paperwork. The bill is likely to be approved by the full House, but the outlook in the Senate is unclear.
The full price for a hot lunch in the public elementary schools here, with choice of two entrees, vegetables, homemade bread and butter, a salad bar, fresh fruit and milk, is $1.10; the reduced price lunch is 40 cents. A full-price breakfast is 75 cents, and the reduced price is 30 cents.
Amanda Amundsen, a Jefferson fourth grader, whose mother was laid off last month from her job as a receptionist with the state, was enjoying a free lunch of roast turkey with whipped potatoes, low-fat gravy, and peas at Jefferson the other day. "I like having a hot lunch," Amanda said. "It's expensive to pack cold lunch. A lot of things in stores are rip-offs."
In the LaCrosse district, 60 percent of schoolchildren rely on the schools for their lunches. Of those, 51 per cent come from families whose incomes qualify them for free or reduced meals.
Under current federal guidelines, a family of four with a combined annual income of less than $19,240 qualifies for free meals; a family with an income of less than $27,380 is eligible for meals at reduced price.
About half of Franklin's 223 students get free lunches and 30 pay a reduced price. Most of the others buy lunch for the full price of $1.10. Only a handful bring lunch from home. About 69 children at Franklin eat free or reduced price breakfasts. The numbers are similar among Jefferson's 216 students.
Twenty years ago, only 36 per cent of the district's children qualified for free or reduced lunches, said Marilyn Hurt, the supervisor of LaCrosse's school nutrition programs for 17 years. "Families don't make as much money as they used to," Ms. Hurt said.
Today, with more and more single parents, both parents working, and odd shifts and overtime, school officials say many children would go hungry if they could not eat at school. For some children, school may be the only time during the week that they do not eat alone.
In the spotless Franklin cafeteria recently, 7-year-old Brittney McGuire talked over toast with peanut butter, cornflakes with low-fat milk, and grape juice. "A lot of parents don't have time to make breakfast," she said. Her mother, for example. "My mom has to leave at 6 A.M. to make boots at the rubber mill," she said matter-of-factly."
Dozens of children at Jefferson and Franklin who were interviewed for this article volunteered that they liked, even loved, school lunches. They are served here along with lessons in good nutrition. The staff introduced broccoli by doling out samples over several months and now it is the school vegetable.
"My favorite is cheese dunkers," said Lindy Kron, a fifth grader, after finishing off the dish made with herbed garlic bread, mozzarella cheese and marinara sauce. "I need food. I can't think without it."
Nancy Dull's fifth graders were having a hard time understanding what was happening in Washington. Block grants are a new idea for them. But they have heard plenty from their parents and they say they are mad too.
"I think it stinks," Nate Kennedy said. "Some kid could go hungry."
Michael Shuda, 11, chimed in, "They obviously need more money -- need or want. They should give the kids a vote."
The hallways at Franklin are hung with signs that say: "Breakfast -- Don't Go To Class Without It." Mr. Witzke, the principal, is so passionate about breakfast he found money in the budget this year to serve it free to all his students two days out of every six.
He said his thinking has changed radically since he arrived at Franklin 25 years ago. "I believed in more and more parental responsibility," Mr. Witzke said. "By giving children breakfast and lunch, I thought we were facilitating the attitude of 'let the schools do it.' "
Mr. Witzke, who is 55, said he had in mind the way his grandparents raised him in LaCrosse. "My grandmother made me French toast and cream of wheat for breakfast. When I came home from school, I would smell her homemade bread. She ironed my shorts. I had this naive idea that that's the way it should be."
But Mr. Witzke said the lives of the children at Franklin changed his mind. "If I had my way, we'd have universal free meals. There are too many other obstacles to overcome. We can preach all we want, but if kids are hungry they aren't going to learn."
With all the meals currently federally subsidized, school officials said the proposed legislation might force states to raise prices. Families would drop out of the program, they said.
Wanda Werner, a nursing assistant whose husband earns $8.50 an hour as a mechanic, said she carefully budgets the $48 it costs to buy a month of full-price school lunches for her two children at Jefferson.
"There's times we don't have enough money so I'll make them cold lunch," said Mrs. Werner, who is a Republican and who counts on hot dogs to stretch the Kraft Macaroni and Cheese blue-box dinner. "The school sent home a sheet of what we should pack for a balanced lunch." She laughed. "There's no way you can do it for $1.10."

HEADLINE: DIARY;
Developments in Washington

 BODY:
LEGAL REFORM: The House began debating an overhaul of the American legal system as it considered legislation that would for the first time place civil laws governing personal injuries and defective products under Federal rules. The debate, which is expected to occupy much of the week, began with a proposal to require that people who undertake civil lawsuits, and then lose, pay the costs and fees of their opponents in many cases. The bill is a sharply curtailed version of the "loser pays" proposal embodied in the House Republicans' Contract With America.
ENDANGERED SPECIES: With Congress preparing to rewrite the Endangered Species Act, the Clinton Administration proposed changes intended to increase the law's flexibility and decrease its economic costs without putting rare plants and animals in greater danger of extinction. For instance, it wants to exempt from regulation most homeowners and activities on small plots of land, allowing some disturbance of habitat as long as the overall effect on a species is negligible. Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt also wants to give more power to state governments in carrying out the law, and has said that future decisions to list species for protection would have to be supported by independent scientific peer reviews. 
 MILITARY SPENDING: Suggesting that his Republican rivals were less sympathetic to the needs of veterans, President Clinton denounced as "unwise and unnecessary" a proposal approved by the House Appropriations Committee last week that would eliminate $200 million from current spending on veterans' health. He has proposed an $1.3 billion increase in spending over the next five years for the Department of Veterans Affairs, most of it for health care.

HEADLINE: Iran Signs Oil Deal With Conoco; First Since 1980 Break With U.S.

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

 BODY:
A major American oil company said yesterday that it had been awarded a contract by Iran to develop a huge offshore oilfield in the Persian Gulf, the first energy agreement involving Iran and the United States since Washington severed relations with Teheran in 1980.
American companies are permitted to buy oil from Iran, but they may not resell it in the United States. The contract by Conoco Inc. goes far beyond buying oil to sell to a third party, and the arrangement to develop oil and gas sources in Iran indicates a long-term relationship. 
 The deal was announced despite support in Congress for a bill that would impose an economic embargo on Iran.
Although the financial details of the Conoco deal were not disclosed, some oil analysts estimated that the project could be worth $1 billion.
The contract was signed after three years of negotiations, according to Jim Felder, a spokesman for Conoco, which is based in Houston and owned by the chemical giant E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company of Wilmington, Del.
Mr. Felder said he would be briefing the Clinton Administration on the deal in the next few days. He said some officials in Washington knew that Conoco was pursuing it.
Administration officials said Conoco had informed them that they were planning a deal with Iran. Officials said they planned to discuss it with the company, but did not try to hide the fact that they were displeased with the agreement, although they were reluctant to criticize it publicly.
The Administration officials said they were seeking more details to determine whether the agreement violated prohibitions of loans at below-market interest rates or transfers of advanced technology that could be used by Iran's military.
Christine Shelly, a State Department spokeswoman, said the Administration had sought to exert economic pressure on Iran and had focused on three areas: trying to limit arms transfers, government-to-government loans and sales of advanced technologies.
Furthermore, the Administration last year protested Iran's membership in an $8 billion oil consortium of mostly Western companies in Azerbaijan, a former Soviet republic. Iran's $350 million investment, a 5 percent share in the Azerbaijani oil project, was vehemently opposed by Washington.
Concerns by the United States over the potential for Iran's growing influence in the gulf region prompted a policy of containment in 1993 to limit Teheran's strength and reach.
The policy was aimed at putting pressure on Iran to relinquish its pursuit of weapons of mass destruction, its sponsorship of international terrorism and its opposition to the Middle East peace effort.
Denying charges of terrorist activity and of a nuclear weapons program, senior Iranian officials have blamed the United States for growing economic hardships, saying Washington is hostile toward Iran because of its Islamic Government.
The bill introduced in January by Senator Alfonse D'Amato, Republican of New York, and referred to committee, would forbid all economic and financial transactions, banning American companies from buying Iranian oil.
Paul Ting, an oil analyst for Oppenheimer & Company, said Iran and other Middle Eastern oil-producing countries had been feeling the pinch to come up with money for major oilfield development since lower oil prices have cut their revenues.
He said there had been doubts whether Iran could reach its goal of increasing its oil production from 3.6 million barrels a day to 4 million without substantial help from foreign oil companies.
Major oil producers in the Middle East have been seeking to increase their production capacity to meet growing demand in the coming decade. Some oil analysts have predicted that oil supplies may be tight by the end of the decade because Middle Eastern countries have not been expanding production fast enough as they faced greater demands to spend more on domestic needs.
Mr. Felder said that under the agreement, which was also announced by Oil Ministry officials in Iran, Conoco Iran N.V., a Netherlands-based affiliate of Conoco, would act as the contractor to develop the offshore fields on Sirri Island. Mr. Felder said he did not know the estimated size of the oil and gas reserves in the fields.
Sirri Island, 700 miles south of Teheran, is near the Strait of Hormuz, a strategic thoroughfare for shipping.
Mr. Felder said two fields, which were discovered in 1972 and 1976, would be developed. They are expected to produce more than 120,000 barrels a day in two years. The United States needs to import about 8 million barrels of crude oil a day to meet its needs.
He said a natural gas pipeline would also be built from Sirri Island to producing oil fields in Dubai. He said some gas would be injected into the existing fields in Dubai to increase their output. Sirri Island is about 80 miles from Iran and 90 miles from Dubai.
Mr. Felder added that Conoco had been competing with European oil companies including Elf Aquitaine S.A. and Total for the project.
Based on unofficial figures, American oil companies have purchased 30 percent of Iranian oil exports through subsidiaries.
Western diplomats have made it clear that economic ties would be a vital question before Washington would consider any restoration of diplomatic relations with Teheran. But high-ranking Iranian officials publicly maintain that ideological considerations take precedence over economic and political factors in shaping foreign policy.
"Establishing relations with the United States is not on our foreign policy agenda," Abbas Maleki, Iran's Deputy Foreign Minister for Strategic Research, said last week, the newspaper Salam reported.
Nevertheless, the special circumstances of today's oil agreement, which was signed in the Netherlands, apparently through a United States company subsidiary, was reported in the state-run press as a deal with "the Dutch company Conoco." That the project is to be based off shore merely underscored the sensitivity surrounding any important deal with American companies.

LENGTH: 1280 words

HEADLINE: A Presidential Hopeful for '96 With a Low-Key, Serious Air

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 6

 BODY:
Richard Green Lugar has been a United States Senator from Indiana for 18 years, but much of the national electorate has yet to notice. That would not seem to make for a promising start to a campaign for the Republican Presidential nomination like the one Mr. Lugar disclosed, to the surprise of many here, on Thursday.
Unlike Senator Bob Dole, the majority leader, who can summon network cameras whenever he wants toopine on any issue, Mr. Lugar is known largely as an authority on dry topics like arms control and foreign affairs. Unlike Senator Phil Gramm, of the Texas twang and saber-toothed sound bites, Mr. Lugar speaks in flat tones and shades of gray. 
 Lamar Alexander, the former Tennessee Governor, wears flannel shirts and wants to cut Congress's pay and send its members home. Mr. Lugar lives in dark suits and white shirts and leaves no question that Washington is a lifetime career.
"I'm glad Dick Lugar is in the race," said William Kristol, the Republican savant who used to be chief of staff to another Indianian, Vice President Dan Quayle. "But I don't know how he wins, frankly."
Neither do some of his supporters, yet. Still, they see a combination of qualities -- steadiness, deftness in crisis, bipartisanship -- that they believe the President and many of his Republican rivals lack. Some cast Mr. Lugar as a natural successor to Mr. Dole, a man of similar views and generational stature, if the Kansas Senator stumbles in the primaries as he did in 1988.
"He's not from the junior leagues," said Jeff Nesbit, a onetime Quayle adviser and current Lugar supporter. "He'll walk through the door ready to be the leader of the free world. This is a man who reads his briefing papers for hours before hearings. He takes the job seriously."
When he appeared with other Republican Presidential aspirants last month at the first of New Hampshire's many Presidential cattle shows, Mr. Lugar was notable for being the only speaker who did not try to crack a joke. Not many people doubt that he would be a serious and extremely well-briefed President.
The case against Mr. Lugar lies elsewhere. Even supporters say he is a premier foreign-policy expert in an era dominated by domestic politics, running in a race that frequently turns on issues like the flag, crime and the economy. Mr. Lugar seems to recognize that and has recently sought to raise his domestic profile.
In mid-February, he used his post as chairman of the Agriculture Committee to call for a drastic reduction in farm subsidies as part of the effort to reduce the Federal deficit. He also opposes demands by leading Republicans in the House and Senate for an income-tax cut for middle- and upper-class families, something Mr. Lugar says the country cannot afford now.
Such stances are unusual for a senator from a farm state and not popular among Republicans. They could set him apart from rivals like Mr. Dole, who does not like Mr. Lugar's proposed phase-out of crop subsidies for farmers in Kansas and elsewhere, and Mr. Gramm, who fervently supports tax cuts while fighting proposals to pay for them by trimming popular Texas programs.
Slim as Mr. Lugar's prospects might look, they could worsen if another Republican pragmatist, like Gov. Pete Wilson of California, enters the primaries, as many predict.
Supporters say Mr. Lugar intends to make the deficit a principal issue in his campaign, arguing that he would approach the question of balancing the budget with the unflinching resolve that Mr. Clinton lacks and his rivals are hard put to match. Mr. Lugar maintained last week that Mr. Clinton's failure to step up to fiscal problems had eroded what he called the "American advantage," an alliteration voters will have to get used to if his campaign prospers.
He also contends that he has experience in domestic matters that even rivals like Mr. Dole lack, though the comparison can sometimes seem stretched. Mr. Lugar oversees a small family farm outside Indianapolis and likes to say that he knows more than most politicians about filling out Federal forms and complying with tax rules. He also was Mayor of Indianapolis, and dubbed "my favorite Mayor" by President Richard M. Nixon, two decades ago.
"The Presidency is not a solo voice," he said last week. "It's a question of finding the best team. And I've been a consensus-builder." By comparison, he noted, Mr. Gramm was a professor, and Mr. Dole has been in politics almost his entire adult life.
Mr. Lugar is no novice to high-level politics. He has run the Senate Foreign Relations Committee; been considered three times for vice president, by Presidents Nixon in 1973, Ronald Reagan in 1980 and George Bush in 1988; run for Senate majority leader, and lost to Mr. Dole, and currently is leading the Agriculture Committee.
Now at the age of 62, he suggested on television last week that being President required "maturity" and "many years of experience," making an implicit comparison to the 47-year-old Mr. Clinton.
Still, Mr. Lugar cannot escape his label as a foreign-policy expert, and he appears not to want to. In interviews, he has suggested that the Government and Congress have a healthy supply of experts and ideas to deal with most domestic issues, whereas only the President can properly address the nation's two biggest concerns: the Federal debt and an increasingly unstable world.
In a news conference on Friday, he opened his pitch by accusing Mr. Clinton of conducting foreign policy in "episodic chapters." Later that day, he criticized Mr. Clinton in a speech at the Center for Strategic and International Studies, a Washington policy organization. He accused the President of virtually abdicating American leadership in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization by supporting the group's eventual expansion to include nations in Eastern Europe, but never specifying how the countries would join, or trying to sell the idea to the American public.
Mr. Lugar disagrees with Mr. Clinton over more than NATO. He believes the President has embraced the Russian President, Boris N. Yeltsin, too unreservedly. He criticizes the Administration's Bosnia policy. He has qualms about the accord to curb North Korea's nuclear program.
But his broad approach to foreign affairs is bipartisan. With Senator Sam Nunn, Democrat of Georgia, Mr. Lugar wrote the policy that earmarked $2 billion to help Russia dismantle much of its nuclear force and convert its industry to peacetime uses.
Mr. Lugar pushed for sanctions against South Africa in the 1980's when his party opposed them. This year, he criticized Mr. Dole's call for the United States to ignore an international arms embargo and begin allowing weapons to flow to besieged Bosnian Muslims.
He disputes Speaker Newt Gingrich's demand to end aid to Russia if Moscow supplies Iran with nuclear reactors, saying that Moscow's reactors are similar to those the United States may supply North Korea. And he opposes Mr. Gingrich's demand to pull American peacekeepers from United Nations forces unless they are placed under American command.
Those positions wear well with a foreign-policy establishment disenchanted with Mr. Clinton and fearful of the isolationism of Mr. Gingrich and those to his right.
"He's very solid on foreign policy," said Brent Scowcroft, the retired Air Force general who was Mr. Bush's national security adviser.
But what is reassuring to Washington's establishment may well enjoy less support in primary elections, where the voters are often diehard Republicans and the diehards are disproportionately to Mr. Lugar's right. And in the end, Republican political analysts say, that may cost him votes and money.

HEADLINE: Potash Buys Big Producer Of Phosphate

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

 BODY:
Elf Aquitaine S.A. of France and the Williams Companies announced yesterday that they had sold Texasgulf Inc., one of the world's largest producers of phosphate rock, to the Potash Corporation of Saskatchewan for $810 million in cash.
The sale signals a major pullback from Elf Aquitaine's long and costly entry into chemicals in North America. The French oil company had owned 85 percent of Texasgulf, with the rest held by Williams, a pipeline company in Tulsa, Okla., that transports natural gas and oil. 
 Potash, based in Saskatoon, Saskatchewan, is the world's largest producer of potash. Both phosphate and potash are used in fertilizer.
Paul Ting, an oil analyst for Oppenheimer & Company, said the cash from the sale would strenghten the ability of Elf Aquitaine to finance its primary business, which is finding and producing oil and natural gas.
Elf Aquitaine has been one of the state-owned companies involved in the French Government's drive toward privatization. The Government has reduced its stake from 50.8 percent to 13 percent.
The company, which has other chemical units and a pharmaceutical business, plans to sell about $1 billion worth of assets this year.
Phillip Jaffre, the chairman of Elf Aquitaine, had said that Texasgulf would be put on the block because it did not fit well with the company.
Elf Aquitaine acquired Texasgulf in 1981 and spent heavily to upgrade its operations in solid and liquid fertilizers, animal-feed supplements and purified phosphoric acid.
Texasgulf, based in Raleigh, N.C., is a big producer of sulfur. With a price closely tied to the economic cycle, sulfur did well for Elf Aquitaine for a while but the last recession caused prices to fall and Elf Aquitaine took a large write-down in 1990 to reflect the reduced value of the unit.
John B. Parry, an analyst with John S. Herold, a securities firm in Greenwich, Conn., said that the price Elf Aquitaine received was fair and that the money could be used to expand the oil, gas, and specialty chemicals businesses.
"The division did not fit in well with their plan to be mostly in fine and specialty chemicals," he added.
Also, he said, the company needed the cash because it had been increasing its debt to maintain capital spending and pay its dividend.
C. E. Childers, chairman, president and chief executive of Potash, said the acquisition would broaden the company's fertilizer product line and virtually double its work force and assets.
Douglas Groh, a chemicals analyst at Merrill Lynch & Company, told Bloomberg Business News: "Potash Corporation was the right one to buy it. The acquisition diversifies Potash Corporation's business and uses their balance sheet better."

HEADLINE: California Job Loss Affected Base Closing List

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 6

 BODY:
Concern about job losses in California led the Navy to limit its base closing list, Navy Secretary John Dalton told the base closing commission today.
Mr. Dalton's comments were the clearest statement to date that top Pentagon officials scaled back the closing list not only because of the high initial costs of closing bases but also to protect jobs in the nation's most populous state. 
 "I decided to make some economic impact decisions as it related to the state of California," Mr. Dalton said.
The Navy considered closing four small training and maintenance installations, three in the San Francisco Bay area, Mr. Dalton said. But such a recommendation, with a loss of 1,720 civilian and military jobs, combined with the impact of previous closings, would have meant a combined loss for California of about 30,000 jobs.
Still, those concerns were not enough to save the Long Beach Naval Shipyard, leading to the direct loss of 4,058 jobs as well as 9,248 jobs not directly affiliated with the yard.
A Navy chart ranked Long Beach slightly ahead of the Portsmouth Naval Shipyard in Kittery, Me., for overall military value. But Mr. Dalton said the Portsmouth yard's ability to service nuclear-powered attack submarines led to the decision to keep it open and close Long Beach.
Mr. Dalton and Adm. Jeremy Boorda, the chief of naval operations, said they made their decisions independently, without political pressure from the White House or the Secretary of Defense.
"I got input from a number of sources, but the decision was mine," Mr. Dalton said.
In a separate speech today to the National Association of Counties, Defense Secretary William J. Perry said communities like Long Beach could turn base closings into job producers "and actually wind up, many of them, better off with a more diverse economy and more jobs."
To do so, he said, they must plan carefully and avoid long local debates over how to use the space.
"Over the last three decades, almost 88,000 Federal jobs were lost as a result of base closing, but a total of 171,000 jobs, nearly twice as many, were created in and around the bases after they closed," Mr. Perry said.

HEADLINE: Whitman's Urban Agenda Outlines Self-Help Program

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON 

DATELINE: TRENTON, March 6

 BODY:
On a hill where rioters tore the heart out of New Jersey's capital city in 1968, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman announced a new urban agenda that offers the cities of New Jersey help in planning for economic recovery, but not much help in paying for it.
Calling for the creation of neighborhood-based development groups that would seek money from private and nonprofit groups, the program announced today was carefully tailored to the Republican self-help philosophy of a tax-cutting Governor with no money to spare and scant political support in the cities. 
 "For our urban strategy to truly succeed, we are calling on everyone -- community groups, businesses, clergy, educators, local officials, police and charitable foundations -- to work together," the Governor said in her remarks. "The power that comes from these partnerships will revitalize our cities neighborhood by neighborhood."
Governor Whitman's plan envisions the creation of numerous Neighborhood Councils, composed of local businesses and residents and assisted by nonprofit development groups such as Isles Inc., based in Trenton.
These local councils would create revitalization plans that they would submit to city governments and to the Governor's Urban Coordinating Council, a new group made up of cabinet members whose role would be to cut through red tape in focusing state aid to local groups with approved revitalization plans. New Jersey currently spends $2 million a year in urban aid, and the Governor said that figure would not be increased any time soon.
Four cities -- Trenton, Camden, Elizabeth and Asbury Park -- will take part in the program initially, and their mayors joined Mrs. Whitman under the spire of the Trenton Battle Monument, where George Washington dug in his artillery for the Battle of Trenton in 1776, and where, in 1968, rioters ended Trenton's life as a working city.
The mayors, all Democrats, said they were glad to have the state pay attention to their problems, which include negligible business investments, soaring real estate taxes and crime.
"It creates a discussion, it creates a framework, but clearly, it's no panacea," said J. Christian Bollwage, the Mayor of Elizabeth.
Trenton's Mayor, Douglas Palmer, declaring that the Battle Monument area would be the first district of the city to begin a renewal under the Governor's plan, said: "Today, the Governor has given Trenton what we have needed all along, a hand up, not a handout, to accomplish our goals."
The announcement of an urban development strategy makes good a promise Mrs. Whitman made early in her administration. While it may lack specifics in how each local government will accomplish its goals, the initiative fills a gap in the social agenda of a Governor whose political base is in the suburbs, far from the blight that surrounded her today.
Mrs. Whitman also has yet to mend her relations with New Jersey's black and Hispanic political and religious leaders, who have often accused her of ignoring their issues. New Jersey's cities missed out on the economic boom of the 1980's, and their leaders are intent on positioning their communities to catch the next wave, if and when it comes.
Evidently intent on deflecting criticism that she is not coming up with new money for urban areas, Mrs. Whitman said that $7 billion from a variety of state programs had gone to the four target cities over the past 10 years without solving their problems.
The mayors argued that the way that money was spent was out of their hands. Of the $2 billion given Elizabeth over that decade, Mayor Bollwage said, better than two-thirds went to education, medical services and welfare, programs over which mayors have scant control.
"The philosophy espoused by state and national leaders that urban areas just throw money away is not true, and I challenge anyone who believes it to come to Elizabeth and see that it is not true," he said.
Although the state does not have new money to offer the cities, Governor Whitman said special stress will be put on attracting money from private companies and nonprofit groups.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Marriott to Acquire a Ritz-Carlton Stake

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
Eager to add a luxury chain to its portfolio, Marriott International announced yesterday that it had agreed to acquire about 49 percent of the Ritz-Carlton Hotel Company.
Marriott is not buying any of the Ritz hotels, which are mostly franchised, only the right to manage them. The proposed acquisition, which also includes several minority partners, is scheduled to close this spring, and Marriott could later acquire the rest of the company. 
 "This is one of the most significant developments in the hotel industry in the last decade," said Joseph J. Doyle, an analyst with Smith Barney. "Marriott is probably the best hotel management company in the world and the Ritz-Carlton is probably tied with the Four Seasons as the best luxury brands in the world. The Ritz just hasn't been able to generate the occupancy and cash flow that Marriott has, but if anyone can significantly improve the profitability, Marriott can."
Marriott stock rose $1.375 a share, to $32.625, on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. The Atlanta-based Ritz-Carlton is controlled by William B. Johnson, an Atlanta developer and real estate investor who bought the Ritz-Carlton trademark in 1983. He owns three of the hotels and has investments in 10 others.
The transaction, which is said to be valued at almost $200 million, originated with Frederic V. Malek, one of the investors in the deal and chairman of Thayer Capital Partners, a private investment firm in Washington that specializes in management buyouts. Mr. Malek was campaign manager for the 1992 Presidential bid of George Bush and before that was president of Marriott from 1980-88.
"I started on the transaction about Dec. 1," Mr. Malek said, "and when it became apparent the synergies that could be added by Marriott could be pivotal to the deal, I went to Bill Marriott."
That was on Feb. 2, and the parties signed an agreement in Atlanta on Feb. 24. Bill Marriott is J. William Marriott Jr., chairman and president of the company. Mr. Malek, who reported directly to Mr. Marriott for 15 years, said Mr. Marriott was one of the few people who could accept that another company -- the Ritz-Carlton -- was doing a great job of pampering its guests, and who would maintain the integrity of its brand name.
The investment group includes Mr. Malek, Richard E. Rainwater, the Fort Worth investor; Frank Pearl, an investor from Washington, and Raymond G. Chambers, a co-founder and formerly senior partner of the Wesray Capital Corporation. Mr. Malek described their investment position as "a minority one, but not insubstantial."
With Ritz-Carlton access to Marriott money, reservations system and worldwide sales force, the transaction is expected to strengthen the Ritz-Carlton properties and spur the growth of the chain. The name was derived from Cesar Ritz, the Swiss-born hotelier who made his name synonymous with quality and service.
Although Marriott has about 900 hotels, from the 258 upscale Marriott Hotels, Resorts and Suites to the 172 economy Fairfield Inns, J. William Marriott Jr., chairman and president of the company, said that Marriott and the Ritz-Carlton complemented each other. While they serve different market segments, he said, they share "an incredible commitment to customer service."
The Ritz-Carlton's growth potential is "tremendous" outside the United States, Mr. Doyle said. If Marriott can profitably manage those or the existing properties, he added, "it can go to individuals who want to develop luxury hotels and say let's do it together. We can make you good money."

HEADLINE: Peso Reaches Lowest Point In 3 Months

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, March 6

 BODY:
The political and economic storm battering Mexico took a further toll on the badly weakened peso today, driving the currency to its lowest point since the crisis began last December.
The peso traded at an exchange rate of more than 7 pesos to the dollar at midday before Mexico's central bank stepped in to buy pesos and help stabilize the currency. At the end of the day, the spot rate for the peso was 6.555 to the dollar, or just above 15 cents, compared with nearly 29 cents before the peso's first devaluation on Dec. 20. Since then, the peso has lost 47 percent of its value. 
 Financial analysts here and in New York said the peso was hurt by several factors, including the weakness in the United States dollar, the continuing melodrama of Mexican politics, the Government's takeover last Friday of a large Mexican bank and delays in the revised economic stabilization plan that investors have been awaiting for the last two weeks.
"There was just a mixture of more bad news and no good news imminent," said Geoffrey E. J. Dennis, head of Latin American equity research at Bear, Stearns in New York. "All roads lead to the peso at the moment and we need some more guidance from the Government."
Banpais, Mexico's eighth-largest bank, was taken over Friday by the Government, which mentioned "irregularities." Carlos Escalante, a currency analyst with the Vector brokerage firm in Mexico City, said the administrative takeover of Banpais worried investors who feared that it might signal the beginning of a cycle of bank failures.
"There's a lot of speculation that there might be other banks with problems and that all that's missing is the official notices" of failures, Mr. Escalante said.
All the problems did not seem to hurt the Mexican stock exchange today. The market gained 3.2 points and closed at 1,522.7, which analysts said reflected the inflow of a small amount of speculative money that was not expected to last.
While a new economic plan had been expected two weeks ago, President Ernesto Zedillo now says that he will wait until the Mexican Congress has a chance this week to examine the details of the $20 billion bailout from the United States before announcing anything.
Mexican Government officials say Mr. Zedillo wants to build a broad public consensus on the objectives of the new plan before committing himself to a revised set of economic goals and projections.
Last month, Mr. Zedillo conceded that the Government could not achieve its initial plan's targets of 19 percent inflation, wage increases limited to 7 percent, economic growth this year of 1.5 percent and an exchange rate stabilized at 4.50 pesos to the dollar.
A new version of the plan is expected to peg inflation to more than double the original estimate. It could include wage increases of 15 percent or more, no economic growth in 1995 and a peso exchange rate of around 5.50 to the dollar or higher.
Some analysts said they thought that Mr. Zedillo was trying to buy more time by waiting for Mexico's Congress to examine the American rescue plan. The President himself has said congressional approval is not needed because the plan does not increase the Government's level of debt. Mr. Zedillo's party has a solid majority in Congress and the Mexican Government has already started using some of the bailout money authorized by the United States.
"What we're hearing is that there are a lot of negatives being brought out by labor and the corporate sector about the economic plan," said Eduardo M. Cabrera, manager of Latin American strategies for Merrill Lynch & Company in New York. "To use the excuse that they are waiting for Congress when they control the Congress, and can pass it if they want to, raises a lot of questions."
Mexico economic problems have been compounded by unrelated political melodrama, with Raul Salinas de Gortari, the older brother of former President Carlos Salinas de Gortari, accused of ordering the murder last Sept. 28 of Jose Francisco Ruiz Massieu, secretary general of the governing Institutional Revolutionary Party. A motive has not been given.
Mr. Escalante said that the confusing political picture had driven investors to dump pesos.

SECTION: Section A; Page 18; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 525 words

HEADLINE: Food Stamps in Peril

 BODY:
The food stamp program is the best part of the nation's welfare system. It saves millions of poor Americans from hunger and malnutrition every year and, unlike other welfare programs, is sensibly designed to insure equitable treatment from state to state. Yet if House Republicans get their way, this exemplary program could be wrecked within weeks.
Food stamp benefits are paid by Washington, indexed for inflation and set at identical levels across the country -- worth up to $375 per month for a family of four. They are a true safety net: if you are poor, you qualify. During the past 20 years, states have allowed cash assistance to the poor to fall, after accounting for inflation, by over 20 percent; food stamps alone have stood between poverty and malnutrition. 
 The House G.O.P. now proposes to rip two huge holes in this safety net. First the bill, which the House is almost sure to approve, would allow those states that adopt fraud-detection systems to opt out of the Federal program. They would then receive a fixed sum from Washington and distribute it to the poor any way they please. To protect taxpayers from possibly excessive outlays, states would most likely end an individual's right to collect stamps.
Judging from the past 20 years, states will balance their budgets in hard times by ratcheting down benefits. The pressure to cut is intensified by the fact that skimpy benefits encourage poor families to leave the state, relieving taxpayers of the burden of all their assistance costs.
Second, the G.O.P. would deliver an even worse blow to the remaining Federal food stamp program, which for the foreseeable future would probably enroll the bulk of recipients nationwide. Under current law, Congress spends whatever money it takes to feed hungry Americans -- increasing spending when, for example, recession hits and workers lose their jobs or when inflation drives food prices higher. But under the Republican bill, spending on food stamps would be capped. Come a recession, Congress would be forced to kick families out of the program or reduce the value of food stamps.
The bill would also require able-bodied adults without children to find work within 90 days of enrolling for food stamps. But the bill provides no money for job training or public-sector jobs. The next time the economy slows, 100,000 workers would lose their jobs and food stamps in quick order.
The benefit formulas would also leave recipients prey to inflation: the dollar value of stamps would not keep pace with prices, leaving the poor with less food every year. The list of other insults is so long it is hard to take stock: for example, the bill would save money by stripping food stamps away from many legal immigrants, no matter how long they had worked and paid taxes.
The House G.O.P. would eventually cut the $25 billion program by probably more than 15 percent. That reduction goes well beyond any reasonable estimates of waste, fraud and abuse. The richest country in the world would strip its citizens of the ironclad right not to starve. Perhaps the Senate can save the country from that ignominious distinction.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: A Shrewd Move on Schools

 BODY:
The pilot program announced by Mayor Rudolph Giuliani and Schools Chancellor Ramon Cortines to privatize the maintenance and repair of New York City schools is a smart idea. It could save money. It could help prevent the city's school buildings from collapsing around the students and teachers who inhabit them.
The system of repairing schools has long been inadequate. The fault has been shared by the Board of Education's Division of School Facilities and the school custodians. Together they are responsible for more than 1,000 school buildings. 
 Mr. Cortines has already shaken up the division, appointing a new administrator and decentralizing some decision-making to the borough level. Meanwhile, City Hall negotiated a tough labor settlement with the custodians, who had long been permitted to operate under sloppy work rules. The agreement calls for stricter accountability, and ties future pay increases to job performance. As an added goad to the custodians, the Board of Education contracted with private companies for cleaning services at about 90 schools. City Hall made it clear that it would push for more privatization in the future.
The board and City Hall are now making good on these promises. They will seek bids from private companies to clean and repair an additional 52 city schools beginning in July. The companies will not only clean the schools, as custodians are supposed to do, but will also do minor repairs, like fixing shattered windows or re-plastering walls, that custodians are not now required to do. The companies will serve a cluster of a half-dozen to a dozen schools within certain areas, which should allow for some economies of scale in purchasing and labor.
It is unclear how much money, if any, can be saved from the $300 million originally budgeted for repairs this year. What is clear is that whatever its cost, a competitive system to patch up the schools will almost surely save the city heavy capital expenditures down the road.

HEADLINE: Doctors, on Offensive, Form H.M.O.'s

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
Doctors, on the defensive in recent years as employers and insurers sought to control medical costs, are starting to fight back against the growing sway of insurance and health care companies over the practice of medicine. And in a challenge to health maintenance organizations and other insurers, a small but growing number of physicians are leapfrogging the middleman by offering to sell their services directly to employers.
The doctors insist that they, rather than insurers, can do the best job of protecting the interest of patients while providing the economical care that the public demands. 
 Seeking greater influence with health care buyers, physicians across the country organized hundreds of new medical groups in the last two years, abandoning their old individual and two-doctor practices.
Now some doctors are going even further to gain influence in the marketplace. In New Jersey, 3,500 doctors recently contributed $5,000 each to raise $17.5 million to organize their own health maintenance organization. About 200 doctors in El Paso County joined last year to form the El Paso Community Health Plan, which has just announced an agreement with a Levi Strauss plant in El Paso to treat job-related injuries. The Holzer Clinic, based in Gallipolis in southeastern Ohio, which has 80 doctors, has a contract with the local operations of the Federal-Mogul Corporation, an automobile parts maker.
One of the biggest and best-known doctor-run groups, the Mayo Clinic, has provided care for Deere & Company workers in Iowa and Illinois since 1993, and last year it enrolled 8,000 I.B.M. employees in Rochester, Minn., Mayo's home base.
In the New York metropolitan region, the Long Island Physician Holdings Corporation is planning a new doctor-owned H.M.O. "We're the people who provide the care," Dr. Rosario J. Romano, a board member, said. "We would like to have some control over our own destiny."
Even doctors who are not contracting directly with employers now recognize that they must form groups to survive. "Individual doctors don't stand a chance," said James C. Robinson, a professor of health economics at the University of California at Berkeley. "The future is in the large capitated medical group," which accepts a monthly per capita fee for everybody it covers. "It can bargain as equals with the H.M.O.'s," Professor Robinson said.
Dr. Peter Kongstvedt, a partner at Ernst & Young, the accountants and benefits consulting firm, said the per capita deals were "the way for physicians to lock in business and profit margins." He added, "Then those physicians who succeed under comprehensive capitation can be very big winners."
Some of these groups have been so successful that they have received buyout offers from some of the same health care giants that many doctors are dodging. In Connecticut,
M.D. Health Plan doctors are considering a $101 million offer from Health Systems International, a big California-based H.M.O. That would be a huge windfall for members of the Connecticut state medical society, who started the North Haven group with a $5 million investment in 1987. But the doctors would also be giving up control.
And Bridgeport doctors who have a majority of the shares of Physicians Health Services announced recently that they were seeking to put the company up for sale.
"Physician-owned H.M.O.'s are continually being propositioned" with big-money takeover offers from health care companies, said Dr. Jacque J. Sokolov, a Los Angeles-based consultant who is working with an American Medical Association program that encourages doctors to run their own show.
Many group practices are acquiring the ability to largely duplicate services generally provided by H.M.O.'s. These include eliminating wasteful practices, taking the financial risk of per capita contracts, and rewarding physicians for keeping costs down.
But it can take millions to start an H.M.O., which requires an expensive computer information system to project costs, keep track of performance and handle billing. The American Medical Association said recently that it would provide help in obtaining capital for doctors who want to organize medical groups, joint ventures with hospitals or start a doctor-controlled health maintenance organization.
A growing number of medical groups are making deals with health care management companies to handle business chores that many doctors say are daunting. For a fee and share of profits, companies such as the Caremark Corporation, Phycor Inc., Pacific Physician Services and Coastal Healthcare Group provide financing, legal services and access to information systems. They often negotiate contracts with the health plans and hospitals.
Lawrence Marsh, an analyst with Wheat First Securities in Richmond, said the physician management business had tripled in the last three years. He said publicly held physician companies would report $1.4 billion in 1994 revenues and privately held companies had $1.1 billion to $1.6 billion in revenues.
State medical societies in 21 states are organizing physician networks, H.M.O.'s or other types of managed care groups. The state society in Florida recently sold a 40 percent minority interest in a new physician network to Coastal Healthcare for $7 million in start-up money and working capital.
To be sure, the overwhelming majority of medical groups still work with or for health maintenance organizations and other insurer middlemen. Many big employers prefer to deal with intermediaries that can bargain with individual doctors and hospitals. "We are not interested in being in that business," Helen Darling, a corporate benefits planner for Xerox, said.
The GTE Corporation, for example, set up its own doctor network in San Angelo, Tex., and brought Travelers in to administer the network," George Crowling, a GTE regional benefits manager in Dallas, said.
The insurance companies obviously have a different view of doctor-owned H.M.O.'s. "The system works best when insurance companies and doctors are partners," said Dr. William C. Roper, chief medical officer of the Prudential Health Care System.
"Relationships with doctors are fragile and need to be carefully tended," he added. "The living together in a happy marriage doesn't come by accident."
Existing health maintenance organizations hardly welcome doctor-owned H.M.O.'s as competitors, either. In California, where H.M.O.'s are powerful, two big medical groups backed off their plans to start their own health maintenance organizations after existing H.M.O.'s threatened to stop using affiliated physicians.
"We didn't think it was worth going to war over," said Dr. Albert Barnett, chief executive of the Friendly Hills Healthcare Network.
Seeking to avert just this type of problem, Long Island Physician Holdings asked for a preliminary opinion from the State Attorney General's office, said Jay Kossman, senior vice president of Nextstage Healthcare Management, a Roslyn, L.I., company that is helping the doctors organize an H.M.O. "We were told that if physicians were dropped from a network because they are in another network, it would violate the Federal antitrust laws," he said.
But it works both ways. A group that has exclusive deals with too many doctors in a region may also be taken to court. In a closely watched case, United Wisconsin Services, a for-profit Blue Cross plan based in Milwaukee, brought charges of civil antitrust violations against the Marshfield Clinic, a physician-owned group in central Wisconsin. United Wisconsin said Marshfield had effectively barred it from doing business in the region by signing up most of the doctors there.
A jury in Federal District Court in Madison recently awarded $48 million in treble damages to United Wisconsin. A spokesman for Marshfield said it would appeal.
The Mayo Clinic, which has acquired clinics in nearby western Wisconsin, is taking no chances. "The network is being developed so there will be ample competition," Dr. Michael O'Sullivan, chairman of Mayo's regional practice board, said. "We don't look to dominating the entire region and acquiring all the practices."

HEADLINE: THEATER REVIEW: DEATH DEFYING ACTS;
Really a Jungle Out There, a Jungle of Urban Neuroses

BYLINE: By VINCENT CANBY 

 BODY:
A lawyer with a fully developed talent for obfuscation is suddenly put into the position of defending his most important client (himself). The charge: burying a hypothetical lawn mower. An angry hooker, who describes herself as a "para-professional," pours out her heart to the suicide counselor, a man new on the job, answering the telephone at a Manhattan hot-line center. Meanwhile, over on Central Park West, two civilized, upwardly mobile couples straighten out their Byzantine extramarital relationships, not through cool analysis but with a snub-nosed gun.
Deliciously overwrought basket cases all. 
 They're also the principal characters in "Death Defying Acts," the program of three effervescent one-act comedies by David Mamet, Elaine May and Woody Allen, which opened last night at the Variety Arts Theater. Who needs Broadway when Off Broadway can be as much easy and mischievous fun as this?
To be accurate about it, "Death Defying Acts" is really two extended sketches: Mr. Mamet's "Interview" and Ms. May's "Hotline," which are the program's first half, and Mr. Allen's fully developed, farcical one-act comedy, "Central Park West," which concludes the program after intermission. Though each playwright has a distinctive voice, a unifying theme is provided by the kind of late-20th-century urban desperation that prompts everything from benign smiles to belly laughs.
Also holding things together is the expert staging by Michael Blakemore, the Australian director responsible for such Broadway hits as "City of Angels," "Lettice and Lovage" and "Noises Off." The cast is a dream ensemble of comic talents headed by Linda Lavin, Paul Guilfoyle and Gerry Becker, each of whom play two or three roles, and Debra Monk, who, as a psychiatrist, barges triumphantly through "Central Park West" with the authority of an Upper West Side Queen Boadicea.
Programs of one-act plays are usually a risky business in the commercial theater. With the end of each segment and the start of the next, the program starts and stops throughout the evening. Momentum can slow; attention may wander. "Death Defying Acts" is so cannily constructed that it successfully builds from its comparatively quiet, spookily funny beginning, "An Interview," through the alternately desperate and hilarious "Hotline," to the riotous revelations of marital betrayals in "Central Park West."
It's especially good to have Ms. May back in the theater. After apparently contributing to, and sometimes salvaging, more screenplays than she ever takes credit for, she is again writing under her own name in "Hotline," which is about the common-sensical, terminally depressed hooker named Dorothy (Ms. Lavin).
"Hotline" recalls one of those classic (Mike) Nichols and May telephone sketches of the 1960's updated with the jargon of the 1990's. The stage is divided between Dorothy's sloppily barren apartment and the office at the suicide hot-line center, run by the eager but inexperienced Ken (Mr. Becker). Though Dorothy's preparing to end it all, she has ordered in one last hamburger and wants to chat with whomever she can reach on the hot line.
It's not easy. For one thing, the information operator can't find the right number, giving her instead the number of a coffee shop called the Suicide Center. Then when Dorothy does reach Ken, he's such a nitwit that she's ahead of him all the way. "Hotline" is the comic flip side of "The Human Voice," Jean Cocteau's celebrated (and possibly overrated) melodramatic monologue about a suicidal woman who won't put down the phone.
As played with furious and sarcastic spirit by Ms. Lavin, Dorothy is not easily salvageable, but she has a tenacity that magically transforms the feckless Ken into a man of action. They're both like characters seen in line drawings. The economy of detail with which they are realized provokes a kind of delight particular to theater. This is a marvelously actable stage piece.
Mr. Mamet's program opener, "An Interview," starts in Kafka territory and winds up as a blackout sketch: the Attorney (Mr. Guilfoyle), a professional hair-splitter, sits across a table from his examiner, who's identified only as the Attendant (Mr. Becker). The Attendant is a bland, utterly unflappable fellow with the self-assurance of the Stalinist interrogator in "Darkness at Noon."
In fact, he asks very few questions, allowing the increasingly panicky Attorney to talk himself not into a corner but over an abyss. "AnInterview," which is wittier than it is funny, is a shaggy dog story about the practice of law and, as such, might be taken as a kind of commentary on what's going on at the O. J. Simpson trial. The piece is acted to dry, caustic perfection by Mr. Guilfoyle and Mr. Becker.
As much as it's about anything else, including the hypothetical lawn mower, "An Interview" is about the debasement of thought through tricky language. It's a fitting introduction to a program that celebrates the art of the writer.
"Central Park West" is set in more familiar terrain. That is, the Upper West Side Mr. Allen has explored in so many film comedies, a land of big, old-fashioned apartment buildings with doormen, high ceilings, waste space and psychiatrists on every floor.
When introduced, Phyllis (Ms. Monk), a successful therapist, is steaming mad and a little bit tight. She has just broken an expensive sculpture aimed at her philandering husband, Sam (Mr. Guilfoyle), and strongly suspects her best friend, Carol (Ms. Lavin), to be Sam's latest paramour. Also participating in the evening's revels are Carol's husband, Howard (Mr. Becker), a would-be writer and manic-depressive (currently in an up mood), and the pretty, young Juliet (Tari T. Signor), one of Phyllis's former patients.
Mr. Allen has written several plays ("Don't Drink the Water," "Play It Again, Sam" and "The Floating Light Bulb"). Yet he has never written anything for the stage with quite the manic efficiency of this chef-d'oeuvre about the sexual bungles of the overarticulate. Ms. Monk and Ms. Lavin are priceless as they go to war over a man who would like to be rid of them both. Mr. Guilfoyle and Mr. Becker are splendid as the would-be guilty parties in liaisons that inevitably fail. Ms. Signor, a tall waif, is lovely in the sort of role that Juliette Lewis played in "Husbands and Wives."
The terrain may be familiar, but not the theatrical skill with which Mr. Allen sends his characters into riotous, near-lethal combat. "Central Park West" is a joy.
Though the space at the Variety Arts Theater is limited, the physical production matches the classiness of the performance, particularly the contributions of Robin Wagner, who is responsible for the sets, Jane Greenwood (costumes) and Peter Kaczorowski (lighting).
"Death Defying Acts" (a fine title, by the way) is lighter than air, an elegant diversion. I trust it will be around for a while.
 
DEATH DEFYING ACTS
Three one-act comedies directed by Michael Blakemore. Sets by Robin Wagner; costumes by Jane Greenwood; lighting by Peter Kaczorowski; sound by Jan Nebozenko; production supervisor, Steven Zweigbaum; general management, Richard Frankel and Marc Routh; associate producers, Letty Aronson and Meyer Ackerman. Presented by Julian Schlossberg and Jean Doumanian. At the Variety Arts Theater, 110 Third Avenue, at 13th Street, East Village.
 
AN INTERVIEW By David Mamet.

HOTLINE By Elaine May.

CENTRAL PARK WEST By Woody Allen.

HEADLINE: Babbitt Seeks to Ease Rules in Bid To Rescue Imperiled Species Law

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 6

 BODY:
With the Republican-controlled Congress preparing to rewrite the Endangered Species Act, the Clinton Administration today proposed changes intended to increase the law's flexibility and decrease its economic costs without putting rare plants and animals in greater danger of extinction.
Among other things, the Administration said it wanted to exempt from regulation activities on most small plots, like house lots, allowing owners to disturb the habitats of endangered and threatened species as long as the overall effect on the species was negligible. 
 Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt also called for giving more power to state governments in carrying out the law's protections, and said future decisions to list species for protection would have to be supported by independent scientific peer reviews.
His proposal boils down to this: if better science is used to understand the condition and needs of a species, more flexible ways can be found for protecting it while minimizing the disruption of human activities.
Described as a set of "guideposts" for Congress, it was the most detailed presentation yet of Mr. Babbitt's proposals for defending a law that in the current political climate sometimes seems as vulnerable as the rarest butterfly.
In the last two weeks, the House of Representatives has voted overwhelmingly to suspend all new listings of endangered species temporarily and to require that landowners be paid for any decline in property values that results from restrictions under the Endangered Species Act. The law is overdue for its periodic revision, and there are separate legislative moves afoot to cut the spending of the agencies that enforce it.
To stave off the assault, Mr. Babbitt has been changing many of the regulations that enforce the law, trying to shore up political support by protecting private property owners from the law's more onerous restrictions. The proposals he described today would expand ideas he has been testing for a year or more.
"I've never taken the position that the terms of this act are graven in bronze, never to be changed," he said. "But this act, in its basic premises, in its basic framework, is a good law."
Mr. Babbitt said that the provision adopted by the House to compensate private landowners "would simply gut the Endangered Species Act."
His proposal calls for the law to be "carried out in a manner that avoids unnecessary social and economic impacts upon private property and the regulated public, and minimizes those impacts that cannot be avoided."
Some of the ideas Mr. Babbitt proposed can only be carried out by changing the law, while others can be put into effect administratively under the existing law.
As an example of administrative changes, he said, the National Marine Fisheries Service and the Fish and Wildlife Service, the two agencies charged with species protection, have directed that an independent scientific peer review be done for any proposal to list a species for protection and any plan to assure that a species will recover.
New guidelines are being drafted for petitions requesting protection for individual species, toughening the standard of scientific evidence in support of these proposals.
Mr. Babbitt has emphasized that the Government would make it easier for private landowners to comply with the law. For example, he wants landowners who come up with an approved plan for conserving habitats for imperiled species to be protected against later demands that they do more.
The exemptions for small landowners would exclude from regulation activities on land occupied by a single household and used solely for residential purposes; one-time activities that affect five acres of land or less, as long as the land was acquired before the species it contains was listed for protection, and other activities deemed to be negligible.
Conservationists responded cautiously to Mr. Babbitt's proposals. James Waltman, director of refuges and wildlife at the Wilderness Society, said that he was uncomfortable with the idea of giving blanket exemptions to small landowners, and that it would be better to grant such exemptions on a case-by-case basis. "Five acres can be the world to a small invertebrate," he said.

HEADLINE: A Hard Look at Corporate Welfare

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 6

 BODY:
On the same day last week that the Senate dramatically rejected a measure to force the Government to balance the budget, an obscure Federal agency was accepting last-minute requests for annual handouts from some of America's largest businesses.
As a result, the Campbell Soup Company, which receives $500,000 a year from the Government, will most likely be using taxpayer money once again to help advertise V-8 Juice and soup in Argentina. 
 Although complaints of dubious drains on the Treasury are a staple of political life, the Republican takeover of Congress and the prospect of deficits running $200 billion or more for at least the rest of the decade have raised the level of urgency about continued subsidies to business through direct Government payments and indirect tax breaks.
Concern over the issue has brought together such rare allies as the Labor Secretary, Robert B. Reich, one of the most liberal members of the Clinton Administration, and the Cato Institute, a conservative group with a strongly libertarian cast.
"At the same time that we are trying to cut welfare and make sure we get people into work, we ought to take a look at aid for dependent corporations -- and there's a lot of it in this country," Mr. Reich said earlier this year.
"Corporate pork is pervasive," the Cato Institute said in a report issued today. Every major department, it added, "has become a repository for Government funding of private industry."
The obscure agricultural subsidy is a prime example. Not only is Campbell Soup a major beneficiary, but the Pet Food Institute also expects to receive about $1 million, some of it to be used to wean Japan's dogs from table scraps to Friskies. And the U.S.A. Rice Federation will use part of its anticipated $3 million to promote Uncle Ben's, a brand belonging to Mars Inc., the confectionery giant, in places like Turkey, Poland and Saudi Arabia.
"All the majors are on the program," said Jim Willis, vice president of the Houston-based rice group, which represents producers and processors.
What Mr. Willis is referring to is the market promotion program operated by the Foreign Agricultural Service. In all, it dispenses about $100 million a year to help American business interests overcome quotas or other trade barriers in selling their agricultural products abroad.
While many companies do not acknowledge participation -- it is not a matter of public record when they operate through trade associations -- the program is fiercely defended by many users as crucial to success and, in some cases, to survival.
"Exports have gone up tremendously," said Larry Graham, president of the Chocolate Manufacturers Association, who noted that foreign sales jumped to $520 million last year from less than $100 million a decade earlier. For rice, which suddenly lost 20 percent of its exports with the embargo against Iraq, Mr. Willis said that without the promotion program his industry would be "in a marginal state of trying to survive."
Yet this effort, passionately defended as it is, pales in comparison with the full panoply of Federal largesse for business. According to the Cato Institute, the Washington-based free-market research organization, the total outlays on such programs will exceed $86.2 billion this year.
Moreover, this does not include tax breaks, which the Progressive Policy Institute, an arm of the centrist Democratic Leadership Council, contends are just as large. The institute today published "Cut and Invest: A Budget Strategy for the New Economy," which lists possible savings over five years totaling $265 billion.
Among the multibillion-dollar items noted by the two groups are grants for energy research and supply and for airports and waste-water treatment plants. From both sides of the political aisle, the two groups also zero in on income tax exemptions worth more than $18 billion over five years for companies, mostly prescription drug manufacturers, earning money in Puerto Rico and other offshore territories.
The Government also builds roads in national forests to make it easier for private industry to bring out timber, gives low-interest loans through the Rural Electrification Administration that hold down the cost of running ski resorts in Aspen, Colo., and casinos in Las Vegas, Nev., and is providing $333 million to help American automobile manufacturers create a new generation of "clean" cars to help keep them competitive.
Still, despite all the complaints from Washington think tanks, little is done to curb the practices. Many of them are popular with politically influential businesses and other groups that are heavy contributors to both Republicans and Democrats. And nearly all of them are defended as necessary to help support the economy. Indeed, Mr. Reich has so far found little support from others in the Clinton Administration for his repeated calls to end the corporate welfare practices he decries.
For instance, there has been only a modest paring back in some energy research programs. The White House, worried about a political backlash in states critical to Mr. Clinton's re-election, rejected a recommendation by Hazel R. O'Leary, the Energy Secretary, that the Government sell the Tennessee Valley Authority and other Federal agencies that market low-cost power in several regions of the country, including the Northwest.
The Clinton budget "does not substantially cut spending for any significant constituency," said Robert J. Shapiro, a founder of the Progressive Policy Institute and a principal economic adviser to the President's 1992 campaign.
In fact, the Administration has requested an extra $500 million to expand the Technology Reinvestment Project, a military conversion program using subsidies to help develop civilian technologies. Among the 1994 recipients were Texas Instruments Inc., which got $13 million, and the Chrysler Corporation, which got $6 million.
On the other hand, Secretary Reich's specific challenge in November to the capital's research organizations to produce their own lists of corporate targets has been eagerly accepted.
Stephen Moore and Dean Stansel of the Cato Institute said they found 127 Government programs that provided subsidies to particular companies or industries.
Cato does not include tax expenditures in its calculations because it wants them to be abolished by fundamental tax reform rather than considered in conjunction with spending cuts.
But these groups and others generally agree that subsidies are poor policy on various grounds, among them that governments around the world have repeatedly failed in attempts to "pick winners" and that subsidies divert resources from more productive uses, corrupt the political process and often raise costs to consumers.
While not expecting immediate success in breaking the political stalemate over subsidies, Mr. Shapiro said he was encouraged over what he called the convergence of thinking at the policy level. Indeed, the failure of the balanced budget amendment, he said, could force its supporters into trying to do something promptly to preserve credibility.
In any case, corporate largesse at its current scale is inevitably doomed, Mr. Shapiro contended, since it represents the last sizable source of money "before you get to entitlements" like Social Security.

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

STATE SENATE PASSES DEATH PENALTY
The State Senate voted overwhelmingly to return the death penalty to New York State 18 years after the state's last capital punishment law was declared unconstitutional. At 1 this morning, the Assembly was still locked in a sometimes fiery debate that had begun late Monday afternoon. A1.
 
IN CITY HOSPITALS, CHAOTIC BUREAUCRACY
When New York City's public hospitals underwent their last major reorganization more than 25 years ago, civic leaders renewed a longstanding promise to bring medical care for the poor up to the standards of the best private hospitals. The system that emerged is now under attack for both its ideology and its cost. But long before the change in political sentiment, New York's public hospitals were moving toward a crisis of their own making, with problems that had a familiar ring. A1.
 
ALLEGATIONS OF CO-OP FRAUD
Year after year, the retirees and working-class families who live in the Big Six Towers cooperative in Queens dutifully paid their monthly maintenance fees. And with the promise of great earnings, many even invested their life savings in a plan to expand Big Six's shopping center. But the stunned residents of the Big Six have now learned that they may never recover their investments. A1.
 
NEW YORK CITY
 
COUNCIL ASSAILS MAYOR ON HOSPITALS
Several City Council leaders assailed Mayor Giuliani's philosophy on hospital privatization, attacking the Mayor's contention that a high death rate among newborn babies in New York City public hospitals demonstrated the need for the city to sell some hospitals. B3.
A woman whose bound and gagged body was found in the basement of a burning house in Queens was identified as a 20-year-old college student from Canarsie, Brooklyn. B3.
 
REGION
 
PATAKI GETS A GRADE
At a time in his term when many politicians are still enjoying a honeymoon with voters, Governor Pataki's favorable ratings are barely higher than those of Governor Cuomo at the lowest point of his administration. B5.
 
D'AMATO TO SUPPORT DOLE IN '96
Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato plans to announce his support for Senator Bob Dole's 1996 Presidential campaign, a move that is expected to trigger a chain reaction of endorsements for Mr. Dole by New York Republicans. B5.
 
ECONOMIC PLAN FOR NEW JERSEY CITIES
On a hill where rioters tore the heart out of New Jersey's capital city in 1968, Governor Whitman announced a new urban agenda that offers the cities of New Jersey help in planning for economic recovery, but not much help in paying for it. B6.
 
NICOTINE REPORT WINS JOURNALISM AWARD
Reports on subjects ranging from the nicotine content of cigarettes to fraud at the Immigration and Naturalization Service have won the George Polk Awards for 1994. B6.
 
VANDALS PAINT SWASTIKAS IN L.I. OFFICE
Vandals broke into the office of a Long Island dentist, drew swastikas on the walls and poured black paint on his records and files, the Suffolk County police said. B6.
