HEADLINE: Mexico Says Ex-Aide Impeded Inquiry on Brother's Killing

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, March 6

 BODY:
The Government announced today that it had charged a former Deputy Attorney General, Mario Ruiz Massieu, with impeding the investigation he conducted into the assassination last fall of his own brother, a leader of Mexico's governing party.
The action represented a potentially explosive turn in the inquiry. The prosecutors asserted that while Mr. Ruiz Massieu was serving as a close aide to Carlos Salinas de Gortari, the former President, he intimidated witnesses and falsified evidence to keep Mr. Salinas's elder brother from appearing as a crucial suspect in the case. 
 Responding to a preliminary extradition request from the Mexican Government, a Federal magistrate in Newark ordered today that Mr. Ruiz Massieu be held without bail pending hearings on his possible return to Mexico. He was arrested on a customs charge Friday night as he prepared to board a plane from Newark to Madrid with more than $ 40,000 in cash.
A lawyer for Mr. Ruiz Massieu said he would seek political asylum in the United States.
In an important finding in Mexico today, officials said a judge ruled that the Government had enough evidence to prosecute former President Salinas's brother, Raul Salinas de Gortari, for ordering the slaying on Sept. 28 of Mr. Ruiz Massieu's brother, Jose Francisco Ruiz Massieu.
According to senior officials, some of the Government's strongest evidence against Raul Salinas comes from witnesses and documents that have been available to the Attorney General's office for months.
"Mario knew about all of it right away," one official said. Why Mr. Ruiz Massieu might have hidden the information, he added, "is something that we are going to find out."
The Government of President Ernesto Zedillo did not comment publicly today on whether it believed Carlos Salinas might be implicated in the case. But two officials, speaking on the condition that they not be identified, said there were indications that Mario Ruiz Massieu had briefed the former President extensively about his investigation.
The Goverment's move to prosecute Mr. Ruiz Massieu appeared to have begun just as Carlos Salinas ended a brief, bizarre hunger strike that he said was meant to defend his honor.
In making the protest, Mr. Salinas said he wanted the Zedillo administration to stop blaming him for the country's three-month-old economic crisis and admit the importance of its own mistakes. He also demanded that the Government clear him of any responsibility for what it described as efforts to cover up another political slaying last year, that of the governing party's presidential candidate, Luis Donaldo Colosio.
Throughout, Mr. Salinas insisted that the hunger strike had nothing to do with the arrest of his brother Raul, which brought an end to decades in which former Mexican leaders and their families enjoyed virtual immunity from prosecution for corruption and other crimes. But some officials speculated that Mr. Salinas may have meant the hunger strike as a signal of the lengths to which he would go to try to save his tattered reputation.
In a complaint filed on Mexico's behalf, the United States Attorney's office in Newark said the Mexican Government had evidence that Mario Ruiz Massieu had pressed two major suspects in the investigation to change their testimony to protect Raul Salinas. Mexican officials also said they had documentary evidence and accounts from prosecutors and others that corroborated the suspects' assertions.
While Government officials have said there is some evidence of a connection between the two assassination cases, the possible ties remain unclear.
The conspiracy theories swirling around both of them have included governing-party politicians and powerful drug traffickers as possible suspects. Increasingly, however, the Government has described the slaying of Jose Ruiz Massieu as a result of a personal feud between Raul Salinas and the victim.
The elder Mr. Ruiz Massieu was a close friend and political ally of Carlos Salinas from the time the two finished their studies at the national university. He was also married for a time to Adriana Salinas de Gortari, the younger sister of Carlos and Raul.
Yet while Carlos Salinas said in an interview last week that Raul Salinas and Jose Ruiz Massieu had a "respectful" relationship, friends of Mr. Ruiz Massieu said the two men had disliked each other for years and had sometimes fought bitterly.
According to documents from Jose Ruiz Massieu's personal files that officials said were taken into evidence shortly after his death, the two men began to clash as early as 1987 over what Mr. Ruiz Massieu, then beginning a six-year term as Governor of the western state of Guerrero, took to be corrupt dealings by Raul Salinas.
Among the documents are a hand-written letter from the Governor to Carlos Salinas after he became President in December 1988 voicing outrage at a legal suit filed against the state government by a subordinate of Raul Salinas.
By then, Raul Salinas had been installed as a senior official of a powerful food-distribution agency called Conasupo. But in an annex to the letter, Jose Ruiz Massieu appears to suggest that the legal suit was an attempt at revenge by Raul Salinas for the Governor's having previously denied him and a man described as his business associate, Roberto Gonzalez Barrera, a lucrative contract to build a corn-flour production plant in the state.
A spokesman for Mr. Gonzalez Barrera, the billionaire owner of a huge corn-processing company called Maseca, said he had no immediate comment on the matter.
A Government official who was a friend of Jose Ruiz Massieu said he also clashed with Raul Salinas over the construction of a $ 2 billion toll road through Guerrero and a huge real-estate development in the Guerrero resort city of Acapulco, called Punta Diamante.
Both Maseca and the big construction company that won a one-third share of the highway construction project, Grupo Tribasa, have also been tied in the past to the family of one of the governing party's richest old-guard politicians, Carlos Hank Gonzalez, who served as Agriculture Minister under Mr. Salinas. Mr. Hank's eldest son, Carlos Hank Rohn, serves on the boards of both companies.
Late on Sunday night, the Mexican Government sent a diplomatic note to the United States State Department saying that it would seek the extradition of Mario Ruiz Massieu, who was arrested on Friday night at Newark International Airport for filing a false customs declaration.
American officials had been alerted to Mr. Ruiz Massieu's movements by Mexican officials who say he intended to flee to Monaco, which has no extradition treaty with Mexico. A Justice Department official said American agents lost his trail after he flew to Houston on Thursday night, but he was apprehended as he prepared to board a plane bound for Madrid with his wife, their 6-year-old daughter and $ 46,000 in cash. That was more than double the amount of American and Mexican currency he had claimed to be carrying.
At Mexico's request, the Justice Department filed a provisional warrant today seeking Mario Ruiz Massieu's extradition. At a hearing in United States District Court in Newark this afternoon, a Federal magistrate, Ronald J. Hedges, ordered that he be held without bail at the Metropolitan Corrections Center in Manhattan pending another hearing on March 14.
The Mexican authorities have 60 days to present a formal extradition request. Mr. Ruiz Massieu also faces a single charge of filing a false customs declaration, which carries a maximum penalty of five years' imprisonment and a fine of $ 250,000.
Mario Ruiz Massieu left Mexico on Thursday night shortly after completing six hours of testimony to the police about how Raul Salinas had managed never to appear in any of the witness statements or other evidence gathered in his investigation.
Adding to the Government's suspicions about his conduct, one official said that before leaving Mario Ruiz Massieu had large amounts of money deposited for himself in several banks. Mario Ruiz Massieu's personal secretary, Maria Dolores Mota, said she knew nothing of any such deposits.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
MCDONNELL DOUGLAS TO CLOSE A FLORIDA PLANT

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
The McDonnell Douglas Corporation will close its plant in Titusville, Fla., putting 1,000 people out of work, because of the loss of a $1 billion missile contract, company officials said yesterday. The plant will be shut down later this year as production of the Navy's Tomahawk cruise missiles winds down. Military cutbacks are also causing the company to close a plant in St. Charles, Mo., where 800 workers make electrical and ground support equipment for aircraft and missile systems. About 300 employees will be laid off and 500 will be reassigned, the company said.

HEADLINE: THE DOCTOR'S WORLD;
Secretary of State's Bleeding Ulcer Illustrates Arthritis Drug Problem

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE K. ALTMAN, M.D. 

 BODY:
THE bleeding stomach ulcer that Secretary of State Warren Christopher suffered as a complication of a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug he took for arthritis vividly illustrates the dangers of such drugs.
Complications of these drugs, referred to by doctors as Nsaid's (pronounced EN-seds), are a significant public health problem. The complications have been described in a medical journal as the most prevalent serious drug toxicity in the United States. Each year such complications lead to about 41,000 hospitalizations and 3,300 deaths, studies show. They are a principal reason for the procedure known as gastroscopy, which Mr. Christopher underwent, in which doctors pass a tube through the mouth into the stomach to diagnose stomach disorders. 
 Mr. Christopher's ulcer sent him to the intensive care unit of Ottawa Civic Hospital during President Clinton's visit to Canada last month. Doctors there said the ulcer had been caused by complications of Ansaid, a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug made by the Upjohn Company of Kalamazoo, Mich. It is one of 25 Nsaid's approved for marketing by the Food and Drug Administration.
On his return to Washington, Mr. Christopher, 69, checked into Georgetown University Hospital for overnight observation. Now back at work, Mr. Christopher is to leave today on a trip to the Middle East. It will be another month before the ulcer is completely healed.
Mr. Christopher was luckier than many who develop a bleeding ulcer due to an Nsaid. The death rate from such complications is about 8 to 10 percent, said Dr. Marie R. Griffin, an expert on the epidemiology of drugs at Vanderbilt University in Nashville who has carried out studies on Nsaid usage.
About 3.4 percent of the 2.2 billion prescriptions written each year are for Nsaid's. Millions more nonprescription Nsaid's are bought as over-the-counter drugs like aspirin, ibuprofen and naproxen, which are often used for short-term use to relieve inflammation and pain from osteoarthritis and rheumatoid arthritis. Nsaid's are among the oldest commercial drugs still on the market; aspirin and another Nsaid, sodium salicylic acid, were developed in the 19th century. In the 1950's, drug companies began marketing the first newer ones and the numbers have been increasing ever since. The latest Nsaid approved was in 1993.
Among people aged 65 and over, half have pain or swelling in at least one joint. Rheumatologists say it would be harder to give patients relief if Nsaid's were not available. Their use is expected to increase as more people live longer.
But some experts say that aggressive marketing practices of drug companies have made Nsaid's too popular and that many people could get as much relief with fewer adverse effects and at less cost if they took milder drugs like acetaminophen (Tylenol), which is not an Nsaid. Some prescription Nsaid's cost 12 times more than over-the-counter ibuprofen.
On any day, 10 to 15 percent of Americans aged 65 and older have a filled prescription for an Nsaid.
Although Nsaid's have merit, they should be prescribed and used cautiously with the risks explained to each patient, said Dr. Janet Woodcock, a rheumatologist and official of the Food and Drug Administration.
Dr. Stuart Nightingale, an associate commissioner of the F.D.A., has cited studies showing that bleeding ulcers develop in about 1 percent of those who use the drugs for three to six months, and from 2 to 4 percent of those who use them for a year.
Studies also have shown that those who use the drugs have a four times greater risk of developing an ulcer than nonusers in all age groups. Complications of the drugs lead to 30 percent of the hospitalizations and deaths from ulcers in people aged 65 and older in this country, Dr. Griffin said. The remaining 70 percent are caused by a bacterium, Helicobacter pylori.
"It appears that you are at about the same risk in the first month of taking an Nsaid as in the 12th or 24th, not getting any worse or better," Dr. Woodcock said. With some drugs, like sulfa or penicillin, the risk of a catastrophic event is highest when it is first taken.
The Arthritis Foundation in Atlanta says, "No single Nsaid is guaranteed to work; you may have to try several types before you find one that works for you."
The foundation advises users of the drugs who are bothered by repeated nausea, vomiting, stomach pain, heartburn, gas, bloating, constipation and diarrhea to check with their doctors.
The Medical Letter, a respected review of drugs and therapeutics published in New Rochelle, N.Y., warns that these drugs may interact to decrease the effectiveness of many other drugs that are used to lower high blood pressure. Doctors also warn that the interaction of Nsaid drugs with alcohol or aspirin can be harmful.
It is not clear whether some drugs in the group are more likely than others to cause complications. Dr. Woodcock said the F.D.A. is studying reports that piroxicam (Feldene) may cause a higher rate of intestinal bleeding than others.
The National Kidney Foundation in New York City has expressed concern about the increased risk of kidney failure from chronic use of the drugs.
Over all, Dr. Griffin said, "the adverse effect rate is pretty high for a drug that is not curative and used mainly to relieve symptoms." She said the complication rate of the drugs was about that of anti-coagulant drugs that are used to prevent blood clots and for which doctors generally exercise greater precaution.
Dr. Gerald Weissmann, a rheumatologist at New York University, said: "All the newer Nsaid's are safer than aspirin and are valuable when used under a doctor's observation for defined inflammatory arthritis," but that they are overused by people who take them for more non-specific reasons.
Most doctors believe that the benefits of daily use outweigh the risks for those who get substantial relief. But studies indicate that many people take more than they need to get relief.
Concern also exists for those who seem to get only a modest or marginal benefit from the drugs and for the many patients who are unclear why they are taking them.
"Many people have a misconception about how good these drugs are," Dr. Griffin said. "For some people they work great, for other people they don't work that well. We and many others who treat elderly people believe that the complication rate is high and that they should probably try acetaminophen first" because it affords about the same relief for osteoarthritis as the prescription and nonprescription medications.
Chronic use of acetaminophen, or Tylenol, however, has its own set of problems.
In criticizing studies of Nsaid's, Dr. P. A. Dieppe and his colleagues from the University of Bristol in England have written in The Lancet, "We still know very little about the causes, diagnosis, natural history, and appropriate management of osteoarthritis."
Most studies of the drugs last only a few weeks, while the pain of the condition is present for months or years in most cases. Few studies have compared the effectiveness of an Nsaid with that of a pure analgesic like Tylenol, and "one of the main reasons for this paucity of comparative studies of simple analgesics and Nsaid's must be the vested interests of the pharmaceutical industry," Dr. Dieppe's team wrote.
Large trials are needed, but the money for them is unlikely to come from drug companies, they said.
A major reason for the widespread use of the drugs is that dealing with arthritis is frustrating for patients and doctors. Many arthritics get incomplete relief of pain, and doctors and patients want to do something to improve their quality of life. So doctors are continually tempted to try new drugs, even when their effect is symptomatic and does not address the root cause of the disease.
Each new drug that comes on the market is advertised as easier on the stomach than its predecessors, leading doctors and patients to try it in the hope that this will be the drug that really helps.
But head-to-head studies have shown little difference in effectiveness between the many available, Dr. Griffin said, and only ibuprofen has been found consistently safer than the other drugs, presumably because individuals take it in smaller amounts than they do the others.
Doctors and patients often overlook many alternatives like exercise, weight loss and measures to relieve the load on affected joints, Dr. Griffin said, adding, "They take much time and are harder to comply with than taking a pill."
Doctors also tend to underestimate the dangers of these drugs, largely because the overwhelming majority of their patients do not have trouble and when they do develop ulcers and other complications they do not always link them to the drugs, Dr. Griffin said.
Dr. Woodcock said that her drug agency was trying to find new ways to provide information about the drugs people use. For many years, she said, "there was a complacency where many people seemed to take all kinds of drugs and consumers did not recognize that they could result in bad adverse reactions."

HEADLINE: In Chaotic City Hospitals, A Bureaucracy to Match

SERIES: Mismanaged Care: A Health System in Peril -- Last of three articles.

BYLINE: By DEAN BAQUET and JANE FRITSCH 

 BODY:
When New York City's public hospitals underwent their last major reorganization more than 25 years ago, civic leaders renewed a longstanding promise to bring medical care for the poor up to the standards of the best private hospitals.
Faced with financial mismanagement, squalid conditions and a bureaucracy out of control, they drew up plans for a sleek, modern business unfettered by politics: the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation. Forged in the more magnanimous era of the Great Society, the public corporation was to insure the most generous medical services of any American city. 
 "We all know that New York's problems are the toughest in the world," Joseph T. English, the new corporation's first leader, said shortly after his appointment in 1970. "And it has the courage, guts and imagination where no one else is willing to try."
The system that emerged is now under attack for both its ideology and its cost. But long before the change in political sentiment, New York's public hospitals were moving toward a crisis of their own making, with problems that had a familiar ring.
The plans of nearly 30 years ago fell apart almost from the beginning. The corporation was supposed to be a temporary vehicle to improve the troubled public hospitals before placing them under private management. Instead, it became a permanent bureaucracy hampered by political meddling, as troubled as the one it was supposed to replace.
And rather than addressing serious problems that have arisen over the decades, its administrators have allowed them to linger. As a result, the system is vulnerable, both to economic forces and a more conservative era in New York politics.
Delivery room disasters reported by The New York Times over the last two days are only the most dramatic examples of chronic trouble. Many of the system's 11 hospitals operate on the edge, barely meeting the minimum standards of the national agency that evaluates them.
In the last three years, two of the hospitals -- Lincoln Medical and Mental Health Center in the Bronx and Woodhull Medical and Mental Health Center in Brooklyn -- have lost their accreditations because of poor care and unsafe conditions, then regained them. Three others received only conditional approval.
Doctors seethe with frustration over their daily struggle against a bureaucracy that seems bent on defeating them. Dr. Janet Mitchell, who treats high-risk pregnant women at Harlem Hospital Center, routinely orders two, and sometimes three, copies of the same test to increase the odds that she will actually get the results.
The health care agency is one of the city's most enduring and unwieldy bureaucracies, with a $3.8 billion budget and layers of central office staff and consultants. It employs nearly 50,000 people in a far-flung network of 11 hospitals, 76 clinics and 5 chronic care centers.
As this vast system struggles with problems large and small, the health care marketplace is changing all around it.
Nationally, health care is moving away from the kind of expensive and comprehensive services offered by big hospitals like those in the Health and Hospitals Corporation. In Albany, Gov. George E. Pataki has pledged deep cuts in Medicaid, the major source of revenue for the public hospitals.
In the city, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani wants even deeper Medicaid cuts and has announced plans to sell 3 of the 11 hospitals. He is considering closing others. And he has said that the city should consider getting out of the hospital business altogether, a suggestion that would have been unimaginable a decade ago.
"By and large, the city should be in the role of provider of last resort," Mr. Giuliani said last week, "meaning, to cover the populations that aren't being covered; and, secondly, as a regulator of standards."
Supporters of the system say such a realignment would represent a retreat from New York's longstanding promise of equal medical care for rich and poor. They say the public hospitals would face the fate that generations of officials have tried to prevent: becoming dumping grounds nobody wants, struggling with the complex problems of the least desirable patients -- drug addicts, prisoners, the homeless and the mentally ill.
"You're going to end up with hospitals that are lousy, in the worst sections of the city," said Dr. Billy E. Jones, who headed the hospital corporation for 18 months at the end of the Dinkins administration. "And nobody's going to want to work in them."
Under Mr. Giuliani's plan, private institutions would have to take on a greater load of the city's poor and working-class patients, a burden that some critics say the private hospitals are unlikely to accept without pressure.
Even the Mayor's choice to head the hospitals corporation, Dr. Bruce Siegel, who took over a year ago, questioned whether New York's private hospitals would be willing to treat the toughest cases.
"Would they take care of every undocumented immigrant we now take care of?" he said during a series of interviews. "Would they take care of the city's AIDS patients? Could they do it? Theoretically.
"Would they do it? I don't know."
 
The Corporation
From the First, Power Struggles
 New York City has run public hospitals for more than 200 years. Its earliest hospitals, like Bellevue, which opened in 1736, were regarded as national models of compassionate care for the poor. But by the early 20th century, the hospitals had weathered waves of scandal and recurring reports of Dickensian conditions.
With each scandal came plans for reform. The most recent was in 1967, when a city commission chaired by Gerard Piel, the publisher of Scientific American magazine, concluded that conditions in the hospitals -- 20 of them at the time -- were "deplorable."
The commission recommended that the city turn over hospital management to some of the city's best private institutions. The Health and Hospitals Corporation was created to unite the hospitals, which were run by several city departments, under one agency that would be independent from City Hall. The agency, in turn, was supposed to affiliate each public hospital with a private partner, and then dissolve. The city would then pay the private hospitals a management fee and monitor their performance.
The commission did not want to sell off the public hospitals because the city would then lose ultimate control of medical care for the poor. Then, as now, the city was skeptical of private business's commitment to quality care for all.
The plan barely got off the ground before labor unions and local politicians began to exert influence. They persuaded City Hall to let the corporation continue as part of a hybrid arrangement, in which administrators hired by the city and doctors from the private institutions co-managed public hospitals. This arrangement left thousands of nonprofessional and union jobs under the city's control.
It also set the stage for management turmoil that continues to this day, and a daily struggle for control of the wards and clinics of the public hospitals.
"You could never tell who was in charge of the hospitals," said Mr. Piel, the system's architect. The divided leadership hampered the hospital system from the start, he said. "I've always denied paternity of that corporation."
Beyond the struggle, questions have been repeatedly raised over the years about whether the private hospitals and medical schools have lived up to their part of the bargain.
"I can't tell you right now with a straight face that we get $475 million worth of service from the affiliates," said Dr. Siegel, the 34-year-old internist who now runs the system.
In a series of interviews, Dr. Siegel, the former New Jersey Commissioner of Health, accused the private institutions of using New York City's money to finance arcane specialties for their residency programs, the teaching regimens for young doctors. These specialty departments -- he described them as a "luxurious maze of clinics with very few patients in them" -- have little to do with the needs of the communities they serve, he said.
As a result, he said, the system actually has too many doctors over all but not enough in more mundane, yet crucial, sections of the hospitals.
In particular, he expressed dismay that the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons, a highly regarded medical school, has escaped public criticism for the role it played in the disintegration of Harlem Hospital Center, its public partner.
"We have a hospital that basically didn't develop what it needed, and paid the price, because people stopped going there," Dr. Siegel said. "Nobody wants to take responsibility for what happened. I'm willing to take some of the burden for H.H.C., but where was the affiliate all these years."
Dr. Edward B. Healton, an associate dean at Columbia and the medical director of Harlem Hospital, said the hospital's decline has been exaggerated by the city. But, he acknowledged: "Columbia is a big institution. Certainly, there are times when we'd have liked the university to pay attention to the Harlem affiliation."
One of the major problems over the years, by Dr. Siegel's account, is that no one leading the public system has had the will to challenge the "barons of American medicine" who run the city's prestigious private hospitals and force them to realign their services.
"I think the fundamental flaw is that you have a low-power, low-prestige organization -- the public hospitals of New York -- paying a large sum for professional services to a series of high-power, very high-prestige organizations in New York," he said. "It's a very unequal relationship." For example, the city is financially liable for the mistakes private doctors make at the public hospitals.
But Dr. Siegel and others inside the system concede that the hospitals corporation has done little to monitor the care being provided in its hospitals, despite repeated warnings from state regulators and others.
For example, one regulatory report after another has criticized the corporation for permitting Kings County Hospital Center, the busiest hospital in the system, to be dominated by inexperienced doctors just out of medical school. Those trainees receive little guidance from more experienced physicians, many of whom are provided by the State University Health Science Center, Brooklyn, the reports say.
"Kings County is terrible," said Dr. Jeremiah A. Barondess, president of the New York Academy of Medicine, who warned of the supervision problems in his sweeping 1992 study of the city hospitals.
In 1993, a resident at Kings County hospital two years out of medical school waited too long to help a patient who was severely short of breath, state reports show. The patient developed seizures and died.
A year earlier, regulators said, a third-year Kings County resident ignored a senior doctor's requests and declined to order a brain scan for a 73-year-old woman who complained of chest pains. The woman also died.
Officials of North Central Bronx Hospital, including Emilio Morante, its executive director, said they repeatedly went to their private affiliate, Montefiore Medical Center, to complain that poorly supervised midwives were handling deliveries far too complicated for their training. But, the North Central Bronx officials said, the complaints were not taken seriously.
"It was so bad that we were afraid we would lose our accreditation," said Mr. Morante, who left the hospital late last year.
Montefiore officials said the midwives provided high-quality care.
 
 
The Leadership
Problems Outlast Faces at the Top
 The main reason the corporation fails to solve its problems, even when they are obvious, is the lack of consistent leadership. There have been 14 presidents in 25 years.
"The turnover is too frequent to call it managed," said Edna Wells Handy, who was the hospital corporation's lawyer until a year ago. "It's too unstable. It's too fractured."
Former presidents say that by the time they came to understand the byzantine system and its myriad problems, political pressures had forced them out of their jobs.
Dr. Jones, the former corporation president, said that few administrators, including himself, were around long enough to gain control of the bureaucracy. "All you have to do is outlast the president, which usually takes no more than two or three years," he said.
Dr. Siegel, too, acknowledged that the agency's churning leadership had trouble getting things done. "Things don't get fixed," he said, because of a "lack of continuity, lack of leadership, changing faces."
The story of Woodhull Medical and Mental Health Center illustrates how a clearly identified problem can outlive generations of corporation leaders. The hospital has been regarded as an embarrassment for 25 years, even before it opened. Twice in the last six years, the Joint Commission on Accreditation of Healthcare Organizations, the industry group that inspects hospitals, has refused to accredit Woodhull, citing poor care and management failures.
Through one crisis after another, Woodhull has been run by a private corporation, Woodhull Medical Associates, which receives $42 million a year from the city.
In the summer of 1993, Dr. Jones and other corporation officials found that Woodhull had committed a grievous offense: Someone had rewritten internal records in a way that seemed to conceal serious lapses in care.
Shortly afterward, the hospital corporation announced that Woodhull Medical Associates was out, and that a task force would find a new management team.
Dr. Siegel said that he made numerous management changes at Woodhull in the last few months, and that the corporation was still trying to find someone willing to replace Woodhull Medical Associates.
"We're getting rid of it slowly," Dr. Siegel said. "We're not doing it overnight. We're actually going through and looking at it department by department, how to get rid of it. We can't do that overnight. But we are doing it. And let that be on the record."
 
 
The Politics
A System Mired In Patronage
 As it has grown, the health care agency that was supposed to be free from politics has come to be dominated by patronage. Norman Steisel, a deputy mayor under David N. Dinkins, called the hospitals corporation "the last great bastion of patronage in the city."
For example, Lincoln Medical and Mental Health Center, perennially portrayed by regulators as one of the worst hospitals in the system, has long been the fief of Ramon S. Velez, a South Bronx power broker. Hospital officials acknowledge that Lincoln is packed with Mr. Velez's allies.
Even the Giuliani administration, while attacking the hospitals corporation as antiquated and wasteful, has not resisted using it to reward political friends.
Last year, Leonard R. Piccoli was named an assistant director of North Central Bronx Hospital, even though hospital officials said they did not need another administrator. Mr. Piccoli is a former hospital manager, as well as a former top aide to State Senator Guy J. Velella, the Bronx County Republican leader, who supported the Mayor in his election effort.
"We created the job for him," said Mr. Morante, formerly executive director of the hospital. "They gave me instructions to create a deputy's slot for him. Siegel called and said he was between a rock and a hard place, and was under pressure from City Hall to take on Piccoli."
Mr. Morante said that Mr. Piccoli, at a salary of $90,000, was forced on North Central Bronx at a time when the hospital needed to cut more than $8 million from its budget.
Dr. Siegel acknowledged that he gave Mr. Piccoli's name to North Central Bronx officials, though he said he did not recall speaking to Mr. Morante. He recalled having received Mr. Piccoli's resume from City Hall, but said he did not pressure the hospital to hire him.
Through a spokeswoman for the health care agency, Mr. Piccoli declined to be interviewed.
While the corporation is dominated by the Mayor, the individual hospitals hew to powerful local interests, from community groups to City Council members and state legislators. Each hospital must navigate through local politics when making most major decisions, from appointing top hospital officials to deciding which departments to shut down.
"The hospitals are not just hospitals in these communities," said Mr. Steisel, the former deputy mayor. "They are police stations; they're welfare offices."
The result is an agency paralyzed by its need to win a consensus on every decision, no matter how mundane. Metropolitan Hospital Center in East Harlem, for instance, could not pick a new director of nursing without a series of meetings with community leaders who were concerned about the ethnic backgrounds of the candidates.
The clearest example is the city's inability to shrink any of its hospitals, even those that are underused. Most experts have long agreed there is no longer a need for 11 hospitals, some just a few miles away from others. During the Dinkins administration, Mr. Steisel said, "There was a general feeling that many of the hospitals were redundant."
But no one was willing to publicly single out a particular hospital for closing, he recalled. "There was a general feeling that politically, you couldn't do it."
 
The Future
Fearing the Worst: Modern Asylums
 It seems certain that there will soon be fewer public hospitals. Mayor Giuliani will have little trouble finding buyers for at least two of the hospitals he has put up for sale -- Elmhurst Hospital Center and Coney Island Hospital.
For many New Yorkers, the disappearance of public hospitals will have little impact. In working- and middle-class neighborhoods, patients who could pay for better care or had insurance abandoned them long ago.
More recently, private hospitals, desperate to fill their own beds, have begun wooing the most lucrative of the hospital corporation's remaining constituents -- Medicaid recipients. At least partly for that reason, 8 of the 11 hospitals in the system have lost patients over the last decade.
But some experts say the private hospitals will not want to treat some patients, like the homeless, drug abusers and the mentally ill, whose presence might scare off other patients.
"Are there people who are undesirable, people who they don't want?" said Robert D. Gumbs, executive director of the state-financed Health Systems Agency, which examines health care trends. "Yes. The corporation could be left with that, the uninsured and the undesirable."
As the Mayor makes over the city's health care system, Mr. Gumbs and other planners say, one of his biggest challenges will be to find a place for these patients. They number in the hundreds of thousands.
By all accounts, Mr. Giuliani will have to come up with a package of financial incentives and new laws to force private hospitals to take on more of the patients they do not want. And, the planners say, the administration may have to fashion a pared-down public system to treat the worst cases.
The most difficult task will be keeping those public hospitals from degenerating into modern-day asylums, the kinds of places the city set out to eliminate decades ago. Some of the Mayor's critics look to the future and warn of squalid hospitals with relentless problems that will repel most doctors and all but the most desperate patients.
Even before confronting this daunting task, the Mayor will have to overcome some more basic obstacles -- the nitty-gritty details of selling huge public institutions, the inevitable outcry from neighborhoods whose economies are driven by public hospitals and the opposition of political opponents.
For one thing, when Mayor Giuliani begins breaking apart the system to sell its pieces, he is likely to find that many hospitals will have no takers.
"Who's going to buy Woodhull?" asked Dr. Jones, the corporation's former president.
Beyond that, some members of the corporation's board, particularly those aligned with former Mayor Dinkins, are angry that Mr. Giuliani announced his plan to sell hospitals without telling them first.
"We read about it in the press," said Dr. James R. Dumpson, a board member and longtime Dinkins ally. Dr. Dumpson said that Mayor Giuliani must get a majority of votes before shaking up the system, though he acknowledged that mayors generally get their way with the board.
Dr. Siegel himself has expressed reservations about the idea of selling or shutting down hospitals.
In interviews before the Mayor's plan was announced, Dr. Siegel said he was not yet willing to give up on the corporation. He outlined proposals for sweeping changes that he hopes will revitalize the system, like shutting down little-used services and getting tougher with the private affiliates.
He also said it was time for the corporation to return to the model first proposed by Mr. Piel's commission -- recasting itself as an independent body free from City Hall's meddling and swings in political philosophy.
"My sense is the city wants to get out of the hospital business," he said. "And that's fine. I want the city out of my business."

"A Parade of Presidents, 1967-1995"
Charts: "The Hospitals Corporation: By the Numbers"
 The agency that runs New York City's public hospitals, the Health and Hospitals Corporation, has had 14 presidents in nearly 30 years. Dr. Bruce Siegel, who was appointed president in 1994, has said, "Somebody asked me why we don't have pictures of the presidents on the wall here. Well, there's not a wall big enough."
 
1967: One of five investigations into city health services finds that the public hospitals "fail to meet urgent needs" of ppoor patients and recommends the formation of what will become the Health and Hospitals Corporation.
 
1970: Dr. Joseph T. English, a psychiatrist, is appointed the agency's first president.
 
1973: Dr. English resigns because of disputes between the corporation and the Mayor.
 
1973-1974: Donald H. Eisenberg serves as acting president.
 
1974: Dr. John L.S. Holloman Jr., an internist, is appointed president.
 
1976: A task force appointed by Mayor Abraham D. Beame finds the corporation is an "unmitigated disaster." One hospital official says, "The municipal hospitals are a bad enterprise made worse by the Hospitals Corporation, if that's possible."
 
1977: Dr. Holloman resigns at the insistence of Mayor Beame because of financial crisis at H.H.C.
 
1977: Joseph T. Lynaugh, an administrator of a state health agency, serves as president.
 
1978: Doctors blame the death of a woman, who was transferred out of the the intensive car unit, on severe shortages of nurses and intensive-care beds.
 
1978: Mr. Lynaugh resigns at the request of Mayor Edward I. Koch as a new administration takes over at City Hall.
 
1979: Joseph C. Hoffman, a former New York police official, is appointed president.
 
1979: Mr. Hoffman vows to cut the corporation's "festering bureaucracy" by almost 50 percent.
 
1980: Mr. Hoffman resigns as Mr. Koch plans to decrease his power.
 
1980: Dr. Abraham J. Kauvar, an internist, is appointed president.
 
1981: De. Kauvar is forced to resign after five months' tenure after using racial slur at a meeting.
 
1981: Stanley Brezenoff, Commissioner of the Human Resources Administration, is appointed president.
 
1983: Officials announce a resturcturing of the system to make clinics and emergency rooms a priority over more expensive specialized care.
 
1984: Mr. Brezenoff resigns to becomre a deputy mayor.
 
1984: John J. McLaughlin, a city administrator, is appointed president.
 
1985: Mr. McLaughlin resigns while under criminal investigation for stealing profits from a private investment fund. He was later convicted.
 
1985: Dr. Jo Ivey Boufford, an internist, is appointed president.
 
1986: At City Council hearings on the corporation, testimony includes reports of chronic shortages of personnel that endanger patient care.
 
1988: City monitors disclose Dr. Boufford has spent $20,000 on consultants whose duties, among other things, include advising her on wardrobe and hairstyle.
 
1989: A malfunctioning mechanical bed fatally crushes a 5-year-old boy. Officials admit they knew of the problems with the beds since 1987, but failed to remove them all.
 
1989: Dr. Boufford resigns to take a fellowship in England.
 
1989-1990: Raymond J. Baxtor serves as acting president.
 
1990: Dr. J. Emilio Carrillo, a physician, is appointed as president.
 
1991: Dr. J. Emilio Carrillo resigns amid criticism of his management and for taking personal loans from people in the hospital system.
 
1991: James R. Dumpson is appointed acting president.
 
1991: After Yankel Rosenbaum dies in the emergency room of Kings County Hospital following racial violence in Crown Heights, a special report finds the hospital in "chaos."
 
1992: Mr. Dumpson leaves.
 
1992: Dr. Billy E. Jones, a psychiatrist, is appointed president.
 
1992: A commission headed by Jeremiah Barondess conducts a sweeping study of the city's public hospitals, finding that meddling from City Hall and inattention from private institutions providing care have "inhibited the ability of H.H.C. to function effectively."
 
1994: Dr. Jones resigns after the election of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.
 
1994: Dr. Bruce Siegel, an internist, is appointed president.

HEADLINE: A Well-Founded Fear

BYLINE: By Geraldine Brooks; Geraldine Brooks is author of "Nine Parts of Desire: The Hidden World of Islamic Women."

 BODY:
She makes women's clothes. In today's Algeria, that is a political act, and potentially a fatal one. Until last year, when she abandoned her market stall in Algiers, 38-year-old Naima Belahi imported fabric from France and Italy and sewed it into beaded evening gowns or stylish short dresses. Then, last March 10th, Algeria's Islamic insurgents ordered all women to veil themselves within a week or risk becoming legitimate targets of murder. The day after the deadline, militants killed a 16-year-old high school student who was walking to class without a head scarf.
Ms. Belahi, visiting the U.S. at the time, was afraid to return home. She neither makes nor wears the shroudlike Islamic dress that must cover the female body. To do so, she feels, would be to signal agreement with the extremists. She has taken refuge with a Connecticut family and applied for political asylum. 
 Unfortunately for Ms. Belahi, her case has fallen into a chaotic system that almost never considers persecution of women a basis for asylum. Despite growing worldwide abuse of women by religious extremists -- not just in Algeria but also in Afghanistan, Sudan, the Gaza Strip and Saudi Arabia -- the Immigration and Naturalization Service works from a sketchy manual that advises against accepting most sex-based claims.
Asylum seekers must show a "well-founded fear of persecution." This can be based on race, religion, nationality or political views. Less commonly, it can be based on membership in a "particular social group" that is subject to abuse.
In Algeria, more than 50 women have been killed since the Islamic insurgency began in 1992. Many more have been knifed or raped for working alongside men or wearing Western dress. The murdered women have included the principal of a co-ed school, a secretary who worked at a police station to support her unemployed siblings and a 22-year-old woman wearing jeans and buying cigarettes -- enough to identify her to the militants as a "prostitute."
Yet when an Algerian doctor applied for asylum here this year, saying she had been threatened with death because she supervised male physicians, the I.N.S. case officer said that violence in Algeria was "too random" to support her claim to belong to a "particular social group" at risk of persecution.
If Algeria's violence is considered too random to warrant asylum, awkward questions arise about countries -- including a close U.S. ally, Saudi Arabia -- where abuse of women is systemic. In 1993, after almost two years of deliberation, Canada granted asylum to a Saudi student known as Nada who had argued that she risked flogging and imprisonment for walking in the street with her hair and face uncovered. In the U.S., asylum experts say that Nada's predicament would most likely have been viewed by the I.N.S. as a matter of cultural mores rather than as persecution.
But substitute race for sex and the American position seems untenable. Imagine a country half black and half white, where the blacks may not legally leave the house without a white's permission, or where they may be caned in the street for refusing to wear the official segregating dress. That is the situation for women in Saudi Arabia.
Last spring, some experts in immigration law at Harvard Law School submitted guidelines on asylum for women to the I.N.S. with the hope that they might become the basis for a fairer assessment of claims of persecution. With anti-immigrant sentiment rampant in the Republican Congress, however, any attempt to liberalize I.N.S. standards is sure to meet resistance.
Yet asylum seekers constitute a tiny fraction of the people seeking admission to the U.S. each year. Opening the gate wider to persecuted women is hardly likely to result in a flood of new applicants. Most of the persecuted women live in countries where men control their right to leave the country, or even the house.
By granting asylum to women like Naima Belahi, the Algerian seamstress, the U.S. could send a powerful message to those who distort religion to justify terror. The message would be that Americans, too, hold certain things sacred -- and among them are liberty, equality, the pursuit of happiness and the right to hold one's own beliefs.

HEADLINE: Mexico Stock Market Gains

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, March 7

 BODY:
Mexico's stock market ended marginally higher today in another slow session, as investors stayed on the sidelines, waiting for the Government's economic plans to become clearer.
"The absence of news is keeping investors away from the market," one analyst said. "For the time being, it is more prudent to keep liquidity." 
 The lower house of the legislature gave formal approval to the $20 billion American loan guarantee package today. It now goes to the Senate, where passage would clear the way for President Ernesto Zedillo to announce measures to resolve Mexico's 11-week-old financial crisis.
The 37-share IPC index inched 1.48 points higher, or one-tenth of 1 percent, to close at 1,524.20 after moving across a range of 22 points. Despite the index's rise, declining shares far outnumbered gainers 46 to 22.

HEADLINE: New Croat-Bosnian Link Worries U.N.

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: ZAGREB, Croatia, March 7

 BODY:
Three weeks before its threatened expulsion of United Nations peacekeepers is to begin, Croatia has forged a new military alliance with Bosnia, establishing what on paper is a common front between former adversaries to counter Serbian rebels in both their countries.
The move, announced on Monday night, added to the concerns of United Nations officials and Western nations over the possibility of renewed war in Croatia and Bosnia if the Croatian President, Franjo Tudjman, goes through with his threat to expel the 12,000 United Nations peacekeepers in Croatia when their Security Council mandate expires on March 31. 
 The Croatian leader's threat has prompted the United Nations to consider revising the mandate under which its forces operate here, the United Nations spokesman, Michael Williams said, but he declined to give details.
Some United Nations officials have suggested that the United Nations force might be reduced by more than one half and limited to a narrower area of Croatia. There was no formal confirmation of other reports here tonight that the United Nations had proposed replacing peacekeeping troops with unarmed monitors on Croatia's international borders instead of along cease-fire lines.
The reported proposal could satisfy the Croatian Government, which argues that the armed United Nations troops have prevented it from reasserting control over the 30 percent of its territory now in the hands of rebel Serbs. But it would also run into strong opposition from the Serbs.
The United Nations' strategy reflects growing fears that the new pact between Croatia and Bosnia is one more preparation for renewed conflict if the United Nations forces withdraw.
The new agreement was "in fact a preparation and an agreement on how to act if the situation starts developing" toward broader and fiercer hostilities after the March 31 deadline, said Kresimir Zubak, the Croat who leads the Muslim-Croat federation set up in Bosnia with the backing of the United States one year ago.
The remark intensified the bellicose drumbeats echoing through the Balkans at a time when Western diplomacy is again faltering.
A United States attempt to persuade Mr. Tudjman to allow the United Nations peacekeepers to stay on has produced no visible sign of a breakthrough. Indeed, Croatian and Bosnian military leaders announced their pact just as Assistant Secretary of State Richard C. Holbrooke was meeting with President Tudjman in what was billed as a last-hour attempt to avoid renewed fighting.
The State Department in Washington denied today that the encounter had been a failure.
But a United Nations spokesman, Chris Gunnes, registered "increasing concern" today at violations of the year-old cease-fire in Croatia, saying there was an "unacceptable degree" of military activity by Croatian Government forces and the Serbian rebels who control one-third of the country.
As for Bosnia, the French Foreign Minister, Alain Juppe, told a news conference today in Paris that the risk of a resumption of hostilities "is higher than ever." He spoke at a meeting of officials from France, Germany and Britain to assess inconclusive efforts to persuade the President of Serbia, Slobodan Milosevic, to recognize Bosnia and Croatia in return for an end to economic sanctions against the rump Yugoslav federation, which is dominated by Serbia.
Against the background of such uncertain diplomacy, the players in the Balkans are maneuvering for whatever advantage they can through whatever high-stakes plays they can arrange.
The Croatia-Bosnia military pact is apparently intended to counter a similar pact by Serbian rebels in Bosnia and Croatia two weeks ago. European diplomats said Croatia apparently viewed the new pact as a possible means of pinning down Bosnian Serbs and thus preventing them from helping rebel Serbs in Croatia in the event of renewed fighting in Croatia, which has been mostly quiet since cease-fire in early 1992.
The newest military agreement is the most dramatic result of the federation so far but diplomats here said it had still to prove that it was more than a symbolic gesture between two groups that were essentially at war with one another only a year ago, and still harbor deep mutual mistrust. But in the nervous days leading up to the March 31 deadline in Croatia and to the April 30 expiration of an already badly frayed cease-fire in Bosnia, they appear to be reaching for any advantage.
"It's another development that we view with some concern," said Michael C. Williams, a spokesman for the United Nations forces in the former Yugoslavia.
United Nations officials say the most likely flash point is the Krajina region, held by rebel Serbs since 1991, where, the United Nations says, peacekeeping forces have been alarmed by increased movements of heavy weapons and larger-than-usual troop movements.

HEADLINE: Valea Calugareasca Journal;
From Communist Vineyards, a Bouquet of Iodine

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH 

DATELINE: VALEA CALUGAREASCA, Romania

 BODY:
With a slight air of apology, Viorel Stoian eased the cork and a piece of faded plastic out of a bottle of cabernet sauvignon that had rested in the cellar of the National Wine Institute of Romania for almost two decades.
"Like almost everything in Romania, the corks we had were so bad that we had to put plastic in with them to keep the wine from running out," he explained. 
 Mr. Stoian poured some of the deep-red liquid into a small glass, swirled it around and raised it to his nose, a faint smile crossing his face. After a sip, he offered it with satisfaction to his guests.
"It gives you the sense that something is burnt, something very fine," said Mr. Stoian, a 59-year-old viniculturist. "There is also the faintest touch of an iodine. It's a godly wine."
A touch of iodine, or "burnt," may not be how most people would describe a fine cabernet, but Romania remains a world apart when it comes to promoting its products.
Mr. Stoian and his wine institute, set in the middle of 1,800 acres of hills carpeted with vineyards, are fighting an uphill battle in the growing business of Eastern European wines.
Since the fall of Communism in 1989, Hungary and Bulgaria in particular have pushed their inexpensive but worthy table wines into the Western market, offering consumers in Britain, Germany and the United States cabernets, merlots and sauvignon blancs at a fraction of the cost of their counterparts from France or California.
Bulgaria has thrown open its markets to Western investors and entrepreneurs and now exports 70 percent of its production. Hungary has heavily subsidized its wine exports and is selling 40 percent of its production on the world market.
But, despite what many experts say is its far superior climate for viniculture, Romania seems stuck in the past.
One reason is its political legacy. Although most vineyards are now in private hands, the Government of President Ion Iliescu, led by former Communists, has refused to permit foreigners to own land. That means outside investors must find local partners who already own vineyards. Wine merchants say that when investors seek to buy assets in Romania, the Government overvalues them. Few doubt, however, that the investment restrictions will eventually be eased.
"We are in a transition period from a very stupid Government to a medium-stupid Government," Mr. Stoian said. "Meanwhile, our vineyards are deterioriating."
Romanians have long been attached to wine. A bottle typically costs less than the equivalent of $1, and annual consumption in this bleak economy is very high, more than 40 bottles per person -- more than twice the rate of consumption in Britain.
Romania is also the world's eighth-largest wine producer, at 600 million liters, or roughly 150 million gallons, a year. But it exports barely 4 percent of that amount.
During the 25-year dictatorship of Nicolae Ceausescu, any hard currency from wine exports was funneled by central planners into heavy industry like aircraft manufacturing and oil field equipment. Since the 1989 revolution that overthrew and executed Mr. Ceausescu, the Government has been so short of money that state financing for the wine industry has been stagnant.
With 10 research centers across the country and 500 employees, the wine institute has a budget of less than $1 million. It also has income from a limited amount of wine from its own vineyards that it sells both on the local and international markets.
"There is essentially no money for us, so how are we going to compete?" Mr. Stoian asked as he opened a bottle of white made out of a Romanian grape called sarba (pronounced CHAR-bah), that he hopes to develop during the next few years. It is a tart, young wine that looks somewhat cloudy. "It's a whimsical grape," he said. "After you swallow it, you get the sense of rose."
The institute is in the Dealul Mare region, which is on the same latitude as the Bordeaux region of France and is considered optimal for producing red wines. In the cool mountain plateaus of Transylvania, the country grows only whites, particularly sauvignon blanc and two of its own varieties, Feteasca Alba and Feteasca Regale.
Though many consumers may not be familiar with Romanian wines, Mr. Stoian's reputation, and that of several of his institute's varieties, extend well beyond the country's borders. He is best known for developing Romania's pinot noir, considered one of the most fickle of grapes.
"This is a very difficult wine to produce because it is prone to disease and it yields a very low quantity of grape," said Dan Muntean, commercial manager for Halewood Vintners of Yorkshire, England, the main importer of Romanian wines in Britain. "But that is Romania's best red wine, and that is mostly thanks to Viorel."
Mr. Stoian, whose normal attire is an olive-green polyester sports jackets over an an old charcoal-gray sweater, said one of his goals over the next few years is to develop Romania's Feteasca Negra wine, which is already gaining an international reputation. Mr. Stoian believes it should be classed among the great reds of the world.
He said the best indication of its potential as a world class wine came in 1990, when he allowed one of his assistants to enter it under the cabernet classification at a competition in Italy.
"He picks up a bottle of 1983 Fetesca Negra, tastes it and insists it is a cabernet," Mr. Stoian said of his assistant. "I decided not to say anything. So he goes and enters it as a cabernet. And it wins all kinds of prizes."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Viorel Stoian is developing a new grape, the sarba, which he describes as "whimsical," in the hopes of putting Romanian vineyards on the world oenological map. Although Romania is a major wine producer, averaging about 150 million gallons a year, it exports barely 4 percent of the total. (Andrei Iliescu for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Orange County Discloses Plan To Trim Jobs And Services

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: SANTA ANA, Calif.

 BODY:
The human and social costs of Orange County's financial crisis came into painful focus today as its new chief executive announced the layoffs of 1,040 employees and the elimination of 563 other positions, and elected officials decided that the county could not afford to pay a public defender to represent a man accused of killing 12 people.
The new chief executive, William J. Popejoy, told county supervisors that the layoffs and job eliminations -- amounting to more than 10 percent of the 15,000-member work force -- were necessary just to balance the county's budget in the coming fiscal year. 
 The job cuts would allow the county, which declared bankruptcy after its investments lost about $1.7 billion last year, to make a 41 percent cut in its discretionary budget. The budget for the fiscal year beginning July 1 will be $275 million, down from $463 million in the year that will end on June 30, Mr. Popejoy said.
But the cuts and layoffs will not help close a $382 million shortfall in the amount the county will owe bondholders this summer, he said.
"I wish to underscore the human costs," Mr. Popejoy told the supervisors. "The county employees who may be laid off did not cause the bankruptcy. Many have devoted their entire years to serving Orange County. This is not the thanks they deserve."
The supervisors also decided that the county was too impoverished to pay the costs of defending Charles Ng, the Northern California man whose mass-murder trial was moved here because of pre-trial publicity. On a 4-to-1 vote, they deferred paying the first $100,000 necessary for the county public defender to provide services to Mr. Ng.
They also authorized the board president, Gaddi H. Vasquez, to write a letter to the presiding judge of the Orange County Superior Court, asking that the case be moved elsewhere.
Supervisor William Steiner refused to support the motion, saying that the county should immediately decline to pay any costs in the case.
"I can't even believe we're having this discussion," Mr. Steiner said. Noting the layoffs and cutbacks in services like child-abuse investigations, he said: "And we want to defend this guy?"
Mr. Ng is accused of torturing and killing 12 people at a remote mountain house in Calaveras County, about 150 miles east of San Francisco. The authorities found a torture chamber and charred human bones at the compound in 1985.
Calaveras County would repay Orange County for some costs, but Orange County would have to bear the administrative expenses incurred by the court, the public defender's office and the sheriff's office.
Orange County officials have blamed Merrill Lynch & Company and other brokerage firms for the $1.7 billion loss, claiming they exploited the county's former treasurer, Robert L. Citron, by supplying him with risky investments.
Cities, schools and other elements of the government have also been forced to cut services.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Continuing Drop in Price

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of long-term Treasury securities continued their slide for a fifth day yesterday as the dollar plunged again in the currency markets.
Analysts said an early muted response by Treasuries to the dollar's fall in Europe forced some investors to cover short positions hurriedly and gave an early lift to bond prices. But the buying quickly ended as the dollar fell even lower. 
 The 30-year Treasury bond fell 12/32 , to a price of 1002/32 , sending the yield up to 7.62 percent, from 7.58 percent on Monday. Some expect the shorter maturities will continue consolidating, as traders await Friday's report on jobs data.
Yesterday rumors that the Federal Reserve was in the market to buy two- , five- and ten-year maturities for another central bank gave some support to the intermediate maturities. Many dealers speculated that the Bank of Japan was the other central bank.
Matthew F. Alexy, chief market strategist at the CS First Boston Corporation, said he was impressed with the market's resiliency. While the volume was average, he said, it was surprisingly well behaved, considering the sharp currency fluctuations.
Two clues to the market's composure are that the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, will be testifying before the House Budget Committee today, and the market may be waiting to see if he touches on the currency situtation.
"All along the Fed has been saying domestic policy will be the chief determination of monetary policy," Mr. Alexy said. "Currently some think the economy has cooled a bit from its fourth-quarter pace.
"What is currently happening to the dollar and to the economy are two separate issues. What happens next depends on the Fed, which has to determine the trade-off between the two. Helping the dollar could cause problems with the economy."
Indeed, because of the economy's strength, some analysts expect an interest rate increase of 50 basis points -- or hundredths of a percentage point -- when the Federal Open Market Committee, the Fed's policy-making arm, meets on March 28.
"The dollar is still only a marginal policy factor and will only become a central issue if it threatens a major financial crisis in the U.S.," said James Hale, a fixed-income analyst with MMS International in San Francisco. "The economy and inflation remain the primary policy parameters for the Fed, with the economy still growing at a respectable 3.5 percent pace in the first quarter."
Municipal bonds were little changed as investors moved to the sidelines, waiting to see how the $1.258 billion of new state, city and agency issues sold yesterday would be priced.
Municipal bond issuers sold $540.8 million through negotiated transactions and $717.9 million through competitive bidding; Georgia priced the largest competitive issue that will be seen this week.
The state sold $349 million of debt to pay for capital projects. If the state's quality rating was not incentive enough to pay a premium price, this year's decline in new bond issues has increased the competition among investors for the quality deals, driving up prices.
Moody's Investors Service, which expects continued economic growth to keep the state's economy among the strongest, says Georgia's economy will receive a lift from the 1996 Olympic Games.
Merrill Lynch won $328.21 million of the general obligation bonds, with serial bonds priced to yield from 5.10 percent for an issue due in 2001 to 6.05 percent for bonds due in 2014 and 2015. J. P. Morgan Securities was awarded $21.8 million of the bonds and priced them to yield from 4.50 percent.

HEADLINE: Six Communities Compete For a New Military Center

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 7

 BODY:
Wanted: 140,000 square feet of secure office space. Good airline connections to Latin America. Affordable family housing. Strategic site for nabbing drug lords and running top-secret military missions.
With American forces scheduled to withdraw from Panama by 1999 under terms of the Panama Canal Treaty, the Pentagon is looking for a new home for its Southern Command, the headquarters responsible for United States military activities in Latin America. 
 The selection of a new headquarters site is particularly rare at a time when scores of American military bases are closing, and six communities are using political ties and financial incentives to compete for it. Beyond bragging rights to one of the military's five major regional commands, the prize, by one estimate, will mean 1,500 new jobs and a five-year infusion of $100 million into the local economy.
The Pentagon has narrowed the field to Miami, Tampa, New Orleans, Atlanta, Washington and Puerto Rico, and is expected to announce its choice later this month. Most of the competing communities have been spared base closings in the past, although Miami's Homestead Air Force Base was ordered partly shut in 1993.
The Defense Department is trying to treat the move, in which Miami and Tampa appear to be the front-runners, as a by-the-books real-estate deal that weighs only affordability and military needs. But politics is playing a big role.
Florida, which will have 25 electoral votes in the 1996 Presidential election, has a powerful Congressional delegation that is lobbying heavily for Miami or Tampa, as is the Democratic Governor, Lawton Chiles. Louisiana legislators, led by Representative Robert L. Livingston, a Republican who heads the House Appropriations Committee, are pushing hard for New Orleans.
The communities are rushing to outbid one another. Miami has spent $100,000 on an aggressive promotional campaign, including a helicopter tour of the city for senior military officials. Puerto Rico is offering up to $100 million in financing to build homes for officers and their families.
And officials in Atlanta, billing their city as one with an ideal management climate, got right to the point when a Pentagon review team visited recently: Saab, Holiday Inn and the United Parcel Service all recently moved their corporate headquarters there. "The object wasn't to wine and dine them," said William Hubbard, senior vice president for economic expansion at the Metro Atlanta Chamber of Commerce. "These were numbers guys."
The Southern Command is responsible for United States military activities in 19 Latin American countries, excluding the Caribbean and Mexico. The command, which now has 8,500 troops based in Panama, provides humanitarian aid to the region, wages an aggressive counterdrug campaign there and protects the Panama Canal.
But even as the Pentagon looks for a new hub, some budget-cutters say the military could save money by consolidating the Southern Command into some other headquarters. For example, Gen. John J. Sheehan, the head of the Atlantic Command, based in Norfolk, Va., believes that the Southern Command would fit naturally in his fief. Gen. Barry R. McCaffrey, the head of the Southern Command, bristles at that idea and instead wants to seize the Caribbean from General Sheehan's jurisdiction.
Turf wars like that one are important to an understanding of the debate. General McCaffrey, a decorated veteran of the Vietnam and Persian Gulf wars, likes Miami because, among other reasons, he would be the only four-star commander there. If the Pentagon picked Tampa, the general would have to share the city with the four-star generals who head the Central Command and the Special Operations Command.
The military nearly picked a new Southern Command headquarters late last year, when an assessment team recommended two sites in Miami and two in Puerto Rico. But that first assessment failed to consider costs, and lawmakers from the losing communities expressed outrage. Mr. Livingston, along with Louisiana's two Senators, J. Bennett Johnston and John B. Breaux, fired off an angry letter to Deputy Defense Secretary John M. Deutch last Dec. 1. "There has been no attempt," they wrote, "to inform the Congress as to how the Department of Defense intends to specify criteria for a site selection or objectives for a site evaluation."
Mr. Deutch then formed a team -- made up of Assistant Defense Secretary Edward L. Warner; the principal deputy comptroller, Alice C. Maroni, and Lieut. Gen. Wesley Clark, the Joint Staff's director of strategic plans and policy -- to undertake a new search that would hold up to Congressional scrutiny.
A group of staff members headed by Mr. Warner's deputy, Thomas K. Longstreth, has since narrowed the list of candidates to 12 from 112, and then to the final 6, all of which they have visited. Pentagon officials want a site that is near Latin America (or at least one plane connection away), that is reasonably priced and that offers good housing, schools and health care for about 700 military and civilian employees. The military will either build a new headquarters or renovate an existing center.
In its new headquarters, the Southern Command will have no permanently assigned troops. Instead, like the Central Command, whose primary area of responsibility is Southwest Asia, it will summon forces as needed from around the country.
Each location still in the running has given its own particular pitch to the staff group. Atlanta promoted itself as a corporate center, Washington as the center of government. Tampa said it had room for another command at MacDill Air Force Base. New Orleans cited its deep port and naval air station. Puerto Rico positioned itself as the site closest to Latin America, not only geographically but also culturally.
But all competitors concede that Miami will be tough to beat. Officials in that city, which bills itself as the cultural, business, transportation and telecommunications hub of the Americas, estimate that the new headquarters would bring more than 1,500 new jobs and inject $100 million into the economy over five years through construction, wages of permanent new workers and entertainment spending by the frequent visitors to a command that operates largely through personal contacts.
Dan Tarman, the coordinator for Team Miami-U.S. Southcomm, a coalition of civic and business leaders in the Miami area, said, "Miami is the best place for this thing, because it enhances the command's ability to meet and greet."

HEADLINE: House Panel Votes to Cut Food Stamps

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 7

 BODY:
The House Agriculture Committee began voting today on legislation to cut $16.5 billion from projected spending in the food stamp program over the next five years, despite protests from Democrats who said the bill was immoral and mean-spirited.
The Democrats complained bitterly that the Republicans were making vast changes in the food stamp program with little analysis of the effect on human lives and no reliable estimate of the savings. 
 But the chairman of the committee, Representative Pat Roberts of Kansas, said he had "marching orders" from House Republican leaders to finish work on the bill this week, so it could be combined with welfare legislation from other committees in one big package.
The overall bill is expected to win approval in the House within a few weeks, although the outlook in the Senate is unclear.
Nonetheless, Democrats were intent on having their say. Representative Earl Pomeroy, Democrat of North Dakota, said the food stamp proposals were "God-awful." Representative Tim Johnson, Democrat of South Dakota, called it "radical, right-wing extremist" legislation that punished children.
Representative E. (Kika) de la Garza of Texas, the ranking Democrat on the committee, said, "We have a responsibility as a nation and as a people, a moral responsibility, to see that in this, the greatest nation in the world, there is no hunger." Another Democrat, Harold L. Volkmer of Missouri, said the bill would hurt "the neediest of the needy."
Republicans offered comparatively little defense of the bill, except to say that it would control costs and reduce fraud. Representative Nick Smith, Republican of Michigan, said the food stamp program was "one of the most corrupt welfare programs we have in this country."
Mr. Pomeroy said the committee was irresponsible to vote on the legislation without cost estimates from the Congressional Budget Office.
Such numbers, he said, are needed to show "how deep are the cuts we're making in the food stamp program."
Twenty-seven million people get food stamps. Slightly more than half of them are children. Benefits average $69 a month for each person.
House Republicans said their proposals would cut $16.5 billion, or 11 percent, from the $149 billion that would otherwise be spent on food stamps in the next five years. But the Agriculture Department estimates that the savings would total $24.4 billion over five years.
The committee rejected a proposal by a freshman Republican from Indiana, Representative John Hostettler, to scrap the food stamp program and replace it with a lump-sum payment of Federal money, which states could use for any form of nutrition assistance. This proposal was part of the Republicans' original Contract With America, and Mr. Hostettler said, "It's time to give the program to the states."
Lawmakers from both parties said they wanted to preserve food stamps as the ultimate national safety net for poor people, at least for several years, until states were ready to issue food stamp benefits through an electronic accounting system.
The Republican bill would establish strict new work requirements for food stamp recipients. People 18 to 50 years old would be denied food stamps after 90 days unless they were working at least 20 hours a week.
The bill would also reduce the annual cost-of-living adjustment for food stamp benefits, deny benefits to legal immigrants for at least five years and set overall limits on food stamp spending.
The Acting Secretary of Agriculture, Richard E. Rominger, denounced the bill, saying it would "eliminate the national nutritional safety net" and harm the health of low-income people.
Specifically, he said, the Republican bill would destroy two features of the food stamp program that have made it highly effective: uniform national standards for eligibility and benefits, and a budget that increases automatically to meet additional need in time of recession.
Under the bill, states that issue benefits in electronic form could eventually get Federal food stamp money in a block grant and could then set their own eligibility standards and benefit levels. As a result, Mr. Rominger said, "there could be 50 vastly different state programs using 50 different eligibility standards and offering 50 different nutrition benefits." Indeed, he said, "each state could set up different standards for different counties."
Mr. Rominger said the proposed work requirement would end food stamp benefits for 1.2 million people who were willing to work but unable to find jobs. Thus, he said, "the bill holds nutrition benefits hostage to jobs that may not exist."
The committee today rejected a Republican proposal that would have prohibited the use of food stamps to buy coffee, tea, cocoa, candy and other snack food.
Representative Mark Foley, Republican of Florida, said it was wrong for the Federal Government to subsidize "people's appetite for popcorn, potato chips, ice cream, Coca-Cola and Gatorade."
On the other hand, Representative Sam Farr, Democrat of California, said the committee was not authorized to enforce morality. And Mr. Volkmer said, "This is going too far in punishing children."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Representative Pat Roberts of Kansas, left, chairman of the Agriculture Committee, conferred yesterday with a staff member during hearings on legislation to scale back the Federal food stamp program. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times)
